editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: ANATOMICAL EXERCITATIONS, Concerning the GENERATION Of Living Creatures: To which are added Particular Dicoures, of Births, and of Conceptions, &c. By WILLIAM HARVEY, Doctor of Phyick, and Profeor of Anatomy, and Chirurgery, in the COLLEDGE of Phyitians of LONDON.
LONDON, Printed by James Young, for Octavian Pulleyn, and are to be old at his Shop at the Sign of the Roe in St. Pauls Churchyard. 1653.

div.head: TO THE Venerable, & highly Accomplih't, THE PRESIDENT & FELLOWS of the COLLEDGE of Phyitians in LONDON, GEORGE ENT Wiheth Health and full Felicity.
div.p:
ABout Chritmas lat, while, full weary of anxious, and in the end not much availing Solicitude, I endeavoured to render my mind erene, and free from that Eclipe; I addreed my elf to that Eminent Peron, the chiefet Glory and Ornament of our Colledge, Doctor Harvey, at that time reiding not far from the City: and found Him very intent upon the percrutation of Natures Works, and with a Countenance as cheerful, as Mind imperturbed, Democritus like, deeply
earching into the Caues of natural things. I then intantly aluted Him, with, Are all Affaires well, and right?

How can they, He gravely anwered, when the Common-wealth is urrounded with intetine troubles; and I my elf as yet far from land, tot in that tempetuous Ocean? And, unfeignedly (added He) if the comfort of my Studies, and the remembrance of many things, long ince fallen under my obervation, were not ome refrehment to my Mind; I know not what could prevaile upon me, to deire to urvive the preent. So it hath happened, that this umbratile kind of life, and vacation from publique Cares, which commonly caueth a Sadnes of Mind in others, hath proved a Sovereign Remedy to mine.

Here I anwering, aid, Sir, I hall oon afford you the Reaon of that happy Event; which is this: While
the greatet number of men flatter themelves with thoughts of growing wie, by the notions of others Brains, and (without any addition, unles the deceitful Glos of different Phrae, and new Method) with otentation obtrude upon the World the Traditions of the Ancients; it hath been always your choice, about the ecrets of Nature, to conult Nature Her elfe. And this kind of Study ever hath as les of Fallacy, o more of Delight: in regard, that frequently, while you are fixt upon the indagation of ome one thing, many others offer themelves to your obervation; and uch, perhaps, of which you had no thought to enquire. For, your elf (I well remember) was pleaed once to tell me, that you never yet Diected any Animal (and, indeed, you have diected very many) but you found in it omewhat beyond your expectation, and which you never o much as thought of before.

'Tis true, replied He; it hath ever been the delight of my Genius, to make trict Inpection into Animals themelves: And I have contantly been of opinion, that from thence we might acquire not only the knowledge of thoe les coniderable Secrets of Nature; but even a certain Adumbration of that Supreme Eence, the Creator. And, though I was ever ready to acknowledge; that many things have been dicovered by Learned Men of former times: Yet do I till believe, that the number of thoe things which remain yet concealed in the darknes of Impervetigable Nature, is incomparably greater: nay, I cannot forbear frequently to wonder, and ometimes mile at thoe, who perwade themelves, that all things were o conummatly and abolutely delivered by Aritotle, Galen, or ome other great Name, as that nothing was left to the uperaddition of
any, that ucceeded. Nature, truly, is Her elf the mot faithful Interpreter of Her own ecrets: and what he exhibits, either more briefly, or more obcurely, in one kind, the ame he explains more largely and openly, in another. No man doubtles, hath ever rightly determined of the Ue, or Office of any Part; who hath not in many Animals, beheld, and with himelf diligently conidered the Fabrick, Situation, annexed Veels, and other Accidents thereof. Thoe Ancient Oracles of Widom did terminate the knowledge, as of all Countries, o alo of all Animals, Plants, and other things whatever, allmot with the narrow limits of Greece alone: But, to Us the whole Theatre of the World is now open, and, by the Sedulity of Travellers, we well know, not only the Place, Habits, and Manners of its Inhabitants; but alo,
what Animals, what Vegetables, what Minerals every Region is furnihed withal. Nor is there any Nation o Barbarous, which hath not either by chance, or the contraint of ome inevitable neceity, found out omething for the common ue and benefit of Mankind, which hath ecaped the invention of other Nations more Civilized. And hal we think that nothing of Commodity can accrue to the tock of Sciences, from thee Helps and Advantages: but that all the Fountains of Widom were drawn dry by the Firt Ages? Certainly, this Fault is to be imputed to our own defect of Indutry; not at all to Nature.

To this, another Evil hath adjoined it elf; which is, that many, wanting the Experimental cognition of things, from the formerly conceived veriimilitude of ome Opinion, afterwards boldly broach a poitive
Judgment thereupon, as if it were certainly known: whereupon it follows, that they are not only grosly deluded themelves, but educe others alo (who are not ufficiently circumpect) into Error.

Thee, and other Dicoures of the like importance; flowing from the Doctor, with admirable readines, as is cutomary with Him; I interrupted Him, aying: Sir, How free you are from all culpability in this kind, all, who know you, ufficiently undertand: and that's the reaon, why many Learned and Judicious Men, who are acquainted with your Unwearied Indutry, in the advancement of Philoophy, greedily expect the Communication of your further Experiments.

And would you then advie me, (milingly replies the Doctor) to quit the tranquillity of this Haven, wherein I now calmly pend my days: and
again commit my elf to the unfaithful Ocean? You are not ignorant, how great troubles my Lucubrations, formerly publihed, have raied. Better it is, certainly, at ome times, to endeavour to grow wie at home in private; then by the haty divulgation of uch things, to the knowledge whereof you have attained with vat labour, to tirr up Tempets, that may deprive you of your Leaure and Quiet for the future.

Yea but (anwered I) to deerve well, and receive ill, is the uuall reward of Virtue: And the Winds, which raied thoe your troubles, have, like the Wind Caecias, drawn michief upon themelves. With that, He hewed me His Exercitations, touching the Generation of Animals, A work framed, and polihed with very great pains. At ight whereof, I intantly rejoicing, aid, I now have obtained what I
earnetly deired: and mut tell you, that, unles you impart thee Exercitations to the World, you will both be wanting to your own Honour, and envy the Utility of others. Nor hall you utain any further trouble in the Buines; for, whatever of Care is requiite to the overight of the Pres, I hall willingly take wholly upon my elf. To this He condecended with much adoe, at firt urging, among many other Diwaive Arguments, that this His Tractate would be imperfect, without the conjunction of the Hitory of the Generation of Inects. In a word; at length I prevailed: and He aid, Loe, I reign thee my Writings freely into your hands, with abolute power, either uddainly to publih, or for a while to uppres them, as you hall think convenient. Having returned Him very many thanks for o high a favour; I took my leave, and departed
as another Jaon, enriched with the Golden Fleece. And when, upon my return home, I had urveyed the Book; I could not but admire that o vat a Treaure had laien o long concealed: And that, while other men arrogate o highly to themelves, onely for the entertainment of their naneating Readers, with Trifles and Toies, and Dihes twice (yea, an hundred times) brought to the Table before; the Modety of this Gentleman hould be uch, as to et o mall a value upon thee His Excellent Obervations. And truly, when ever He hath been pleaed to give any of his own Inventions leave to ee the light, He hath not deported Himelf with Otentation, or uperciliounes, after the cutome of many, as if an Oak had poken, or he had deerved a draught of Hen's-Milk: but, His Dictates were Oraculous, and Merits above the reach
of Elogie, or Reward: but, with exceeding Modety, as if onely caually, or without any difficultie of inquet, he had fallen upon the Dicovery of thoe Myteries, which, indeed, he long earched into with profet diligence, and tudy indefatigable.

And this alo is an Argument of eminent Candour in Him; that he never inwades the reputation of any Author, but every where delivers his own judgement, in mild and friendly language. For, with him it is Proverbial, that That Caue is worthy to be upected for carcely good and profitable, which its Author contends for with brawling and fiercenes: But Truth can want no Patron.

And when it was eaie to him, to have woven this whole Web, from materials of his own; uch was his care, for the prevention of Envy, that he yet choe to follow the clue of Aritotle and Aquapendens, as if he
had contributed thereunto no more then meerly the Woofe. Of Him I hall peak no more, let I appear to praie to his face a Peron, whoe Worth hath advanced Him infinitely above my praies; epecially to You, to whom his Virtue, Candor, and Ingenie, are long ince very well known. But, of My elfe, I hall adde onely thus much; that in this great Buines I have performed no more then the meer office of a Midwife: producing into the light this noble Iue of His Brain, in all its parts and line • ments perfect and conummate, as it is now preented to your View; but taying long in the Birth, & fearing, perhaps, ome injurious Blat of Envy or Detraction. To peak more plainly, I made it my Province to overee and correct the Pres; and becaue the Author writes o obcure a Hand (A thing, as we ay, common to learned men (as that carce any man, but who hath bin
accutomed thereto, can read it without difficulty, I ued all diligence to provide againt the Errors of the Compoitor, that might be occaioned thereby; which I oberved, not to have been duly prevented in the Impreion of a mall Treatie of the Doctors, not long ince et forth.

And thus, mot Learned Sirs, have I rendered you the Reaon of this my Writing to you; which is, to let you know, that our HARVEY hath Sacrificed to the Benefit of the Commonwealth of Learning, to the Dignity of our Colledge, and to His own Eternal Honour.

div.head: To the Incomparable Dr. HARVEY, On his Books Of the MOTION of the HEART and BLOOD, And of the GENERATION of ANIMALS.
div.l: TO Sol, the grateful Perian homage payes;
He Sees by them, and o Adores the rayes:
Deeming the Suns jut title to arie
To th' Tribute, as to th' Viion of his Eyes.
And uch is thy due claime, Great Light of Art,
Who to the long-dim World dot ight impart.
To thy Loud Fame for ever be apply'd,
As th' Conduct, o the Glory of our Guide.
While gray Antiquity Oracular heares,
Not for the Truths he brings, but for the Yeares,
And her owr Dictats from the Tripod thrown,
Look more to be Obey'd, then to be Known.
Thy daring Art firt tands her, and doth breed
This Reeue thence, that Science is not Creed.
Who for their Age alone doe Writers trut,
Prize Armour, not for th' Proof, but for the Rut.
From Books to Nature thy Appeale is made,
Thy Copies by their Archetype are wayd.
Though High and Reverend thy Authors it,
Yet the Creation is thy Claick Writ.
The various Colonies, whoe brood upplyes
Inhabitants to Earth, to Seas, and Skies,
Thee are thy Vatican, and onely thee
Are thy Infallible Hippocrates;
Thy Sibyll-Volumes, and Thou knowt them all,
Like their firt Godfathen before the Fall.
Their Natures, Kinds, Ditinctions and Concent,
The Parts conteinec't, and Parts continent,
Their Order, Subtance, Temper, Site, their Force,
Relations, and confederate Entercoure.
Their different Cells which different Bowels bound,
Rooft and partition'd from their Neighbours ground.
The Numerous Intrals Thou hat earched through,
Might both Appeae the Gods, and Surfet too.
Not in the dull Emerit Carcae, where
The Shops remain where once the Workmen were;
And onely yield this cold Account; there tands
The Stuffe and Tools perhaps, but not the Hands.
But in the Living Laboratories, when
The Vitals ply'd their task like Lab'ring men;
When Life and Indutry one Fountaine fed,
And to give over Work, was, to be Dead.
And now the Beats hold their Intructive life
Innobled by the cunning of thy Knife.
Their Fall heares Sacrifice to th' Publick good,
Nor is it to be Slaine, but Vndertood.
There thy Oberving Eye firt found the Art
Of all the Wheels and Clock-work of the Heart:
The mytick caues of its Dark Etate,
What Pullies Cloe its Cells, and what Dilate.
What ecret Engiues tune the Pule, whoe din
By Chimes without, Strikes how things fare within.
There didt thou trace the Blood, and firt behold
What Dreames mitaken Sages coin'd of old.
For till thy Pegaus the fountain brake,
The crimon Blood, was but a crimon Lake.
Which firt from Thee did Tyde and Motion gaine,
And Veins became its Channel, not its Chaine.
With Drake and Candih hence thy Bays is curld,
Fam'd Circulator of the Leer World.
Yet thou no ooner wroughtt this wonder out,
Though proof both gaint the cool upene of Doubt,
And rougher Violence o'th' Depiers tongue,
But Europe round with hot combutions rung:
Its early firt Defiance prung up here,
At lat a warm of Champion Pens appeare
From Forreign coats, and to the conflict come,
Some thy bold Challengers, thy Seconds ome.
But when Experience vanquiht their defence,
And Prejudice was captive led by Sene:
The Ingenuous laid down Arms, and fled to You,
As their Intructor, and their Victor too.
Thus twice endeer'd, thy Secrets we allow,
By Truths at firt, and by Oppoers now.
So Gold diputed, and Approved uch,
Comes Mettle, but parts Treaure from the Touch.
A Calmer welcome this choice Peice befall,
Which from freh Extract hath deduced all,
And for belief, bids it no longer begg
That Cator once and Pollux were an Egge:
That both the Hen and Houwife are o matcht,
That her Son Born, is only her Son Hatcht;
That when her Teeming hopes have prop'rous bin,
Yet to Conceive, is but to Lay within.
Experiment, and Truth both take thy part:
If thou cant cape the Women! there's the Art.
Live Modern Wonder, and be read alone,

Thy Brain hath Iue, though thy
<>
have none.
Let fraile Succeion be the Vulgar care;
Great Generation's elfe is now thy Heire.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p: SInce many have requeted, and ome have importuned mee; it will not, I hope, be unwelcome, (candid Reader) if what I have oberved concerning the Generation of Animals, out of Anatomical diections (for I have found the whole matter to be much different, from that which is delivered, either by Philoophers or Phyitians) I expoe in thee Exercitations, in favour, and for the ue of the Lovers of Truth.

All Phyitians, following Galen, teach, that out of the Seed of Male and Female mingled in Coition, according to the predominant power of this, or that, the Child reembles either this, or that Parent, and is alo either Male or Female. And ometimes they pronounce the Males Seed to be the Efficient caue, and the Females the Materiall; and ometimes again the clean contrary.

But Aritotle (Natures mot diligent earcher) affirms that the Male and Female are the principles of Generation, and that he contributes the matter, and he the form; and that forthwith after Coition, there is formed in the Womb out of the Mentruous bloud, the Vital principle, and firt particle of the future Foetus, (namely, the Heart, in Creatures that have bloud.)

But that thee are fale, and rah aertions, will oon appear; and will like clouds intantly vanih, (when the light of Anatomical diection breaks forth) nor will they require any elaborate confutation, when the Reader, intructed by his own eyes, hall dicover the contrary by ocular inpection; and hall alo undertand, how unafe, and degenerate a thing it is, to be tutored by other mens commentaries, without making tryal of the things themelves: epecially, ince Natures Book is o open, and legible.

I have therefore exhibited to publick view, what in thee my Exercitations, I intend to deliver concerning the Generation of Animals; not onely that poterity may thence dicern the certain and apparent truth; but alo, and that cheifly too, that (by revealing the Method I ue in earching into things) I might propoe to
tudious men, a new, and (if I mitake not) a urer path to the attainment of knowledge.

For although it be a more new and difficult way, to find out the nature of things, by the things themelves; then by reading of Books, to take our knowledge upon trut from the opinions of Philoophers: yet mut it needs be confeed, that the former is much more open, and lee frandulent, epecially in the Secrets relating to Natural Philoophy.

Nor is there any reaon, why any man hould be deterred by the trouble of it; if he will but o much as conider with himelfe, that even life it elfe is continued to him, by the never Wearied Agitation of the Heart. Nor truly would this journy preent o much of olitude and deart to us; did not mot men by the cutome (or fault rather) of the age wee live in, yeilding themelves up to luggihnee, deire rather to erre with the many, then with the expene of their paines and coine, endeavour to be wie with the few: when notwithtanding the Ancient Philoophers (whoe indutry alo even we extol) went a quite contrary way to work; and by indefatigable toile earching after everal experiments, have et
up a clear light to direct our tudies. So that, whatever notable and approved thing we have in Philoophy, it all is derived unto us by the paines and indutry of ancient Greece. Yet when we content our elves with their dicoveries, and calmly believe (which is meer leepines) that there is now no more place for new inventions, the pritely edge of our owne wit languiheth, and we extinguih the lamp which they lighted to our hands. And certainly he alone wil grant, that the whole truth was ingroed by the Ancients, (who is ignorant of the many noble dicoveries, to pas by other Arts) lately found out in the buines of Anatomy. And this was cheifly done either by uch, who wholly intent upon ome one thing, did caually decry ome other: or (which is more commendable) by thoe, who following Natures conduct with their own eyes, have at length through a perplexed, but yet a mot faithful tract, attained to the highet pitch of Truth. And in uch an undertaking it is pleaant, not to be tyred onely, but even to faint away; where the Irkeomnes of Dicovering is abundantly recompened by the dicovery it elfe. We ue, being covetous of Novelty, to wander far into unknown lands, that our
own eies may witnes, what our ears have received at econd hand: where yet for the mot part

Let us then bluh, in this o ample, and o wonderful field of nature, (where performance till exceeds what is promied) to credit other mens traditions only, and thence coine uncertain problemes, to pin out thorney and captious quetions. Nature her elfe mut be our advier; the path he chalks mut be our walk: for o while we confer with our own eies, and take our rie from meaner things to higher, we hall be at length received into her Cloet-ecrets.

div.head: Of the Manner and Order of attaining knowledge.
div.p:
THough there be one onely roade to Science, namely, that by which we proceed from things more known, to things known les; and from that which is more manifet, to that which is more obcure; and though Univerals are chiefly known to us (for Science is begot by reaoning
from Univerals to Particulars) yet that very comprehenion of Univerals in the Undertanding, prings from the perception of Singulars in our ene. So that both Aritotles
L. 1. c. 2. 3. aertions are true, as well that in his Phyicks; There is a way naturally layed from thoe things which are more known and cleare to us, to thoe things which are more intelligible and cleare by nature. For the ame things are not both known to us, and imply o too: wherefore we of neceity mut thus proceed; to wit, from thoe things which are by nature indeed more obcure, but yet are more clearer to us; to thoe things which are more cleare and intelligible by nature. But thoe things are firt perpieuous and manifet to us, which are mot confued. Therefore wee mut goe from Vniverals to Singulars: for the Whole is more known by ene: now an Vniveral is a certain Whole. As that in his Analyticks. Singulars are more known by
Pot. 2. us, and doe firt exit according to ene: for nothing is in the undertanding, which was not before in the ene. And although that Ratiocination is naturally firt and more known, which is made by Syllogime; yet that is more conpicuous to us, which is made by Induction: and therefore we define Singulars with more eae, then Univerals: for there lyes more Aequivocation in Vniverals. Wherefore
wee mut pas from Singulars to Generals.

That which we have now delivered, hangs very well together, though at firt it eem to clah: becaue Generals are firt collected from Singulars by ene, and o farre onely are more known to us, as an Univeral is a certain whole and inditinct thing; and that Whole is more known to us according to ene. For though in all knowledge, we begin from Sene, becaue, (as the Philoopher aid before) Senible particulars are mot known to Sene; yet Senation it elfe is an Univeral thing. For (if you minde it well) though (while we perceive) that which is in the outward organ of ene be a Singular, as uppoe, a yellow colour, in the ight: yet that which is thence abtracted by the internall ene, and is judged and apprehended by it, is an Univeral. Hence it comes to pas, that everal perons, do at the ame intant, abtract divers pecies, and fahion everall notions, even of one and the ame Object. As it is evident in Poets, and Painters: who, though at the ame time, and in the ame place, all circumtances being alike, they behold one and the ame Object, yet each of them, be they never o many, expres and decribe it a everal way, according
to the everal Ideas which they have drawn in their Phanie. So that a Painter being to draw any one mans picture, though he take a thouand everal draughts, will make them all ditinct faces; and them too not onely differing from each other, but from the Archetype it elfe: yet with o mall ditinction, that if you look upon each of them apart, you will think hee till brings the ame piece hee brought before: and yet et them all together and compare them, and you will plainely dicover a difference. Now the reaon of all this is, that in Uiion, or the act of Seeing, each particular by it elfe was clear and ditinct: which very particular, the Object being removed, (as uppoe you hould hut your eies,) abtracted in the Phanie, or laid up in the Memory, is preented obcure, and confued: nor is it any longer apprehended as a particular, but as ome General and Univeral thing.

This ubtilty Seneca doth elegantly expres, Epit. 58. according to Plato's opinion. An Idea, aith he, is an eternal Exemplar of Natural things. I will explain this definition, that you may conceive it the better. Suppoe I intend to draw your picture, you your elf are the Exemplar of that picture, from
whom my minde takes a repreentation, which he indeavoureth to pattern in her work. So then your face, which is my director, & which I labour to repreent, is the Idea. And a litle after, he aith. In my dicoure even now I made ue of a picture-drawer, to illutrate what I was peaking of. He, when he would paint Virgil, his eye is upon Virgil himelf: Virgils face is his Idea, and the Exemplar of his future deigne: now that which the Artit takes from this Idea, and worketh off, is the Picture. If you demand the difference between thee two, it is this: the one is the Pattern, the other is the copy taken by the Pattern, and layed upon the work: He imitates the one, and makes the other. A Statue hath a face, but that face is but the Idos, or repreentation: But the Exemplar which the Statuary copies out, hath a face, and that face is the Idaea. Doe you deire a farther explication? take it thus. The Idos is that which you ee in the piece: the Idea is quite without the piece, and not onely without it, but alo had a being before the piece was at all. For thoe things that have been formerly oberved, and either by ue, or cutome have taken deep root in the minde of the Artificer, doe contitute art it elfe, and the Operative Habit: for Art it elf is nothing but the reaon of the
work, implanted in the Artits minde. And the ame way by which we gaine an Art, by the very ame we attain any kinde of cience or knowledge whatever: for as Art is a habit whoe object is omething to be done; o Science is a habit, whoe object is omething to be known: and as the former proceedeth from the imitation of Exemplars; o this latter, from the knowledge of things naturall. The Soure of both is from ene and experience; ince it is impoible that Art hould rightly be purchaed by the one, or Science by the other, without a direction from Ideas. Yet in both Art & Science too, that thing which in enible objects wee perceive, differs from the perception it elf, which is kept in the memory, or imagination. That, is the exemplar, the Idea, the forme informing: this, the Repreentation, the Idos, the abtracted Species. That, is a natural thing, a real entity; this, a reemblance, or imilitude, and an ens rationis. That, is imployed about ome particular thing, and is it elfe a ingular, and an individual; this, is a kinde of univeral and common thing. That, is in every Artit and Philoopher, a enible thing, clear, and perfect; this belongs to the mind, and is obcure. For what wee dicover by ene, is much more ure
and manifet, then what we dicover by the Intellect: becaue the latter prings from the former, and is illutrated by it. To conclude, Senible Objects are of themelves, and before Intelligible; but Intelligible are after them, and arie from them: nor can we attain to them at all, without their help.

Wherefore it is, that our judgement erreth about phantames and apparitions compried in our minds, unles ene give a right verdict, etablihed upon frequent obervations, and infallible experiments. For in every Science, be it what it will, a diligent obervation is requiite, and Sene it elf mut be frequently conulted. We mut not (I ay) rely upon other mens experience, but on our owne; without which, no man is a proper diciple of any part of natural knowledge; nor a competent judge of what I hall deliver concerning Generation; for without experimentall skill in Anatomy, he will no better apprehend it, then a man born blind can judge of the nature and difference of colours; or one born deaf, of Sounds. Therefore (dicreet Reader) trut nothing I ay, about the Generation of Animals; I appeale to none but thine eyes. For ince every perfect Science builds upon thoe
Principles, which it finds out by Sene: we mut have a pecial care, that by cutomary diections, we be ure thoe Principles are afely grounded. If we do otherwie, we may get a tumid and floating opinion: but never a olid and infallible knowledge: As it happeneth to thoe, who ee forraign countries only in Mapps, and the bowels of men fally decribed in Anatomical tables. And hence it comes about, that in this rank age, we have many Sophiters, and Bookwrights; but few wie men, and Philoophers.

And thus much I thought fit to premie as a Tat, that you may undertand, by what helps I my elf was aited, and upon what conideration I was induced to communicate thee my Obervations, and Experiments: and that you treading the ame path, may be able not onely to be in equitable Umpire between Aritotle, & Galen, but alo foraking al ubtleties; and probable conjectures, and viewing Nature in her own glas, may earch out many other things yet unrevealed, and perhaps more precious.

div.head: Of the former matters, according to Aritotle.
div.p:
NO kind of knowledge is innate to us, according to Aritotle: For neither
Opinion, nor Art, nor Undertanding, nor Speech, nor Reaon it elf, are in us by nature, and from our birth; but all thee are of the linage of thoe things, which happen to us from without, according to nature As alo all thoe qualities and habits which are eteemed to be pontaneous, & placed within our own power; uch are Virtues and Vices, for which we receive neither commendation, and reward, or digrace, & punihment. The knowledg therfore of any thing whatoever mut be ou • proper purchae. But which are the firt principles of this knowledge, is not the cope of this dicoure.

Yet I uppoe it will not be amis, t • premie here, Whence, and How we com • to know, that we may attain to a mo •• perfect undertanding of the Generation Animals, and alo take away any cruple which any man might raie about Aritotle opinion. For he affirms, all doctrine, an •
Analyt. pot. l. 1. c. 1. Dianoetical dicipline to be framed out of precedent knowledge: Whence it eems to inue, that there is either no firt knowledge or ele that that firt knowledge is bo •• with us; which is dionant to what is ai • before.

This doubt is hereafter cleared by Aritotle
Ib. l. 2. cap. ult. himelf; where he teacheth th •
manner how knowledge is acquired. For having taught, that all certain knowledge is gained by Syllogim, and Demontration; and that all demontrative Syllogimes, are built upon ome firt, true, and neceary principles; he at lat inquires, how principles become known, and what is that notifying habit; as alo, whether habits are begotten, ince they were not in us before; or ele, whether they lurked conceal'd, in cae they were in us? We have not, aith he, thoe habits; for it happens that they are hid from thoe who acquire more exquiite knowledge by demontration. But if we receive them, when we had them not before, how hould we make it known, and how hould we learn out of a non-preceding knowledge? It is plaine therefore that we have them not, and that they are not in us, and we not know of them; and that they cannot be begotten in men that have yet no habit at all. Wherefore it necearily follows, that we have ome power to attain them, and yet not uch a one as is more excellent, and exquiite then they. Now this eems to be a common thing to all creatures living: to have a connate power of Judging, which is called Sene.

p.hi: Now ince they have Sene, ome of them retain in them the things they perceive by ene, and ome not. They who retain not,

have either no knowledge at all, or ele no knowledge of what they do not retain, beyond the bare enation it elf. Others do retaine in their Soul omething of what they perceive. And ince there are many uch, they are thus differenced; that in ome there doth reult a certain dicoure from the memory of things retained, and in ome not. By Sene therefore memory is made, as we ay; and out of a frequent remembrance of the ame thing, is experience made: (for many numerical Remembrances, are one Experience) but out of Experience, or an Univeral reting in the oul (namely out of one, which is ditinct from the many particulars, and is one and the ame in all of them) is raied a Principle of Art, and Science: of Art, if it relate to Generation; (that is, to doing, or effecting;) of Science, if it appertain to that which is, (that is, to the knowledge of an Entity imply;) o that the habits we peak of, are neither naturally in us, neither are they made out of other habits more known, but they proceed from Sene.

div.p:
By which words of Aritotle, it evidently appears, by what Order the knowledge of any Art, or Science is attained: Namely, by Sene there remains an impreion of the thing perceived: by that impreion is made a remembrance of it, and from multiplied memory, proceeds Experience: from
Experience, Univeral Reaon, Definitions, Maximes, or common Axioms, which are the mot certain Principles of knowledge. As for example, The ame thing, under the ame capacity cannot poibly be, and not bee. Every Affirmation, or Negation, is either true or fale; and o forth.

Wherefore, as we aid before, no perfect knowledge, which may be called ours, is in us; but uch as is in ome ort derived to us from Experience, and Sene; or is at leat examined, and approved by them, and trongly grounded upon ome knowledge pre-exitent in us. For without memory, there can be no experience, which is nothing ele but a multiplied memory: neither can memory bee, without a remaining impreion of the enative object, and the object cannot remaine, where it never was.

The great Dictator of Philoophy hath Metaph. l. 1. c. 1. another paage to this purpoe. All men naturally deire knowledge. And this is evidenced, by the love of our Senes: amongt which we prefer the ight; becaue this chiefly conveyeth knowledge to us, and ditinguiheth bet of things.

p.hi: Now naurally Animals are enative: but ome of them remember not what they perceive by ene, and ome do. And for this caue

hi.U: ome are prudent, ome are more capable of dicipline then others that remember not. Prudent, without being taught; as all thoe that have not the ene of hearing, as Bees, and all uch other kinds of creatures; But all creatures may be taught which have both memory, and hearing too.

div.p: Therefore other creatures have phanies, and memories, but have no title to experience. But Men have Arts, and Ratiocination. And to them experience comes by remembrance: for many recordations of the ame thing, make one Experience. Wherefore experience eems much of kin to Art, and Science. For by experience men gain both Art and Science. For Experience begets Art (as Polus rightly notes) but Inexperience, Chance.

By which he clearly hews, that no man Apud. Plat. in Gorgiâ. can be truely called prudent, or knowing, who doth not by his own experience (attained by manifold remembrance, frequent enation, and diligent obervation) know things to be o. For without that, we think onely, or beleive: and uch a knowledge as that, is to be reputed other mens, rather then our owne. Wherefore fond and erroneous is that Method of eeking truth, in ue in our times: while mot men diligently inquire, not what the truth is, but what other men
ay it is: and inferring Univeral concluions from particular premies, & thence haping to themelves irrational deductions, they tranmit to us things like truth, for truth it elf.

Hence it is, that Sophiters and halfe-knowing men, polling other mens inventions, aucily impoe them upon us for their own; (hifting onely the phrae and order, and adding ome impertinencies of their own) and render Philoophy (which ought to be clear and perpicuous) obcure, intricate, and confued. For whooever they be that read authors, and do not, by the aid of their own Senes, abtract true repreentations of the things themelves (comprehended in the authors expreions) they do not reent true Ideas, but deceitful Idols, & Phantams; by which means they frame to themelves certaine hadows and Chimaera's, and all their theory and contemplation (which they count Science) repreents nothing but waking mens dreams, and ick mens phrenies.

Give me leave therefore to whiper this to thee (friendly Reader) that thou be ure to weigh all that I deliver in thee Exercitations, touching the Generation of living Creatures, in the teady cale of experiment; and give no longer credit to it,
then thou perceivet it to be ecurely bottomed, by the faithful tetimony of thy own eyes. This very thing did Aritotle perwade us to; who when he had dicoured much of Bees, added at lat: That the Generation of Bees is after this manner, appears
De gen. an. l. 3. c. 1. by reaon, and by thoe things which are een to come to pas after the maner of Bees. Yet have we not a ufficient dicovery of what may fall out. Therefore when the dicovery hall be compleated, then is Sene more to be truted to, then Reaon. For o far onely is Reaon to be relied upon, as thoe things which are demontrated, agree with thoe things which are perceived by ene.

div.head: Of the Method to be oberved in the knowledge of Generation.
div.p:
SInce therefore in the Generation of Animals (as in all other things of which we covet to know any thing) every inquiition is to be derived from its Caues, and chiefly from the Material and Efficient; it eems fit to me, looking back on perfect animals (namely by what degrees they are begun, and compleated) to retreat, as it were, from the end to the beginning: that o at lat when there is no place for farther
retreat, we may be confident we have arrived at the principles themelves: and then it will appear, out of what firt matter, by what efficient, and what proceion the platick power hath its original; and then alo what progres Nature makes in this work. For both the firt, and remoter matter, appears the clearer (being tripped naked as it were) by Negation; and whatoever is firt made in Generation, that is, as it were, the material caue of that which ucceedeth. So, for example, A Man, was firt a Boy (becaue from a Boy he grew up to be a Man;) before he was a Boy, he was an Infant; and before an Infant, an Embryo.

Now we mut earch farther, what hee was in his Mothers Womb, before he was this Embryo, or Foetus; whether three bubbles? or ome rude and indigested lump? or a conception, or coagulation of mixed eed? or whether any thing ele? according to the opinion of writers.

In the ame manner, before a Hen or Cock came to perfection, (and that is called a perfect Animal, that can beget its like) there was a Chicken; before that Chicken, there is een in the egge an Embryo, or Foetus; and before that Embryo, Hieronymus Fabricius Aquapendens hath decried the
rudiments of the Head, Eyes, and Spine of the Back. But where he affirms, that the Bones are made before the Mucles, Heart, Liver, Lungs, and all the Vicera; and that all the inward parts ought to exit before the outward; he relieth upon probability, rather then experience; and laying aide the verdict of ene, which is grounded upon diections; he flies to petty reaonings borrowed from mechanicks: which is very unbeeeming o famous an Anatomit. For he ought to have told us what daily changes his own eyes had dicovered in the egge, ere ever the Foetus came to perfection. Epecially eeing he profeedly wrote the Hitory of the Generation of the Chicken out of the Egge; and hath decribed in pictures what progres is made from day to day. It was, I ay, befitting o much diligence, to have acquainted us from the allegation of his own ight, what things in the egge are made firt, what lat, and what happen together: and not to have confined himelf to the example of building of Ships, and Houes, to render a cloudy conjecture and perwaion only, of the order, and manner of forming the parts.

We therefore (according to the Method propoed) will explaine, firt in an Egge, and afterwards in other Conceptions
of everal creatures, what is contituted firt, and what lat, in a mot miraculous order, & with a mot inimitable prudence and widome, by the great God of nature; and at length we will dicover, what we have found out, concerning the firt matter out of which, and the firt efficient by which, the foetus is made, as alo of the order & Oeconomy of Generation: that thence we may attain to ome infallible knowledge of each faculty of the formative and vegetative Soul, by the effects of it; and of the nature of the Soul it elfe, by the parts, or organs of the body, and their functions.
Now this indeed we could not perform in all kind of Animals; becaue ome of them cannot be gotten; and others again are o exceeding mall, that our eyes can hardly dicern them.

Let it uffice therefore that we have done it in ome creatures, which are more known to us; to whoe platform, the firt originals of all other creatures may be reduced. We have made choice therefore of uch, as might render the credit of our experiments lee quetionable, namely larger, and perfecter creatures, and uch as are within our own power. For in the larger creatures, all things are more conpicuous;
in the perfecter, more ditinct; and in thoe that are in our own power, & converant amongt us, more obvious: o that we have liberty (at pleaure) by earching into them, to recue our obervations from wavering heitation. And of this ort, in the race of Oviparous creatures, are Hens, Geee, Pigeons, Ducks Eihes, Shel-fih of both kinds (as Lobters, Oyters, &c.) Fihes that have no hells at all, Frogs, Serpents: alo Infects, as Bees, Wapes, Butterflies, Silkworms. And of Viviparous, Sheep, Goats, Dogs, Cats, all Cattel that divide the Hoofe; and in chief, the perfectet of all creatures, Man himelf.

Having thorough inight & knowledge of thee things, we may then contemplate the abtrue nature of the Vegetative Soul; and dicern in all creatures what ever, the manner, order, and caues of their Generation: becaue all other creatures agree either generically, or pecifically with the fore-cited, or at the leat with ome of them; and are procreated after the ame manner of generation, or ele in a manner proportioned to it. For Nature being divine, and perfect, is always cononant to her elf in the ame things. And as her works do either agree or differ (namely in kind, pecies,
or ome analogy) o her operation (that is to ay, generation or Fabrick) is the ame or different in them. Whoever entereth this new, and unfrequented path, and inquires for truth in the vat volume of Nature, by Anatomical diections, and experiments, he meets with uch a croud of obervations, and thoe too in uch exotick hapes, that to unfould to others the myteries himelf hath dicovered, will bee more toyl, then the finding of them out: for many things occurr which have yet no name; uch is the plenty of things, and the dearth of words. So that if a man hould cloath them in Metaphors, and expres his new inventions by old words, and uch as are in ue: the Reader could no more undertand them, then canting: and would never be able to comprehend the buines, ince he never aw it.

And then again to mint up new and fictitious terms, would rather cat a mit, then enlighten. For o he mut needs expres things unknown, by that which is lee known: and the Reader would be more afflicted to unriddle the words, then to undertand the matter. And therefore Aritotle by unexperimented perons is thought obcure: And this perhaps was the reaon, why Fabricius ab Aquapendente
choe rather to decribe the Fabrick of the Chicken in the Egge by tables then words.

Therefore be not offended, Courteous Reader, if in etting out the Hitory of an Egge, and in the decription of the Generation of the Chicken, I make ue of a new method, and ometimes of unuual terms; nor think me hereby more deirous of vainglory, then of advantaging others by true experiments, and uch as are grounded in Natures elf. To take off that prejudice, know, I tread but the teps of other men who have lighted me the way, and (o farre as is fit) I make ue of their notions. But in chief, of all the Ancients, I follow Aritotle; and of the later Writers, Hieronymus Fabricius ab Aquapendente, Him as my General, and This as my Guide. For as they which finde out new Plantations, and new Shores, call them by names of their own coyning, which Poterity afterwards accepts and receives; o thoe that finde out new Secrets, have good title to their compellation. And here, me thinks, I hear Galen adviing; If we conent in the things; contend not about the words:

div.head: The Reaon why we begin with a Henns Egge.
EXERCITATION I.
div.p: HIeronymus Fabricius Aquapendens (whom, as I aid before, I have choen for my guide) in the beginning of his Book concerning the formation of the Egge and Chicken, hath thee words: My purpoe is to treat of all orts of formation of the foetus, taking my rie from that which proceeds from an egge; For this ought to precede all other dicoures of this nature, in that it not only be friends us with a more eaie dicovery of Aritotles thoughts concerning this matter, but becaue the Treatie of framing the foetus out of an egge is much the fullet, and exceeds the other both in extent, and difficulty.

But we begin our dicoure from the hitory of an Egge, both for the reaons by him recited, and likewie, becaue we may thence borrow more infallible grounds, which (in regard they are more
known to us) may enlighten us to contemplate the Generation of any other Animals. For ince Egges are a cheap merchandize, and are at hand at all times, and in all places; it is an eaie matter to oberve out of them, which are the firt evident, and ditinct ground-works of Generation; what progres nature makes in formation, and with what wonderfull providence hee governes the whole worke.

Fabricius goes on: That the contemplation of framing the foetus out of Egges is the larget of all, appeares in this, that the greatet part of animals are begotten of egges. For to pas by almot the whole race of Inects, and imperfect Creatures, which ene it elf dicovers to pring from eggs; even the mot part of perfect productions are of that extraction. Hither he referreth, All orts of Birds; and of Fihes too; (bating only Whales) alo Cruted-fih, Shell-fih, and Fihes without cales,; and amongt Terretrials, all Creeping things, Creatures that have numerous feet, and alo all kindes of Serpents; and amongt four-footed Beats, all orts of Lizards.

But we pronounce (as hall appeare hereafter) all animals whatever, even Viviparous alo, nay man himelf to be made of an Egge: and that the firt conceptions of all living creatures which bring forth young, are certain Egges, jut as the firt conceptions of all Plants are certain eeds. And therefore Empedocles rightly tiled the eeds of Plants, a ort of Egges. The hitory therefore of Egges is mot pacious, becaue it yields an inight into all kinde of generation.
Wherefore of an Egge, we hall firt hew, where, whence, and how it is made. And then, by what means, order, and degrees, the foetus or chicken is fahioned, and perfected in the Egge, and of it.

Here again Fabricius: The productions of Animals do ome of them pring out of Egges, ome out of Seed, and ome out of Putrifaction; and hence it is, that ome are called oviparous, ome viviparous, others the iues of putrifaction, or creatures born of their own accord; by the Greeks,
< in non-Latin alphabet > .

But I dilike this diviion; becaue all Animals may in ome ort be aid to be born out of Egges, and in ome ort out of Seed: beides, they are tiled Oviparous, Viviparous, or Vermiparous, rather from the iues themelves bring forth, then from the original matter of which themelves were made; namely, becaue they produce an Egge, a Worm, or a living Creature. Some of them are alo aid to be ponte nacentia, creatures born of their own accord, not becaue they quicken out of putrid matter, but becaue they are begotten by chance, by natures own accord, and by an aequivocal generation, (as they call it) and by parents of a different pecies from themelves. For other Animals alo do bring forth an Egge, or a Worm, as their Conception, and Seed; out of which, after they have expoed it to the wide world, they produce a foetus, and o are named Oviparous, or Vermiparous. But now the Viviparous are therefore o called, becaue they retain and cherih their conception, or eed, o long within their own bowels, till the foetus come forth haped, and alive.

div.head: Of the place of Generation.
EXERCITATION II.
div.p: NAture (aith Fabricius) was firt olicitous of the place, which he at length decreed to be either within the Animal, or without it; and appointed the womb to be the place, within the creature; but without, the egge: in the womb, nature generates of eed and blood; but, in the egge, of uch parts as the egge is made of.

For whatoever is begotten of eed properly o called, is begun, and perfected, either in the ame place, or in a divere. All Viviparous creatures have both their original and perfection in the womb it elf; but all Oviparous, as they have their foundation within their parent, and there become an egge; o are they compleated into a foetus, when they are divided from their parent. And, in the Catalogue of thee, ome creatures continue their eggs o long within themelves, till thoe eggs be ripe, and accomplihed: and thus doe Birds and Beats too, as many as bring forth eggs; and erpents likewie. But others againe expoe their eed whiles it is yet unperfect and immature, to acquire its growth, perfection, and ripenes from abroad: and thus do many orts of Fihes, Froggs; alo Fihes without cales, and both orts of Shellfih, and Snails, whoe eggs, when firt excluded, are but deignes or beginnings, being yolks onely, which do afterward invet themelves with whites, and by degrees attracting, concocting, and affixing aliment to themelves, become perfect eed, and a compleat egge And of this kinde alo is the
eed of Inects (which Aritotle aith is a Worme) which being expoed incomplete at the firt, eek their own food, and o thrive, and enlarge, from an imperfect egge, to a perfect egge, and eed. But the Henne, and all other Oviparous creatures, doe lay a perfect egge; of which, from without the womb, they hatch a foetus. And for this caue Aquapendens mentions two places aigned to generation; one Internal, namely the womb; the other external, which he calls the Egge. But (in my opinion) he might, upon better grounds, have called the Net, or Repoitory, the external place; becaue in that the expoed eed is cherihed, ripened, and hatched into a foetus. For the Generation of Oviparous creatures, is mainly differenced by their Net. Nor is it les then admirable, that uch little creatures hould make choice of thee receptacles with uch exquiite prudence; and hape, build, guard, and conceale them, with uch unimitable art and contrivance: whence we mut needs conclude (with the Poet treating of Bees) that they are endowed with a portion of divine inpiration: and that we may eaier admire their unintructed art and prudence, then attain unto it.

div.head: Of the Ovary, or upper part of the Henns womb.
EXERCITATION III.
div.p: THe womb of the Henn is divided by Fabricius, into the Upper, and the Lower; the Upper hee names the Ovary.

The eat of the Ovary is next under the Liver at the pine of the back, above the decending trunk of the great Artery. For jut in that place where in bigger angineous creatures, the Coeliacal artery goes into the Meentery, namely, at the original of the Emulgent veines, or a little lower; and in that place where the preparing eed veels which go down to the Teticles have their rie, in all other anguineous & viviparous creatures; & where alo the cock wears his Teticles, there is the Hens Ovary found. For ome Animals have their tones hanging out, others conceal them about the Loins within; in a middle pace as it were, at the beginning of the preparing vesels. But the Cock hath his tones immediatly adjoined to the vaa praeparantia, as if his eed wanted no preparation. Aritotle indeed aith, that the Egge is begun at the midriffe; but we, aith Fabricius, in our treatie of Repiration, deny that Birds have any midriffe at all. Which difficulty is thus reolved: Birds are not quite detitute of a midriff; becaue they have a thinne membrane intead of the midriff; which Arit. calls cinctum, or eptum: but they have no muculous midriffe, as other Animals have, neither is it ued by them for Repiration. But, to ay truth, Aritotle acknowledged no mucles at all.

Thus, in one and the ame breath he accues the Philoopher, and excues him too: yet hee himelf is in an Errour the while. For it is certaine, that Aritotle did acknowledge mucles (as we have elewhere oberved, and demontrated) and alo that membranes in Birds (which are not onely placed tranverly to gird the body, but are alo extended according to the longitude of the belly) do upply the place of the diaphragma, or midriff, and do conduce to repiration: as in another place in our Exercitations, concerning the Repiration of
animals, we have clearly proved. And, to ay no more at preent, Birds do not onely repire with much more facility then other creatures, but in their ongs doe tune and accent their voices with manifold variety: yet, notwithtanding all this, their Lungs are o knit to their ribbes and ides, that they can be but very little dilated, raied up, or contracted. Beides all this, (though no man to my remembrance hath ever oberved o much before) their Bronchia, or extremities of the rough Artery are hollow as far as the very abdomen, and they treaure up the inpired aire in the cavities of their membranes. Even as Fihes, and Serpents draw the aire into large bladders, which are eated in their abdomen or belly, and o reerve it, and by that means are conceived to wim the better: and as froggs, and toads, in the Summer time when they breathe mot, doe imbibe much more aire then at other times into their numerous veicles, (which occaions their wondrous welling) that o they may afford more liberall expirations in their croaking: So in Birds, the Lungs eem rather a thorough-fare, and a paage for breathing, then the adaequat organ of it. Which had Fabricius oberved, he would not then have denyed, but that thoe membranes (at let with the aitance of the mucles of the belly) doe erve for repiration, and execute the office of a diaphragma: ince even that is not a repiratory organ, without the help of the mucles of the belly; though it have alo another imployment in thoe creatures in whom it is muculous, and flehy; Namely, to depres the tomack enlarged with meats, and the guts ditended with winde and excrements; let the heart and lungs hould be traitned by their intruion, and the cloet of life it elfe invaded. Now, ince there is no fear of any
uch michance in Birds, their midriffe is membranous, and exceeding advantagious to the work of repiration; and for this caue they are aid to have a diaphragma. Moreover, were birds quite detitute of a diaphragma, yet Aritotle were not to be blamed, for aying, That Eggs receive their firt rudiment at the eptum tranverum; for by this name he onely points at the place where the diaphragma is commonly found in other Animals. So we alo ay, that the Ovary is cituate at the beginning of the preparing permatical vesels, though a Henne hath no uch veels at all.

The Perforation of the Lungs, by me firt dicovered (of which I made mention but now) is in no ort dark and obcure; but, in Birds epecially, very patent: o that in an Otrich I found many perforations, into which I could eaily thrut the top of my finger. In a Turkey, nay in an ordinary dunghill Cocke, and almot all Birds whatoever, a probe being put into the winde-pipe, will finde an open and wide paage, clean through the lungs into the cavities of the abdomen, or lower belly. Blow the aire into their lungs with a pair of bellowes, and you hall finde it haten into the lower parts, and that not without a enible force.

Nay, we may very well quetion whether, even in man whilet he is living, the air doth not penetrate into the cavity of the chet, by the aforeaid paages. For could otherwie the putrefied matter of impotumated, and the blood hut out of the veins of pleuritical perons, flow from thence? How could the aire, when the breat is wounded (though the lungs be untoucht) ruh out of the wound? or how could injections cat into the cavity of the chet, be returned again with the pittle? But of this at large in our Exercitations, of
the Caues, Intruments, and Ue of Repiration.

I return now to the Ovary, and the upper part of the wombe of the Henne; in which the firt rudiments of the Eggs are conceived, which are (according to Aritotle) mall at firt, and white; but increaing, afterwards become of a pale yellow.

As for this upper womb mentioned by Fabricius, the truth is, there is no uch thing at all, till the Henne have conceived, and hath the principles of Eggs within her, which may then be properly called a cluter of wheals. And therefore he aith very rightly: The uperiour matrix is nothing ele but almot an infinite crowd of yolks, which are amased in one heap together, being of a round figure, and of divere magnitude; amongt which there is a like difference from the greatet to the leat, as between a grane of mutard-eed and a walnut, or a medlar. This multitude of yolks are united and knit together as it were upon a bunch: and therefore I call it a Vitellary, or a bunch of yolks, becaue it much reembles a bunch of grapes. As Aritotle alo aid of fihes that want cales, where he writes, That their eggs are laid as if they were glewed together like grapes; for as in a bunch of grapes, the berries are ome bigget, ome les, and ome leat of all, and each is tyed to its proper prig, o is it in the Vitellary.

But now in Fihes, Frogs, hard or cruted Shellfih, and Snails, the matter is much otherwie; for they contain in them Eggs of the elf-ame magnitude; which being dicharged, do grow alike, are perfected alike, and at the ame time produce yong ones. But in the Ovary of a Henne, and almot of all other Oviparous creatures, there is a ditinct increae of the yolkes, from almot an inviible malnes, till they arrive to a complete magnitude: though the Eggs of Hennes (not unlike the
eggs of thoe creatures which conceive and lay their egges together) are hatched into chickens in the ame net, almot at the ame time. Yet in Pigeons (which lay, and hatch onely two egges at a time) I have oberved all the Eggs in the Ovary to be of a like magnitude, excepting only thoe two which were greater then the ret, and were now ready to decend into the econd uterus, or womb; o that of them there is great increae, not by the multitude of their young at once, but by the frequency of their repeated births, which happen every moneth. So in cartilaginous Fihes; as the Thorn-back, the Fork-fih, the Dog-fih, &c. two eggs are only ripe at a time, and falling down on both ides from the right and left horn, they are cherihed in the lower womb, and exclude their young alive (as the Viviparous creatures do:) yet in their Ovary they have almot an infinite number of eggs, and of different dimenions; in the Thornback I have numbered above a hundred.

But the Eggs of other oviparous creatures are either perfected when they are out of the womb, as the eggs of fihes; or at leat concocted, as the eggs of nailes, of hard hell-fih, and of piders. The nailes they treaure up their eggs in froth; cruted hell-fih, (as hrimps, cray-fih, lobters) carry them about fatned to their finnes; but the pider beareth them about with her, as it were in a baket wrought of her webbe, and o cheriheth them. The Beetle wrappeth her eggs in dung, (rowling them in it with her hinder leggs) and o layeth them up: and, in all thee, there are an incredible number of eggs. Fihes have two oblong bladders, or bags, as you may ee in the Carp, the Herring, and the Smelt; in all which, as there is no womb at all dicernable, beides the Ovary, o is
this Ovary ometimes o thronged with eggs, that it far exceeds the bulk of the whole body beides.

Of the Ovaries of thee Carps and Mullets, amaed together, and alted, and hardned in the moak, is made that kinde of meat o much in requet with the Greeks and Italians (called by thee Botarcha, by the Greeks
< in non-Latin alphabet > , that is to ay, pickled eggs) uch as is that which is found in our red Herrings, & the red and compacted eed within a Lobter. That meat which is made of the alted eggs of Sturgem, is called Caviare, which reembleth black ope, and is the delight of gluttons.

In all fihes (which have a numerous offspring) o great abundance of egs is generated, that the whole capacity of the belly can hardly contein them, when they are newly conceived, much les when they are of any growth. And therefore in fihes, aving their Ovary, there is no other part dedicated to generation. For their eggs take growth abroad; nor need they any womb for that office. And this Ovary eems to carry ome Analogie to the reticles, or litle eminal bladders, not only becaue they are found in that place where the tones are bred in males; (for the tones in Cocks are cituate, as we have aid, at the ingres of the Coeliacal artery, neere the midriff, and there the Hens Ovary is found) but alo, becaue in both exes of fihes, at the time of generation, there are two litle bags paing through the whole belly, alike in ite, figure, and magnitude; which increaing at the ame time, are filled, in males with a imilary, permatical, and milky ubtance, (whence it is called fihes milke) and in the females, with litle inviible graines or ands; o that in the beginning of conception (by reaon of their cloe fabrick) they look like a imilar
body, and like the males milk regularly coagulated, and may afterwards be dicerned like the mallet ands clinging together in their proper bags.

In leer Birds (which bring forth egges, and thoe few ones, but once a year) you will carce finde any Ovary at all; but jut where the tones hang in males, there in females, intead of an Ovary, are found three or four bubbles (according to the number of egges, whoe foundation they are) as dicernable as the teticles of the males.

In the horns of the Serpents womb (which are like the permatical vesels of the males) appear the firt rudiments of the eggs, like litle balls fatned on a tring, as is uual in womens bracelets, or chaplets of beads made of amber.

They therefore that are found in the Vitellary, or Ovary, are not to be counted perfect eggs, but the firt ground-works or rudiments of eggs, which are in uch order and magnitude dipoed in the bunch, that one may daily ucceed the other, to upply the hennes laying. But no egge in the Ovary is cloathed with a white, for onely yolks are found there; which, as they gain growth, get without the mall ones; that being arrived to a larger room, they may the better thrive and enlarge. And therefore that of Fabricius is very true, where he aith, The greater yolks of the bunch are in the urface, pag. 3. the leser are in the middle, encompased as it were by the greater; latly, the leat of all lie undermot. For as they get greater bulk by growing, they are eparated from their fellowes; which, while it is doing, every yolke, beides his proper coat, borroweth another from the Ovary, which encompaeth it without, and tyeth it to the foundation from whence it prung: wherefore by Fabricius it
is called pediolus, ive pedunculus, the talk, becaue by its means, as the fruit draweth nourihment and increae from the tree, o doth the yolk from the cluter. For this talk is a membranous hollow fatning, which is extended from the bottom of the cluter to the yolk: which o oon as it arrives at, it is dilated, and (jut as the optick nerve is pread in the eye) covereth the yolk with an outward coat. Hence Aritotle probably called it
< in non-Latin alphabet > , that is, the litle umbilical appendix, or pipe. This litle talk conveighs De Gen. An. l. 3. c. 2. with it many vesels into the yolke, through which they are many waies divaricated.

Thee things are indeed truly delivered by Fabricius, but he mitaketh, when he aith, This coat doth not environ the whole yolke, but onely a litle more then half of it, jut as the cover of an acorn, called the cup: whence it cometh to pas, that the outward part of the yolke, being deerted by the fore-mentioned membrane, is expoed to the view without veines, and appeareth naked. For it embraceth all the yolk; but in the outward part of the yolk, it is not eaily dicerned from its own coat, becaue they both are very thin. But, in the fore-part, where the yolk repecteth the foundation of the cluter, this coat adhereth not to the yolk, neither doth it end any veines into it, but only begirts it like a bag.

Every yolk aumeth a particular coat from the ame foundation; and therefore this place is not to be reputed the common womb, ince nothing is here to be found, beide the cluter, or heap of many eggs, of different magnitude, ariing from the ame foundation.

Now this Foundation is a particular body of it elf, ariing at the pine of the Fowle, annexed to the great Artery and Vein, being looe, porous, and fungous, that o it may produce divers yolks out of
it elf, and afford each of them their coats; which coats do afterwards tretch, as the yolks enlarge, and incloe them like a Bag, with a narrow neck, but a large belly, in like manner as glas-vials are fahioned by the breath of the Glas-maker. Fabricius aith further; The yolks, as they pring from a very mall original, being about the magnitude of the eed of Millet, or Mutard, o they are very litle, and white, as Aritotle oberves, and do alo increae by degrees; and, as the ame Aritotle aith, grow like yolks, and yellow, till they attain the jut magnitude which every body knoweth them to be of. But I have oberved them to be much les then the eeds of Millet, even as lender as the mallet wheals, or pots, or ands, (uch as I have told you are found in the Ovaries of Fihes) carce to be dicovered by the eye it elf, as if they were onely the ruggednes of the membranes of that part from whence they proceed.

div.head: Of the Infundibulum, or Tunnel.
EXERCIT. IV.
div.p: THe next part of the Womb of the Hen, is by Fabricius called the Infundibulum: for it is like a Tunnel, or Trumpet, tending down-ward from the Ovdry, (which it every where encompaeth) and growing wider by degrees, is terminated in the uperiour production of the Womb.

This Infundibulum doth afford a paage to the yolks (when their talks are broken off) into the econd womb (as Fabricius thinketh) and reembleth the Tunicae vaginalis, or coat of the Teticles in
the Cod, coniting of an exceeding thin membrane, and eaie to be dilated, that o it may entertain the yolks which dayly rowle thither, and conveigh them into the aforeaid Uterus.

Do you deire an Illutration of this matter? fahion in your minde a very lender plant, whoe knobby roots may repreent the cluter of yolks, and its trunk the litle vaginal, or heath-like pipe: as the talks of that herb do in the winter dye, and vanih away; o, in like manner, when the Hen ceaeth to lay any more egges, the entire Ovary, together with the Infundibulum, are retired, and abolihed, and (like ueles things) quite dried up; leaving onely the fundamentum remaining, and ome tracks and footteps of their roots.

That this Infundibulum doth onely upply the office of a thorow-fare, is hence enough evinced, in that the yolke is never found reiding in it: but as the Teticles ometimes do through the Tunica vaginalis creep upwards into the Groin, and as thoe Teticles are in ome creatures (as the Hare and Mole) hidden within the Abdomen, and do from thence again return and decend; o by the Infundibulum do the yolkes lide down from the Ovary into the Uterus; and it upplieth the place of that Tunnel (as it alo hath its form and hape) through which liquors are tranmitted, from one veel into an other of a narrower neck.

div.head: Of the Exteriour part of the Uterus of the Henne.
EXERCIT. V.
div.p: FAbricius proecuteth the decription of the Uterus, after the Ovary, and o by a pervere method, premitteth the treatie of the uperiour part, and production of the womb, to that of the very womb it elf. And is alo too precie and concluive in aigning three circles to it, and in determining their certain cituations, when indeed themelves are uncertain. And there alo he doth prepoterouly repeat the definition of the Infundibulum.

Give me leave therefore to propoe here my Obervation, and hitory of the Uterus of the Henne, (which I apprehend to be more commodious, according to Anatomical method) and to proceed from the outward parts to the inward, (contrary to the coure of Fabricius.)

In a Henne that is plucked, you may perceive the Fundament, not (as in other creatures) gathered up into a ring, but having a depreed orifice divided tranverly, hrunk up as it were into two lips, the uperior of which gathereth the inferior into it, and o covereth and concealeth it. That uppermot lip, or covering, arieth from the root of the rump; and, as the upper eye-lid covereth the eye, o doth this the three orifices of the Privity, (namely that of the Fundament, of the Uterus, and of the Ureters) which lye retracted under this covering, as under a praepuce, or fore-skin: as in the Lap of a Woman, the paage into the womb and bladder is
vailed by the labra of the privity, and the parts called Nymphae; o that, without diection, or at let ome forcible retraction of that covering, neither the paage of the Excrements out of the guts, nor of the Urine out of the Ureters, nor of the Egg out of the Uterus, can appear in a Hen. And therefore thoe two excrements (namely the Urine, and the Dung) are rejected both together, as out of a receptacle common to them both, by lifting up of that covering, & o dicloing the perforation: and o likewie in coition, the Hen unvaileth her lap, and accommodateth it for the Cock that treadeth her: as Fabricius oberved in a Turkey-Hen, which courted a Cock. I have een an Otrich-Hen (when her Keeper gently troked her back, with deigne to inflame her) groveling on the ground, lift aide that vaile, and expoe and tretch out her lappe; which the Cock perceiving, being intantly cupidtruck, proceeded to tread her; and having one leg on the ground, and the other on her back, with an exceeding large Yard (of the dimenions almot of a Neats-tongue) purued his attempt: great was the noie and clamours on both ides, and their necks often extended and retracted, and many other expreions of content. Nor is this proper to Birds onely, but common alo to other Creatures, which by removing aide their Taile, and extending their Lap, prepare themelves to receive the Male. So that the Tail in other creatures eems to be almot of the ame ue, with the Vail in the Hen, which, unles it be removed, or lifted up, there is neither paage for the excrements, nor the addrees of the Male.

In Hinds and Does (as if they were more everely chat then other beats) uch a skreen of modety, and skinney covering, hrowdeth both the lap,
and paage of urine, which mut of neceity be lifted up, ere they can have converation with the Male. In Beats alo that have tailes, there mut be an elevation of them, before they can bring forth their young. And Midwives alo, by unction and retruion of the extremity of the os acrum, do facilitate womens labours.

A certain Chirurgion of my acquaintance, an honet man, being returned from the Eat-Indies, told me upon his credit, that in the Iland called Bornea, in the Inland and Hilly parts of it, there are a race of men born with Tails, (as Pauanias writes of another place) and that he aw a Virgin of that flock, whom they had much ado to catch, (for they are wilde) who had a flehy, thick tail, a pan long, reflected between her leggs, to conceale her modety: uch care hath nature to hide thoe parts.

The fabrick of this Covering in a Hen, is like to that of the upper lid of the eye, compoed of skin, and of a flehy and muculous membrane, with fibers every where drawn from the circumference to the Center; and its inward uperficies, like that of the eye-lid, and fore-skin, is oft. It hath alo in its extremity a emicircular mall gritle, like the Tarus of the eye-lid: and, beide that, between the skin, and flehy membrane, a cartilaginous intertitium, from the root of the rump joined in a right angle to the emicircular Tarus, or gritle: (as Batts have a kind of litle taile, concealed under their membranous wings) by reaon of which compoition, this covering doth, as it were with a taile, helter and hide the perforations of the privities. The Perforations in the Fundament of a hen.

Wherefore, no ooner is this protection cut away, but certain perforations appear, whereof ome are more apparent, others more obcure. The more
viible, are that of the fundament, and the lap; namely, the paage of the excrements, and the entrance into the womb: the obcurer are, as well that through which the urine flowes from the kidnies, as alo that maller one found out by Fabricius, into which (aith hee) the Cock doth immit his eed; which cavity notwithtanding Antonius Ulmus a diligent diector in Aldrovandus did not own, nor any one ele beides Fabricius, o far as I The Sink. know. Thee Holes are all o neer neighbours the one to the other, that they eem all to conent and pas into one and the ame cavity; which (becaue it lies in common both to the excrement and the urine) may be called the Sink; becaue, in it, the excrements of the guts, together with the urine decending from the reines, are mixed together, till they be together excluded. And through this the egge alo paing forth, worketh its way.

The making of this cavity is uch, as if both the excrements decended into the Bladder, and nature did abue the urine into a natural clyter. And therefore it is omething thicker and ruggeder then the gut, and alo in ejection and coition, thruts it elf out, (the covering, as I have aid, being removed) and hangeth out like the inide of the gut: and at that time all the holes appear ditinctly; which preently again upon its retraction, being collected as it were into a pure, are hidden out of ight.

The more conpicuous Holes, (namely that of The cituation of the orifice of the womb. the fundament, and the lap) obtain a contrary cituation in all fowles, from all other creatures; for in thee, the Pudendum, or female genital, is eated foremot, between the right gut and the bladder: but in thoe, the paage of the Excrement is placed foremot,
and between that paage and the rump, the paage into the matrix.

But that Hole into which Fabricius thinketh the The Perforation of the Pure, o called by Aquapendens.
Cock doth cat his eed, is dicovered between this doore of the matrix, and the rump. But, for my part, I acknowledge no uch employment of it; for, in Pullets or young Hens, it is hardly found at all; but in grown fowle it is promicuouly as well in the Cock as in the Hen. And, beides that, this hole is very mall and obcure, and cannot therefore be imagined to be of o concerning an office; for it carce admits the point of a mall needle or a lender hair, and terminateth alo in a blind and obcure cavity: nor could I ever perceive any eminal humour at all in it; though Fabricius affirmeth, that the emen is there reerved as in a pure, for a whole year together, and that in the interim all the eggs receive fecundity from thence, as hall be dicoured hereafter.

All Birds, Serpents, Four-footed beats, which are Oviparous, and Fihes alo, (as is evident in Carps) The paage of Urine in a Hen. are endowed with Kidnies and Ureters, through which the Urine floweth: which Aritotle, and other Philoophers hitherto knew not. But Birds, and Serpents, whoe Lungs are fungous, have but very litle urine; becaue they drink but litle, and that by ips; and therefore they need no Bladder of Urine, but do depoit it (as we have aid) into the common ink and receptacle with the dryer excrements. But in Carps, and ome other fihes I have found a Bladder of Urine.

In a Hen, the Ureters decend form the Kidnies on both ides, (which Kidnies are large and ample and eated in the cavity or hollow of the back and do end in the cavity or common ink. But their
Out-let is o obcure, and concealed in the very entrance of the cavity, that to dicover it from without, or to earch it with the mot lender probe, is altogether impoible. Nor is it indeed any great wonder; for in all creatures, even in the greatet of all, the inertion of the Ureters neer the neck of the Bladder, is dark and winding, that (though urine, nay and tones too do ometimes glide through them into the bladder) not o much as the aire it elfe can go back that way, nor the urine, be it never o much forced.

All thee things are clear in an Otrich; in which I have found, beide the outward orifice of the common cavity, which was vailed by the Covering; another orifice within the Fundament, which was round and gathered up, and hut as it were with a phincter mucle. But to pas thee, and return to our purpoe.

The Orifice of the Womb, or Lap; namely the paage out of the publik cavity into the womb of The Orifice of the Uterus. the Hen, is as it were a certain oft protuberance or riing, looe, wrinkled, and orbicular; jut like the end of the Fore-skin cloed up, or a prominence of ome interiour coat of the matrix. But it is cituate (as I aid before) between the perforation of the fundament and the rump, tending omething to the left hand; which Ulyes Aldrovandus conceives o to be dipoed, for more convenient coition, and more commodious reception of maculine incurion.
