But I have often oberved, that the Hen doth indifferently incline her back parts towards the Cock, on which ide oever he prepare his acent, be it on the right or left. I finde no Penis, or Yard at all in a Cock, neither could Fabricius finde any, though it appear mot manifet in Drakes, and
Ganders. But, intead thereof, I finde an Orifice in a Cock (not different from that of a Hen) but it is les, and narrower; which Orifice is like wie found in the Swan, the Drake, and the Gander: but the Penis of the Drake and Gander (in the act of Coition) is ent out of this orifice.

In a black Drake, I aw a Penis of that extent, that after coition, the Duck purued it as it trailed upon the ground, with intent to devour it; (deeming, as I uppoe, that it had been a worm) which occaioned the Drake to retract it ooner then his cutom is.

In a Male-Oirich, I found, within this orifice of the Privy-parta a very large glans, or nut of the yard, and a ruddy nerve, of the form and magnitude of a Deers tongue, or mall Neats tongue; which I oberved him many times brandih in coition, tiffe, and omething embowed: which, when he had dipatched into the female, he detained there a good pace, without any commotion of thee parts at all, as they had been taked together; yet all the while trange were the geticulations of their Heads and Necks (as if they had approved their Nuptials) proclaiming their full complacence.

I have read in D. du Val, a mot learned Phyitian of Rouen, that a certain Hermaphrodite was delivered up to the Chirurgians and Midwives, to determine whether he was a Man or a Woman. They, upon dicovery, judged him to be a woman; and thereupon he was enjoined to habit himelfe like one of that ex. He notwithtanding was in the mean time accued of oliciting women, and playing the mans part. And at lat he had a penis iuing out of its hidden prepuce, (as out of a womans ecrets) which executed the mans office.
I my elf once aw a mans penis o hrunk up (excepting onely when it was provoked) that nothing appeared in the wrinkled prepuce above the crotum, but the meer extremity of the Glans.

In a Hore, and ome other creatures, the vat dimenion of that part is hut forth from within. In a Mole alo, that litle Animal, there is a great retraction of the penis into the skin and mucles of the Abdomen; and his female alo hath a longer and deeper Matrix then is uual.

I conceive, it is with a Cock, who hath no penis, as it is with the leer ort of Birds; which quickly conclude their acts of coition, and do perform them by affriction onely. For the Orifices of the Privities (of the Cock and Hen) by often conjunction, as by repeated alutes, do celebrate coition, not by one continued inition, (which orifices being turned outward, do protuberate, wax tiffe, and tretch after the manner of a Glans; epecially that of the Cock, which onely doth outwardly pres upon the female, and, as I uppoe, doth not enter in.

In the Coition of Hores, Dogs, and Cats, and other creatures, when the male preenteth his penis, the female proportioneth her parts tiffe, and extended. And Birds alo that are tame, uffer themelves to be gently troked, and welling with Venereal appetite, expoe that Orifice, which you may by your finger perceive to be hardened and reiting. Nay ometimes birds are o lutfull, that if you only gently mooth their backs, they will intantly incline, and extend and make bare their Uterine Orifice; which if your finger oftly comply with, they will declare their accepted recreation, in extravagant murmurs, and flutterings of their wings. And that the females will even thence
conceive eggs, both Aritotle beareth witnes, and I my elf have found in a Thruh, a Black-bird, and others: and this experiment I gained long ince, and by chance, but at my own cot. For my wife had an excellent, & a well intructed Parrat, which was long her delight; which was now grown o familiar, that he was permitted to walk at liberty through the whole houe: where he mied his Mitree, he would earch her out, and when he had found her, he would court her with a cheerfull congratulation. If he had called him, he would make anwer, and flying to her, he would grap her garments with his claws, and bill, till by degrees he had caled her houlder; whence he decending by her arm, did contantly eat himelf upon her hand. If he bad him talk, or ing, were it night, and never o darke, he would obey her. Many times when he was portive and wanton, he would it in her lap, where he loved to have her cratch his head, and troke his back, and then tetifie his contentment, by kinde mutterings, and haking of his wings. I till interpreted all this to proceed from his cutomary familiarity and obequiounes, for I alwaies thought him to be a Cock-Parrat, by his notable excellence in inging and talking. For amongt Birds, the females eldom ing, or provoke to dicoure; but the males onely charm the females by the pleaant muick of their voice, and allure them to pay their homage to Venus. And therefore Aritotle aith, If Partridge-hennes tand
Hit. an. l. 5. c. 5. and l. 6. c. 2. over againt the cocks, and the winde blow from whence the cocks are, they conceive and grow big, and for the mot part, they teem even by the voice of the cock, if they be at that time wanton and lutfull: and this alo may fall out from the cocks flying over them; namely if the cock do tranmit a fructifying pirit into the Hen.
And this happens chiefly in the Spring-time; whence the Poet: Virgil. 2. Georg.

lg.l: Vere tument terrae, & genitalia emina pocunt.
Tum Pater Omnipotens foecundis imbribus aether.
Conjugis in gremium laetae decendit, & omnes
Magnus alit, magno commitus corpore, foetus.
Avia tum reonant avibus virgulta onoris,
Et Venerem certis repetunt armenta diebus.

l.U: wells in Spring, and fertile eed requires,

lg.l: Decending Aether with her vote conpires,
And fruitful howrs cheer his glad conorts hart,
Which do to all her Iues growth impart.
The Deart woods are then the hrill Birds Quire,
And all Beats are inflam'd with Venus fire.

div.p: But not long after thee kinde dalliances, the Parrat, which had lived many years ound and healthy, grew ick, and being much oppreed by many convulive motions, did at length depoite his much lamented pirit in his Mitrees boom, where he had o often ported. When diecting his carkae, (to finde out the caue of his death) I found in the womb an egge almot completed, but, for want of a Cocke, corrupted. Which many times befalleth thoe Birds, that are immured in Cages, when they covet the ociety of the Cock.

By this and other examples, I am induced to believe, that the Dunghill-Cock, and the Cock-Pheaant, doe not onely delight their Hennes by their voices, but alo do confer omething by thoe very voices to the conception of the egges: for even at night, ome of the Hens at root with him, do betirre themelves at the Cocks crowing, haking their heads and wings; as if poeed by a gentle horrour, their enes were ravihed as after Coition.

A certain Fowle, as big again as a Swan, was not
long ince brought into Holland out of Java, a • Iland of the Eat-Indies, which fowle the Dutchmen called a Caoware: the figure of this fowle Aldrovandus repreenteth, and aith, that the Indians
Ornith. lib. 20. p. 541. call it Eme: it is not cloven-footed, as the Ostrich, but hath three claws on every foot; one of which is armed with o long, o hard, and o trong a purre, that it will eaily pierce through an Inc •
board. Now its manner of miting is forward; its body, legs, and thighes, are like an Otriches, but it hath not a broad bill, as the Otrich hath, but a roun •
and black one. Intead of a cret, it hath upon the head a round extuberant horn; it hath no tongue at all; eateth any thing without ditinction, be it tones, or coales, and thoe red-hot too, likewie pieces of glas; it hath two feathers pringing out from every quill, and thoe black, hort, and thinne, approaching to the nature of hair, or down; it hath very litle wings, and imperfect; it is a creature of a horrid apect, and hath long red and blew gils hanging down the neck (like a Turkey-Cock.)

This fowle continued in Holland above even yeares, and afterwards Maurice, the mot Illutrious Prince of Orange ent it, with other things, for a Preent to King James, in whoe gardens it lived above five yeares: but afterward, when two Otriches, Cock and Hen, chanced to be kept in the ame place, and the Caoware oftentimes over-heard them at the act of coition, being but in the next pennes (where they were fed apart) She unexpectedly conceived egges (tirred up, as I uppoe, by a certain ympathy, from thoe that were omething of the ame kin and linage with her) yet all that aw her, did conjecture he was rather a Cocke, then a Henne, conidering her we apons and martiall proviions. One of thee egges he laid whole and entire,
which I opened and found it compleat; for it had a white embracing the yolk round about, together with the chalazae, or pecks like hailetones annexed on both ides, and alo a litle cavity or emptines in the obtue end of it: there was likewie the cicatricula, the litle cicatrice, or whitih peck; the hell was thick, hard, and trong, which I caued to be made into a cup (the top being taken off) uch as is uually made of the Otriches egge. This egg was omething les then an Otriches egg, but every way perfect, as I aid before; yet without all quetion it was but a ubventaneous and an unfruitfull one, by reaon of the want of a Cock. But at the ame time as he brought forth the egge, I did preage he her elf would die; and that according to Aritotle, who aith, That Birds will be ick and dye, unles they bring forth, which fell out not long Gen. an. l. 3 after: and diecting her, I found an imperfect and corrupt egge in the Upper end of her Uterus, which caued her untimely death, (as I had formerly oberved in the Parrat and other Birds.)

Mot Birds, by how much the more alacious they are, o much the more fruitfull are they; and ometimes doe without a Cock (either from high feeding, or ome other caue) conceive eggs, which very eldom are either perfected, or brought forth at all, without the ue of a Cock; but they thenoe fall into deperate dieaes, and at length dye.

But the Dunghill-henne doth not onely conceive egges, but lay them alo; and thoe perfect too, but yet ubventaneous and barren ones. So alo many of the Inects (in whoe lit are Silk-worms and Butterflies) do both conceive, and lay egges, without conjunction with the male, (as fihes alo) but they are all addle, and wind-eggs. As if it were the ame thing for thee creatures to be with egge, as for
virgins to have their wombs grow warm; their termes flow, their breats increae, and (in a word) to become marriageable; which if they be too long detained from, they are aaulted with dangerous ymptoms; (namely hyterical affections, or furor Uterinus) or ele fall into the green icknes, and everall other ditempers. For all Creatures, when they are love-truck, grow extravagant, and if debarred of enjoyment, do at length recede much from their uual temper. Hence ome women grow frantick for love; and this extravagancy is o outragious in ome, that they eem bewitched, planettrucke, or poeed. And this inconvenience would be frequent, did not pious education, repect to their reputation, and in-bred modety, temper and awage thee inordinate commotions of the minde.

div.head: Of the Privities of a Henne.
EXER. VI.
div.p:
FRom the exterior uterine orifice, is the paage to the inner parts, and matrix, in which the egge is perfected: and this paage in other creatures is termed vagina uteri, or vulva, into which the males penis is tranmitted to the matrix. But in a Hen, this paage is o perplexed, and o wrinckled and folded, by reaon of the laxity of its inward coat, that though there be an eaie paage from the matrix outward, inomuch that a very great egge can come forth without any great difficulty; yet that the maculine penis hould get in, and that the eed hould finde admiion into the inner cavity
of the Uterus, is carce probable: for I could not trace a way inward, with either probe, or britle, nor could Fabricius neither; nay, if you will credit his tetimony, the very aire cannot be blown into the womb: which, I uppoe, was the caue why he, decribing the hitory of the Egge, proceedeth from the interiour to the exteriour parts: And alo conidering this fabricke of the womb, he denyeth pag. 30. the eed to attain o farre as the cavity of the womb, or to contitute any part of the egge: of which opinion I willingly profes my elfe. For you hall finde nothing at all in a fertile egge, either added, or altered, (which is not in an addle one) to give any upicion of the entrance of the Cockes eed into the womb or egge. But yet though all the egges are, without the acceion of the Cock, ubventaneous and addle; yet by his aitance (even for a good while after his treading) the ubequent egges, of which there is yet no principle, or matter out of which they can be made, become fertile. Fabricius, that he may expres after what manner the eed of the Cock maketh the egges fertile, pag. 17. hath thee words: Since no eed at all appeareth in the egge, and yet it is cat by the cock into the womb, it may be demanded, to what purpoe the cocks eed is cat into the womb, if it pas not into the egge? as alo, if the eed be not in the egge, how can the egge be made fertile by that eed which is not in it? My opinion is, that the eed of the cocke injected into the beginning of the womb, doth make the whole womb, and alo all the yolks that come into it, and latly, the whole egge, fertile; and that it doth this by its vertue, or piritual irradiating ubtance; after the ame manner, as we perceive other creatures become fertile, by the teticles, and eed: for if any man conider that incredible tranmutation, which doth eize upon a creature
that is gelded, by which it looeth its heat, vigour, and fecundity in the whole body; he will eaily conent, that what we ay, may well befall the ingle womb of a Hen. But that it is mot true, that the power of rendering all the egges fertile, together with the womb it elf, proceedeth wholly from the eed of the Cocke, appeareth, even from the practice of women, which having a Hen without a Cock, commit her for a day or two to a neighbours Cock: and from this mall commerce, all the eggs are endowed with fertility, for all that year. And this is alo confirmed by Aritotle, who is of opinion, that
de Gen. an. l. 3. c. 1. after birds have once had the advantage of coition, almot all the egges they lay afterward are fertile. Now, let the vertue of making fertile, which is contained in pag. 38. the eed, hould by any means exhale or evaporate, but that it may remaine long in the womb, and o be imparted to the whole; nature hath concluded, and treaured it up as it were in a pure, in the cavity neer the fundament, which is annexed to the womb, to which there is onely an entrance, but no retreat, o that the eed being there long detained, its vertue may be the better preerved, and communicated to the whole womb.

But I did doubt the verity of the foreaid experiment, and that the rather, becaue I perceived the Philoophers words were fally recited; for, hee doth not ay, that, Birds, when they once have had the advantage of coition, almot all the egges they lay are fertile, but, they lay almot all their egges: where the word Fertile is uperadded by Fabricius: for it is one thing, to ay, that Birds are with egge after coition; and another thing, to ay, that thoe egges are made fertile by coition. And this is more manifet by Aritotles precedent words, where he aith, In Birds, not o much as thoe very egges which are begotten by coition, can for the mot part gain their jut
growth, unles that coition be continued. And the reaon is, becaue, that as in women by coition with the male, the mentruous excrement is drawn forth (for the womb being warmed draweth the moyture, and the pores are opened) o it falls out in birds, whilet the mentruous excrement cometh by litle and litle, which cannot get out, becaue it is but litle, and is contained above about the diaphragma, but lideth down into the womb it elf. For with this the egge is nourihed, as the foetus of viviparous creatures is nourihed with that which comes in at the Navel. For after birds have once been at tread, they till perit to have almot all their eggs, but yet mall ones, and imperfect; and therefore barren: for the perfection of an egge, is its fecundity. If therefore without continued coition, not o much as thoe very eggs which are conceived by that coition, do attain their Growth, or (as Fabricius interpreteth it) their Perfection; much les can thoe egges be fertile, which the Birds perit to lay, without coition.

But let no man think that thee words (namely, the womb being warmed draweth, and the pores are opened) do any way conclude, that the womb can draw the eed of the Cocke into its cavity; for we mut take notice, that the Philoopher doth not ay, that the womb draweth the eed from without, but, that in women, the mentruous blood is drawn out of their own bodies, the veines and paages being opened by the heat caued by coition; and o likewie in Birds, that the blood is drawn to the womb, it being warmed by repeated coition, and that the eggs do thence encreae; as the foetus of viviparous creatures do by the Navel. But what he adjoineth concerning that cavity or pure, in which he fancyeth that the eed is entertained, even for a whole year together, is confuted by us formerly; where
we affirm, that no eed at all is contained in it and that both henns and cocks indifferently have that cavity.

Wherefore, though I eaily believe (if by fertility we undertand an encreae of more and fairer eggs) that poor womens henns (whoe poultry probably wanteth good feeding) will lay leer and fewer egges, except they have reort to a cock (according to that of the Philoopher, namely, If they once mixe with a cocke, then they continue to have fairer, better, and more egges, for the whole enuing year; to which end alo, plenty and wholeomnes of feeding do very much conduce) yet that hennes, by ome few acts of coition with a cock hould lay all fertile egges for a whole year together; that, I ay, eemeth to me improbable. For if a few acts of coition were of force to o lating a generation, Nature (which maketh nothing in vain) would have made the male birds les alacio •
then they are: nor would the cocke o often in one day invite his hennes to Venery, nay ometimes force a rape upon them.

Wee all know, how the henne, o oon as he foraketh the net where he hath layed her egge crieth out with a hrill voice, and enticeth the cock to coition; who alo replying with a loud and divided tone, carefully eeketh her out, and having found her, intantly acendeth: which urely Nature had never permitted, but for procreation ake.

A Cock-Pheaant, penned up in an aviary, both with uch corching lut, that unles he have ewrall hennes with him, (ix at the let) he will •• extremely afflict them with repeated Coitions, and rather retard their fertility, then promote it ••• once aw a Pheaant-henne, o pent and worn o ••
by the cocke who was hut up with her (whom he could no wayes ecape, neither by flight, nor concealment) that her back was grown bald by his frequent acents, untill at lat, in mierable torture, •• e expired for grief. Yet, when I cut her up, I ound not the let rudinient of an egge. I have oberved likewie a Gander, who wanting a mate, ojourned with the hennes, where his lut was o unbounded, that for ome hours together he purued a young pullet whitheroever he fled, arreting her with his bill, till at length he triumphed upon her wearines, and ubdued her to a Rape.
A dunghill-cock having gotten the matery in the duel, doth ate his deires not only upon the concubines of his foe, but upon the conquered himelf.

So likewie ome females are o prone to Venery, that they will chatie their males with their biteings; (as if they meant to whiper and advie them of conjugal delights) ometimes getting uppermot themelves, endeavouring by thee and other arts to entice them to their recreation: and in this rank are pigeons, and parrows.
And therefore it eems not o likely, that a few coitions celebrated in the beginning of the yeare, hould tore up fecundity enough, to endow all the egges for a twelve-moneth following.

And yet once (that Fabricius may have ome patronage) in the Spring time (attempting ome dicovery of the time wherein coition is mot uccesfull, and the neceity thereof) I did eparate two hennes from the cocke for foure dayes pace, which in that time laid three egges a piece, which were as prolifical as the ret. And I did after that immure another henne, which on the tenth day of her eparation laid an egge, and another egge on the twentieth, and both were fruitfull: o that it may
eem poible, that one or two acts of conjunction may fructifie the whole cluter, and conequently all the egges of that year.

I hall tell you likewie, what I farther oberved at that time; when I retored the two hennes (which I had formerly divorced) to the cocke again, whereof one of them was now big with egg, the other had newly layed; the cock ran intantly to the latter, and enjoyed her greedily three or four times: about the former, he circuited often, and by trailing his wings at her feet, eemed to greet her kindely, and congratulate her return; yet preently retired to the other, and repeated his lut again, and again, committing violence upon her refual; neglecting in the mean time the henn that was with egge, uing no olicitation nor requet. Truly I admired, by what ignifications he could be inpired to know, that coition could be ueful to the one, and uneaonable to the other. It is not eaie to ay, how males will either by the eye, eare, or mell, ditinguih (even from farre) which females are ripe for their turne, and deirous of their company. Some, though they onely hear their voice, or ent their urine, or foot-teps only on the ground are preently heightned, and purue them to a compliance. But of this elwhere, in our tract o • the Love, Lut, and act of Generation of Animals, w • hall treat at large. Wee returne to our purpoe.

div.head: Of the Belly of a Henne, and other Birds.
EXERCIT. VII.
div.p: FRom the outward Orifice through the privy parts, we arrive at the Uterus or matrix of the Henne, wherein the egge is perfected, encompaed by the white, and covered with the hell; but before we peak any thing of its cituation, and poition, omething mut be premied, concerning the peculiar anatomy of the Belly of Birds. For I have oberved the tomacks, guts, and other entrals of Feathered creatures, to be otherwie eated and contituted in their lower belly, then of other creatures that go upon the ground.

All kindes of Birds, almot, have a twofold tomack, whereof one is the Ingluvies, the other the Ventriculus, properly o called: in the former they treaure up their meat, and prepare it; in the latter, they diget it, and concoct it into the chyle: the firt, we call the crop or craw; the latter, the Giard. Birds reerve in their craw the whole grains which they ingorge, and from thence tranmit them into the giard, moitened, macerated, and oftned by the water which they imbibe, that it may there be grinded, and concocted. And for that purpoe, almot all orts of Fowle wallow down ands, tones, & other harder bodies, & reerve them in their giard with their meat; (when no uch thing is to be een in their craw) and this giard of theirs is compacted of two exceeding thick
• t trong mucles, (which in leer Birds are compoed of fleh or ligaments) that with thee two, as it
were with two Grind-tones, fatned together with two hinges, they may grind and mould their food; whilet the tones upply the place of teeth, of which they are detitute. By this means they diget and chylifie their meat, and afterward by compreion (as we train a juice or a pultis out of herbes or fruits bruied) the ofter and more liquid part lyeth uppermot; and that they conveigh into the beginning of the guts (which in them is jut at the entrance into the gullet, eated above the giard. Now that this is o, appears in everal orts of Birds, in whoe giard, if gravel, or any other harder and rugged bodies continue any time, they receive o much impaire and moothnes from the continual attrition, that at lat they grow ueles, and o are ejected. And for this caue Birds exercie their tongues in the choice of their pibbles, and if they dicover that they are no •
rough, they preently refue them. By this mean • I have found Iron, Silver, and Stones, almot worn away and conumed in the giard of an Otrich, and the Caoware; which gives occaion to the popular perwaion, that they diget Iron, and are nourihed by it.

In Falcons, Eagles, and other Birds of Prey, if you bring your ear near, when their giard is empty you hall evidently dicover the noie of tones collected in it, grating one againt another. For Hawkes doe not wallow pibbles to coole and all •
their heat, (as the common ort of Falconers dream) but to grinde their meat: as alo other Birds (whoe giard is made flehy on purpoe t • mould their meat) for the ame intent, do ingor ••
pibbles, or and, or uch like bodies.

The giard of Birds therefore, is eated within the capacity of the Abdomen, beneath the Heart,
Lungs, and Liver; but the crop ticketh (for the mot part) as it were out of the body, in the lower part of the necke, at the Os Jugale: in which (as I have aid) their meat is onely mollified, and prepared: and from it ome Birds return their meat macerated to their chickens, and nure them up (at the ame rate as four-footed beats doe theirs with milke) as you may oberve in all orts of Pigeons, and alo in the Spermologi, which we call Rooks. And Bees alo, when they are returned to their Hives, do refund the hony which they gather from the flowers, and have digeted in their tomack, into their proper celles: and o do Hornets and Waps nourih their off-pring. And a Bitch hath been een to digorge the meat which he had wallowed before, and half concocted, to upply her whelps. Wherefore, the wonder is les, when we ee poore beggar-women, when their milk faileth them, to feed their Infants with craps, which their owne teeth have firt prepared, and reduced into a kinde of pap.

The Guts in Birds arie (as is aid) from the upper part of the Giard, and are replicated up and down in Longitude (not tranverly, as in us.) And next to them, jut under the heart, about the middle of the body, where the diaphragma (which is wanting in Birds) is eated in Beats, is their Liver, which is very large, and divided into two lobes, (for they have no pleen neither) placed on either ide, and fills the hypochondria: below the Liver is the giard put, under which lye the replications of the intetines, having very many lender membranes interpoed, which are filled with air: for into thee (as we have aid) the rough arteries of the lungs decend with open mouth. The kidnies (which are large in Birds) being of an oblong figure,
compoed as it were of gobbets of fleh, having no cavities at all, doe lye on both ides of the Spine, and great decending vein and Arterie, and are buried in the pacious oblong cavity of the huckle bones or ides-men. From the fore-part of the kidnies are the Ureters extended in Longitude, even to the common inke, and fundament it elf: that o the erous excrement may from the Reines be wafted thither. Now Birds have very litle of this erum, becaue they are mall drinkers, and ome of them (as the Eagle for one) drink not all. Nor doth their urine flow apart by its elf; but, as we have aid, doth ditill from the Ureters into the common receptacle, which is allowed alo to entertain the excrement of the guts, whoe dicharge is by this means the better provided for. The urine of Birds differeth from that of other creatures; for the parts of their urine are two-fold, one more erous, and liquid, the other more gros and thicke, which in men in health we call the hypotais, and when the urine is now cold, it inketh down to the bottom: now Birds (clean contrary to other viviparous Animals) have greater tore of this thick ediment; which is ditinguihed from the other part of the urine, by its white or ilver-like complexion, and it is not only dicernable in the cloaca or inke, (where it much aboundeth) and giveth a tincture to the excrements of the guts: but in the whole conduct of the Ureters, which are ditinguihed from the coats of the kidnies, by this very white excrement. Nor is the thicker ubtance which decendeth from the Reines, only viible in Birds, but in Serpents alo, and other oviparous creatures; epecially thoe whoe egge is guarded by a harder kinde of hell. And they have much more abundance of this, then of the thinner
erous part: and it hath a middle conitence between a thicker kinde of urine, and the excrement of the guts; o that as it paeth through the Ureters, it reembleth milk coagulated, or omething thickned, and preently upon ejection it congealeth into a crut that is friable.

div.head: Of the cituation and fabrick of the ret of the parts of the Womb in a Hen.
EXERCIT. VIII.
div.p:
BEtween the Giard, and the Liver, at the Spine of the backe, where in men and other animals the Pancreas lyeth, between the vena Porta, and decending trunck of vena Cava, at the beginning of the Emulgent veines, and the preparing permatical veells, where the Coeliacal artery goeth into the Meentery, there alo in a Henne and other Birds, is the Ovary, and cluter of yolkes bred, which hath Before it the Trunk of the Vena Porta, the gullet, and the mouth of the Giard; and Behinde it, the Hollow vein, and the Great Artery decending by the Spine of the backe; Above it lyeth the Liver, Under it the Giard. And therefore the Infundibulum, which is contituted of a very thin membrane, decendeth down-ward from the Ovary, all along the back, between it and the Giard. And from the Infundibulum or Tunnel (between the Giard, Guts, Reines, and Loynes) the Proces of the Uterus, or its uperiour part, having many revolutions
and cells (like the Colon & right-gut in a man) decendeth into the Womb it elf. But the Womb it elfe, which is continuous to this Proces, is eated below the Giard at the Fundament, at the lower end of the Abdomen, between the loynes, kidnies, and right-gut: o that when the egge now cloathed with the White is contained in it, it preeth down o low, that you may eaily perceive by your finger, whether it be oft, or hard, and ready to be layed.

This Womb, in a Hen, is of different magnitude and fabrick: For in a Henne which is big with egge, or hath lately layed, it differeth very much from the womb of a Virgin-henne, or Pullet; for her womb is flehy and round, lik an empty pure; mooth without, within rough, having certain folds and revolutions according to its longitude: at firt ight, you would conceive it to be a larger kinde of bladder of Urine, or a econd leer giard. But in a teeming Hen, and one ripe for the cocke (which our houewives ditinguih by the rednes of their cret, or comb) the Uterus is of much better growth, and more carnous, having larger folds, and thicker, and of that extent, that it may conveniently receive an egge. And this womb is extended and paeth upward a good way, along the Spine of the back, and is made up of many complications and cells; (as the Collick-gut is) which everal cells are compoed of the replications of the womb it elfe. The Bottom hereof, as it is the larget, o it is the thicket, and mot carnous part of all, fortified with more and greater foldings then the ret, whoe figure within is Ovale, as if it were the Mould to cat egges in. I call the Acending part, or production of the Womb, a Proces: Fabricius calleth it, the econd Uterus, and aith it conits of three rundells
or turnings: Ulyes Aldrovandus calleth it the tomack of the womb: there are, I confes, mot commonly three pires or rundels, yet this is not o contant, but that nature fahions it otherwie, for varietie, (as he doth ometimes in the circumgirations of the Colon.

This womb, the higher it goeth, the lenderer and parer it groweth by degrees, and hath fewer and leer circumvolutions, till at length as it were diolving into very thin membranes, it becomes to be the Infundibulum, which ariing up as farre as the diaphragme, encompaeth all the Ovary.

And therefore Fabricius divideth his econd womb into three parts; viz. the beginning, the middle, and pag. 17. the end. The beginning, aith he, degenerating into a tender and mot oft membrane, frameth a wide orifice, repreenting as it were a litle pipe or tunnel. The middle part (which I call the Proces of the Uterus) is contituted of three tranvere pires or Rundels, and erveth to furnih the yolk of the egge with a white, and extendeth it elf to the lowet and mot capacious place or part of all; which he calls the End of that Uterus, wherein (aith he) the Chalazae, or pecks, and the two membranes and hell are formed.

The whole ubtance of the Uterus (epecially about the folds) as well in the Uterus it elfe, as in its Proces, is embroydered with many large veines, and yet there are more divarications of Arteries then of Veines.

The Folds which in the inide of the womb are oblique and tranvere, are of a flehy ubtance, and look exceeding white and milkey, breathing forth a kinde of tiffe moyture; o that the inward uperficies both of the Uterus, and alo of its Proces, is lined as it were with very much, and thinne whites of egges; by which meanes the decending yolk
gaines greater bulk, and cloatheth it elf in white by degrees, till it arrive at full perfection.

You hall eldom finde the Uterus unfurnihed of eggs, but that there are ome till either ticking in the revolutions of the Proces of the womb, or ele conteined in the Uterus or womb it elfe. If you blow up this Proces when it is empty, it will appear like a litle oblique ditorted pipe, riing up harp at the end in manner of a nailes hell, or a Top. And the Fabrick of the womb is like that which wee lately oberved in the privy parts; namely, that though there be open way enough to receive the egge in its decent, yet there is carce any return to be obtained upwards again, (even for the air it elf, though backed by inflation.)

The Proces of the Uterus, together with the pires, is o diminihed in a Hen pat laying (as we have aid) and alo in young pullets, that it reolveth into mot thin membranes, and is quite abolihed, and leaveth no appearance of it, as neither of the Ovary, or Infundibulum; only there remains (like the root of the cluter) a glandulous and pongy ubtance, which tateth pretty weet in a boyled Hen; as in Viviparous creatures (epecially if they be young and tender) the Pancreas, and Thymus doe; which therefore the people call the Sweet-Breads.

The Womb, together with its Proces, is by the helpe of a membrane fatned to the back: which membrane Fabricius doth therefore call Meometrium; becaue, the econd womb, together with this membranous body, wherein many veines are divaricated, may fitly be compared to the Intetines, and their Meentery. For as the Meentery keepeth firm the Guts, o doth that Meometrium faten this long Proces from the chine, let being dilocated, and involved,
it hould diturb and obtruct the paage of the yolks, whereas now being free and open, it entertaineth them gently. Through this Meometrium, many veels tored with blood, are branched into every replication of the womb. And therefore it beareth much analogy to the Meentery, both in its beginning, ubtance, fabrick, ue, and office. There is alo a Ligament (like a fillet) extended long-wayes from the bottom of the womb to the Infundibulum, uch a one as we may ee produced in the upper region of the Colon; which is as it were a portion or fragment of the outward coat, going along and contracted, that the ret of the Proces might by its help be wrinckled into folds and replications. Thus, if you cut off a gut, and put in a thred into it all along the whole length of one ide of it, and then tye it hard, the other oppoite ide will curle up into wrinckled complications and windings.

This then is the Contitution of the womb of a Henne that layeth egges; namely, flehy, large, ductile and extenive into length and breadth, full of windings, pires, and convolutions all along the pine of the back from the fundament, upwards, and continuous to the Infundibulum.

div.head: Of the generation of the Egge.
EXERCIT. IX.
div.p: THe yolk, in the cluter, is onely a litle wheale or puh, and growing by degrees, attaineth the complexion and bulk of a yolk; and falling off from the cluter, it decendeth through the Infundibulum; and rowling through the Spires and cavernes of the Proces of the womb, doth cloath it elfe all over with the White: though (as Fabricius rightly oberved againt Aritotle) it doth adhere to the womb no where at all, nor is it nourihed by any Umbilical veels: but as the egges of frogs or fihes, provide themelves whites out of the waters wherein they lie; or as beanes, peae, and other pule and graine, being moitened, do well, and thence acquire aliment to the blooms which pring from them: So in like manner out of the aforeaid foulds of the womb, an albugineous humidity iuing thence (as it were out of a dugge, or Uterine cake) the Yolk (by vertue of a vegitative heat, and faculty wherewith it is endowed) findeth out, and concocteth its white. And therefore in thoe foulds, and in the cavity of the Uterus, a liquor, in tat much like the white of an egge, doth mot plenteouly abound. And in this ort the yolk decending by little and little, is inveted with a white, until at lat, auming membranes, and a harder hell in the extremity of the womb, he is compleated for his Exit.

div.head: Of the Growth and departure of the Egge from the Womb.
EXER. X.
div.p: ATtend Fabricius: as we pronounce (aith he) the action of the Stomack to be Chylification: and pag. 8. the action of the Teticles to be the Generation of Seed; becaue we find chyle in the Stomack, and Seed in the Teticles: So we confidently affirm the Action of the Birds womb, to be the Generation of egges, becaue there we finde the eggs. But this is not the only Function of the womb, but the Augmentation of the egge alo, which ucceedeth immediately after the Generation, till the egge be perfected, and purchae a jut enlargement, is implyed. For the Henne doth not naturally lay her egge, before it be compleat, and have attained a convenient magnitude. The Action therefore of the Uterus is both the Generation, and Augmentation of the egge: Now Augmentation uppoeth Nutrition, and includeth it. But ince all Generation proceedeth from two Principles; namely, the Efficient, and the Subject Matter: The Efficient in the procreation of egges is nothing ele, but the Intruments, or propoed organs, namely, the twofold Uterus: and the Subject Matter, is nothing but Blood.

But we, for Brevity ake (omitting, as is meet, all controverie) as we do eaily allow, that the ue and office of the womb, is to procreate egges: o we pronounce the Adaequate Efficient (as they call it) to be contained in the egge it elfe: and wee do conceive that both the Generation, and Augmentation of the Egge, proceedeth not from the
womb, but from an innate natural principle of its own: And that this Principle doth flow firt from the whole Henne, into the Yolk while it yet is only a rudiment, or firt wheale as it were; which afterwards like a congenial heat, or Efficient Nature) inherent in the Yolk, nouriheth and Augmenteth it: As there is a certain in-bred faculty in every part of the Body, by which it is fed and augmented. As concerning the manner how the Yolk is inveted with the White, Aritotle eems to de Gen. an. l. 3. c. 2. have conceited it to be thus: That there is in eggs, while their membranes are yet tender, a kind of Umbilicall channel, exitent in the harper end of the eg (at which he determineth the eg to begin) by which it increaeth: which perwaion Fabricius reprehendeth, denying any being at all to any uch channel; Or that the Yolk doth any where adhere to the womb: and alveth that cruple concerning that mall appendix found in the egge after it is layed, aying; The augmentation of the egge is two-fold, pag. 11. according to the two-fold womb, that is the uperin, and inferior: and alo, according to the two-fold ubtance, whereof the egge is compounded, that is, the Yolk and the White; the Yolk is increaed by a true Augmentation; namely, by blood; which is conveyed to it by the Veins, whilet it is yet adjoyned to the Vitellary. But the White is increaed, and groweth to the yolk, after another fahion: For it receiveth not nourihment by the Veins, nor by a true kind of Nutrition, as the Yolk doth but by Juxtapoition, adhering to the Yolk, while it paeth through the Second Uterus.

But in my Opinion, the Egge is augmented after the ame manner (whereoever it be) as the yolk is augmented in the cluter, viz. from an Intrinecal concocting principle, with this ditinction
onely, that while it is in the cluter, its aliment is conveighed to it by the veels, but in the womb it findeth it ready for it to imbibe. For in all Nutrition and Accretion, a Juxtapoition of the parts is equally neceary, and alo a Concoction and Ditribution of the applied nutriment; nor can the one be thought to be lee a True Nutrition then the other: for both of them are made by a new acceion, appoition, agglutination, and tranmutation of the Aliment. Nor can Beanes or Peae, which attract moiture from the Earth (which they uck in like punges) be aid to be lee truly nourihed, then if they did draw in that moiture through the Orifice of Veins: And Trees alo drinking Dewes and Showres in at their Barks, are as truly nourihed, as they are by their Roots. But concerning the manner of this Nutrition, we have poken more largely in another place. At preent, it remaines that we encounter another difficulty; that is, whether the Yolke, while it acquireth a White, doth not make ome eparation, and choice in it: and o, while it is about augmenting, whether ome more earthy part be not dimied into the Yolk or middle of the egge, (as into the Center, as Aritotle would have it) and the lighter, and thinner parts be not reerved in its uperficies or urface: For between the Yolk which is yet in the cluter, and that which is in the midt of the eg when it is perfected, this is the difference in chief, that though the former be yellowih in colour and appearance, yet its conitence repreenteth rather the VVhite; and being odden, thickneth like it, groweth compact, and vicous, and may be cut into lices. But the Yolk that is in the midt of a perfect egge, being boiled,
groweth friable, and of a more earthy conitence, not thick and glutinous like the White.

div.head: Of the Egg-hell.
EXERCITATION XI.
div.p:
IT is convenient, that having declared how the Egge is generated, wee hould now treat of its parts, and their differences. An Egge is compounded pag. 22. (aith Fabricius) of a Yolke, a White, two Chalazae, or pecks, three membranes (namely one membrane proper to the yolk alone, and two other, common to the whole egge) and lat of all, of a Shell. To all which, two things are to be added, which may not be truly ranged amongt the parts of the egge; one whereof is a certain mall cavity in the blunter end of the egge neer the top of the Shell; the other is a certain litle white print, like a mall round Cicatrice, affixed to the uperficies of the yolk. The accompt of every of which we hall lay down more punctually, beginning from the outward parts. The outward Covering (which is by Pliny called the Barke, Rind, or Paring; and by ( <> Serenus, the Egg-hell) is a hard, lender, friable, and porous tegument, having divers colours, namely, white, pallid, red, potted, and prinkled with everal p ••
ctures: to wit, the Hens, and Pigeons egg-hells <> white; the Water-fowles, pale; the Hawkes, or Ketrells, red as Vermilion; the Pheaants, potted, and ditinguihed with points, as Aritotle noteth. All eggs have not a hell; for Serpents eggs have none; and
de Hit. an. l. 6. c. 2. ome hens (though rarely) lay eggs without a hell
This hell, though it be hard, is not equally hard in all parts, but is more hard about the top, and uperiour part of the egge. And therefore Fabricius aith, It is a quetion, when the egg-hell is formed, and out of pag. 13. what ubject-matter. For Aritotle and Pliny affirm, that the hell is not made within, but when the egge is
Hit. an. l. 6. c. 2. & gen. an. 1. 8. l. 10. c. 52. de gen. an. l. 3. c. 2. laid, & as it is going out; o that the outward heat drying up the moyture, the Air condeneth & hardneth it. And this is done, as Aritotle uppoeth, both that it may have the eaer paage, and alo that it may not pain the parent: As they ay that an egge oftned in vineger, may be crowded into a veel of a narrow neck.

Fabricius indeed was long at odds with this opinion, by reaon he had found an egge with a hard hell in the belly of the Hen; an experiment which is dayly proved by houe-wives, whilet endeavouring to know whether the Hen be ready to lay, they grope the belly without, to try whether the hell be hard. But afterwards, when he had received from creditable women, that the egg-hell aumed its obduration from the • ire in its exit, which aire doth exiccate a tiffe moyture which environeth the egge, and condeneth and fatneth it to the hell, before the hell of it elf be exactly hard: and having alo dicovered the ame by his own experience, he altered his opinion, and was perwaded, that the egge in the Uterus hath truly a hell, which hell is of a middle conitence, between oft and hard, but that it obtaineth a much greater degree of obduration preently after it is layed, by reaon of a certain clammy tenacious humidity which concealeth about the hell, occaioned by the evaporation • f the thin and moit parts; with which humidity the whole uperficies is bedewed, which adhering to the tender hell, is dryed and hardned, the cold ambient aire • mducing omething thereunto. And this (aith he)
you may oon perceive, if you keep Hennes in your yard, and be dexterous and diligent to receive the eggs from them, as they lay.

This opinion of Aritotle did for a long time prevaile with me, till I dicovered the contrary by infallible experience. For I take it as a meaured truth, that the Egee-hell is mot commonly hard even in the womb itelf. And I once aw an egge cut out of a live Henne, which had no hell at all, but yet was througly drenched and begin with a glewey moiture: and yet the egge never hardned at all, by the congelation, or evaporation of the moiture about the Skin, (as Fabricius would have it) nor was it any whit altered by the ambient cold aire, but continued the tendernee which it had in the womb. I have alo een a Newlaied egge, which had a compleat hard hell, over which was a cae made of a cuticular oft membrane, which membrane did never congeal. Moreover I have een an egge exactly urrounded with a Shell, ave only on the very top of the acute end of the egg, where remained a mal oft riing, uch a one as Aritotle perhaps conceived to be the Reliques of the Navel.

And therefore Fabricius eemeth to me to be in an errour; for though I was never o good at light of Hand, to urprie an egge in the very laying, and o make dicovery whether it was oft or hard; yet this I confidently pronounce, that the Shell is compounded within the womb, of a ubtance there at hand for the purpoe: and that it is framed in the ame manner as the other parts of the egge are, by the Platick faculty: and the rather, becaue I have een an exceeding mall egge, (Fabricius calleth it Ovum Centeninum, and our Women call it the Cocks egge) which had
Shell of its own, and yet was contained within another egge, greater, and fairer then it, which egge alo had a Shell too. And this Egge I hewed King Charles my mot gracious Mater, in preence of many others. And that very year, cutting up a large Limon, I found another mall, but yet a perfect Limon in it, which had alo a yellow rind: Which thing is now frequent in Italy, as I am informed.

It is the uual errour of the Philoophers of thee times, to eek the diverity of the caues of Parts, out of the diverity of the matter, from whence they hould be framed. So Phyitians affirm, that the different parts of the body are fahioned and nourihed by the different materials of Blood, or Seed; namely the ofter parts, as the Fleh, out of a thinner matter; and the more earthy parts, as the Bones, &c. out of groe, and harder. But this errour now too much received, we have confuted in another Place. Nor are they lee deceived, who make all things out of Atomes, as Democritus; or out of the Elements, as Empedocles. As if (forooth) Generation were nothing in the world, but a meer Separation, or Collection, or Order of things. I do not indeed deny, but that to the Production of one thing out of another, thee fore-mentioned things are requiite: But Generation her elf is a thing quite ditinct from them all. (I finde Aritotle in this opinion) and I my elf intend to clear it anon; that out of the ame White of the Egge (which all men confes to be a imilar body, and without diverity of Parts) all and every the parts of a Chicken, whether they be Bones, Clawes, Feathers, Fleh, or what ever ele, are procreated and fed. Beides, they that argue thus, aigning onely a Material caue, deducing the caues of
Natural things, from a voluntary or caual concurrence of the Elements, or from the everal dipoition or contriving of Atomes: they doe not reach that which is chiefly concerned in the Operations of Nature, and in the Generation, and Nutrition of Animals: namely, the Divine Agent, and God of Nature, whoe operations are guided with the highet artifice, providence, and widome, and doe all tend to ome certain end, and are all produced, for ome certain Good.) But thee men derogate from the honour of the Divine Architect, who hath made the Shell of the Egge with as much skill, for the egges defence, as any other particle; dipoing the whole out of the ame matter, and by one and the ame formative faculty.

Now though what I have delivered is very true, (namely, that the egge whilet it is yet in the womb, is guarded with a hard Shell) yet I have till prized Aritotles judgement o highly, that I never would recede from his Oracles without premeditation, and therefore I do conceave (which thing alo my own obervations do confirm) that ome acceion to the induration of the egge-hell, doth accrew from the ambient air in its very exit: and that, that tiff and limy moiture, (wherein it is drenched at its being laied) doth preently after its excluion harden. For the Shell, while it is yet in the womb, is much thinner, more tranparent, and of a moother uperficies: But after laying, it is much thicker, lee tranlucid, and of a rough Superficies (as if it were rough cat with a white powder, which had newly dried to inides.)
And now we are upon this ubject, give me leave to expatiate a while.

In the Eatern barren Ilands of Scotland, there is uch a mighty affluence of all-mot all orts of of Sea-fowle, that if I hould relate all that I have heard, though from perons of great integrity, I fear I hould be upected more Fabulous then thoe everal Authors, who dicoure of the Scotih or Soland-Geee, which they tory to be born from the fruit of certain Trees falling into the Sea (which fruit or Geee, themelves never aw) However I hall venture to relate what my owne Eyes have een.

There is a little Iland, the Scots call it Base, (by this, Reader, gues at the ret of them) it is not far from the hore, eated in the Main Sea; tanding upon a rugged and dangerous Clift, (you may call it rather one great continued Stone, or Rock, then an Iland) it is not above a mile about. The uperficies of this Iland (in the moneths of May and June) is almot covered quite over with Nets, Egges, and Young-Ones, that for their infinit abundance, you can carce et your foot in a pare place, and uch a mighty flock hovereth over the Iland, that (like thick clouds) they darken and obcure the day: and uch a cry, and noie they make, that you can hardly hear thoe that tand next you. If you look down into the Sea beneath you (as from a teep Tower, or Precipice) you hall ee it all pread over with everal ort of fowle, wimming to and fro, in puruit of their Prey. Jut at the rate, as ome ditches and lakes in the Spring time, are paved with Frogs; and open Hills, and teep mountains, are tuck and emboed with flocks of heep, and Goats. If you aile round the Iland, and look up into the everal Clifts, and Cavernes of it, you hall finde them all peopled and inhabited with everal colonies
of Birds and Fowle, of ditinct Kinde, and magnitude: more indeed, then in a clear night, when the Moon is abent, there are Starres to be dicerned in the Firmament: and if you oberve the everal Regiments of thoe that aily out, and thoe that flocks home wards at the ame time, you would take them for an infinite warm of Bees. It is not to be imagined what a vat yearly revenue the Lord of the Iland maketh of the Plumes, and the Remainders of the Nets (which are ueful for firing) together with the Egges which hee eetheth, and then trafficketh away: that which he himelf told me, was indeed incredible. But this one thing which reflects neerer upon our dicoure, eemeth to me remarkable in chief, and doth give a cleer tetimony of the exceive multitude: which is, that this Iland as you approach it, hineth with a white glaing, and the clifts reemble mountaines of the puret Chalke, though the native complexion of the Stone be obcure and black. That which thus dicoloureth the Iland, is a white crut, which is friable, and of the very ame Conitence, Complexion, and Nature with the Egge-hell; o that all parts of the Iland are plaitered over with this hard tegument, and crumbling or friable crut or hale. The bottome of the Iland which the Tyde waheth every day, retaining till its natural colour, clearly heweth that that fucus, or ophiticated whitenes, proceeds from the liquid Excrements of the Birds (which they dicharge when they diburden their Belies) and by which, as it were with an Egge-hell, white, hard and friable, the Walls are cruted and diguied: And after the ame manner, doe Aritotle and Pliny conent, that the Egge-hell is formed. None of thee Birds are Citizens of the place, but
Forreigners all, and reort thither for convenient Laying, and there they continue ome weeks as in their Inne; till they and their Young-ones be all in condition to fly away together. But that white Ruff-cat is o olid, firme, and thick, that you would think it were the genuine and natural ubtance of the oile.

This liquid, white, and bright Excrement, doth glide with the Urine from the kidnies of the Birds through the Ureters, into the common cavity or Jakes, and there covering over the excrements of the guts, paeth forth together with them, and it is a thicker part of their Urine, then that which we call the Sediment or Hypotais in ours. We have poken omething of this matter before, and wee have demontrated it fuller elewhere.

Store of this white excrement is there chiefly to be een, where the Hawkes defile the walls that do neighbour their pertches with their ejections, which they be-dawb with a glewy white, and ditinguih as it were with a Cerue.

I have found as much of this limey cement in the repoitory of a dead Otrich, as would fill ones hand: o alo in a Land-Tortoie, and everal other Four-footed creatures, that are Oviparous, this white plaitering-tuff doth abound; and being diloaded, the thinner parts evaporating, it doth oon congeale either into a friable cruly ubtance, or into a dut or powder, reembling the egg-hell, pounded in a Morter.

Amongt the o many everal kindes of Birds (which make their conflux to the aforeaid Iland for Procreation ake) and o many everal tructures of their nets, wherein they hatch their young, there was one Bird hewed me above all the ret, which layeth one onely egge, fixing it upon the
teep point of a harp tone, (having neither net, not any other materials to upport it) and that o ecure, and firmly, that the mother-bird can leave it there, and return again to it at pleaure, without any prejudice to the egge at all. But if this egge be once removed from its tation, no art nor cunning in the world can faten it again, but it intantly falleth into the ea, as from a precipite, without redemption. The reaon is, becaue the place where it is mounted, is incrutated all over with the white cement; and the egge being newly layed, wreaketh with a tiff and vicous humidity, which preently congealing, it is agglutinated to the ubjacent tone, as it were with a kinde of oulder.

An example of o nimble a concretion as this, we may ee at the Statuaries, who out of calcined Alabater, or certain morter tempered with water, doe make a liquid cement; which being artificially applied, will take off the figure of the countenance of a dead man, or the hape and reemblance of any thing whatoever, be it never o litle; and o that growing hard, remaineth for a Mould.

As therefore in almot all liquors there is ome earthy conitence, (as in Wine, there is the Tariar; in Water, mudde or and; in Lie, alt; which when the greater part of the moiture is exhaled, doth ubide, and congeal at the bottom) o is there a white ediment, decending with the urine from the Birds kidnies into the common Jakes, with which I did conceive the egge was there incrutated, and plaitered over; as the pavements are by Hawks, and the clifts of the fore-aid Iland by the numerous conflux of Birds and Fowle: And thus Chamber-pots, and places where people urine much, ue to be over-cat with a yellow crut, from the
concrecence of that ubtance, which createth tones in the kidnies and bladder, and other parts of the Body. I did, I ay, conceive (epecially being induced thereto by the authority of Aritotle and Pliny) that out of this white hypotais, which doth much abound in all Oviparous creatures, (whoe eggs are encompaed by a hard hell) the fabrick of the Henns egg-hell was erected, and congealed (upon excluion) by the cold ambient aire. And this opinion is o rooted in me by many other experiments, that I can hardly forbear to believe, that ome part of the hell at let, is produced from thence.

But (as Fabricius rightly advieth) let reaon be ilent, where experience warranteth the contrary; for it is too much the crime of the age we live in, to obtrude opinions built upon conjecture, and lender reaoning, as infallible truths (without any tetimony at all from ene.)

For I am certainly aured from Experiment, that the egge (at let here in England) is adorned with its hell, while it hath its abode in the Womb, though Aritotle and Pliny affirm the contrary, and Fabricius alo is not very obtinate in the negative. Perchance indeed in hotter countries, where the hennes are of a tronger contitution, the egges are commonly layed oft, and without hells, but that is very rare amongt us. So when I was at Venice, Aromatarius, a famous Phyitian, hewed mee a mall leaf formed between the two hales of a Peae cod, though with us in the like cae there is onely a mall knob of the future pule to be een. So much doth the indulgent temper and clemency of the Heavens, Soil, and Aire, conduce to the fecundity, and happy increae of things.

div.head: Of the ret of the parts of the Egge.
EXERCIT. XII.
div.p: WHere, how, and when the ret of the parts of the egge are generated, we have partly declared already in the hitory of the Womb; and hall partly mention hereafter, when we come to treat of their Ue.

The White (aith Fabricius) is by Pliny called pag. 22. The White. Ovi albus liquor; by Celus, Ovi candidum; by Paladius, Ovi Albor; by Apicius, Ovi album, and albamentum; in Greek, < in non-Latin alphabet > ; by Aritotle,
< in non-Latin alphabet > ; by Anaxagoras,
< in non-Latin alphabet > , Lac avium, the Milk of the Bird. And it is the cold, tiffe, white liquor of the egge, of different thicknes, (for at the obtue and acute end of the egge it is more fluid, but more cras in other parts) and quantity (for it is in more abundance at the blunt end of the egge, and les at the harp, and yet till les in the other parts) embracing the yolke round about.

But I have ever oberved in a Hennes egge, not onely a difference in the ame White, but two ditinct Whites in the ame egge, and both of them involved in a peculiar membrane of their own: One of which is more thin and fluid, and almot of the ame conitence with that humor which we have aid to flow in the folds of the Uterus, and to contitute and nourih the White. The other White is more thick and vicous, & dyed of a deeper whitecolour then the other; which in tale, and uch eggs as the Hen itteth on, after ome dayes of her Incubation, waxeth yellowih; and as this thicker White doth immediatly urround the yolk, o doth the liquid
White encompas this. Now, that thee two whites are really ditinct, will oon appear, if after you have broken and removed the hell, you •• ick the two membranes which come next to • ind; for then preently this liquid and exteriour White will runne about, and the two membranes inke to the bottom of the baon: but the groer White will all the while keep within its own bounds, and globous figure, as being terminated with its owne proper membrane, which yet is o ubtile and lender, that your eye cannot perceive it; but if you cut it cros the White, it will preently tream out, and loe its round figure: as when a bladder is divided, the moiture contained therein is et at liberty; and o alo if you make a breach upon the proper containing-coat of the yolke, the affron-coloured juice will iue out, and its former globoity be detroyed.

The Yolke (aith Fabricius) is called in Latine Vitellus, from Vita, Life; becaue the chicken liveth The Yolk. pag. 23. upon it: It is alo called from its colour Ovi Luteum, the yellow of the Egge; in Greeke,
< in non-Latin alphabet > ; by Hippocrates, < in non-Latin alphabet > ; by Aritotle, < in non-Latin alphabet > , and
< in non-Latin alphabet > ;
•• e Antients (as Suidas out of Menander) < in non-Latin alphabet >
that is, the pullus, or chicken; becaue they conceived the chicken was bred of that part. It is the oftet juice that is in all the egge, and confined within a mot thin membrane, which being broken, it preently glideth forth, and is then incontant to any figure: it is treaured up in the middle of the egge, being ometimes yellow, and ometimes of a mixed complexion, betwixt yellow and pallid; it is exactly circular, and of divers magnitude, according to the diverity of the magnitude of the Fowles themelves; for Water-fowle have a larger yolke, and Land-fowle a larger White, aith Aritotle. According to whom alo, The yolk
Hit. an. l. 6. c. 2.
and White are of a contrary nature, not in colour only but power; for the yolk is condened by cold, which cold doth not condene the white, but diolve it. And o on the contrary, the white is condened by fire, but the yolk is not condened thereby, but remaineth oft unles the egge be over-roted; being more dryed and hardned by being boyled then roted. And as in the greater world, the earth is depoited in the Center the Air and the Water being round about it, o alo the yolk, as the more earthy part, is incircled by the two whites, whereof the one is groer, the other finer. Nay (Aritotle addeth further) if any man beat many egges together in a baon, and boyle
Hit. an. l. 6. c. 2. de gen. an. l. 3. c. 1. them with a oft and gentle fire, the yolks will in their entire mas gather themelves orbicularly into the midt, and the whites urround them. Yet Phyitians generally do decree the White to be the colder part. But of that more hereafter.

The Chalazae, that is, the Hail-tones, or litle pearls or pecks, like Haile (which the Italians call The Chalazae.
Galladura, and wee the Treddle) are two in every egge; one eated in the obtue, the other in the Acute Angle of the egge. The major part of both which is found in the white, but yet they adhere cloer to the yolke, and are annexed to its membrane. They are omething oblong bodies, more congealed, and whiter then the white it elf, knotly, and in ome ort tranparent, as Hail is, from whence they borrow their compellation: for every Chalaza containeth everal hail-tones as it were, glewed to one another by the white. One of thee Chalazae is larger then his fellow, and more ditant from the yolke, towards the blunt end of the egge; the other maller, and tendeth from the yolke to the harp end of the egge. The larger of thee two is made up of three knotty ubtances, like haile-tones, or
eed-pearles, which are placed a mall pace one from the other, the leer lying behinde the greater.

In all eggs of all Birds whatoever, whether they be fertile, or addle, thee chalazae are to be found, and that in each end, one; whence the fond perwaion of old Wives, that the chalazae are the Cocks eed, and the ubject matter out of which the chicken is procreated, lyeth wate, and overturned. And yet Fabricius himelf, though he abolutely deny that they are made of the eed of the Cock, yet he laboureth with many arguments, to prove, pag. 48. that they are that immediate matter, which the Cock endoweth with fecundity, and out of which the fabrick of the chicken is erected: which he endeavoureth to evince by this fraile ground, that (forooth) in an pag. 57. egge when its boyled, the chalazae are in uch ort contracted and hrunk up, as that they repreent a conception, or chicken haped, and hatched. But how improbable a thing is it, that every egge hould have two eeds or rudiments, for the contitution of one only chicken, when no man living ever yet beheld any foundation or progres of a chicken, but only in the blunt angle of the egge? And moreover, there is no enible difference at all between the chalazae of thoe eggs which coition hath made fruitful, and thoe which are altogether barren. But this worthy man was mitaken in the intent of the chalazae, which hall appear more clearly hereafter.

In the eggs of the leat Birds of all, you may track thee chalazae, which appear there like a fine thred, or lender nerve. But in the two ends of the egs of the Otrich and Caoware, I have een exceeding thick, long, and white chalazae, coniting of many little globous bodies, of different dimenion.

In the blunter end of the egge, neer the hell in The Cavity. the inide, you may dicover a litle mall cavity, or hollownes; which is ometimes exactly at the top of all, and ometimes inclining to one ide, almot directly oppoite to the Chalaza which is at the other end: the figure of it is mot commonly circular, but in a gooe or duck-egge it is not o preciely round. This cavity you may plainly ee, appearing like a cloudy pot, if at night you hold an egge againt a candle in one hand, and lay the other hand tranverly upon the obtue angle of the egge.
In a new-layed egge it is but litle, eeming in magnitude of the bignes of the ball of a mans eye; but it increaeth dayly, according as the egge groweth taler, and the weather hotter.

After one dayes incubation, it preadeth mainly, as if ome thinner part of the white, which lyeth uppermot, were exhaled, and the ret contracted, and o the pace grown wider. For this cavity reideth between the hell, (which in that place hath no membrane to line it) and that outward membrane which containeth all the liquidities of the egg. All eggs whatever have it, nay, I have found it in the eggs which remain as yet in the Uterus of the Henne, o oon as ever they aume a hell. Some that pretend to cunning in this matter, will prognoticate, that if this cavity be directly in the top of the egge, the chicken then will be a cocke, but if it deflect to the ide, it will be a henne. But this is mot certain, if the cavity be very mall, it ignifieth the egge is new-layed, but if it be any thing large, a tale one. But more largely of this hereafter.

There is a very mall white circle embracing the The Cicatrice.
coat of the yolke (in fahion of a mall Cicatrice)
which Fabricius therefore calleth Cicatricula; but he etteth litle by it, counting it rather a blemih, then a part of the egge. This is a very litle pot, about the bignes of a mall Lentile, like the ball of a Birds eye, being white, flat, and round. And all egges have this too, even from their very firt original in the yolk. And therefore Fabricius is deceived, while he fancieth this pot to be nothing but a relique of the talk broken off from the yolk; by which it was incorporated to the cluter in the Ovary. For the Pedunculus or talk (as himelf acknowledgeth) is hollow, and as it approacheth neerer to the yolk, it dilateth it elf, that it may encompas it round, and hut it up as in a litle bag or pure; for it is not fatned into the middle of the yolk (as the talks of Apples, and other Fruits are) that o it hould leave a relique behinde it, when it falleth off. Now if ometimes in a very fair yolk (as Fabricius reporteth) you chance to finde a double Cicatrice, it may probably occaion a Monter, or Twinnes, (as hall be dicoured hereafter) but doth no way import a double talk. But he is extremely overeen, in thinking this Cicatrice to be utterly ueles: for it is the mot material, concerned part in the whole egge, for whoe ake all the ret of the parts are created, and the original and foundation out of which the Chicken it elf is formed. And Parianus doth fally contend, that this is the Cocks eed.

div.head: Of the difference of Eggs.
EXERCIT. XIII.
div.p:
THere is a two-fold acceptation of the word Egge; proper, or improper. An egge in its proper Acceptation is that thing, to which Aritotles definition
Hit. an. l. 1. c. 5. of an egge doth quare: An egge is that thing, one part of which doth contitute an Animal, and the ret doth nourih it, when it is contituted. In its improper acceptation, it is that to which Aritotles definition
de gen. an. l. 1. c. 2. about the ame place is proportioned. An Egge is that thing out of which the whole Animal is contituted. And of this kinde are the eggs of Ants, Flies, Spiders, ome kinde of Butterflies, and many other very mall egges of that kinde: which Aritotle doth almot every where cruple to call by the name of eggs, but tileth them little wormes. Thus far Fabricins; but we (whoe deigne is chiefly to treat of the pag. 19. generation of Hen-eggs) have no intention to deliver the everal ditinctions of all orts of Eggs, but only to lay down the diverities of Hen-eggs. Of Hen-eggs therefore, ome are new-laid, and ome taler, the former are whiter then the later; for The ditinction and difference of Eggs from their Age. time doth clowd them, and epecially incubation. The New-laid alo have a very mall hollownes or cavity in the obtue angle; and if they be very new indeed, they are omething rough with a dut or powder that ticketh to their ides; but thoe that are tale, as their complexion is darker, o their hell is moother. New-layed eggs (if they be whole) being put near the fire will weat, and are of much pleaanter tate, and more eteemed of, then other. And eggs after two or three dayes incubation,
are even then weeter relihed then tale ones are: as if the cherihing warmnes of the Hen, did refreh and retore them to their primitive excellence and integrity. And after full fourteen days (when the Chicken now beginneth to be downey, and extendeth his dominion over half the egge, and the jolke is almot till entire) I have boyled an egge till it was hard, that o I might dicerne the poition of the chicken more ditinctly, which was limned out in the white of the egge, as if the chicken had been cat in a Mould: and yet the yolke was as weet and pleaant as that of a new-laid egge, when it is in like manner boyled to an induration. The yolke of an egge taken out of a live Hen, and preently eaten, tateth much weeter raw, then dreed.

Eggs are likewie ditinguihable from their figure; From their Figure. Hit. an. l. 6. c. 2. l. 10. c. 52. lib. 9. de Rut. c. 5. for ome are longer, and harper then others. Out of thee oblong and acute eggs (according to Aritotle) are hennes begotten, and of the blunt, cocks. But Pliny aith the contrary; The rounder ort of eggs (aith he) breed Hennes, the other, Cocks. And Columella is of his minde too: If one would have good tore of Cocks (quoth he) let him place the longet and harpet eggs under his Hen; and if the contrary, let him provide the roundet he can get for money. Aritotles
Scaliger upon the place. opinion is grounded upon this reaon; namely, becaue the Rounder are the hotter; for it is the cutom and condition of heat, to congregate, and fix; and that heat is mot powerful, that •• mot operative. And therefore from the tronger, and perfecter principle, the tronger and perfecter Animal doth arie. Now uch is the Male in repect of the Female (epecially the Cock being compared to the Henne.) And now on the other ide, the leer ort of egges are reputed imperfect,
and the leat ort of all, utterly improlifical. And therefore Aritotle, to procure a contant race of egges of a fair ize, recommendeth the frequent coition of cock and hen; for he concludeth the barren and ubvontuneous egges to be all of the leer ort, and more inipid; and that becaue they are moiter and imperfecter then others. Now this ditinction of egges here poken of, is to be undertood of the egges of one and the ame hen (for hould a hen lay eggs alwaies of the ame dimenions, he would alwaies hatch them all cocks, or all hennes) becaue if you take it otherwie, the conjecture of which will be a cocke or a henne, raied from the ignes above mentioned, will be very dubions. For everal henns, lay eggs of a everal hape, and magnitude: for ome lay oblong, ome rounder, and litle differing the one from the other. For though I have ometimes found a difference in the eggs layed by the ame henn, yet the ditinction is o exceeding mall, that unles a man be very well vered, he will not perceive it. For ince all the eggs of the ame henne, are cat and modelled in the ame womb (as in a Mould) they are all impreed with, neer upon, the ame figure: and therefore it cannot be avoided, but that they hould much reemble one another (as thoe excrements that are figured in the ame complications of the ame Colon) inomuch that I my elfe have with cae in a litle basket of egges orted every hennes egges by themelves. And who ever practieth it, hall be nimble at it. Certainly it is worth our wonder which dayly experience declareth in Keepers. The more diligent ort of Keepers of Parks, that have the charge of everal herds of Deer, will tell you punctually which and which are the Hornes of uch and uch Deere, as often as they ca •
their Heads. A illy, ignorant Shepherd, who had the care of a great flock of heep, grew o well acquainted with every particular heep, that if any one were miing (though he had not arithmetick enough to count them) he could punctually tell which it was, of whom it was bought, and whence it came. And once, to make tryal of him, his Mater commanded him, out of forty lambes which he penned up in a Fould on purpoe, to ingle out the particular lamb of uch an Ewe, which he did exactly, and carried to the Damme. I know ome Huntmen, that if they have once een a Deer, or the hornes of a Deer, or footteps only in oft ground, are able to know the ame Deer again from all the Herd beides, even by thoe very horns, or tread: (jut as the Lion is ditinguihed by his Pew) nay having meerly een the print of the Deers hoofe, they will exactly reolve, how large the Deer is, how fat, and how wift: as whether he be well in breath, or over-hunted; and alo, whether a Buck or a Doe. And more then this, there are ome, who when forty Dogs are puruing the Chae, and are in full Cry, will ditinguih them all, (though a great way off) and will by their ••• inform you, which Dog is firt, and which behinde; which hunteth upon the ent, and which is at a los; whether the Deer be till in flight, or •• a Bay, & diputing the conquet with his horns; whether he have tood long, or be newly rowed. And all this in the very midt of the dogs, hunters, and windings of the horns, even in a woody Park, and where they were never in their lives before. We are not therefore to wonder o much, if thoe ••• t practie it, can dicover which Egge belongeth to which Hen: I would we could as eaily judge which Son belongeth to which Father.

But the chiefe difference of Eggs coniteth in this, that ome are fruitfull, and ome addle, which From their Fecundity. are called Ova improlifica, irrita, Hypenemia, or ubventanea, and Zephyria. They are called Hypenemia, which being layed by the Hen without conference had with the Cock, are therefore of no ue to the generation of Chickens, being tiled hypenemia, quai a vento prognata forent, as if they were begotten by the winde: as Varro aith, that Mares in Spain conceive by the Winde. For the de Re rut. c. 1. Wet wind is exceeding fruitfull, and thence the name Zephyrus, quai
< in non-Latin alphabet > , enlivening; for o Virgil:

lg.l: —Zephyrique tepentibus auris
Laxant arva inus, uperat tener omnibus burner,
Parturit omnis ager, &c.
—And when warm Zephyrus blows,
The fields diolve, oft moiture overflows,
And every Pature grows.

div.p:
And therefore the people of old, eeing their Hens in the Spring-time lay, this wind then blowing, did conceive Zephyrus to be the Author of the generation of thoe eggs. Eggs are likewie Urine, and Cynoura (when the Hen will it no longer upon them) o called, becaue egges grow often addle in the Dog-dayes, for the henne deerteth them by reaon of the extream Heat; or ele becaue about that time of the year, it thundered often: for Aritotle aith, that Egges rot, if at the
Hit an. l. 6. c. 2. Pliny lib. 10. c. 54. time of the Hennes incubation it chance to thunders Thoe egges are eteemed foecunda, fruitfull, which (if there be no outward impediment) by a quickning heat will generate chickens; which may be effected not onely by the incubation of the Hen •
whoe egges they are, but of any other Fowle of competent magnitude to cherih and cover them, or by any other cherihing warmth whatoever.

For Aritotle aith, That chickens are as well hatched upon the ground of their own accord, as by the Ibid. birds incubation: As in Egypt they cover the egges with dung. And the Story goeth, That a good fellow of Syracua ate o long upon a mat under the which eggs were layed, that ere he had done tipling the chickens were hatched. The Emperee Livia is alo reported to have cherihed an egge o long in her boom, till the chicken was bred. And to this day in Egypt, and other parts, chickens are hatched by toves and ovens. An egge therefore (as Fabricius truly affirmeth) is not only the Uterus, and place pag. 19. of reidence of the chicken, but the matter alo on which the whole generation of the foetus doth depend: which generation the egge doth performe and accomplih, both as Agent, Matter, Intrument, Place, and ever other Requiite whatoever. For certain it is, that the chicken is contituted by an internal principle in the egge, and that there is no acceion to a complete and perfect egge, by the Hennes incubation, but bare cherihing and protection: no more then the Hen contributeth to the chickens which are now hatched, which is onely a friendly heat, and care, by which he defendeth them from the cold, and forreign injuries, and helpeth them to their meat. And therefore the Incubation of the Henne is required, that he may upon that relation undertake the education of the chicken, intruct and direct their walks, prepare and look for their feeding, and by the comfort of her wings cherih them. And all thee things will not be o well performed by any but her. We have indeed Capons, and mungrel-fowle, uch as are the iue
of a Pheaant-cock and a Dunghill-henne, which will it upon the egges, and hatch them too, but they have no dexterity to guide the chickens, or mannage the charge of their education.
