I can here but admire (intending to treat larger hereafter of the ame matter) with what contancy and patience, almot all female Birds will out-it whole nights and dayes, and impare their healths, and almot famih themelves; and to what hazards they expoe themelves in defence of their egges, which, if upon neceary occaion they are at any time contrained to leave, oh! how earnetly, and with what dipatch doe they haten their return! Ducks, and Geee, for the time of their abence, cover their eggs with traw. And with what undaunted reolution will thee feeble parents many times combat in right of their egges, which perhaps are ubventaneous or addle, nay ometimes artificial of-prings, the iues of chalk or ivory, whoe injuries yet they will revenge with the ame magnanimity, with thoe done to their legitimate productions? Indeed the Birds affection towards the dull, liveles egge, is exceeding wonderful, which is altogether incapable of making any return of friendhip or repect. Who can forbeare to be amazed at the affection, or phrenie rather of a Henne that is glocking, or ready to it •
which nothing can extinguih, but a deluge of cold water; for o long as this rage is upon her, <> groweth quite careles, and walkes like a bed him, with her wings trailed, and feathers rough, and advanced, and he her elf mournful, and retles: •• he meet with any Henne itting, he will depoe • her, having all her thoughts bent upon egges and incubation; nor will he deit, till hee either <>
egges to it upon, or chickens to dicipline: which
then he doth aemble, nurture, feed, and protect with admirable zeal. Who can refrain miling, to ee a Henne follow young Ducklins, and having hatched up that uppoititious brood (apprehending them to be her own) purue them when they are now wimming in the Pond, while he her elf circuites about the brimmes, and many times attempts to ail after to the hazard of drowning, till calling, and enticeing them back, as if they had mitaken themelves.

Aritotle giveth this reaon why teril egges produce Hit. an. l. 6. c. 2. no chickens, namely, becaue the juices contained in them receive no thickening by incubation, neither doth their yolk or white recede any thing from the nature they were of before. But of this wee hall dicoure hereafter, in our general contemplation of Generation.

Our women, that they may ditinguih between egges that have chickens in them, and egges that are barren and addle, after the fourteenth or ixteenth day from the Hennes firt itting, do gently drop the egges into warme water, and thoe that inke to the bottom they account barren, but thoe that wim, fertile. And if the chicken in the egge be of any coniderable growth, and betirre himelf lutily, the egge will not onely tumble up and down, but leap and caper. And if you liten cloe for ome dayes before excluion, you may perceive the chickens, kick, make a noie, and cry after their manner. Which kinde of Commotions when the Sitting Henne dicovereth in her net, he removeth the egges, and rowleth them to and fro, (as carefull mothers do their diquiet and peevih infants in the craedle) till the chickens being accommodated with convenient poture, lye huhed, and till.

Hen-eggs are likewie ditinguihed from their From Number.
Number. For ome Hens (aith the Philoopher) lay
Hit. an. l. 6. c. 1. all the year long, bating onely the two Winter moneths. Some gallant Hens will bring ixty eggs before the Suting time; yet thee are not o fruitfull as the ordinary ort of Hens. The Adrian Hens are mall, but lay every day; yet they are very tety, and many times <> their chickens; and their feathers are of change <> colours. Some dometick Hens will lay twice a day and the fecundity of ome, horteneth their dayes.

Some Hens in England lay every day; but the ordinary fertile race, for the mot part, lay for two dayes together; namely, the firt egg in the morning, the econd in the evening following, and the third is a day of vacancy. Some Hens have an unlucky cutome to break their eggs, and leave their nets; but whether this be their dieae, or vice, is yet unreolved.

There are differences alo taken from Incubation; for ome Hennes it once, ome twice, others thrice, Incubation. and ome oftner. Florentinus writeth, that certain Hennes, Natives of that Alexandria which is in Egypt, called Monoirae, of whom pringeth a race of Game-cocks, doe it two or three times, having the chickens which they have newly hatched taken from them, & brought up apart. By which mean it cometh to pas, that one Hen will hatch forty, ixty, and ometimes more chickens at one itting.

Some Eggs alo are of a large, ome of a les, and Magnitude. ome of the leat ize of all; and thee lat are commonly called in Italy, Centenina; and our Women, to this day, (as of old alo) bely them to be Cocks-eggs, and that they produce Bailisks. The Common people (aith Fabricius) think this mall egge to be the Hennes concluding production, after he hath layed at pag. 10. hundred eggs (from whence it is called Centeninum, the Hundredth egge) which hath no yolk at all; yet
hath all the other parts, as the Chalazae, the White, the Membranes, and the Shell. For it is likely that this is then layed, when all the yolkes are already completed into Eggs, and there is no more remaining, yolks the Vitellary, that may become eggs; but yet on the other ide, there is till ome litle White behinde, and •• of that Modicum of White it is probable this litle Egge is framed. But this eemeth not probable to <> ; becaue it is an aured truth, that when the Ovary is exhauted, the Second Uterus alo (as himselfe confeeth) is alo pent, and wated into a
• eer membrane, not containing any reidue of the White, or Moiture at all. Fabricius goeth on: There i • ound a two-fold Ovum Centeninum, one without a yolk, (and this is properly called Centeninum) which is the lat the henne layeth, with which the henne, concludeth her Laying for that eaon: the other alo is a very mall egge, but hath a yolke, and is not the concluding, but ome intervenient egge, after which the henne doth perit to lay egges of a jut magnitude, as before; but it faileth in its dimenions, by reaon of some impair in the vegetal faculty, as it happeneth to Peaches, and other Fruits, whereof ome are of a full growth, and others exceeding mall. He might have accued for this michance, the inclemency of the Aire, and Soile, alo the penury, and pravity of the nourihment. But, that the lat Egges are alwaies very litle, I cannot willingly conent.

Nor are even Egges without their Monters. For Aldrovand. Ornithol. l. 14. pag. 260 the Augurs (aith Aritotle) did account it Ominous, when Eggs were laid that were all yolke; or when uch egges were found in the henne, he being cut up, under the Septum Tranverum, and they of the magnitude of a Perfect Egge.

And hither may be referred Ova Gemellifica, Twinne-eggs, which are furnihed with two yolkes;
uch as I lately found in the Uterus of a henne, i • being complete, and guarded with a Shell, having Yolks, Cicatrices, and the groer Whites, all doubles it had alo four Chalazae; but, as for the White of thinner conitence, there was onely One, which did encompas all the ret: it had alo two onely common inveting Membranes, and one ingle Shell. For though Aritotle affirme, that ome hennes alwaies produce uch Eggs; yet, that it o happeneth by the coure of nature, I can hardly believe. And though two chickens may be hatched out of uch Eggs, (which I have experimented, contrary to Fabricius his perwaion, who aith, that of uch all eg, the chicken hatched will have four legs, two heads, & four wings; of which hereafter) yet they are not vital, but commonly dye oon, and that either for defect of Aire, or room in the Shell, or that one is an impediment to the other, and doth violence to it; for it cannot be, that both hould be equally ready and ripe for Excluion, and that one hould not prove an Abortion.

To umme up all: The Differences of Eggs are chiefly of three kindes: For ome are Fertile, and ome Addle; ome produce Cocks, and ome Hens; ome pring from Parents of the ame pecies, and ome from Parents of a divere pecies, and o bring mungril-chickens; uch as are conceived from a Dunghill-hen, and a Cock-Pheaant, and o reemble either the Cock that obtained the firt, or lat Coition.

For, according to Aritotle, the egge which is contituted by Coition, paeth from its own kinde into another,
Hit. an. l. 6. c. 2. in cae the henne proceed to Coition, (having either a barren egge in her, or ele an egge conceive by the emen of cocks of different kinde) before the yolk have procured its white. And thus are barren egg
fructified, and fruitfull eggs entertain the form of that • ocke, who had the lat courteie in Coition. But if the White be already obtained, it cannot be, that either barren eggs hould be altered into fruitfull; or that thoe egges which are already conceived by Coition, hould pas into the kinde of that cock who was lat entertained. For the Cocks emen is (as Scaliger harply oberveth) like A Tetament, where the lat will In loc. is that which taketh place.

To thee differences may be perhaps added, that, whereby ome Eggs are trong, veget, and (if wee may o ay) couragious; for as there is a oule in Eggs, o have they likewie a competent vertue. For as in other orts of Animals, ome Females are o libidinous and full of venery, that they take like Tinder, from one ingle act of Coition (be it never o feeble, and the male never o impotent) and conceive forthwith, and bring divere foetues by that one act: others again are o dull and luggih, that unles they be provided with a more generous male, and him alo highly inflamed (and the coition likewie repeated and continued) they will remain unuccesfull. The ame alo befalleth in Eggs, whereof ome, though conceived by coition, are improlifical, unles they be impowered by repeated, and continued coition.

Hence it cometh to pas, that ome egges are quickly altered, and after three dayes of Incubation dicover ome rudiments of a foetus: but others are either eaily corrupted, or are low in their progres towards chickens, and yield no expectation of a chicken, even at the eventh day: As hall be hereafter proved, in the dicoure of the Generation of the Pulbus, or Chicken out of the Egge.

And thus farre of the Womb of the Hen, and its Office: as alo of the Generation of the Hen-egge, its
differences, and accidents: wherein we have delivered what we have experimented our elves; by which you may give judgement of other Oviprous creatures.

It now remaineth that we hould proecute <>
hitory, of the Generation, and Formation of the Foetus out of the Egge. For (as I informed you before) the whole Contemplation of the brood of H •• and Cocks is comprehended in thee two things namely, how the Egge is produced of the Henne and Cocke, and how the Cock and Henne are framed out of an Egge: and by this circle the propagation of their Race may by the benefit and favour of Nature, be prolonged, and continued.

div.head: Of the generation of the Foetus out of a Hen-egge.
EXERCIT. XIV.
div.p: WEe have already dicovered the Formation, and Generation of the Egge; it remains that we now deliver our Obervations, concerning the Procreation of the Chicken out of the Egge. An undertaking equally difficult, uefull, and pleaant as the former. For Natures Rudiments and Attempts are involved in obcurity and deep night, and o perplext with ubtilties, that they delude the mot piercing wit, as well as the harpet eye.

Nor can we eaier dicover the ecret recees, and dark principles of Generation, then the method of the fabrick and Compoure of the which
world. In this reciprocal interchange of Generation and Corruption conits the Aeternity and Dura
••
of mortal creatures. And as the Riing and • etting of the Sun, doth by continued revolutions complete and perfect Time: o doth the alternate viciitude of Individuums, by a contant repetition of the ame pecies, perpetuate the continuance of
• ading things.

Thoe Authors which have delivered any thing touching this ubject, do for the mot part tread a everal Path: for having their Judgements prepoeed with their own private opinions, they proceed to erect and fahion principles proportionable to them.

Aritotle of old, and Hieronymus Fabricius of late, Hit. an. l. 6. c. 3. have written o accurately concerning the Formation and Generation of the Foetus out of the Egge, that they eem to have left litle to the indutry of Poterity. And yet Ulyes Aldrovandus hath undertaken Ornithol. l. 14. the decription of the Pullulation or formation of the Chicken out of the Egge, out of his own Obervations: wherein he eems rather to have directed and guided his thoughts by the Authority of Aritotle, then his own Experience.

For Volcherus Coiter, living at Bononia at the ame time, did by the advice of the aid Aldrovandus (whom he calls Tutor) dayly employ himelf in the opening of Egges then at upon by the Hen, and hath dicovered many things truer then Aldrovandus
Nobil. exer. l. 6. himelf, of which he alo could not be ignorant. Likewie Aemilius Parianus (a Venetian Doctor) depiing other mens opinions, hath fancted A new procreation of the Chicken out of the Egge.

But becaue omethings, (according to our experience) and thoe of great moment and conequence,
are much otherwie, then hath been y •• delivered, I hall declare to you what dayly progres is made in the egge, and what parts are alt ••
ed, epecially about the firt dayes of Incubation at which time all things are mot intricate, confued, and hard to oberve, and about which Authors do chiefly tickle for their own obervation, which they accommodate rather to their own <>
conceived perwaions (which they have entertained concerning the Material and Efficient caues of the generation of Animals) then to truth her elf.

What Aritotle relates concerning the Pr • c ••
tion of the Chicken, is mot true in it elfe; yet li •• one who had not experimented the matters him elf, but had received them from other experienced perons, he doth not rightly ditinguih them by their proper times: and is very much mitaken concerning the place in which the firt principle of the Chicken is cat, which he decrees to be in th •
Acute Angle of the Egge, and is therefore jutly reprehended by Fabricius. Nor doth he eem to have oberved the beginning of the Pullus in the egge, or to have been able to have found thoe things there, which he accounts neceary to every Generation. For he would have the White (becaue nothing can poibly be made of nothing, according to the natural coure) to be the Matter contitution the Chicken. Nor did hee ufficiently apprehend how the Efficient caue (namely the Cocks eed)
•• act without a contact; or how the Egge could of its own accord, without any inherent geniture of the Male, ingender the Foetus.

Aldrovandus, partaking of the ame error with Aritotle, aith moreover, (which none but a blind man can ubcribe to) that the Yolk doth in the firt dayes, arie to the Acute Angle of the Egge: and
tinks the Grandines to be the Seed of the Cock; and that the Pullus is framed out of them, but nourihed as well by the Yolk as the White: which is clean contrary to Aritotles opinion, who conceived the Grandines to conduce nothing to the fecundity of the Egge.
Volcherus Coiter delivers truer things, and more cononant to Autopie, yet his three Globuli are meer fables. Nor did he rightly conider the principle, from whence the Foetus is derived in the Egg.

Hieronymus Fabricius indeed contends, that the Grandines are not the Seed of the Cock: and yet he • ill have the body of the Chicken to be framed out of them. (as out of its firt matter) being made fruitfull by the Seed of the Cock. He likewie aw the Original of the Chicken in the Egge; namely the Macula, or Cicatricula annexed to the membrane of the Yolke, but conceived it to be onely a Relique of the talk broken off, and an infirmity or blemih onely of the Egge, and not a Principle part of it.

Parianus hath plentifully confuted Fabricius his opinion concerning the Chalazae or Grandines, and yet himelf is evidently at a los in ome certaine circles and points of the Principle parts of the Foetus (namely the Liver and the Heart:) and eems to have oberved a Principium, or firt Principle of the Foetus, but not to have known which it was, •• that he aith, That the Punctum Album in the Middle of the Circles is the Cocks Seed, out of which the Chicken is made.
So that it comes to pas, that while each of them deire to reduce the manner of the Formation of the Chicken out of the Egge, to their own pre-conceived opinions, they are all wide from the mark.

For ome conceive the Seed and Blood to be the Matter which doth contitute the Chicken: Others
conceive the Seed to be the Efficient and producing caue, or Artificer that builds the fabrick of it: wh •• yet upon deliberate conideration it appears mot infallible, that there is no matter at hand at all, <> no mentruous blood, which the Seed of the Male can fall to work upon, or coagulate: (as Aritotle would have it) nor is the Foetus made of the Seed of Male or Female, or any commixture of them both.

div.head: The firt Inpection of the Egge, what the firt day of Incubation doth produce in the Egge.
EXERCIT. XV.
div.p:
THat we may the better dicover what the firt day of incubation hath produced in the Egge we mut firt know what alterations will befal o •
egges of their own accord; by which a tale egge is ditinguihed from a freh, (without any conideration of the Hens itting at all) that o it may appear, what is wrought by the very incubation it elfe. There is therefore (as we have declared before) in all egges, a certain cavity or hollow i • the blunt end of the egge; which cavity as the egge groweth taler, increaeth accordingly: epecially in hot Countries and eaons (by reaon the exhalation of a thinner part of the white:) we have poken in the Hitory of the egge. An • while that cavity doth expatiate, it enlarges mo •• according to the longitude, then latitude of the
Egge, and obtaineth a figure at lat which doth re
••• e from being orbicular.
The Egg-hell being now les tranparent, growth cloudy.

The White groweth thicker, and more vicous,
• ding towards a duskey or Straw-colour.
The Proper membrane or coat of the Yolke becometh more remis and looe, hrinking up into winckles.

The Chalazae continue till the ame place, ite, and conitence, at each end of the egge (and that not in new-layed egges onely, but tale ones; nor •• thoe alone that are conceived after coition, but wind-eggs alo;) by whoe firme connexion, the Yolk and White are o fat cemented together, that both retain their proper poition. For thee are two abiliments mutually oppoed, or the Poles and •• inges of this Microcome: o compoed, as if they were onely a conflux of the numerous coats of the White, and were wound as it were into a knotty •• rd, at both ends where they repect the yolk. And hence it cometh to pas, that the yolk is not eaily •• ted from the company of the White, except the Chalazae be firt divided: which done, they preently dis-join. And by the aitance of thee hin
• es, the yolk is both fixed in the center, and preer
• ed in its right conitence. So that the chief part • f all, namely the Cicatricula, retaineth till the <>
region or altitude in the Egge, and continueth a middle pace from both the extremities. For • is Spot, or Cicatrice, as well in a tale, as new-laid • gge, is till found in the ame conitence, magnifide, colour, and ite. But o oon as ever the egge
• lineth to Pullulation, be it either from the Incubation of the Hen, or the acceion of any other fo
•• ing heat whatoever, this Spot is preently dilated,
and widened like the Ball of the eye: and from it (as from the choiet center of the egg) the ecret platick faculty doth iue out, and germinate. And yet this firt Principle of the egge was never yet (to my knowledge) oberved by any man.

Now, at the econd day of Incubation, when the Egge hath grown warm four and twenty houres under the Hen, as its cavity which is in the obtue angle is much amplified, and fallen lower; o alo doth the interiour contitution of the egge vary and change. For the Yolk which before tuck fat in the center of the White, arieth towards the bl •• angle; and the middle part of it, where the Spot i • ingrafted, is elevated, and applyeth it elf to that membrane which encompaeth the cavity, o that now the Yolk eemeth to be annexed to the cavity by the Cicatrice. And as much as the Yolk rieth upward, o much is the groer part of the White depreed towards the acute or lower angle Whence it appeareth (as Fabricius rightly noted) that either Aritotle was in an errour, or ele the
Hit. an. l. 6. c. 3. there is a fault in the impreion, where it is aid, About that time (namely, within three dayes and a nights) the yellow humour is lifted to the <> there where the eggs beginning is, and where the egg • is naked there about (namely, at the dilated cavity. For Aritotle calleth that the beginning where the Acute Angle is, which parteth lat from the Henn •
Ibid. l. 3. c. 2. But notwithtanding all this, it is an undoubt • truth, that the Yolke arieth towards the Blunt angle of the egge, and that the cavity is there dilated And o quetionles Aldrovandus is deceived, <> (though he peak as if he had experimented <> matter) aith, that the Yolk rieth to the Acute angle. I confes, I have ometimes een, about
econd and third day, the Cicatricula dilated, and a foundation laid towards the formation of the Foetus, when the yolk as yet was not acended. But this is very rare, and I conceived it to happen o, by reaon of the imbecillity, and infirmity of the Egge.

On the econd day of Incubation, or firt of Inpection, the fore-aid Spot is dilated to the magnitude of a Peae, or Lentil, and is divided into circles, (as if they were drawn by a pair of Compaes) which have a very mall white Point for their Center. It is very probable, that Aldrovandus alo did oberve this Macula, or Spot; for he aith, In the midt of the yolk there appeared ome kinde of whitih thing. So did Coiterus, where he aith, The econd day, there remained in the middle of the yolke a whiter part. And Parianus alo, who aith, The econd day, I aw a white ubtance about the bignes of an indifferent faire Lentile, and of that figure: and this (aith he) is the Cocks emen, enwrapped in a white and mot lender coat, lying under the two common membranes of the egge, but above the proper containing coat of the yolke. And yet I conceive, that no man hitherto hath acknowledged, that this Cicatricula was to be found in every egge, nor that it was the firt Principle of the Egge.

In the meane while the Chalazae or eed-pearls, do decline on each ide from the two ends of the egge, towards the ides: and this proceedeth from the hifted cituation of the White and Yolk. So that one of the Chalazae decendeth omething from the obtue angle, and the other acendeth proportionably, from the Acute; as in an Oblique Sphere, by how much one Pole is elevated above the Horizon, by o much is the other depreed under it.

And now the Yolk (epecially about that part where the Cicatricula reideth) doth begin to diolve and melt a litle, and the proper coat thereof (which in taler egges is remis, lack, and wrinckled) groweth mooth and full; the Yolk it elf alo eemeth to have regained the ame colour, conitence, and inoffenive tate, which it formerly had, when the egge was new.

And this is the firt dayes Progres of the Egge, towards a Chicken, and the firt platform of its approach. But Aldrovandus addeth, that there is as yet no alteration at all in the White; wherein hee aith right. But where he affirmeth, that the Semen of the Cock is perceived in the Yolk, he is apparently in the wrong. His Argument by which he would maintain the Chalazae to be Semen Galli, is exceeding lender, and that is, becaue egges which are detitute of thee Chalazae, are not fruitfull. Hee is much in the right; for indeed they are not Eggs without them. For in all eggs, be they fertile, or not fertile, thee Chalazae are ineparable In-mates. But perhaps the Good-wives deceived him (which call thee Chalazae, Galladura, in Italian) and o betrayed him into the common Hereie. Nor is Hieronymus Fabricius les guilty of Imprudence, who offereth to our view the formation of the Pullus, graven in everal Tables; contending, that it is bodyed, and contituted out of thee Chalazae; not o much as taking notice, that the Chalazae are all this while both of them entire, and unaltered (having onely removed their tations) and that the Exordium of the Chicken is to be ought a good ditance from the Chalazae.

div.head: The econd Inpection of the Egge.
EXERCIT. XVI.
div.p:
WHen two dayes are now paed, the aforeaid circles of the Cicatricula are more ample, and conpicuous, being of the breadth of the Ring-finger, and ometimes of the Middle; wherein the whole Macula or Spot is divided into two (and ometimes into three) Regions, and thoe oftentimes inammelled, and obcurely hadowed with everal colours; fully repreenting the figure of an Eye, and that not only by reaon of its protuberance, like that in the Tunica Cornea, or horny membrane, or coat of the Eye; but magnitude alo, and likewie of that mot tranparent, mot lucid humour contained in it: whoe Center repreenteth the Pupilla, or ight of the eye; but having a white point fixed in the center, it reembleth the eye of ome mall Bird, where the middle of the Pupilla is blemihed and disfigured by ome uffuion, or Cataract: (as they call it) and from this Reemblance we call it Oculum Ovi, the Eye of the Egge. Between thee Circles is contained a mot bright refulgent liquor, clearer then any Crytalline humour in the world; which if you look upon againt the light, the whole Macula will now rather appear in the White of the Egge, then rivited into the membrane of the Yolke (as formerly it did) and (like ome part or portion of the White, diolved, and clarified) contained and bounded within a mot lender coat belonging to it elf. And this is the reaon why I call this Liquor, Oculum, the Eye, or Colliquamentum Candidum, the white
diolved ubtance; as if it were ome portion of the white of the Egge, melted and liquefied by the heat hining in its own phere apart, (unles it be cattered and ditracted by concuion) and eemeth like a more refined, and more concocted, pirituous part, ditinguihed from the courer White by a peculiar incloure of its own, and eated and inthroned in the midt, between both Yolk and White. It as much urpaeth the ret of the White in clearnes, and tranparence, as the mot Crytal Spring excelleth the troubled Lake. The Coat encircling this humor, is o nice and fraile, that (if you be not exceeding circumpect) it will oon be rent, and o diparage the purity of this, with the confuion of other liquors.

And here my thoughts were a long time trangly divided, what I hould reolve concerning this Candidum colliquamentum; whether I hould name it the Calidum Innatum, or Humidum Radicale, the Radical Heat, or Moyture, or the prepared matter from which the future foetus was to take its rie: or the Aliment exactly concocted, uch as the Ros is reputed to be amongt the ecundary humours? For I was fully atisfied (as I hall declare hereafter) that in the midt of this the firt rudiments of the Foetus lay, and that this alo was its nourihment, and after it was of ome growth, the place of its abode.

Hence it appeareth, that this Colliquamentum is oon enlarged, (namely in the compas of a day) as is evidently deciphered in Fabricius his econd Figure, epecially the inward Region of it; which, while it dilateth it elf, it obliterateth and quite expungeth the outward. As you may oberve in the Eyes of thoe creatures whoe fight of the Eye is very large, and therefore they ee better in the
Night then in the Day (of which kinde are Owles, Cats, and the like; whoe Sight is mot dilated in the dark, but more contracted in the Light:) for if you transferre uch a creature nimbly from the light into the hade, you hall perceive plainly how the the ight is ditended, o that it will much diminih the other circle, (which is called the Iris) and almot quite over-run it.

Parianus lighting upon thee circles, was much mitaken; for he mutereth up amongt his circles, a white one, a yellow one, one of the complexion of honey, and another white one beides; aerting the foetus to be made of the middle white point (which doth indeed really appeare in the midt of thoe circles) which he fancieth to be the Semen Galli. And that he may approve himelf more cunning and ubtile yet, Before (aith he) there appeareth any bluhing or rednes in the body of the Foetus, there are in it as it were two exceeding mall Bullulae or Bubbles; neither of which hath any ruddines at all at the firt: and one of thee Bullulae he would obtrude upon us for the Heart, and the other for the Liver. But the truth is, that no uch Bullula is to be een at all, before a anguine ruddines doth appear; Nor doth the Foetus look red at all at firt; Nor do any of thoe Bullulae give us any repreentation at all of a Liver, but both of them expres the two Ventricles of the Heart, and by leaping (as hall be explained hereafter) do make mutual returns to one another by their Sytole and Diatole.

p.U:
eemeth to have undertood this colliquamentum,
Hit. an. l. 6. c. 3. where he aith, About that time (namely the third day) there is a certain membrane divaricated with certain anguineous fibers, which contain a white liquor, ariing from the priggs of thoe veines. For by white liquor, he could not mean the whole
white of the egge; becaue the coat of the white is not then princkled with veins, but onely the coat of this colliquamentum. And therefore he aith, There is a membrane alo, intimating a ditinct membrane from thoe of the Yolk and White, in that he aith it arieth from the priggs of the veines, about the third day. Coiterus alo eemeth to have acknowledged this colliquamentum, aying, Some part of the White approacheth neerer to whitenes then the other, and ome to denity. Now the aforeaid colliquamentum is encompaed with its proper coat, and is ditinct and eparate from the ret of the White, before any part at all of the blood appear.

div.p: We hall have occaion to dicoure hereafter of the mighty ue of this colliquamentum, in relation to the foetus of all kinde of Animals. For while they wim there, they are guarded, and skreened from all concuion, contuion, and other outward injuries, and are alo nourihed by it.

I aw long ince a foetus of the magnitude of a Peae-cod, cut out of the Uterus of a Doe, which was complete in all its members (o that it was apparently a Male by the parts:) I hewed this pretty Spectacle and Rarity of Nature to our late King, and Queen. It did wim, trim and perfect, in uch a kinde of White, mot tranparent, and crytalline moyture (as if it had been treaured up in ome mot clear glaie receptacle) about the bignes of a Pigeous egge, and was inveted with its proper coat.

div.head: The third Inpection of the Egge.
EXERCIT. XVII.
div.p: WE have een the econd Progres, or preparation of the Egge towards the Foetus, which falleth within the third dayes Obervation. It followeth that we now attend the third Appearance; which preenteth it elfe to our view after three daies and as many nights.

And of this Aritotle: There doe begin to appear
Hit. • 1. • . 6. c. 3. ome indications of Generation in Hennes, after three dayes, and o many nights; (as uppoe upon Munday morning, in cae that on the precedent Frydaymorning the Eggs were layed under the Hen, then ready to it) and the declaration of this Inpection, is the purpoe of Fabricius his third Figure.

If therefore you oberve on the fourth day, you will meet a great Metamorphois, and wonderfull alteration; which are more evident, for almot every hour all that day long: about which time the Egg beginneth to tep from the life of a Plant, to the life of an Animal. For now the Limbus or hemme of the colliquamentum beginneth to bluh and purple, being encompaed with a lender bloody line: and in the center almot of it, there leapeth a capering bloody point, which is yet o exceeding mall, that in its Diatole, or Dilatation, it flaheth onely like the mot obcure and almot indicernable park of fire; and preently upon its Sytole or Contraction, it is too ubtile for the eye, and quite diappeareth. So lender are the firt Rudiments of Creatures lives, which the Platical faculty
ets on foot by o undicoverable beginnings.

If you are deirous to make dicovery of this obervation toward the declining of the third day, you may if you be extreamly intent, by the aitance of a clear & great light, or by the Sun beams, or a Perpective, make a hift to dicerne it. For ele, this purple treak is o exceeding nice, and fine, and the motion of the Punctum aliens is o imperceptible, that you will only looe your labour. But, at the beginning of the fourth day it is evident, and at the end thereof, mot notoriouly viible, that the Punctum anguineum aliens hath now Animal motion (aith Aritotle) in the candid liquor: (which I call colliquamentum.) And from that (Point) two hollow threads like veines, full of blood, are carried crooked to the purple Line, and the coat encompaing the colliquamentum: cattering as they pas along many fibrous branches through the whole pace and continent of the colliquamentum, all which pring from the ame Original (as the boughs of Trees from the ame Trunke,) In the crooked Angle of this Root, and the Middle of the colliquamentum, the Punctum Rubrum Saliens is enthroned, which keeps time and decorum in its pulation, compounded of a Sytole, and Diatole. In the Diatole, as if it did imbibe a larger proportion of blood, it dilates it elf, and leaps; but connives in the Sytole, as if it uffered a convulion by the troke, and reigned the blood again.

Fabricius hath decribed this Punctum or Point, in his third Figure, and, (which is trange) took it for the body of the Foetus; as if either he had not oberved its leaping, and pulation, or ele had not undertood that text of Aritotle, or at bet had forgotten it. But that which is yet more trange, is,
that he hould be nothing mindfull all this while of his chalazae, from which himelf deduces the rudiments of the chicken.

Ulyes Aldrovandus, a Writer in Bouonia, about Ornithol. l. 14. pag. 217. that time aith, There appeared in the White a litle kinde of Punctum aliens, or capering Point, which is the ame which Aritotle decrees to be the Heart. Out of which I plainly dicovered a litle Trunke of a vein to arie, and two other litle branches tending towards this, which were thoe very channels of blood, which he had wrote to be ent forth to the two coats encompaing the Yolk and White. Now I am clear of his Opinion, conceiving thoe paages to be Veins, and to have a pulation, containing a purer blood in them, and uch as is uefull and proper for the generation of the more principle parts; namely, the Liver, and the Lungs, and the like. But both thee are not veines, nor have they both a pulation; for one is an Arterie, the other a vein, as wee hall hereafter hew: where we hall alo declare, that thee Meatus do become the Umbilical veels of the Foetus.

Volcherus Coiter hath thee words: The litle bloody Point, or Globulus found before in the yolke, is now rather in the white, and evidently pulatile. Now he is out, in ayng, It was found before in the yolke; for that Point which was in the yolke was white; and did not leap neither; nor doth the bloody point or Globulus appear to leap the econd day after Incubation. But that Point (which we have declared to be placed in the Middle of the round, as if it were the center, and which is annexed to the yolke) doth vanih quite away, before the Point, which Aritotle calleth Punctum aliens, can be dicerned at all, or (as I believe) becometh red, and leaping. For both thee Points are eated in the center of the colliquamentum, and neer the root and
original of the veines which pring from thence: but they are never een together, but the Red, which is the Punctum aliens, ucceeds in the place of the White one.

In this indeed Volcherus is in the right, where be aith, The Punctus aliens is now rather found in the White, then in the Yolke. By which words, • was incited to make diligent earch, whether th ••
Punctus albus be tranmuted into the Punctum anguineum; becaue both of them are almot of the ame magnitude, and did eem cituate in the ame place. And ometimes, I found, the glitering purple circle which is the outermot, ending about the vermilion horizon, encompaed by the Colliquamentum; in whoe center there was the Punctus albus, but not the Ruber, or Saliens: but I never aw thoe two Points together. This diquiition is of great moment; namely, Whether there be blood before Pulation, and, Whether the Punctus arie from the Veines, or the Veines from the Punctus?

According to my obervation the Blood eems to be before the Pule; and I therefore believe it, becaue, Upon Wedneday about the Evening, I put three egges under the Henne, and upon Saturday, a litle before the ame time, I found thee egges cold, as being foraken by the Henne; however, opening one of them, I found the rudiments of a Chicken; namely the Purple and bloody Line in the circle: but in the center, intead of the Punctum aliens, I found the Punctum album, which is bloodles. By which I perceived the Henne had not long deerted her charge: whereupon, eizing upon her by force, I penned her up all night, having firt layed the two former remaining egges, with other that were not there before, into the Net. Now for the ucces: The next morning betimes, my two egges
were well recovered; and I found in the center the Punctum Micans, which was much les then the Punctum Album; out of which (namely the Punctum Album) a park or lightning, darting as it were from a cloud, appeared in the Diatole onely: So that to my Apprehenion, the Punctum Rubrum did leap out of the Punctum Album, at leat that Punctum is generated in the Punctum Album, and <> being now there, hath its Birth, or at leat its
<>
there. Nay, I have many times oberved, The Punctum aliens, when (as quite expired) it lay deprived of all motion, it hath regained freh motion and pulation, by a new heat and cherihing. Therefore in order of Generation, I conceive that the Punctum and Blood do firt exit, but the pulation arriveth not till afterward.

And this is mot certain, that nothing at this time appears, beides the bloody treaks, the Punctum aliens, and thoe Veins which are all derived from one Trunk (as that Trunk it elf from the Punctum aliens) and do afterward contitute the Umbilical Veels: which being dieminated farre and wide, the foetus at length (according to it growth) doth attract utenance from the Yolk and White. You may ee a lively reemblance of thee Veins & their propagations in the leaves of Trees, whoe fibres do all proceed from the pedunculus or talk, and are diffued from one Trunk through the whole capacity of the Leaf.

This whole entire Colliquamentum, ditinguihed and prinkled with bloody fibres, repreenteth the form & magnitude of the two wings of a Butterflie. And it is no other then that Membrane which Aritotle In loc. upra dict. peaks of, where he aith, The Membrane divaricated with bloody fibres, containeth then a white liquor, pringing from thoe Meatus of the Veins.

About the end of the fourth, and beginning of the fifth day, being now enlarged, it eemeth to be changed into a mall thin bladder, containing blood in it; which it ejects at every contraction, and recalls again at every diatole.

Hitherto I could not dicover any ditinction of Veels: for the Arteries do not yet differ from veines, either in coat, or Pulation: and therefore I call the veels indifferently veines, or with Aritotle, Meatus Venales, Veinal Paages, or Channels.

This Punctum (aith Aritotle) now betirres it elf like an Animal; for Motion and Sene ditinguih an Animal from a non Animal. Since therefore this Punctum begins now firt to move, wee may jutly ay it hath put on the nature of an Animal: and that the Egge which was before endowed with a vegetative oule, is now over and above that, furnihed with a Motive and enation power; and is raied from a Plant to an Animal and that at the ame time the oule of the Foetus is gone in, which firt formes the chicken ou • of the Egge, and afterward informs that chicken. For Aritotle demontratively reolves of the Lib. de Animâ. Faculties, by the Operations; and from them alo concludes of the caue and fountain of Life (namely the Soul) and that to be in, actually, (where the Operations actually are.)

And I am confirmed by many proofs and experiments, that not motion onely is now the companion of the Punctum aliens, but alo Sene it elf For upon every touch, be it never o gentle, it is variouly provoked, and diturbed, (at the ame rate as enative bodies proclaime their ditates by particular motions) and o offended with repe ••• injuries, that they did confound the chime and
order of its pules. So in the Plant, called the enative Plant, and other Zoophyta, we conclude there is ene; becaue upon touch they contract themelves, and take it unkindly.

I have, I ay, often een, and o have many more who have been preent, this Punctum, upon contaction by a needle, probe, or the finger it elf, nay upon the admiion of a more earching heat or cold, or any other thing that could molet, and diorder, declare many ymptoms of its reentment; for it would flie into many permutations of pule, beating much tronger, and nimble then before. So that, no quetion, this Punctum doth (as an Animal) Live, Move, and Perceive.

Moreover, expoe an egge too long to the colder aire, and the Punctum aliens beats lower, and hath a languihing motion; but lay your finger warm upon it, or cherih it kindely any other way, and it preently gaineth trength and vigour. And after this Punctum hath declined by degrees, and being full of blood hath ceaed from all motion, exhibiting no pecimen of life at all, and was given up for lot, and dead, upon laying of my finger warm upon it, for the pace of only twenty pules, the poor heart hath awaked, and recovered again, and as it were recued from the grave, proceeds to its former harmony afreh. And this hath been done again and again by me, and others, by any other reviving heat, were it of the Fire, or warm Water: as if it were in our dipoe to condemne the litle Soule to the Shades, or repreive it to life, at pleaure.

What we have here delivered, doth for the mot part come to pas the fourth day from the firt Incubation, or at the Third Inpection. I ay, for the mot part; for it falls not out perpetually o, becaue
there is a great diverity in the maturity of Egges, and ome come to perfection ooner then their fellows. As is uually in the fruits of any Tree, whereof ome are ripe, and ready to fall of themelves: whilet others are crude and greener, and cannot be haken from the Boughs. So that ome Egges are lee forward the fifth day, then others the third. And (that I may intance in what I have found and tryed) I have found this true in very many egges, whom the Hen hath fotered the ame length of time, and I have opened them all the ame day. So that I have had no caue to quarrel againt the weaker Sex, the ditemper of the Aire, the neglect of the Henne, or any other Accident; but onely the innate weaknee of the Egge; and the penury of the ingenit Heat.

Ova Hypenemia, or Addle Egges, do at this time (as in a critical day) begin to alter and dicover their genius: For as fruitful Egges, by the innate platick vertue do alter and reolve into a Colliquamentum (which doth after hift into bloud) o Subventaneous Eggs, at the ame time, begin to corrupt, and putrifie. And yet I have ometimes oberved the Macula or Cicatricula to be ditended wider even in barren egges; but it never roe up to the top, nor was ever circumcribed by the circles orderly drawn about it. I have alo ometimes een the Yolk grow clear, and liquifie, and the parts congealed, as it were, by rah, inconiderate coagulation, float up and down like cattered clouds. And though thee Egges cannot yet be called corrupt, putrid, and unavory; yet they are very much prepared towards putrefaction, and do compleatly arrive thither, by the continuation of the warmth of the Sitting-Henne, and et out their progree towards corruption, from the
very place and tage, whence prolifical Eggs advance to Generation.

The Perfecter ort of Egges therefore do now about the declenion of the fourth day, acquire a twofold, or bipartite Veicula pulans, or veicle of pulation, one making anwer and replies, to the other by a double pulation, in that Order and Method, that whilet one is contracted, the other hines and wells with blood; which preently being contracted, dichargeth it elf of the blood that was in it; and in a moments time intervening, the former wells and returns the Pule, o that you may evidently ee, that the action of thee veicles is Contraction; by which the Blood is driven, and pumped into the veels.

The fourth day, (aith Aldrovandus) the two Puncta were dicovered, and each of them did move: which two points were without doubt the Heart and pag. 217. the Liver; which Vicera Aritotle aith are een in the Egges after three days Incubation.

But Aritotle never aid o, nor are thoe vicera uually to be een before the tenth day. And I wonder Aldrovandus could think one of thee Puncta Pulantia was the Liver: as if the Liver ever had any uch motion.

It is afer to believe that one of the Puncta alientia (when the Foetus enlargeth) doth contitute the Auriculae or deaf Ears, and the other the Ventriculi, or Ventricles of the Heart. For in grown bodies, the Ventricles of the Heart are after this manner filled, and upplied by the Auriculae, which by their Sytole, are depleated and emptied againe: as we have oberved in our Tract, de Motu cordis & anguinis. In better grown egges, ometimes about the declining of the fourth day, I know not what cloudy ubtance did obcure thee Veiculae
Pulantes, and did (like an interpoed hade) obtruct my Inpection, that I could not o clearly dicerne the Puncta alientia. Yet by the help of a clearer light, and with a Perpective, and conferring with my obervations for the ubequent days: it appeared to be the Rudiment of the foetus, or a Cloud exhaled from the Colliquamentum, or an Effluvium congealing about the beginning of the veines: as hall more at large be treated of in the fifth days obervation.

Aldrovandus alo eems to have oberved it: The fifth day, (aith he) that Punctum which we called the Heart, did no longer appear to move outwardly, but eemed rather to be covered, and concealed; and the two Meatus Venoi were een more conpicuous, but one larger then the other. But the Learned Aldrovandus is deceived, for this Tutelar deity taketh poeion, and locks himelf up in mot reerved and ecret recees (when the habitation is almot compleatly erected) a long time after. And he likewie mitakes, where he aith, that by the innate vertue of the veins, the remaining portion of the white is turned into a kind of traw-coloured ubtance. For that complexion is in the the thicker white, of all egges that are tale, and is daily increaed in them, (namely, according as the Egge groweth Staler, as is aid) and that without any aitance of veins, by reaon of the thinner ubtance exhaling.

But the Foetus growing bigger, (as we hall declare in its place) and the circles of the branches of the veins being dieminated up and down, part of both the juyces are diolved, not (as Aldrovandus would have it) by an innate vertue of the veins, but by the heat of the blood inhabiting there. For into what part oever of the moiturer
the foreaid veins extend their Territories, there preently appears a colliquation or reolution in the bordering parts; and therefore the Yolk at that time eems double, becaue its uperior part (which is joined to the cavity above, about the obtue angle) being more mollified, and diolved then the ret of the Yolk, appears like melted Wax, compared to the other cold, compacted part. And upon that core (as all melted things do) it obtaineth a larger roome. And that Upper part, liquefied by the genital warmth is diterminated from the other liquors (and epecially from the White) by a peculiar mot thin coat of its own. Whence it happens, that a breach being made upon this lender, frail, and inviible membrane, there preently follows a confuion and mixture of the Yolk and White, which diturbs the whole frame. And it is many times a caue to frutrate and void Generation (when thoe liquors become to be of a divere, nay of a contrary nature) according to that Text in Aritotle,
de gen. an. l. 3. c. 2. o often cited. Egges are depraved and made addle mot in hot weather, and that upon good reaon. For as Wines grow ower in hotter weather, the dregs being ubverted (for that is the caue of their depravation) o Egges are detroyed, their Yolk being corrupted: for thee are the more terrene and earthy parts in both. So that Wine is diturbed by a commixture of the dregs, and the Egges by diffuion of the Yolk. And hither you may jutly reduce that of Hit. an. l. 6. c. 2. him too, where he aith, Egges that are under the Henne in tempetuous thunders, are corrupted. For the exceeding mal membrane is by o great a noie quickly torne aunder. And therefore perhaps, confued and putrid Egges, are called Ova Cynoura, becaue (as we have oberved) it thunders Lib. 8. c. 5. mot in the Dog-days. And therefore Columella
rightly admoniheth, that mot men deeme the Summer-Soltice to be inconvenient for hatching of chickens.

This is mot certain, that Egges uffer quaation, concuion, and diolution very eaily, if any man diturb them while the Hen is Sitting, becaue at that time the liquors in them are liquefied, and well, and the membranes embracing them are dilated, and grow tender.

div.head: The fourth Inpection of the Egge.
EXERCIT. XVIII.
div.p:
THE fifth day of Incubation, is dicerned firt (aith Aritotle) the body of the Pullus, being very
Hit. an. l. 6. c. 3. mall, and white, wherein the head is conpicum and in it the eyes much turgent, which continue o a long time, for it is long ere they abate, and connive. But in the lower part of the body, there is no part •• firt extant, correpondent to the upper. But th •
• Branches which hoot out from the Heart, one tending to the ambient membrane, the other to the Yolk, do upp •• the office of the Navel. The original of the Chicken therefore from the White, but its nourihment from the Yolk by the Navel.

By which words Aritotle eems to ditrib ••• the whole Generation of the Pullus into three cla ••
or orders, namely from the firt day of Incubation to the fifth: and thence, on to the tenth or fourteenth and o on to the twentieth. As if he had o •• recorded thoe things in his Hitory, which he • covered at thee three Inpections. The great
changes in the Egge do indeed happen at thee times: as if by thee Decretory days, as by three ditinct degrees, the progree of the perfect Egge, to the utmot excluion of the Chicken, were ditinguihed. For the fourth day the firt particle of the Foetus, namely the Punctum aliens, and the Blood appear; and after that the Foetus is corporated. The Seventh, the Chicken is ditinguihed into parts, and beginnes to move. The tenth it beginnes to be down-feathered; about the twentieth, it breathes, and cryes according to its kind, and eeks to make its ecape. The Life which it obtains about the fourth day, eems to emulate that of Plants, and is to be eteemed onely a vegitative animation. But from that to the tenth, it enjoyes a enative and moving oul as Animals do: and after that, it is compleated by degrees, and being adorned with Pl •• es, Bill, Clawes, and other furniture, it hatens to get out, that being at length emancipated, it may be unconfined and free.

Aritotle therefore enumerates amongt thoe things which befall after the fourth day, chiefly three; that is to ay, the fabrick of the body, the branchings of the veines, which now upply the Nature and Office of the Navel: and the matter or ubtance whence the Foetus doth firt pring, and is contituted, and nourihed.

Concerning the Fabrick of the Body, he relates four things, firt, what magnitude it is of; econdly, what complexion; thirdly, what parts are mot conpicuous, (namely the Head, and Eyes) and latly, what ditinction or difference there is between the Parts. Truth is, the Body is exceeding mall, reembling in form that common worm or Maggot, out of which the Flie is bred; it is alo white of colour, like that little Worm, which the
Flie depoiteth in putrified fleh. to be cherihed, and bred up; and he elegantly addes, that it is mot notorious from its Head and Eyes. For that which firt appears, is a imilar and inditinct Body, as if it were ome concrete and congealed ubtance of the colliquamentum it elf (like that Gelly which is made of the decoction of Harts-horn) being like a tranparent cloud, which were hardly ditinguihable, were it not divided as it were into two parts; whereof the one lies in a heap together; and is much larger then the other, being the Rudimens of the Head; which is firt dicerned on the fifth day: in which the Eyes are anon manifetly ditinguihed; which at firt are the bigget of all, much puffed up, and prominent, and are dicriminated both from the ret of the Head, and the whole Body beides, by a certain blacknes cat round about them. Any one of thee, is larger then the whole Head; as alo, the Head alone exceeds all there of the Body in magnitude. This Whitenes of the Body, endureth a while, as alo, the tumor of the Eyes: (which are filled alo with a mot clear moiture or water within, but are dark and blackih without, as it is alo with the Brain) that is to ay, to the tenth day, and more: for (aith Aritotle) It is late ere they diminih, and contract to their allotted proportion. Nay, according to my obervation, the Eyes of Birds do never reduce themelves to the Proportion, which is allotted as the tandard between the Eyes, and the Head of a Viviparous Animal. For if you lay aide the Skin, which covereth the Eyes of a Henne, or any other Bird, either of them alone will oon countervail the whole bulk of the Braine: In a Woodcock and the like, any one of the Eyes is bigger then all the Head beides, (bateing onely the Bill) but it is
common to all Birds whatoever to have the Orbita, or cavity which containes the Eyes to exceed the Braine it elfe, as you may ee in their cranium, or Scull. But yet it falls out that their Eyes eem leer, becaue they are all (except the Sight or Apple onely) hrouded with Skin and Plumes; nor are they of an Orbicular Figure (which might occaion their prominence or tanding out) but of a Depreed, as Fihes eyes are.

In the lower part of the Body (aith Aritotle) there is no part extant at firt, which is correpondent to the Superior: And o indeed it is: The Body at firt were carce dicernable, were it not for the Eyes and the Head; o that downwards, it is not ditinguihed by any members at all, whether Wings, Feet, Breat-bone, Rump, or any Vicus: nor indeed is it graced with any Shape of a Body: but as far as I could dicover, it is onely a Litle Subtance, next adjacent to the mall veine, like the carina or keele of an imaginable mall Ship wound up together, and like a Maggot or Worme, without any platform of Ribbes, Legs, or Wings: to which is fatned a litle round body, which is the rudiment of the Head, which is more dicernable th • n it, and divided into three Bubbles, (on which fid: oever you make your Inpection:) But it is indeed divided into four, whereof two are larget, and blackih, being the rudiments of the Eyes; the third of the Braine; and the fourth of the cerebellum, or After-Braine. All thee are full of exceeding clear Water, but in the middle of the Blacknes of the eyes, is the Apple or Ball of the Eye (as in the Center) hining like a tranparent Spark or Crytal. Hence I uppoe, the Tres Bullae, the three Bubbles which are onely conpicuous, have impoed upon thoe, who have not througly oberved the thing.
For having learnt, according to the old doctrine of the Schooles, that there were three Principalities in the Animal Body, and three Principal Parts; (namely, the Braine, the Heart, and the Liver) executing the chief Functions: They oon induced themelves to believe, that thee Three Bullae were the platformes, and ground-works of thee three parts. But Coiterus, as becomes a skilful Anatomit, affirms much truer, that he aw, on the Seventh day after Incubation, the Bill, and the Eyes, but could dicover none of the Vicera.

But to Aritotle againe. Thoe Branches, which proceed from the Heart, one of them tendeth to the circumambient membrane, the other to the Yolk, upplying the office of a Navel. The Foetus being now bodied, thoe veines do execute the office of a Navel: and one of their branches, or propagations is dieminated into the outward coat, which embraceth the White; but the prouts of the other go directly to the coat of the Yolk, and are dieminated through its juyce or liquor. By which it is plaine and evident, that both the Liquors are dedicated to the nourihment of the Foetus. And though Aritotle ay, that the Original of the chicken is from the White, and its nourihment from the Yolk by the Navel: Yet he doth not ay that the chicken is made of the White; for the Foetus is made of that white Liquor which we call the colliquamentum: and all that which we call Oculum Ovi, the Eye of the Egge, is contained in the White. Nor doth he ay that the utenance of the Chicken is onely from the Yolk by the Navel: but I hall interpret his words (according to my one Obervations) thus: Though the Pullus aume its original in the White, yet it is not fed by the White onely, but by the Yolk
alo (to which one of the Sprigs of the Umbilical veines doth extend) nay chiefly by the Yolk; for the White (according to Aritotle) is the more concocted, and purer liquor of the egge, but the Yolk the more terrene, and olid, and therefore more congruous to the Chicken, when he is growne tronger: and therefore (as hall be aid hereafter) it upplies the place of Milk, and is that which is lat conumed; for the remainder of it (after the Chichen is hatched, and walkes abroad with the Henne) it yet contained in its Belly.
What I have hitherto poken, cometh to pae, from the fourth day to the eventh. But When, How, and in what Order, all the Particulars are framed, I hall now explaine.

The Next Appearance, which preents it elfe the fifth day, about the hort veine drawn from the Angle (where the two points leaping in coure are eated) there appears a groer, and whiter ubtance, like a little cloud, (which yet is tranparent) through which the foreaid veine doth obcurely, and as through a cloud, cat a glimpe of it elf. I have een the ame ometimes, in well grown eggs, upon the fourth day. But this is the Rudiment of the Body, which now every hour groweth more cloe, and compact, and doth encompae the foreaid veine, and alo is annexed to it, like a litle globous body. That globous Rudiment doth much exceed the Keele (as I may call it) of this little Worm, in magnitude: and it is of a triangular figure, that is to ay, (like the mall prout of a knotted hrubbe) obcurely divided into three pieces: Whereof one is Orbicular, and larger then the other two, and looks black, by reaon of ome mot lender fibres, which are drawn from
the Circumference towards the Center: reembling the platform of the Septum Ciliare, and therefore it implyes, that this particle is transformed into the Eye. In the midts of this, is a very little Pupilla or Eye-Ball, appearing like a mot bright point: (as we have aid) and upon that ground I raied my conjecture, that this entire litle round body, was deigned for the Rudiment of the Head: and that that black circle was to be one of the Eyes, to which the other tandeth oppoite on the other ide: for they are o eated, that you cannot dicerne them both at once, becaue the uppermot covereth and hideth the lower.

This firt Rudiment of the Body, which we affirm to grow about the veine, (hath obtained an oblong, and omething an embowed figure, (like the Keel of a Ship; it is of a mucous conitence, like the film or hoarines which is contracted by moit things, when they are pent up in a cloe place. But the mall veine to which this hoary ubtance doth accrew, is the decending Vena Cava, paing along the Spine of the Back: as my ubequent obervations have cleared. If you diligently mind the order of the pulation of the two veicles, you hall dicerne the blood driven by the Sytole of that which was lat contracted into the beginning of this veine, and this vein ditended by it.

So that there are two manifet Contractions and Dilatations of the two veicles which caue a motion and pule in one another: and the preceding Contraction of the one, creates the Ditention of the other: for the blood being darted into the econd veicle, by the Contraction of the cavity of the firt, caueth an impletion, ditention, and pulation in it: which by and by contracting it elf, digorgeth the blood (which it now received from the former
veicle) into the beginning of the foreaid veine, and o dilateth that. I call it yet a vein, though by its pule I conceive it to be the Artery, called Aorta; for the Arteries are not yet ditinguihed from the veines by the thicknes of their coats.

Having often oberved thee things with much caution and circumpection in everal eggs, I tood a while in upene, what opinion I hould entertain of them. As, whether I hould conclude this concrete, and annexed globous body were made of the Colliquamentum, (in which it wam) as out of a compacted and coagulated ubtance; as Clouds are formed out of vapours in the upper Region of the Air (which vapors were never dicovered to acend:) Or ele out of ome Effluvium or exhalation of blood tranpiring, or ome Tranudation, weeping by a kinde of diapedeis, from the vein. For the firt Rudiments even of the greatet things, are exceeding mall, and o very obcure, becaue very litle.

This, I preume, I am aured of, viz. that the Puncta alientia, the Branchings of the veins, & the Vena cava it elf are firt exitent, & that afterwards this corpulency or bulke is joyned to them. And I am alo mot certain, that the Blood is driven into this Vein out of the Punctum aliens, and that by this Vein that litle bulke or body is fed. For that firt hoarines or Mucus is firt of all made by an Effluvium of the Vein, (to which it grows) and from it afterward draweth its nourihment and encreae: As filme and hoarines doth in other moit places grow between the chincks of walls, which lie long unwept; as Camphyre upon Cedar-planks, and Mos upon Stones, and Barks of Trees; or latly, as a kinde of downe is bred upon ome kinde of Wormes.

I did alo doubt at the ame time, whether this Rudiment of the Head and Body had its exitence o oon, as the coagulation of the Colliquamentum, together with the Blood, and Punctum aliens had theirs, but was then imperciptible by reaon of its thinnes, and clearnes of ubtance; till congealing into a groer film, it put on a more olid, compacted whitenes, by which it might be dicerned: while yet the Blood which is thicker and hining might be well perceived in the Colliquamentum which is o diaphanous. But whilet I conider the matter more narrowly, I am fully atisfied, that the Blood hath a being, before any other part of the body beides, and is the elder brother to all other parts of the foetus; and that from it, both the matter out of which the foetus is contituted, as alo the aliment by which it is upplied, is deumed, and is (if any thing be) the firt genital particle. But how I am induced to this perwaion, hall be afterwards copiouly recited, when we dicoure concerning the primitive fructifying Part, the Innate Heat, and Radical Moiture; and when alo wee hall reolve what is to be thought concerning the oule, out of many Obervations conferred together.

About this time, almot every hour, all things appear larger and clearer, and more ditinct, and unfolded; and now there comes a nimble Alteration in the Egge, and many things appear one upon the neck of another. The Cavity of the Egge is now much larger, and layeth the upper part of it all void and empty, as if a fifth part of the Egge were vanihed.

The litle branches of the Veins are farther pread out, and grow more numerous in their ditributions, not onely into the Colliquamentum, (as before)
but up and down both into Yolke and White, & both thoe liquors are chequered over with fibers. The upper part of the Yolke is much diolved and melted, as if it were a ditinct thing from the inferiour, and that the yolke were now become two; the uperiour hining like melted wax, welled, and bright; and the inferiour and earthier, together with the duller part of the White, being depreed to the acute angle. And the proper coat of the uperiour part of the yolke is now o thinne, that the leat concuion breaks it; upon which enues a confuion of liquors, and an utter frutration of generation.

And now is the firt Rudiment of the Foetus to be clearly een (as you may perceive it in Fabricius his fifth and ixth Tables;) which being put into a baon of clear water, will plainly dicover, what parts of the body are already framed, and what are yet wanting and behinde. For there appears the form of a mall Worm or Magot, as we ee the rudiments of Wormes and Flies in the boughs of Trees, in the knots of the Bark, in Fruits, Flowers, and other things; but epecially in Oak apples, in whoe center, within a mall round Shell or Kernel, is contained a clear liquor, which thickning and coagulating by degrees, is interlaced with mot lender fibres, and repreents the hape of a Magot, but continues a while immoveable, till at length endued with ene and motion, it becomes an animal, and departs a Flie.

Aritotle decribes a Generation like this, in Hit. an. l. 5. c. 19 thoe things that are called Sponte nacentia. Some creatures are born of the Dew, which falls upon the Leaves. And a while after he aies: Butterflies are made of Worms, but thee Worms of green Leaves; and epecially of the Leaves of that ort of Raphanus,
which ome call Braica. They are firt maller then Millet, and afterward very litle worms; then encreaing, within three dayes they become litle Magots; and after this being more grown, they ceae to move, and changing their form, are called Crytallides, being contained in a hard crut; and if you touch them, they tirre: a great while after the crut or hell is broken, and o they being become winged creatures, take their flight, and are called Butterflies.

But we hall prove anon, that the Generation of all creatures is alike, and that all creatures, even perfect ones, are begotten of a Worm; which Aritotle alo eemeth to have noted, where he aith: In all Creatures, even thoe which produce a perfect egge, the
de gen. an. l. 3. c. 9. firt conception groweth before it be ditinguihed: uch is alo the nature of the Worm. Now this difference there is between the generation of the Worm, and other Creatures; that the Worm growes before hee have his hape, or ditinction into parts: according to that of the Philoopher, An animal is made out of a Worm, not as if it were made out of a part of it, as out of its Egge; but in that the whole Worm grows, and o becomes a dearticulate animal; namely, in growing it becomes to be jointed or ditinguihed.

We have indeed caue to wonder, that the Rudiments
De hit. an. l. 5. c. 9. of all Creatures whatoever, epecially of Creatures that have blood, (viz. of a Dog, a Hore, a Deere, an Oxe, a Henne, a Viper, nay of Man himelfe) hould o exactly reemble the hape and conitence of a Magot, that you can perceive no difference at all.

And now the Rudiment of the Body, (which we all the Keel) doth more ditinctly repreent the
• pina dori, or Chine of the Back: to which, ides begin to be built and appear; for the Wings and legs do now jut out from the Magot. And the veels do now plainly expres the Navel.

div.head: The fifth Inpection of the Egge.
EXER. XIX.
div.p:
THe ixth day the three Bullae of the Head doe more plainly appear, and the coats of the eyes are now ditinct: alo the Legs and Wings do bud forth; as at the end of June, the Gyrini (which the Italians call Ravabottoli, and we Tadpoles) begin to have leggs, when now they forake the wa
• ers, looe their tayl, and put on the hape of Frogs.

The form of the Chickens Rump is yet no other, then that which is een in all other animals, may in very vipers, namely a round lender tail. The Parenchyma of the heart now groweth to the veicula pulans; and a litle after the Rudiments of the Liver, and Lungs are dicovered, and alo the Bill, all appearing exceeding white, epecially the Bill. And about this time all the Vicera and the
Guts may be een. But the heart expoeth it •• firt to ight, and the Lungs before the Liver or the brain. But before all are the eyes viible, becaue o • their largenes and blacknes of their colour.

And now the foetus moves, and gently tumbles, and tretcheth out the neck, though nothing of a brain be yet to be een, but meerly a bright water hut up in a mall bladder. And now it is a perfect Magot, differing onely from thoe kinde of worm •
in this, that thoe when they have their freedome, crawle up and down, and earch for their living abroad: but this worm contant to his tation, and wimming in his own proviion, draws it in by his Umbilical Veels.

The Vicera and the Guts being now erected, and the foetus being furnihed with motion too; yet the fore-part of the Body till lyes wide open, being deprived of the Thorax, and Abdomen; and the Heart it elfe, the Liver, and the Guts hanging out.

About the end of this day, and the beginning of the eventh, the claws are ditinguihed; and the foetus begins to have the Effigies of a Chicken, it opens the bill, and kicks: latly, all the parts are delineated, epecially the Eyes. But the Vicera or bowels are yet o obcure, that Coiterus truly affirme • . That he aw indeed the Eyes and the Bill, but could dicover no Vicus at all, though never o concealed or confued.

That which followeth from the beginning of the ixth day to the end of the eventh, cometh •• pas ooner in ome, and in ome eggs later. No • are the coats of the Eyes een, though they have nothing in them but a liquid clear humor: the Ey •
themelves are omething prominent, or hanging out of their eats, and each of them doth no le •
exceed the brain in magnitude, then the head, the ret of the body that is fatned to it.
A litle bubble, like a cret, placed out of the circuit of the brain, upplied the place of the cerebellum, and that is alo full of a clear water.

The brain eemeth obcurely divided, and hines not o much as the cerebellum doth, though it look whiter. And as the Heart is now to be een without the incloure of the chet, o is the cerebellum, out of the Confines of the cerebrum.

In cutting off the Head, I aw (by the benefit of •• y Perpective) in the Necke, a bloody peck of •• e veine which acends to the braine. And by • his means onely could I ditinguih the rudiment of the Spine, from the other Pulpe, it was of a milkey complexion, but firmer conitence then milk. And o alo like lender cobwebs, narrow white lines, wan
• ing through the pulp of the body, to give ome
•• imen of the Ribbs, and other bones; and this is much more dicernable in the formation of other Viviparous Animals. The Heart, the Lungs, the Liver, and, intead of Guts, the mot lender threds,
• re all white. The Parenchyma of the Liver
• ows to the Umbilical vein, there where it enters • o the Liver, upon thin fibrous trings: in like manner as the Rudiment of the Body grows to the •• paing from the Heart, or to the Veicula pul
•• s. For as Grapes grow to the cluter, buds to •• eir talks, and the eares of corn to the traw: So •• th the Liver to the Umbilical veels, like muh
••
out of Trees, or proud fleh in Ulcers, or flehy ••• rs which border upon the branches of the Ar
•••• es, by which they are fed, and pread ometimes ••
• vat tumor.

Having had an Eye upon this emploiment of Arteries, or circulation of the blood, I have ometimes
perfectly cured exceeding great Herniae carnoae, beyond all expectation; providing onely, that the litle artery being tyed or cut off, no nutriment or pirit might have acceion to the part affected; by which it fell out, that the fatal tumor was afterwards eaily extirpated either by inciion, or adution.

A certain man, beides other infirmities, (and of this tory I can produce many tetimonies) had a Sarcois or flehy tumor in his Scrotum or God, bigger then a mans head, hanging down to his Knees; and from it, another Hernia carnoa, as thick as ones writ (or a cable) paed into his Abdomen, o that the dieae growing to o great a height, no man would undertake the Cure, by inciion, or otherwie. Yet I perfectly cured this o vat excrecence, which o much ditended the Scrotum, and encompaed the Teticle, by the means aforeaid; and yet left the leading and preparing veel to the ue of the Teticle, without any prejudice or touch upon the other veels decending into the S ••
tum, by the Tunica vaginalis, or coat of the Teticles o called. But thee and other Cures, accomplihed clean beide the common opinion, I hall in my Phyical Obervations (if God grant me life) dicover at large.

I mention thee things with this intent, that men may plainly ee, that the Liver grows to the veels, and is generated ome time after the Blood is born, and that its parenchyma is produced by the Arteries, (which adminiter matter to frame <> and alo that for a while it continues white, and without blood; which is likewie common to other parts of the body. For after the ame man •• and order, as we have declared the production
•• the Chicken to be out of the Egge, doth the
<>
ration of Man, and all other Animals proceed. By which it appears, how incongruous their perwaion is, (though it hath obtained both of old, and now too) who decree the Liver to be both the
<>
where the Blood is wrought, and the Author of it; and do upon that account, rank it amongt the
• hiefe and firt-born parts of the Body: who alo give o much renown to this Vicus, that they proclaim it to pring with the Heart, from the firt beginning, out of the emen of the mother; and do rigorouly maintain the Fable de tribus Capellis, or the three imaginary Bubbles. In which Quire, Parianus of late, with a loud, but unmannageable voice, hath ung his part of the Catch.

Thee honet men never took notice, that the Veicles move, the Heart pants, & the Blood is now perfectly concocted, before any track or foundation of the Liver appears. Without all quetion the Blood is to be counted the Author of the Liver,
• ither then the Liver the Author of the Blood. For the Liver is made after the Blood, and of it, cleaving • the Veins that contain the Blood.

Nor yet can I ubcribe to the Aritotelians, which repute the Heart to be the Author of the
•• id. For its ubtance alo, or Parenchyma is born <> the Blood, and is then uperadded to the Ve
•••• la Pulantes. But I am much in doubt whether Veicula, or Punctum aliens or the Blood, that is to • y, whether the contained liquor, or the containing •• els be the elder. Now it eems in reaon, that ••
container is made for the contained; and therefore after it. This indeed our cies can truly witnee, ••• the Veines are the firt woof, and the firt vii
•• foundation of the body, and that all the other <> are uperadden to them, and born after <> . But of this matter hereafter more at large.

In the Interim we cannot chue but mile at that fond and fictitious Diviion of the Parts, into Spermatical, and Sanguineous; as if any part were immediately framed of the Semen, and were not all of one extract and original.

But I return to our purpoe. The extent of the Colliquamentum doth not reach over more then half the Egge. The Heart hanging out, tands omething off from the body. And if you makes diligent inpection, you may dicover ome of the Umbilical Veels beat.

div.head: The ixth Inpection of the Egge.
EXER. XX.
div.p: ON the eventh day all things are clearer, and the primordia of each particular part are now viible; namely, the Wings, Leggs, Genitals, the divided Claws of the feet, the Thighs, the Side • ien, &c.

Now the Foetus betirrs it elf, and kicks, and the Chicken is found complete, there being no addition to be expected after but only the growth o • the parts yet tender: which the more they encreae, the more the White decaies; and the out ward membranes uniting, upply the place of the Secundina, or after-birth; as alo the Veines do every day more and more repreent the Navel. Therefore I conceive it convenient to pas from the Seventh, to the Tenth day, becaue nothing worth obervation doth intervene in the mo •• time, though Authors uually, epecially Aritotle do not do o.

Notwithtanding all this, if you oberve many Egges at a time, you hall finde ome that are forward, and better grown, have all the parts apparent in them; other Truants will preent them Ies ditinct. Though on the other ide, many things concurre to the work, as the Seaon of the year, the warmth of the Net, Outward cherihings, Deligent Incubation, and the like. I remember I have ometimes een in a luggih Egge, the cavity indeed dilated on the eventh day, and the Colliquamentum prinkled ore with veines, alo a Magot in the midt of it, together with the rudi ments of the Eyes, and other things which come to pas in other Egges, about the fourth or fifth day; yet there were no veiculae pulantes at all: nor could I finde the Trunke or root out of which the Veines rie. And therefore I jutly counted it a eeble backward Egge, endowed but with a ickly generative power, and now upon the point to die. And that chiefly, becaue its Colliquamentum was more cleare and refulgent then uual, and the veines did alo hine a litle. For when the Vital pirit departs, that part firt declines and corrupts, which is firt in order of Generation.

div.head: The Inpection after the tenth day.
EXER. XXI.
div.p:
WHatever is viible the tenth day, is delivered o accurately by Aritotle, that litle or nothing remaines to be added. And this opinion, according to my Paraphrae, is thus: The tenth day
all the Chicken is viible; and all pellucid, and white, ave only the Eyes and divarications of the Veines. And the Head is bigger then all the ret of the body beides; and the Eyes tick fat in the Head, or rather tick to the Head as Appendixes, being yet unfurnihed of a Pupilla or Eye-ball; (that is, having none yet perfectly formed; and yet it is no hard matter to dicover the ditinct coats or membranes) for if then you pluck them out, you hall finde them blacke, and bigger then Beanes: from which if you take off the skin, there flows a white, cold humour, very refulgent if you hold it in the light, and beide that humor, there is nothing (namely in the whole entire Head) contained at all. And this is the tate of thee parts, from the eventh day, to the tenth.

At the ame time (aith Aritotle) the Vicera or Intrals alo appear, and all the appurtenances belonging to the Belly and Guts; namely, the Parenchyma of the Heart, Lungs, and Liver, &c. but all are white, mucilaginous, and wahy, and have no firm conitence in them. And the Veines alo that proceed from the Heart, are applied to the Navel. And from the Navel one Vein paeth to the membrane containing the yolke; which is then more liquid and diolved, then his natural contitution ues to be. But the other, to the other membrane, which containeth the whole membrane (namely the coat of the Colliquamentum) which encompaeth the Foetus, and the Yolke, and the interjacent humour. For while the Chicken grows by degrees, part of the yolk is above, and part below; but the White being in the midt, is liquid. And the white is alo under that lower part of the yolke, as it was under it before. So farre Aritotle.
