And now you may plainly ee the Veines accompany the Arteries; as well thoe which <> to the Whites, as thoe which pas to the yolk. The
yolke alo now diolves, and yet not all of it, but that which lyes uppermot: nor do the priggs of the Veines run through the whole yolk, but through that part onely which we have aid to be like melted wax. So alo the Veines which tend to the White, have ome Arteries for their companions. And the greater part of the White it elfe, is diolved alo into that white moiture (called the Colliquamentum) which urrounds the Chicken wimming in the midt of it, and lieth between the two diviions of the yolke; namely, the Upper, and the Lower: under which (in the acute angle of the Egge) the groer and more vicous part of the White remaineth. The Upper part of the yolke appeares now more liquid and reolved, then the Inferiour doth; for whereoever the fibers of the Veines dieminate themelves, the parts grow preently tumid, and ofter.
But Aritotle adds, aying, the White at the tenth day sinketh down, being now grown les, vicous, thicker, and yellowih; namely that part of it which is not transformed into the Colliquamentum.
Now the greatet part of the White is reolved into the Colliquamentum, and the Foetus; that is, all the thinner part of the Albumen, and the greater part alo of the thicker.

But the Yolk appears now larger, then it was at firt. By which it is evident, that the Yolk doth not yet erve for nutrition, but is afterwards designed for that office. And as farre as I could conjecture, by the dieminations and ditributions of the Veines, the Foetus is at firt nourihed by the Colliquamentum; for the Veines are firt ditributed into it alone, and thence into the membrane of the thinner White; and after that, into the groer White, and Yolk: o that even the groer White
becomes the nutriment, before the Yolk. For the mot tender Foetus, whilet it is yet a mall Magot, is fed with the thinnet diet of bet concoction; that is, the Colliquamentum, and the thinner White. But when it grows more hearty, it is received with entertainment proper for its age and trength.

In the next words, Aritotle decribes the cituation of the particulars contained in the egge. At the upper and lower end of the egge, doth the membrane of the egge reide, not the membrane which belongeth to the hell, but under it: and in that membrane is contained the white liquor: (namely the Colliquamentum) then the Chicken, and the membrane containing it, which provides uch a eparation, that the Foetus it elfe doth not wallow in the liquor.

Where I upect a fault in the Text. For the thing it elf peaks, that it hould be rather thus. Then the Chicken encompaed in a Membrane, is eated, or wims in that white liquor; which Membrane is not that exterior one, which immediately lineth the hell, but another Membrane, lying under that: which when the exterior White is pent, and the remaining thicker White is depreed into the Acute Angle, of two Membranes (namely, that of the thinner White, and that which is proper to the Colliquamentum) is made one coat, which begins to appeare like the Secundine, called Chorion. Yet Aritotle aies well, In that Membrane is contained the white liquor: for by that he doth not undertand the Albumen, but the Colliquamentum made of that Albumen, in which the Foetus wims; for the remainder of the Albumen is now unk down into the Acute Angle.

div.head: The Inpection after the fourteenth day.
EXERCIT. XXII.
div.p: From the eventh to the fourteenth day, all parts are enlarged (as hath been aid) and more viible. The Heart and all the other Intrals are now concealed in the everal Venters or Bellies of the Chicken: and thoe that before were expoed, and naked, cannot now be een, but by opening the breat, and lower belly. Now is the Chicken cloathed in Plumes, whoe roots appear, like black points. The Apple of the Eye is now ditinct, and the Eye-lids are plaine to be een: likewie the Membrana Nictatoria, or membrane moving the Eye-lid, is viible in the greater Canthus or corner of the Eye, which is a membrane peculiar to all birds, by which they cleane their Eyes. Alo now the Gyri or Involutions of the braine are ditinguihed, and the After-braine is covered by the Scull: and the Taile hath attained the form of a Rump.

After the fourteenth day, the Intrals (which were white before) put on by degrees a ruddy fleh-colour. The Heart now entered into the cavernes of the Chet, and being guarded by the Sternum, or Bretbone, enjoyes the habitation which himelfe hath erected. The Braine and After-braine grow firm and olid in the Arch of the Cranium or Scull. But the Guts and Giard, are not concluded in the Abdomen, but hang out, being continued and fatned to the ret of the Intrals.

One of the two Veels which are derived to the Navel from the Belly neer the Fundament, is an Artery (as the Pule dicovers) pringing from the Great Artery: the other is a Veine, conveighed from the Yolk by the Guts into the Vena Porta, or Gatevein, at the concavous part of the Liver: for the other Trunck of the Umbilical vesels having received its branches from the White, paeth by the convex part of the Liver, and is inerted into the Vena Cava, or Hollow veine, neer the bais of the Heart.
As thee parts grow daily more conpicuous, o the greater portion of the White is daily conumed; but it is not o with the Yolk, which is hitherto almot entire, and of the ame bulk it was the firt day.

In the ubequent dayes, you may ee the five Umbilical veels, whereof one is a very large veine, ariing from the Hollow veine above the Liver, and cattering branches into the White: the other two veines derived from the Gate-veine (having both the ame original) are dieminated into the two parts of the Yolk; (which we have before decribed) and have two mall Arteries which arie from the Arteries of the loins, accompanying them.

The Chicken doth now poee a greater roome in the egge, then all the other things contained in it: and beginnes to be down-feathered; and the larger the Chicken growes, the more the White diminiheth. And it is worth the obervation, that the membrane of the Colliquamentum, which were have aid is joyned with the outward coate, and with it doth contitute the Secundine, or Chorion) doth now likewie containe all the Yolk, and being grown more contract, doth convey the Yolk
together with the Guts to the Foetus, and faten them to it, and hut them up like a pure, where the trings are drawn together. And though it was ubtile, and tranparent before, yet now as it growes more contract, o it thickens, and becomes more flehy: and at length, like a Hernia intetinalis in the crotum or Cods dilated, it covereth the Guts together with the Yolk, and utaineth them all: till at lat growing narrower by continuall contraction, it contitutes the Abdomen of the Chicken. You may finde the Yolk thus dipoed between the Guts, the belly hanging looer about the 1t day: and yet not o fat rooted, but that the Guts (as it happeneth in the Hernia intetinalis) eaily driven either backward into the belly, or downward into the Scrotum, may be moved up and down together with the Yolk. I have een the Yolk in this manner fall from the belly of a Pigeon, which in the ummer time, had too hatily broke looe from the hell.

About this time the Chicken hath a huge belly, as if it laboured of a Hernia. And now the Colliquamentum by degrees growes troubled and thicke, being altered, and diminihed, (which was before in very great quantity) and the Chicken lies brooding upon the Yolk. And in thoe days, before the Liver attains a bloody complexion, or executes the of office the econd concoction (as they ay) the Gall (which is eparated by the virtue of the Liver, and is an excrement of that econd concoction, as is commonly thought) is now to be een, of a green colour between the Lobes of the Liver. In the Cavity of the Stomack there is a clear Liquor, having the very ame conitence, colour and tat, with the Colliquamentum, in which the Foetus wam; which gliding down the Guts changeth its colour
by degrees, and is converted into Chyle; and at lat jut uch an excrement is dicovered in the lower end of the Guts, as that which the Chickens eject after they are hatched. When the Chickens are more grown, you hall ee the liquor concocted and coagulated in their Stomack: as in Infants that feed on Milk, there is a thick ubtance, which turnes into Whey and Curds.

And now the White being almot pent, and a mall quantity of the Colliquamentum remaining, the Chicken for ome days before excluion, doth no longer wim, (but as we have aid) lies brooding upon the Yolk; and rouling himelfe up in a heap, his Head for the mot part being nuled between his right Legge and Wing, he is compleatly accoutered with Bill, Clawes, Plumes, and other furniture. He ometimes wakes, and ometimes leepes, and tirring himelf, repires and cryes. If you lay the Egge, to your Eare, you hall plainly hear the chicken buling, kicking out his Legs, and according to Aritotle, he will tare upon you, and in his manner cry and complaine. If you let it fall gently into warme water, it will wimme, and the chicken within it, being roued by the ambient heat, will bound and leap, and the egge (as is aid) will tumble up and down. And this is the experiment which women make to prove the fruitful from the barren eggs, for the latter ink in the water. When the White is now clean conumed, a litle before excluion, that other Navel (which as we aid is derived to the White) is obliterated & expunged, or as Aritotle aith, that Navel which is extended to the exteriour Secundine, is looened from the Animal, and falls off. But that which is conveyed to the Yolk, is knit to the mall gut of the chicken.

The firt Excrements that are found in the chicken,
Hit. an. l. 6 c. 3. are white and muddy, like the egge-hell oftned and diolved. And uch alo are to be found out of the Foetus wrapt up in the Secundine. To which Aritotle conents, aying, At that time the Chicken dicharges much excrement to the outward membrane. And a white excrement is dicoverable, not onely within, but without the belly. But in procee of time, when the excluion of the Foetus approathes neerer, the excrement growes greenih, like that which the chicken ejects after excluion. And you may alo perceive in his craw, a part of the Colliquamentum wallowed down, and in his Giord a chiton, or coagulated ubtance.
Nor is the complexion of the Liver hitherto either purple, or anguine, but declining from white to yellow, as the Livers of Fihes, yet the Lungs are anguine.

The Yolk is now concluded in the Abdomen between the Guts: and that not onely while the chicken remaines in the egge, but alo when he is excluded, when he walkes abroad with his Mother to eek his proviion. By which it appears true, which Aritotle o often repeats: That the yolk is intended for the Aliment of the Chicken: for the yolk being hut up within him, the Chicken for the firt dayes after excluion (till his Bill is confirmed and trong enough to divide and prepare his meat, and his Stomack enabled to diget it) feeds upon it: o that it carrieth ome analogy and proportion to milk. Aritotle cats in his uffrage with us, in the place o often recited. Much of the yolk
Hit. an. l. 6. c. 3. doth now lye under the Chicken: which yolk at lat decreaes, and in procee of time, is all turned into the chicken it elfe, in whoe bowels it is contained: o that ten days after the chicken is excluded, if he be
diected, you hall finde even then ome mall remainder of the yolk adhering to his Intetines. Nay I have found ome Reliques of the yolk after the thirtieth day. And, if the argument be of force from the production of the Umbilical veines (which we have hewed to be terminated in the Vena Porta of the Liver, by one or two Trunks) the Chicken is now nourihed by Aliment attracted by the Umbilical veels from the yolk: in the ame manner as he afterward is utained by the chyle drawn out of the Intetines by the Meeraike veins. For the veels on both ides are terminated at the Gate of the Liver, whither they do alike convey the nourihment they draw; that we may not flie to the Vene Lacteae in the Meentery (which in feathered Creatures are no where to be found)

Give me leave to adde omething here, which I have tried often; That I might the better dicern the cituation of the Foetus, and the Liquors after the fourteenth day, to the very excluion: (the greate • part of the White being now exhauted, and the yolk divided) I have boiled an egge till it grew hard, and then pilling away the hell, and eeing the Scituation of the Chicken, I found both the remaining part of the White, and the two parts of the yolk (which as we have aid before, are divided by colliquation caued by the gentle warmth) of the ame conitence, colour, tat, and other accidents, as any other tale egge, thus ordered, i • And upon this Experiment, I did much pondar whence it hould come to pae, that Improlifical Eggs hould, from the adventitious heat of a Sitting Henne, putrifie, and tink; and yet no uch in convenience befall the Prolifical: But both their Liquors (though there be a Chicken in them to • , and he alo with ome Pollution and Excrement)
hould be ound, wholeome, and incorrupt; o that if you eat them in the dark after they are boyled, you cannot ditinguih them from egges that are o prepared, which have never undergon the Hens incubation.

div.head: Of the Excluion, or Birth of the Chicken out of the Egge.
EXERCIT. XXIII.
div.p: THe Egge is (as we have aid) a kind of an expoed Womb, and placed where the Foetus i • formed: for it executes the office of the Matrix, and helters the Chicken till its jut time of Birth: who when he is perfect, is born from thence. Oviparous creatures are therefore not ditinguihed from Viviparous, in this, that thee bring forth their Foetus live, but they do not; (for the Chicken in the Egge doth not onely live and move, but doth breath alo, and exercie a voice, and being born, enjoyes a perfecter life, then the iues of other Animals) but their maine difference con ••• in the manner of Generation; namely, in that Viviparous creatures continue their Womb within them, in which the Foetus is fahioned, cherihed, and compleated: but Oviparous expoe their Egge or Matrix without: yet neverthelee they do ripen and cherih it as much by Incubation, as if they did reerve it within their bowels.

For though the Mother do ometimes upon sundry occaions deers the Egges, yet her affection
continues till with them, and making peedy returns, he receives them in her tender boom, for tereth, and diligently defends them.
But when the Chicken now covets the freer aire, the Shell being parted, he entereth into the world, and this about the one and twentieth, or two and twentieth day.

The Common mitake of Fabricius, and almot all others, concerning this Excluion or Nativity of the Chicken, mut not be paed by. Read Fabricius himelf: The Chicken (aith he) doth want the free aire before it wants meat, becaue there is yet ome aliment pag. 55. reiding within it: in which condition the Chicken being unable to break the hell, in regard the hell is hard, and his hill oft, and alo by reaon of the ditance between them, his bill being heltered under his wing he gives his mother a igne, by which he ignif •• the neceity he tands in to have it broke up, and this •• ne he uttereth by his cry. For the Chicken is at that time oluty, and the cavity o enlarged, and o great a quantity of air contained within it, that his retorations being large, can end forth an exufflation, and cry proper to his kinde, and probably uch a one as doth expres his requet; which alo the tanders by may eaily heare: and this do both Pliny and Aritotle mutually affirm. Which clamour of the Chicken comming
Lib. 10. c. 53. de Hit. an. l. 6. c. 3. to the Hennes care, and he finding a neceity of breaking the hell, that her darling may enjoy the fr ••• aire to continue its life; or, if you will, he being affected with a trong deire to ee her beloved Infan • breaks up the egge with her bill; which is no hard matter to do, ince in that place, by reaon the cavity hath been long detitute of liquor, and hath been much dryed by the aire within it, and the heat without it, <> hell is become more fraile, and brittle. The cry therefore of the Chicken, is the firt and greatet taken of
deire of enlargement, and of the oxigence it tands in •• ant of Air: Which the Henne o exactly understands, that if it o fall out, that he perceive the ••• ckens cry to be low, and inward, then he turns •• egge up ide down with her feet; that he may cleave •• egge jut in that place from whence the voice comes, •• out any injury to the chicken. Hippocrates ad
••
L. de nat. puer. another token of the Chickens inclination to get out <> hell; namely, that the Chicken being now trait
•• for want of utenance, betirres himelf trongly, •• quet of better feeding; and that the Membranes •• ow every where torne a under; and that the Mo
•• dicovering thee violent Motions of her young, •• ratching holes in the Shell, delivers it from bon
•• e.

Thus far Fabricius, pleaantly and elegantly: this arguments are not well bottomed. For •• e found by Experience, that the Chicken it •• (and not the Henne) doth break up the Shell: •• this is alo mot cononant to Reaon. For •• could the egges which are fotered in Stoves •• Ovens (as it is in Aegypt and elewhere) be o
•••• wie broken up? Where there is no Mother to •• the ditreed upplicants, nor redree their brings. And o how can the egges of your Land •• ea-Torties, your fihes, ilkwormes, vipers, and •• bes be unlockt, when either the Iues them
•• are mute and ilent, or ele lye hid under • nd, quite out of hearing. Chickens therefore born by themelves, and break looe from
•• egges by their own indutry. And this I •• prove by infallible Arguments. For in the •• rforation of the Shell, the gap is o litle, • it bears no proportion at all with the Bill of <> , but exactly anwers the chickens; and •• d about the hole (in manner of a coronet)
the Shell tands up in plinters, being always pierced at the ame ditance from the top: and the hivered pieces (epecially if the breach be new made) always jets out erect, and tufted. And as when Glas-Windowes are broken, a man may eaily dicover whether they were burt from within, or without; if he do but take the paines to compare the bent and inclination of the fragments remaining: So alo when the egge is pierced, by the erection of the plinters all along the circuit of the Coronet, it is manifet that the invaion came from within. And I my elf, and many more with me, when we have heard the Chicken grate and crape the Shell with his Claws, have preently een it bored with his Bill, and a circular breach forced through it in the manner of a coronet. I have alo een the chicken bear up the top of the Shell with his Head, and o hake it off. We have been omething large in this ubject, becaue the peculation is not to be contemned: as will appear hereafter. But as for Fabricius, he is eaily anwered: For I grant the chicken hath a voice in the Egge, and perhaps a ignificant petitory voice: But it doth not thence follow that the Henne breaks the Shell, nor that the chickens Bill is o oft, and at o great a ditance, that it cannot penetrate the Shell; epecially ince the Shell, according to his own arguments, is now very brittle. Nor doth the chicken alwayes confine his Head to his Wing, that o he may be made incapable of working his paage, but then only when he is aleep, or ele hath given up the Ghot For ometimes, as Fabricius confeeth, he wake kickes, crapes, oratches, traines the Shell, traggles, tears the membranes that enwrap him, <> (and that he implores help by thee cries, ••
doe not withtand it) and all thee actions may any man hear, that has a mind to it. Wherefore the Hen diligently litening, o oon as he dicovers the voice to be remote, and come from below, he doth not burt the egge, but gently move it to and fro with her foote, till he have procured a more commodious cituation for the prioner. Yet it doth no way appear, that the Pullus doth by his cry ignifie the neceity of his releae from the Shell to his Mother, or deire an enlargement of her procuring, for you may often times, even for two dayes together before excluion hear him cry in the Shell. Nor doth the Henne by the everal removes of the egge, eeke a convenient place to break it up: but as when the ick Infant in the cradle is diquiet, weepes, and roares, his affectionate Mother turnes him from ide to ide, and rocks him till he lye at eae: o likewie the Hen, when he finds her chicken bufling, or crying in the egge: or after his excluion tumbling up and down in a ditempered poture: he preently • arts up, and provides that the weight or heat of her body may not offend him, and moves him from place to place with her Clawes and Bill, till he have procured his eae and quiet.

div.head: Of Twinne-Egges.
EXERCIT. XXIV.
div.p:
THey are called Ova Gemellifica, or Twin-Egges,
de hit. an. l. 6. c. 2. which bring two chickens; being (as Aritotle
<> ) Stocked with two yolks, which in ome are divided
with a lender partition of White, to preerve them from confuion: but in others there is no White at all, but the yolks are contiguous.

I have often een thee Ova Gemellifica or Twin-Egges, where they have had two Whites to every yolk, together with common, and proper membranes repectively embracing them. And I have againe een other egges where the two yolks did cleave to one another, and were both encompaed with one ingle Common White.

There are ome Hennes (aith Aritotle) which bring none but Twinne-Egges, in which the Yolke is clearly dipoed, as we aid before: for a certain Henne in Ibid. two and twenty egges, layed none but Twinne-Egges; except onely thoe that were barren. Now it comes to pas, that one of the Twins is bigger then the other: but the lat is a Monter.

With us ometimes there are Twin-Egges, and the Chickens alo are ometimes Twins too, though very eldome. And for my part I never aw two uch Chickens that both of them lived: but one perihed either in the egge it elf, or in the Excluion. And this alo eems to have befalne Aritotles Chickens, becaue he aith, One was bigger then the other: implying that one of them was hartier then the other, and ooner quickned: but the other weaker, and o les ready to endure excluion: For (I am perwaded that) the two Yolks are of different production, and maturity. And therefore it can hardly be, but that the forwarder Chicken, being now ripe for enlargement, in breaking up the egge, to make way for his own nativity, mut needs induce abortion to his brother: And hould he forbear to break up the egge, his own life were in imminent danger, being now treightned for breath. So that in Excluion, the
one or the other, receives their inevitable doome.

Fabricius either not oberving, or not undertanding pag. 29. thoe words of Aritotle, aith: If there chance to be uch an egge that hath two yolks in it, the Chicken that is produced thence, is born with four legs, and four wings, and two heads, and o becomes a kind of Monter: but the Chickens never come forth o ditinctly two: (as that they may truly be called two) but have onely one main Trunk of body, where two heads, and four legs and the like are adjoyned.

Whence it appears, that himelf never aw, nor heard by others that had een it, that uch kind of Egges produce Twins: and therefore he mut needs be of my mind; namely, that uch egges rarely happen; and that they never exclude two vitall Foetues. Yet I cannot but admire that (if he aw this place of Aritotle) he hould ay, that uch an egg doth never produce two ditinct Chickens, but always a Monter: epecially ince he believes, that the Foetus is formed of the Chalazae, as out of the ubject Matter, and he could not but ee four chalazae in every Gemellifical Egge. I rather believe that when in a Gemellifical Egge there are two Yolkes concluded in the ame White, and are o conjoyned together, that their cicatriculae, while they are opened together, do contitute one Eye (which we call the colliquamentum) a Monter chicken may be then produced, having four Legs, two Heads,
<> . becaue I can ee nothing to hinder it; and uch a one I uppoe was bred of Fabricius his Egge.

Yet nevertheles, where the two yolks are ditinct, and eparate by their proper Coats, and are furnihed with their Grandines, and Whites, and other necearies conducing to the Generation
of the Foetus: I conceive we ought to conclude with Aritotle, that uch an egge as it hath all the parts required to two egges (ave only the Shells) o it obtaines the virtue and power too; and unles it be barren and addle, will for the mot part produce two chickens, but eldom a ingle Monter.

div.head: CERTAIN THEOREMS taken out of the foregoing Hitory of the Egge.
EXERCIT. XXV.
div.p:
THe Hitory of the Hen-Egge, is uch as hath been aid. Wherein we have delivered how the Egge it elfe is generated, and how by its Action (which is Propagation) it formeth the chicken. All which, hath perhaps been ufficiently prolix, and tedious to uch who are not yet acquainted, whither thee o great undertakings, and o exact and accurate Obervations, tend. And therefore I hold it convenient to dicover what fruit and advantage may be reaped by my labour: and hereupon (to ue the expreion of our mot learned Verulamius) we hall proceed to our Second Vintage: collecting certain Theorems out of our former Hitory; ome of which are Infallibly True, ome Doubtful, and mut ubmit to a farther Dicuion: Some are Paradoxical, and contrary to the received opinion: Some of them alo relate
to the Cock, or Male, ome to the Female; ome, to the Egge it elf; and latly, ome to the Formation of the Pullus. Which when we have once throughly dicued, and undertood, Our knowledge and inight into the Generation of all other Animals, will be lee expoed to difficulty, and Errour.

div.head: What an Egge is.
EXERCIT. XXVI.
div.p: THe Theorems, which are employed about the Contemplation of the Egge, ome do teach what an Egge is, ome what its Generation, and others what Parts go to its Contitution.

And firt it is evident, that One Chicken proceeds but from one Egge: which though it be a One Chicken proceeds but from One Egge. kind of an expoed Womb, yet it eldome produces more Chickens then One. And though ometimes it produce two, yet that egge is not to be accounted a ingle, but a double egge; as having obtained both the Nature and Parts of two eggs.
For the egge is a certain Conception proceeding from Male and Female, qualified with the An egge is a Conception. power of both: and out of it being One, one Animal is contituted.

Nor is it the Beginning, but the Fruit alo, and the End; Namely, the Principium, the Beginning Both the Beginning and the Fruit. or Principle of the Ofspring, that is to be generated; but the Fructus, the Fruit of Both Parents; namely, the Cocks and the Hens Work (or End,
which they propoed to themelves in Generation) and the Original of the future foetus. Now, the
De gen. an. l. 1. c. 18. Seed and the Fruit (according to Aritotle) are ditinguihed from one another, under the notion of For
• ar, and Latter: for the Fruit is that which is made • ut of another, and the Seed is that out of which another is made; for otherwie they were both the ame.

The Egge alo eemes to be a kinde of Medium; It is alo a certain Medium. not onely as it is the Principium, and the Finis, but as it is the Common work or production of both Sexes, and compounded of both: which containing in it elf the Matter, and the Efficient or Operative Faculty, it hath the power of both, by which he produceth a Foetus like to One, or the Other. It is alo a Medium, or thing between an Animate and • n Inanimate creature; being neither abolutely impowered with life, nor abolutely without it. It is a Mid-way or Paage between the Parents and the Children; between thoe that were, and thoe that are to come, and the very Hinge and Center about which the Generation of all the Race and Family of Cocks and Hennes doth move, and depend. It is the Terminus à quo, the Point or Original from which all the Cocks and Hennes in the world do arie and pring: and it is alo the Terminus ad quem, the Aim and End propoed by nature, to which they direct themelves all their life long. By which it comes to pas, that all Individuals, while to upply their Species they beget their Like, do continue and perpetuate their duration. The Egge is at were the Period of this Eternity; for it is hard to ay, Whether the Egge be made for the Chickens ake, or the Chicken for the Eggs. Now, which of thee two, namely the Egge or the Henne, have the priority in Nature, or Time, we hall now copiouly handle, when we
come to dicoure of the Generation of all Animals in general.

The Egge alo (which is chiefly to be noted It is alo the Sperma. anwers in proportion to the Seeds of Plants, and hath obtained the ame qualifications with them, o that it may jutly be tiled the Sperma, and Semen, or Seed of the Hennes (as alo the Seeds of Plants may be rightly called Ova Plantarum, the Plants Egges) not onely ex quo, out of which, as out of a ubject Matter; but alo à quo, by which, as by an Efficient caue, the Chicken prings. In which alo there is no part of the Future Foetus, actually
<> it, but yet all the parts of it are in it potentially.

Now, Semen, or Seed properly o called, doth differ from Genitura, Geniture, becaue (according Ibid. The difference between Sperma & Genitura. to Aritotles definition) That is called Genitura, which proceeding from the Male-Parent, is the chief and principle caue of Generation; namely, in f • ll as nature hath deigned to coition; but the emen is that, which proceeds from both Parents in the act of coition, the Seed of all Plants is like to this, and o is the Seed of ome Animals, which have no ditinction of Sex at all, being as it were at the firt a kind of mixture of both Sexes, or promicuous conception, or Animal: for these kind of creatures have in their ingle elves, as much as is required of both Sexes.

An Egge therefore is a Natural Body endowed with an Animal power: namely, with a Principle of Motion, Tranmutation, Ret, and Conervation. And latly, it is uch a thing, as all impediments being removed, it will pae into an Animal: not do heavy bodies, when all obtacles are out of their way, tend downward more naturally; then Seed, and the egge, do by an inbred Natural Propenity incline to become a Plant, or an Animal. And the Seed alo, and the Egge, are the Fr ••
and End, of that very thing, whoe Beginning and Efficient they are.

Of One Chicken there is but One Egge: So Aritotle, Of One Seed is begotten One Body; as for example,
Gen. an. l. 1. c. 20. of One Graine of Wheat, One Eare; of One Egge, one Animal; for a Twinne-egge is Two Eggs.

And o Fabricius aith, Truly: An egge is not onely an expoed Uterus, and place of Generation, but the very thing alo on which the entire Generation of the Chicken depends; which the egge accompliheth, both as Agent, as Matter, as the Place, as the Intrument, and all other things, whatoever are neceary requiites to Generation. He proves it to be in Organum, or Intrument, becaue it conits of everal parts, and that according to Galen, who requires pag. 47. this to the very being of an Intrument, that it be compoed of divers particles, which conpire all to one <> , but under everal capacities, and for everal ues: for ome of thee parts are the chiefe Agent in the Action; ome are neceary Aitants, without which the Action could not be performed at all; others conduce to the more convenient & better performance; and latly, ome againe, to the welfare and preervation of all the ret. And he alo proves it to be an Agent, where he propounds out of Aritotle and Galen, the two actions of the Egge; namely, the Generation, and Augmentation, and Nutrition of the Chicken. And latly, he aith exceeding well, when he affirms, that in the Operations of Nature, the Artificer or Agent, the Intrument, and the Matter are one and the ame thing: So the Liver is both the Efficient, and the Intrument of anguification: and o the other parts of the body: wherefore Aritotle was in the right, aying, It is hard to ditinguih the Agents from the Intruments. In artificial Operations
de gen. an. l. 2. c. 4. indeed the Agent and the Intrument are divided, as
the Smith and his Hammer, the Painter and his P ••
cil. And the reaon is rendered by Galen, becau •• in artificial Operations, the Artificer is without 1. de form. Foet.
Work; but in Natural the Efficient caue is include in the Intruments, and received with intimacy in the very ubtance of the Organ. To which I ad • thoe Perpicuous paages of Aritotle, Of thing that are, ome are caued by nature, and ome by other caues: by Nature do Animals, and their Parts
Phy. l. 1. e. 1. alo Plants, and imple bodies, as the Earth, Fire, <> and Water, conit: For thee and the like, we •• are made by Nature. Now all thee forenamed creatures eem to be differenced from thoe which are not made by Nature. For all thoe things that <> made by Nature, eem to have in themelves a Principle of Motion, and Ret; ome in relation to place ome in relation to increae and diminution, and •• , in relation to alteration. Now a Hore-Litter, and Garment, and all uch kinde of things, according to their everal notions, as farre forth as they are the products of Art, they have no inbred principle of Mutation: but o far as it chances, that they are framed of Stone, or Earth, or bodies compoed of thee, o far they have one. As if Nature were a certain principle and caue, why that thing doth move, and ret, in which it firt is, of it elf, and not by Accident. Now I ay, not by Accident; becaue it may come to pae that a man may be the caue of his own health, in cae he be a Phyitian: Yet he is not in health under the ame Repect, as he is a Phyitian; but it is a men Accident, that the ame Man hould be in Health, and a Phyitian too. And therefore thee two things are ometimes apart. And thus it is in all other artificial things: for none of them have in themelves an Efficient Principle, but ome of them have uch a Principle in others, that are without themelves, as a Houe and
all other Manual Productions: ome indeed have it in themelves, but not by themelves: namely, all thoe things which may by accident become caues to themelves. Nature therefore is that thing which he hath •• eady been aid to be. And all thoe things have • ature in them, which have uch a kind of Principle. And all thoe things are ubtances. For Nature is ever •• me ubject, and in ome ubject.

We have related thee Paages more at large, The Efficient Caue of Generation is in the Egge. and in their Authors own words; that o it may appear, that what we attribute to the egge, is •• ally in it; namely, the Matter, the Organ, the
•• fficient Caue, Place, and what ever ele is required to the Generation of the Pullus. And chiefly, for the clearing of ome mot difficult quetions, <> namely, which is, and what kind of Principle it is, from whence Motion and Generation do pro
•• d? Alo, by what Power the Seed doth act, according to Aritotle? And latly, what it is that • oth inpire and qualifie the Seed with its faecundity? (For Aritotle decrees, that Nature is the Principle of Motion and Ret, Innate in all bodies, •• d not Accidental.) Whether that which in the
• gge, is the Caue Efficient, and Principle of Generation, and of the Vegetative and Vital Operations, be ome Innate thing in it, or omething Added to it? And whether it be in it firt, and by it elfe, as a kinde of Nature: or ele by Accident, as the Phyitian is in the Cure? Whether it be ome In
•• ed, or ome Acquired power which doth tranform the Egge into a Chicken; or nourih it when it was but begun in the Ovary, augmenting, and perfecting, alo preerving it while it is not Set upon by the Henne.

Moreover, what it is that fructifies the egge, whether it be to be called the Soul? or a Part of
the Soul? or ome faculty of the Soul? or ome thing that has a Soul? or an Intellect? or la •• the Deity? becaue it acts for ome end, <> dipoes all things by providence, and <> mitable art, and after an incomprehen ••• manner; and always provides what is bet, b ••• for the being, and well-being; as alo for defence, and ornament. And this not onely in perfect egge which it fructifies, but even in a ubventaneous one too, nourihing, augmenting, and preerving it. And doth not onely upply and nourih the yolk in the Vitellary, but that very le •• peck (whence that proceeds) being of no grea •• magnitude then Millet, or Mutard-eed, which i • feeds and enlarges; and at lat invets it with the White, the Chalazae, the Membranes, and the Sh • ll For it is probable, that even an Improlifical, barr •• egg • , by an innate and inbred principle (though it be contained in the Bowels of the Henne, and adhear to her) doth feed, conerve, augment, alter (in like manner as Fihes and Frogs-egges, which being expoed do grow, and are perfected) and transforme it elf out of a mall Whelke or pe • k into a yolk, and afterward take its journey from the Ovary to the Uterus (though it have no Connexion to the Uterus) and there inrobe it elf in the White; and at lat compleat it elf with the Membranes, Chalazae, and Shel.

But be it what it will, which doth alike both in a Subventaneous, and in a Fruitful, equally produce the ame effects, after the ame manner, and from the ame Caues or Principles; whether it be the ame Soul, or the ame Part of the Soul; in both it is very well worth our inquiry. Now in probability, the ame things do pring from the ame Caues.

Though the egge while it is making, is contained within the Henne, and grows to its parent in Whether the Egge be a Part of the Henne?
<>
Vitellary by the Pedunculus or talk, and is upplied from the Hens veines: yet may it not be • aid to be a Part of its mother, nor to take life and •• getation from her oul, but from its own proper power, and intrinecal principle: As Muh
•• s, Miletoe, and everal kindes of Mos are bred <> of Trees, (which though they adhere to the
• lant, and are utained by the ame ap with its • wn bloomes, and leaves, yet are they not Parts of thoe Trees, nor are they called o. Aritotle to alve thee doubts, allows a Vegetative oul to de gen. an. l. 3. c
• e, even in the very Subventaneous Egge, where he aith, Both Females, and all things that live, have a Vegetative oul, as hath been often aid: Wherefore this • gge (treating of a Subventaneous egge) conidered a • the Conception of a Plant, is perfect, of an Animal, it is Imperfect. And in another place he teacheth the ame thing, enquiring: After what manner
de gen. an. l. 2. c. 4.
•• Subventaneous egges aid to live? for they cannot be aid to live as fruitful egges live: For then an Animal might be produced out of them. Nor are they in the condition of Wood, and Stones; becaue they perih by a kinde of corruption, as things that formerly did in ome ort partake of life. It is certain therefore that they have ome Potential oul: But what Soul is that? doubtlee that Soul which they lat enjoyed, which is a vegetable Soul; for this is indifferently in all Plants as well as Animals.

And yet the ame oul is not in Subventaneous Egges, and in fruitful. For if o, A Chicken might alike be formed out of both. But how their Souls differ, and in what, Aritotle doth not ufficiently declare, in his enquiry, Why all the parts of an egge are framed in a Subventaneous Egge, and
yet an Animal is not procreated thence? Becaue (aith he) it is neceary it hould have a enative oul. As if in fruitful Egges there were a enative oul, beides the vegetative. Unlee you apprehend it thus, that the Vegetative oul is Actually in a fruitful egge, which containes in it a enative oul, in Potentiâ; out of which afterwards an Animal, and the enative parts of an Animal are produced. But this doth not ufficiently alve the cruple, not releae the mind involved in perplexities and doubts. For an Egge eems to be the true Sper ••
of an Animal, according to that of Aritotle. In thoe things that have life, and no ditinction of Sexes,
de gen. an. l. 1. c. 20. the Seed is a kind of Conception already. I call that a Conception (which bears proportion to Seed) which is the mixture of Male and Female; wherefore out of <> Seed proceedeth one Body, v. g. out of one egge <> Animal.

One egge therefore eemes to have one Soul: now What oul is that wherewith the Egge is informed. whether is that Soul the oul of the Henne? or of the Cock? or a mixt oul of Both? For the doubt chiefly concerns thoe egges, which proceed from Animals of a ditinct kind: as out of a dunghill Henne, and a Cock Pheaant. I enquire whether uch an egge participate of the oul of the Henne, or of the Pheaant? or is the oul of the Egge compounded of them both? But how can there be a commixture of ouls, if (according to Aritotle) the oul (as being the form) be an Act, and a Subtance. For no man can deny, but that that thing whatoever it be, which is the Principle and Caue of thoe Effects which we ee produced in a Fertile Egge, is a ubtance uceptible of divers powers, forces, and faculties, as alo of everal conditions, vertues, vices, health, and icknee. For ome Egges are longer lived then others: and ome do
procreate Chickens endowed with the vertues, and oundnee of contitution of the parents; and others produce them inclinable to ditempers. Nor can we for this inconvenience accue the Matter, out of which they are generated, ince the dieaes of the Male are ometimes transferred to the Chickens; who is not concerned any thing at all in the Matter of the egge. For from the Male the Platical and Generative faculty onely doth proceed, which renders the egge fertile, but doth contitute no part of it. For the Geniture which is emitted from the Male in Coition, doth not enter into the Matrix: (where the Egge is formed) Nor (as we have aid before, and Fabricius alo joynes in the Suffrage) can it any way penetrate thoe recees, and much lee the Ovary, which is eated neer the Precincture, or Midriffe of the body, that o it might communicate any portion of the Matter, or any thing at all beides its ingle Vertue. For contant experience tetifies, that one and the ame act of Coition doth fructifie many egges together: and not onely thoe that are exitent in the Uterus and the Ovary; but thoe alo that are not yet begun: as we hall declare hereafter, and have already proved in our Hitory.

If therefore the Egge be rendered Fertile from its own proper oul, or be endowed with an innate The Egge doth not live by the Soul of the Henne. fructifying principle of its own; by which either a dunghil Chicken, or a mongrel-iue between the dunghil-Henne, and the Cock-Pheaant doth arie; and that either Male, or Female, like the Male, or Female-Parent, ound, or ickly; we mut then conclude, that the Egge (even while it is contained in the Ovary) doth not live by the Soul of the
••• ne; but is a freeborn, Independant Iue from <> very firt original: As the Acorne taken off from
the Tree, and the Seed from the Plant, are no longer to be counted parts of them; but creatures, as it were, at their own dipoe; living and ubiting, by an inbred vegetative faculty peculiarly their own.

Now if we affirm that a Fertile Egge hath a oul, a quetion will arie; whether that elf-ame oul, be now at preent in the Egge, and how after, in the Chicken, or whether their ouls be ditinct. For we mut of neceity acknowledge, that ome Principle there is which doth contitute, and nourih the egge; and alo that there is a Principle which produceth and utaineth the Chicken. The quetion therefore is, whether the Principle, or oul of the Egge and Chicken, be one and the ame, or more then one, and divere? For if there be more then one oul; (namely, one which belongs to the Egge, and another to the Chicken) it will be farther enquired, whence, and at what time the Chickens oul arrives to it? And what that is in the Egge, which dilates the Cicatricula raies the Yolk to the top, and produces that Eye, (which we call the Colliquamentum) alters the Contitution of the liquors, and doth predipoe all things for the fabrick and tructure of the Chicken when as yet there is nothing at all of the chicken exitent? Whence alo can we pretend that proper and convenient Aliment is derived to •••
Chicken, to utain and augment it, when there i • yet no Chicken at all? For thee operations •• to belong to the Vegetative oul of the Chicken, •• caue they relate to the Chickens ue; namely ••
nutrition, and Augmentaetion. But now, when the fabrick of the Chicken is in hand, and half-perfected, what is it that makes the Foetus, One •• the ame thing with the Liquors, conjoining the
together by continuity, and concrecence? What is it that feeds, and enlarges the Pullus; that doth vindicate thoe juices which are advantageous to its nourihment from Putrefaction, preparing, melting down, and concocting them?

Since the oul is the Act of an Organical Body, which hath life in Potentiâ, it is an incredible thing that that oul hould be in the Chicken before its body have received any Organization. Nor yet can we believe that the oul of the egge, & the chicken is one and the ame: for the oul is the Preerver of that thing only, whoe oul it is; but the Puttus and the Egge, are two ditinct things; and do exercie not only ditinct vital operations, but Contrary; in o much that one of them eems to reult from the Corruption of the other. May we then ay, that the Caue and Principle of life to them both is one and the ame? namely to the Chicken which is yet but an Embryo, and to the ret of the Egge, as if it were the imple and ingle act of one and the ome body; or as if out of the parts contituting ••• natural body, one oul did pring, which were all in the whole (as they ay) and all in every part. As we finde in the Trunk, Leaves, and Fruits ••• Tree: in which, whereoever we make a eparation or diviion (be it in what part it will) wee ay, that the firt Caue and Principle of that part, •• the ame with that of the Whole, as being the Form and End of the One, but the Principle only of the Other. For o in a Line, in what point oever a diviion be made, it will be the End of the • ore-going part, but the Beginning of the ubequent. And the ame thing may eem to befall in •• lity, and Motion; namely, in every Tranmutation, and Generation.

And o much at preent concerning thee matters:
which we hall more exactly, and more copiouly handle, when we treat in General of the Nature of the Soul of the Foetus, of any Animal whatoever; as alo what it is? From whence, and when it comes? What part it takes firt poeion of? and how it is all in the Whole, and all in every part? And alo how it is the ame, and yet divere? All which we hall determine and reolve out of multiplied experiments.

div.head: That the Egge is not the Production of the Womb, but of the Soul.
EXER. XXVII.
div.p:
AS we conclude (aith Fabricius) the Action of the Stomack to be Chylification; and the action pag. 8. of the Teticles to be the Generation of Seed; becaue the Chyle is found in the Stomack, and Seed in the Teticles: So we poitively reolve, that the Generation of Egges is the action of the Uterus of the Fowle, becaue the egge is found reident there. So then we evidently know, and undertand, which is the Intrument and Place of the Generation of Egges. But <> againe, ince there are two Wombs in a Fowle, th • Superior and Inferior, and thoe much unlike one another, and therefore their Actions are divers, yet it i • apparent which action is peculiar to each. For <> Superior is ordained for the Generation of the Yolk the Inferior of the White, and the other parts, •• the whole, as is evident even to ene: For in the Superior nothing is contained but a throng of Yolks, but
the Inferior the entire perfect egge. And yet this is not all the employment of the Womb; but the Augmentation of the egg, which preently inueth after the egge is generated, and continueth till it be compleated and have attained its jut tature or magnitude, is alo implyed herein. For a Hen doth not naturally lay her egge till it be perfect, and have its jut proportion. The Action therefore of the Womb, is both the Generation and Augmentation of the Egge. Now Augmentation includeth and uppoeth Nutrition. But ince all Generation is effected by two; namely, the Agent, and the Matter: The Agent in the procreation of Egges is nothing ele, but the Intrument or propoed Organs, namely the twofold Uterus. But the Matter is nothing ele but Blood.

Now we, though we acknowledge the Action of the Uterus to be in ome ort the Generation of the Egge, yet we do not agree upon any termes in the world, that the Egge is nourihed and encreaed by the Uterus. And this both for the reaons before alledged, when we dicoured concerning the oul of the Egge, which nouriheth it: and alo becaue it is an improbable thing, that an External Agent (as the Womb is, in regard of the Egge) hould form, nourih, and angment all the interior parts of the Egge, according to their everal dimenions: nay according to Aritotle, it is altogether de gen. an. l. 2. c. 1. impoible. For how can an agent that is extrinecal in repect of the patient, work upon the Aliment that is elewhere provided, and retore it into the place of that which is wated away, according to all dimenions; or how can any thing be affected and altered by that, which doth not touch it? Therefore doubtlee the ame things befall the Generation of Egges, as happen to the exordiums of all living creatures; namely, that they
hould be contituted by ome preexitent external thing; but preently (upon the reception of life) nourih, and augment themelves; and that by • proper inpired efficacy, proceeding from a Principle which is now borne, and implanted in them.

What we have lately delivered concerning the oul, doth eem to evince clearly, that the Egge is neither the Workmanhip of the Uterus, nor controuled or governed by it: For it is apparent that even a Subventaneous egge is furnihed with a Vegetative Soul, becaue we dicover even uch an egge alo to enjoy Vegetation, Nutrition, Augmentation, and Conervation, which are infallible ight of the fore-aid Soul. Now thee faculties cannot iue out of the Mother, or Matrix, becaue the Egge hath no Coherence, or Union to it; but tumbles and roules in its Cavity free, and dijoyned (like a Son who hath obtained his Freedom) and growes up to perfection, as the Seeds of Plants do in the Womb of the Earth, by an internal Vegetative Principle, which can be no lee then a Vegetative Soul.

Much more will it appear, that it hath a Soul, when we conider, after what manner, and by whoe impulion, the Round and Ample Yolk, being new looe from the Vitellary, maketh its decent through the Infundibulum, (which is a lender Tunnel, wrought with a niot thin membrane, which hath no proviion of motory fibres) working out its own way, till through all thoe treights it arrive at the Uterus; where it nouriheth, augmenteth, and invets it elf in the White. And yet all this while, there is no Motory Intrument at all in the Vitellary, which hould expell it thence, nor in the Infundibulum, which hould tranmit
it, or in the Uterus which hould attract it: Nor is the Egge fatned by veins to the Uterus, as in the Ovary, nor hath any dependance upon it by the Umbilical Veels; as Fabricius truely affirms, and is obvious to every eye. What then remains, but that upon dicovery of uch wonderful Operations, we hould cry out with the Poet,

l.hi: Spiritus intus alit, totamque infua per artus

q.l: An innate Spirit feeds, an Infus'd Soul
Into each part, doth the whole Mas controul.

div.p: And though the firt ground-workes of Egges (which we have proved to be but Whelkes, as it were, and of the magnitude of the Seed of Millet) do cohear to the Vitellary by the mediation of Veins and Arteries; (as the Seeds of Plants are born adhearing to the Plants) and thereupon eem to be Parts of the Henne, and to be nourihed and live after the manner of other Parts: yet it is evident, that as the Seeds of Plants being di-united from the Plants, are no more accounted parts of them; no more are Egges, now come to maturity, impowred with fertility, and eparated from the Vitellary, any longer to be ranked amongt the Parts of the Henne, but like a Son come to age, and at his own dipoe, are regulated and enliven'd by their own proper oul.

But of this morefully hearafter, when we hall dicoure concerning the Soul of an Embryo in general; and of the excellence and divinity of the Vegetative Soul, ordering all things after a wonderful manner: (which providence, art, and divine dicretion, as farre exceeding our capacity,
as God excells Man; and therefore are (confeed by all) truly admirable, not to be gazed upon by our cloudy apprehenions, by reaon of their ineffable lutre.

What hall we ay then of thoe litle Animals, which are begotten in our own bodies, which no man ever doubted to be regulated and vegetated by their own proper oul? And of this kind are Worms in the Stomack, Guts, and Fundament, Lice, Nittes, litle Wormes in the Fleh, Mites: Or what hall we reolve concerning thoe Wormes, which proceed from Plants, and their fruit? uch as you may finde in Galls, Nuts, the Scarlet-Berry, and Eglantine, &c. For an Animal may be created almot in all drye things, growing moit, or moit things
Hit. an. l. 5. c. 32 growing drye. It is impoible that thoe Animals which are bred in the Galls hould be enlivened by the Okes oul, though they live joyned to the Oke, and provide their Aliment out of the Sap of the Oke. And o it is credible, that the very Rudiments of the Eggs, while they are yet in the Cluter, do ubit by their own, and not by the Hennes Soul, though they are united to her by Veins and Arteries, and he alo do adminiter nourihment to them. For (as we have oberved in our Hitory) the Whelkes do not all grow at once (as Grapes grow in the Bunch, and Graines in the Eare of Corne) as if they were inpired by the ame concocting and formative faculty; but are increaed one after another; (as by their own efficacie) and that which firt eparates its elfe from its fellowes, changeth colour and conitence, and of a White Whelke is made a Yolke; and o they follow one another in order: And which is more remarkable, in Pigeons, and ome other Birds, they grow up from the Cluter in
paires to make up one Laying, and one of them moves for the mot part a Cock, and the other a Henne. And yet in the meane time ome of the Papulae, or Whelks in the Ovary tay at a tand, till two other grow up for a new production, which have received fecundity from the repeated coition of the Male, and are both inpired with a Soule. Which when they have received, they order themelves, and grow; living at their own, not at their Parents command. For indeed what can you fancie to dipoe, elect, eparate, and perfect thee Papulae, or Whelks (rather then the other) unles it be their own proper oules. For though they aume nourihment from their Parent, yet they doe it no otherwie, then the Plants attract from the Earth, or the Foetus from the Yolke and White.

Latly, becaue the Papula continuing in the Ovary, receives its fecundity from coition, and uch a one too, that it by and by paeth into the forme of the Cock concerned in the coition; (whether it be Dunghill-Cock, or Cock-Pheaant) and ince o great a difference befalls the Papulae, as there is in the males themelves of different kinde, what hall we conclude to be in the Papulae themelves, by whoe virtue they are ditinguihed both from themelves, and their female parent? Doubtles it mut needs be the oule, by which they are diverified both from one another, and from their Mothers alo.

And jut in this manner doe Muhromes, and Plants growing to Trees, live. We dicover likewie often in our own bodies, that Cancers, flehy, and alo phlegmatical Tumors, and uch like wellings, are upplied and fed as it were with their own proper vegetative oules; while in the interim
the true and genuine parts of the Body, doe extenuate and wither: And that becaue thee tumors doe educe all the aliment to themelves, and o defraud the ret of the body of its fotering juyce (as of its Genius) whence they are called Phagedaenae and Lupi, Devouring Cankers and Wolves. And perhaps Hippocrates by his < in non-Latin alphabet > , undertood thoe dieaes, which pring from venom, or contagion; as if they were furnihed with a life, or inpired with a certain divine principle, by which they provide for themelves, and propagate their kinde, and o did beget by contagion ditempers like themelves, in everal peron • . Wherefore (Aritotle aith) Animae plena unt omnia, All things are filled with a oule. And i •
De Gen. an. l. 3. c. 11. Ibid. l. 4. c. 11. another place, he conceives that even Wind hath its life, birth, and deceae. But the yolke, which it is now divorced from the Ovary, and poiled of all commerce with the Henne, then doubtles (a •
beanes and uch like pule derive of their own accord humidity from the Earth, which they imbibe, and diget) paing through the Infundibulum, and reiding now in the Cavity of the Uterus, it doth attract a low thick moiture, which it receives into it elfe, and from it obtaineth nutrition and augmentation, begirts it elfe with the White, and being ingarrioned in the membranes and the hell, is at lat exact and perfect. All which being duely conidered, wee conclude, that it is tored with a peculiar oule of its owne.

div.head: That the Egge is not made without a Henne.
EXERCIT. XXVIII.
div.p: TO omit what ever is in dipute; and to wave all controveries till we come to the General contemplation concerning this ubject; we now proceed to things of more certainty, & more obvious.

And firt it is manifet that an Egge cannot be made fertile, without the help of the Cock and Henne. For without a Cock it cannot be fruitfull, without a Henne it cannot be at all. And this is oppoite to that opinion, which deduceth the firt rie and fabrick of all living creatures out of the clay of the Earth. For ince the everal parts of Generation (namely the Teticles and Leading Veels in the Cock) are formed with uch eminent Art, Indutry, and Reaon, and likewie the Ovary and Uterus in the Henne, together with the Veines and Arteries which are ubervient to them, are o skilfully compoed, and the ituation, figure, and temper of every particular, are dipoed in a miraculous method; and all thee things are ome way or other required to the generation and fecundity of the egge: mot certain it is (for nature makes nothing in vain, nor doth he go to work by digreions, where he may be more compendious in her dipatch) that an egge cannot be any other way produced, then now it is, (namely, by a cock & a hen) neither by nature of her own accord, nor by any other means whatever; nor can either cock or hen be produced, but fro¯ an Egge. So that the cock & the hen are made for the Eggsake, and likewie the Egge for the Cock and Hens ake: and
you may be jutly doubtfull with Plutarch, which of thee is firt, namely the Egge, or the Henne For he was firt in order of Nature, but the Egge i • order of Time. For whatoever excells, is firt in order of Nature; but that from which another i • produced, is firt in order of Time. Or ele we may ay, That that Egge from which this or that particular Henne prung, is of more Antiquity th •• the Henne: and o on the contrary, That Hens which produceth this particular Egge, is elder then it. For this Viciitude and Circuite perpetuate the Race of Cockes and Hennes; while now the Chicken, and now the Egge by a contant eries and return do continue an Immortal Species, out of the decay and ruines of the Individuals. And after this ort do many ublunary creatures emulate and approach to the Perpetuity of Celetial bodies.

And whether we affirm a oul to be in the egge or not, yet by this circumvolution it appears, that there is ome principle of the vicititude from the Henne to the Egge, and again from the Egge to the Henne, which conferrs a empiternity unto them. And that very thing (aith Aritotle) beareth an Analogie to the ubtance of Starres; and caueth the Parents to propagate, and their eed, or eggs, to be de gen. an. l. 2. c. 3. prolifical: and is like Proteus, diguied in everal formes, ever exitent both in the Parents, and in the Egges. For as that Minde or Spirit which rules the world, doth continually reduce the ame Riing and Setting Sun from everal Quarters and Regions of the Earth: o alo in the Progeny of Cocks and Henns, the Vis Enthea, or divine Principle, which is now called the Platical, ometimes the Nutritive, and ometimes the Augmentatin Power or Virtue, is alo ever conceived to be the
Conervative, and Vegetative too: and now putting on the form of the egge, and now of the Chicken, continues for ever. And though ome Animals are born of their own Accord, or (as they commonly ay) of Putrefaction: and others only produced from a Female (as Pliny notes in ome kinde of Lib. 9. c. 16. living creatures there is no Male at all; as in the Ruffes, and the Roches: for they are all taken great with pawn) yet whatoever is produced from a perfect egge, doth not proceed but from both Sexes.

And therefore, aith Aritotle, The Male and the
de gen. an. l. 1. c. 2. Female are chiefly to be counted the Principles of Generation. The Cock therefore and the Henne are the two firt Principles of the egge; the fruit, or common conception of both which is the egge, containing in it the virtue of both Parents. So that an egge can no more be made without the aitance of the Cock and Henne, then the fruit can be made without the Trees aid. And each particular Individuum, both Cock and Henne, eems to be created for the egges ake, that the ame Species may be prolonged, though by the ruine and obequies of the Authors. And it is alo clear, that the Parents are no longer youthfull, beautifull, complete and Jovial, then they can generate, or fructifie their eggs, and produce their own like, by the mediation of thoe eggs. Which work of nature o oon as they have accomplihed, as if then they had attained the highet < in non-Latin alphabet > , or Pitch of their perfection, and lat end for which they were born, they preently wither, grow old, and Emerit, and as if God and Nature had foraken them, they decline peedily, and haten to their end, like creatures weary of their lives. Whereas on the contrary, the Males when they arm themelves, and are in all repects
well appointed for Loves encounter, how trangly doth the potent Cupid heighten their enflamed pirits, how pruce are they, how do they pride it; how vigorous, how tety are they, and prone to conflicts! But when this office and performance ceaeth: oh! how oon doth their force abate, and their late fury coole! how doe they hale in all their welling ails, and check their darings? Nay even while this jocund Sacrifice to Venus is in eaon, no ooner is the act performed, but they grow tame and puillanimous; as if it were then deep printed in their thoughts, that while they impart a life to others, they are in full career to their own urnes. Onely our Cock, full fraught with eed and pirits, approves himelfe the onely cheerfull loer, and with the plaudit of his wings and voice, crownes his pat triumphs, and lights his wedding Torch at his own Cinders. And yet he alo flags after long game, and like an Emerit ouldier reignes his Commiion. And o the Hens likewie, like Plants worn out, grow decayed Matrons, and fore-go their Nureries.

div.head: How a perfect and fruitfull Egge is produced by Male and Female, according to Aritotle.
EXERCIT. XXIX.
div.p:
WEe have lately aid, that an Egge, epecially a fruitful one, is no pontaneous iue; nor doth proceed from any thing but a Hen, nor yet a fruitfull one from her neither, without her intercoure with a Cock: According to that of Aritotle; We are to conclude, that male and female
De gen. an. l. 1. c. 2. are the chief principles of Generation: the Male, becaue he hath the preeminence in the original of the Motus and Generation, the Female in the original of the Matter.

Now according to our deciion, A fertile egge is truly a perme, and genit all eed, Analagous to the eed of Plants, and the firt conception reulting from both Parents, and the promicuous production of them both. For as an Egge cannot have a being without a Hen, o it cannot have fecundity without a Cock.

It remaines therefore that we enquire, how the egge is made by the hen, and how it is made fertile by the Cock; for we ee that ubventaneous egges, and thoe animate too, are produced by the hen: but yet are not prolifical without the Cock. And therefore both Cock and Hen lay their tock together to contitute a fertile egge. And yet (as I conceive) not in that manner as Aritotle would have it; namely, that the Male hould be Mater only of the original of the Matus and Generation: and
the Female onely contribute the Matter. For the contrary appears in Subventaneous egges: And tho •• it be true, where he aith: The Male and Female are different according to reaon, becaue their faculties are divere, and according to ene, becaue ome • of their parts are divers too. The difference between them according to reaon conits in this, that the Male is that creature which doth generate in another; the Female is that, which generates in it elfe, and out of which, that which is generated is made, being contained in that which doth generate it. But ince thee <> ditinguihed by the diverity of the Faculty, and of the Office or imployment; and every performance of <> office requires an intrument; and the parts of the body are commodious intruments to the faculties; it i • neceary that ome parts hould be accommodated for procreation and Coition; and that thoe parts hould be different too, that o the Male and Female may be ditinguihed.

Yet it doth not thence follow, which he ee • deirous to infer, aying: The Male is the Efficient and by the vertue of its Geniture doth produce that which is deigned out of the Matter conteined in <> Female: and the Female doth always contribute the Matter. So that it is neceary that the Female hould contribute the Body, and the Quantity or Magnitude, but there is no uch thing required at the males hand. Nor is it neceary that the Intruments, or the Efficient it elf hould be in thoe things that are produ ••• by them. The Body therefore proceeds from the female, and the oul from the male. For the Subtance of <> Body is the oul. For an egge, and that an anima •• one too, is produced by the Hen alone, without the Cock. Whence it appears, that the Female <>
Hen is alo the Efficient caue; and that all power of Production, or the Soul doth not proceed <>
the Male. And this the example urged by Aritotle eemes to confirm: for he aith. Thoe creatures
De gen. an. l. 2. c. 4. that proceed to Coition, and • re not of the ame kind (which they do, whoe eaon is alike, and time of hearing, together neer at hand, and do not much differ in the dimenions of their bodies) do bring forth their firt iues like to themelves, partaking of the Species of both kindes: as thoe that are begotten by a Wolfe and a Bitch, or by a Partridge and the Dunghil
• rood: but in proces of time, thee divere Parents, produce a divere iue, the off-pring at length auming like form with the Hen, as forraigne Seed is at lat transformed according to the Nature of the Soile where it growes, for the Soile contributes matter and Body to the Seed.

By which words it is manifet, that in the Generation between a Cock-Partridge and a Dunghil-Hen, the Male is not the ole efficient, but the Female is concerned too: becaue a Common Species and form, and not that of the Male onely, is produced; being alike, both in Body, and Soul, as well to the Female as the Male. Now the Soul •• the Forme and Species of an Animal.

And againe: the Female may eem to have mot • ight to the title of Efficient, for he aith, in Pro
•• e of time, thee divere Parents produce a divere <> , the off-pring at length auming like form with the Hen. As if the Seed of the Male were lee powerful; and did in time loe the Species which it imprints; as being razed out and expunged by <> more potent Efficient. And this that intance concerning the oil doth more trengthen: For,
•• reign Seed is at lat transformed according to the •• ture of the oile where it growes. By all which it <> probable, that the Female is a tronger <> in Generation, then the Male: For in the
Univere likewie, the Earth is held to be, as it were, the Female and the Mother: But the Heavens and the
De gen. an. l. 1. c. 2. Sun, and the other Bodies of that kind, Philoopher • call by the name of Father and Genitor. Now the Earth alo produceth many things of its own accord, without any Seed: And amongt Animals, ome Females do procreate of themelves without a Male; (thus the Henne generates a Subventaneous Egge) but the Male never begetteth any thing without a Female.

Nay by thoe very Arguments which contend to prove the Male to be the Principle of Generation, and the primary Efficient; the energy or efficiency of the Female eems to be confirmed, and ratified: For that is to be counted the Primary Efficient, in which the reaon of the foetus, and form of the Production is mot eminent; and whoe apparent imilitude is dicovered in the foetus, and alo which hath an exitence it elf before, and then generates. Since therefore, the Form, Reaon, and Similitude of thè foetus is no lee (not more) in the Female then in the Male; and he alo is in being before, as a Primary Mover: We may well conclude, that the Female is as eminent an Efficient of Generation, as the Male.

And though Aritotle truly ay, that the Conception or egge aumes no part of its body from the Male, but onely its form, pecies, and oul, and that the Female contributes onely the body, and quantity
de gen. an. l. 2. c. 4. Yet it doth no way appear to the contrary, <> that the Female doth contribute in ome •• both Form, Species, and Soul, (and not the Ma •• ingly) As is evident in the Hen, which produ •• Egges without a Male (as the Trees beare the Fruits, Herbs and Seed without any ditinction of Sexes at all.) And Aritotle himelf confe •
that even a Subventaneous Egge hath a Soul. The Female therefore mut be the Efficient Caue of the Ibid. Egge.

And yet though there be a Soul in the Subventaneous Egge, yet that Soul is not Prolifical; and therefore we mut acknowledge that the Henne is not properly the Efficient of a Perfect Egge, but that he is o made, by Authority and Commiion procured from the Cock. For an Egge, except it be Prolifical, cannot jutly be aid to be Perfect. Now uch an Egge is produced onely by the Male; or rather by the Henne, having received uch intructions from the Cock; as if from his Coition, the Female did receive the Art, Reaon, Forme, lawes, Rule and Model of the future Foetus. Thus the Female (like a fruitful Tree) being made fertile by Coition, is made Oviparous, bearing perfect and Prolifical Egges. For though the Henne have at preent no rudiment of Egges at all ready in the Ovary, yet being fructified upon Coition, • he uddainly after, both hath, and layes Egges; and thoe alo Prolifical ones. And here the experiment of poor Women is of ue; Which having a Hen at home, but never a Cock, they commit her for a
Fabric. pag. 37. day or two to a neighbours Cock: and from that mall communication, all her egges ucceed fruitful, for all that eon.

That is, not onely thoe Egges, which now are Yolks, and onely want a White, or ele have ome Rudiment of their future growth, though never o litle; but even thoe Egges alo which are not yet begun at all, and are to be conceived a great while hence, are all rendered fruitfull by the ame vertue.

div.head: The Benefit of this Diquiition con. cerning Fecundity.
EXERCIT. XXX.
div.p:
THe Diquiition wherein we examine, What it is in the Egge that renders it fruitful? is very ubtle, and difficult, and of exceeding great ue: As alo what is in the Conception, what in the Seed, and what in the Hen that confers Fecundity upon them: Likewie what in the Cock ditinguiheth him from a barren cock? Is it the ame caue, which we call the Soule in the Foetus? or ome part of the Vegetative Soul? For the knowledge of the Firt Caue conduceth much to the compleat cience of Generation: For Science prings from Known Caues, epecially thoe that are the firt Caues. Nor is this indagation lee ueful to the knowledge of the Nature of the Soul. But when once the verity of this is throughly dicovered, not onely Aritotles opinion concerning the Caues of Generation is refuted, and chatied; but even thoe things alo which Phyitians have written againt him, are eaily diproved. Our Quere therefore is, whether that which affords the Fertility to the Egge, Yolk, Papula, or Whelke, Cock, Hen, and to its Womb, be one and the ame thing, or divere? Likewie whether it be a Subtance from whence this vertue flowes? For it eems to be uceptible of Powers, Faculties, and Accidents. Or whether it be alo a Corporeal thing For that eems to be mixt it elf, which generates a mixt thing; namely a imilitude common to both Cock and Hen; uch as is that ambiguous Species produced by a Cock-Pheant and a Dung bil
Hen. It eems alo to be a Corporeal thing, which uffers from without; in o much that it doth not onely produce feeble iues, but deformed alo, and ickly ones, and uch as are obnoxious to, and do inherit the Virtues, and Vices of their Parents.

We may alo make a quetion concerning each particular, whether that which confers the Fertility, be ingenerated, or comes from without? Namely, whether it be transferred from the Egge to the Chicken; from the Hen to the Egge, and from the Cock to the Hen. For it eemes to be a thing ex Traduce; namely, which is transferred from the Cock to the Hen; and from Her to the Egge, the Womb, and the Ovary: From the Seed to the Plant, and back again from the Plant to the Seed. For this is common to all things that are perpetuated by Generation; namely, that their firt rie hould reult from Seed. Now the Seed, the Conception, and the Egge are all of one and the ame kinde, and that which renders thee Fruitful, is in all of them the ame thing, or omething of a like nature; and that is ome divine thing, and hath an analogy to the Heavens, to Art, Intellect, and Providence. As is plain by the wonderful operations, artifice and counel of thoe creatures, in whom nothing is contituted in vain, rahly, or by chance, but all for ome Good, and to ome End. We hall hereafter be more ample, concerning the Univeral Speculation, and knowledge of this thing: Having already poken as far as occaion hath preented it elf to dicoure of it by the by, in order to the Hen-Egge. Namely, how many things is that thing in, which brings Fecundity? and how is it in them? whether as an Accident, as either an Affection, a Habit, a Power,
or a Faculty? or as a Forme, and a Subtance or as a thing Contained in a thing Containing or as a thing reerved in ome peculiar part? For it is mot certain, that the very Subventaneous egge is compleat in all parts as far as ene can dicover, and yet it is Barren: and likewie, that the Uterus, and alo the Hen are perfect, and o is the Cock; and yet they all were barren, were they deprived of that which conveys their Fecundity to them. All which we hall relate, after we have expounded, What, and How, the two Principles, Male and Female, do confer to the Egge, and to Generation; and likewie in what manner they may both be called the Efficient Caues and Parents of the egge.

div.head: That the Egge doth not proceed from the Cock and Henne, after that manner which Aritotle would deigne.
EXERCIT. XXXI.
div.p: IT is mot certain, that the Fertile Egge cannot be made, but by both Cock and Hen: and yet not in that fahion as Aritotle thought, as if forooth, the Cock alone were the prime Efficient, and the Hen did contribute nothing but the Stuff, or Materials.

For I am not of his mind, where he aith: When the Seed of the Male enters into the Womb of the
de gen. an. l. 1. c. 4.
Female, it doth reduce the puret part of the Excrement into a conitence: and a litle after. But when the excrement of the Female is in the Womb, it is made by the Geniture of the Male, like to congulated Milke. For that Coagulum is Milke conteining vital Heat, which carrieth parts that are alike, the ame way together, uniting, and joyning them. Now the Geniture ••• eanes it elf jut o towards the Mentrua, or excrement. For the nature of the Mentrua and of Milk is the ame. Therefore the parts being gathered together, the corpulent humour is dicarded, and upon the • refaction of the more earthy part, the Membranes reult to encompas the whole; and this upon neceity, and to ome intent and ue beides. And thee things proceed in the ame manner, as well in all Oviparous, as Viviparous Animals.

But the matter is much otherwie, in the generation of the Egge. For the Seed (or Geniture rather) proceeding from the Male in Coition, can by no means enter the Womb. Nor hath the Hen after Conception, any excrementitious ubtance, or purer part of any uch ubtance, or any Blood at all in the Cavity of the Womb, which might receive perfection from the Geniture of the Male. Nor are the Parts of the Egge (namely the membranes and the Liquors) procured by any kind of Coagulation; nor is there found any thing like Coagulated Milk, as is clear and evident out of what hath paed. And hence it follows, that neither the Conception (out of which the Animal prings, as out of Fertile Seed) is after that manner as Aritotle imagined: For the Conception is after the ame manner in Viviparous, as the Egge is produced in Oviparous creatures: as himelfe confees, and hall anon appear in ome of our Obervations. For it is a certain truth, that the
Egge, be it barren, or fertile, is made and formed by the Hen alone: onely the fertility indeed is derived from the Cock. I poitively affirme, that the Cock conferres neither Matter nor Form to the Egge; but onely that thing by which the Egge is Fertile, and made fit and capable to produce a Chicken. And this Faculty the Cock imparts by his Geniture, dicharged in Coition; not onely to the Egge which is then begun, or already made, but to the Womb alo, and the Ovary, and likewie to the Hen her elf: and that after uch a manner, that the egges which are yet to come (of which there is now no particle in being either in the Ovary, or any other part of the Body) hall have the happinee to be fruitful by it.

div.head: Nor after that manner which Phyitians phanie.
EXER. XXXII.
div.p:
THe Conception according to the opinion of Phyitians is thus: In Coition the Male and Female being both delighted, do eject their Geniture, or Seed into the Cavity of the Womb; and there their united tock or contribution is mingled together; obtaining from both the potentiality of Matter, and the activity or force of the Efficient caue. And that o it comes to pae, as the Geniture of this or that Parent hall get the upper hand, the conception proves either Male or Female. And they farther uppoe, that immediately after Coition (the
Active and Paive ingredients now cooperating together) omething of the Conception is put in • and, and begun.

They till affirming, contrary to thoe who ide with Aritotle, that the Male is no more the Efficient caue of Generation, then the Female, but omething compounded of them both: & likewie, that neither the Mentruous Blood, nor the puret part of it; but the Sperm it elf is the firt Matter of the Conception: and upon this ground, they call the firt ground-works, or firt parts of the Conception, Spermatical Parts; which are afterwards to be nourihed and upplied by Blood.

But the thing is plain, that this alo is not the manner, by which the egge is produced by the Cock and Henne.
