For the Hen doth emit no Seed at all in Coition, out of which the egge may bee framed: nay more then this, there is no part of her Seed to be any where found: for he is quite detitute of all parts neceary to the Generation of Seed; namely, of Teticles, and Spermatical Veels. For though the Hen hath an Efficient power together with the Cock, (as appears by our former dicoure) and that power which renders the egge fertile, be in ome ort a mixt power; yet this proceeds not from the over-ruling force of the Genitures, or from the manner of their mixture: for it is very certain (and Fabricius confees it) that the Cocks Seed enters not into the Cavity of the Womb: nor is there any particle of the egge made in the Womb preently upon Coition; though Aritotle generally affirms there is, (aying, that ome part of the Conception doth forthwith inue) Nay I hall demontrate hereafter, that this commixture of Seeds doth never obtain in any Animal whatoever; and that preently after Coition (though it ucceed and
be fruitful) there is no particle of Seed, or Blood or of any begun or attempted Conception, really in the Womb, or to be found there. Nor is there in truth any thing to be dicerned, in the Conception or Egge, that may any ways argue the Seed the Male to be conteined, or mingled in it. The Common people indeed do fally conceive, that the Chalazae are the Cocks Seed: and I much wonder, that ince there are two of them (in each extremity of the egge, one,) that no man hath hither to fondly pronounced, that the one was the Cock, and the other the Hens Seed. But this popular error is oon blown over; for the Chalazae are a like manner found, both in the Subventaneous, and Fertile egge.

div.head: That both the Male and Female, are the Efficients of Generation.
EXERCIT. XXXIII.
div.p:
THe Phyitians do rightly maintain againt the Aritotelians, that both Sexes participate •• the Efficient power; becaue that which is generated, is a thing compounded of them both: for it is mixt of them both, in the figure and imilitude of the Body, and in the Species too; as uppoe it a thing mixt between a Partridge-Cock, and a Dunghil-Hen. And it is very cononant to reaon, for a man to conceive, that thoe are the Efficient caues of a Conception, whoe com-m ••
ture that which is produced, doth repreent and expres.

And this is Aritotles opinion. In ome creatures, aith he, it is apparent that, that which generates is
Metaphy. l. 7. c. 8. uch like, as that which is generated: and yet not the • ame, not that very numerical thing, but of the ame Species, as in natural productions. For a Man begets • man, unles omething befal praeturnatural; as when •• Hore begets a Mule, and the like. For that which is common to a Hore and an As, is not called Propinquiimum genus, the Next Kind: and yet they two may be commixed in one, for uch is a Mule. And in the ame place he aith; The Generant is ufficient to generate, and be the caue of the exitence of the Species in the matter: but uch a Species being now in uch particular fleh and Bones, is now everal perons, is Callias, and Socrates are.

Wherefore ince uch an entire forme, as namely of a Mule, is mixt of both; namely, Hore and Ae: the Hore alone is not ufficient to produce this form of a Mule in the Matter; but as the whole entire form is mixt, o another efficient caue mut be conferred and joyned to it from the Ae. That therefore that doth produce a Mule mixed of both, mut be it elf adequate, and mixed too, if it be Univocal. As for example. This Man and that Woman, do beget this Socrates; not under the capacity of being both of them Homines, Men, and o are of one and the ame pecies; but by reaon, that this particular Man, and that particular Woman, are of humane kind, compoed of this and that particular fleh, and bones: of both which ince ocrates is a kind of Mixture, and is mingled of them both; that of which Socrates is made, mut needs be as it were a compounded Univocal mixt •• ing; that is to ay, the mixt Efficient of a mixt Effect. And therefore the Male and Female, are not generative apart, but as they are united in
Coition, and made, as it were, one entire Animals and thence from them both, as from one, the true efficient immediate caue of the Conception doth reult, and is deduced.

The Phyitians alo, while they, minding onely what befalls humane kind, give reolutions at large concerning Generation in general; and it eeming probable to them, that the Geniture flowing in Coition from both Parents, is the true Sperme or Seed, proportionable to the Seed of Plants; doe not without reaon contitute that mixture which is the next efficient caue of the future Foetus, out of the mixture of the Seed of both Parents: and therefore affirme, that uch a mixt body is conteined in the Womb preently upon Coition, and is the firt Conception. But our precedent Hitory makes it appear, that the thing is clean otherwie in an Egge (which is a true Conception.)

div.head: Concerning the Matter of the Egge, contrary to Phyitians and Aritotelians.
EXERCIT. XXXIV.
div.p:
THat which Phyitians deny in oppoition to the Aritotelians, namely that the Blood is the Firt Matter of the Conception, doth evidently appear out of the Generation of the Egge. For there is no Blood at all conteined in the Womb of the Hen, either in Coition, or before, or after it:
Nor are the Rudiments of the Egge anguine, but white. And many living Creatures conceive, in whoe Genitals (if you open them nimbly) not one drop of Blood is to be een.

But while they contend, that the Mothers Blood is the Nutriment of the Foetus in the Womb, epecially of the Partes Sanguineae, the bloody parts (as they call them) and that the Foetus at firt, as if it were a part of the Mother, is utained by her blood, and quickened by her pirits: in o much that the Heart beats not, and the Liver anguifies not; nor any part of the foetus doth execute any publick function; but all of them make Holy-day and lie idle; in this Experience it elfe confutes them. For the Chicken in the egge enjoyes his own Blood, which is bred of the liquors contained within the egge; and his Heart hath its motion from the very beginning: and he borrowth nothing, either blood, or pirits, from the Hen, towards the Contitution either of the Sanguineous parts, or Plumes; as thoe that trictly oberve it may plainly perceive. And I make no quetion, fully to demontrate in my ucceeding Obervations, that the foetus of Viviparous creatures, while they are yet imprioned in the Womb, are no way utained by the Mothers blood, nor vegetated by her pirits, but do rejoice in their own Soules and indowments, (as the Chicken ues to do in the egg) and ate themelves from their owne tocke of Blood.

But as for that which concerns the Matter of the foetus, ariing from Male and Female, and that o magnified manner of Generation, o much countenanced by the confident Schools (namely, that the Conception is rendered prolifical from the com
•• ture of the Genitures, and their mutual Action
and Paion) as alo thoe other Hereies of their concerning the Seed of Females, and concerning the diviion of Parts into Spermatical, and Sanguineous; many, and thoe very remarkable and excellent obervations, which hall be treated •• hereafter, have compelled me to dient from them. I hall at preent ay onely this, that I extreamly wonder, how Phyitians (epecially uch as are skilfull Anatomits) hould prop up their opinion upon two arguments, as mot invincible • when thoe very arguments, if rightly undertood • do make againt them rather.

As for Intance. From that Concuion, Solution and Profuion of Humour (which befalls Women many times with delight, in Coition) they conclude • that all Women do emit a Semen in Coition, and that that Semen is neceary to Generation. Whereas, to pae by this reply, namely, that the Female of all Animals, nay all Women have not uch a Profuion; and that it is no way neceary that th ••
Conception mut be frutrate without it: (for • know many Women that are Mothers without it, and ome alo, which upon having it, were indeed much affected with enjoyment, but came much hort of their former fruitfulnee: Beides infinite and innumerable examples of Women, wh •• though they receive much atisfaction by their Husbands, do yet emit nothing, but do conceive how ever) But I mot admire that thoe, who com • this Emiion neceary to Propágation, did not mind how that humour is ejected clean out, and lot for the mot part neer the Clitoris, and out ••• of the Secrets; but is eldom admitted into them and never into the Uterus, that o it may be come mixt with the Sperma of the Male; and that it alo of an Ichorous, and Serous conitence,
<> is, and not o Compact and Unctuous as ••
Geniture, which the very touch denoteth.

Now wherefore hould that be excluded out of <> , which is of o great conequence within? <> that humour, under pretence of departure, thrown out to the utmot approaches of the U
•• , that o it may be recalled again with the •• ter bounty and favour?

Another Argument they erect upon the Spermatical Organs of Women; namely, the Teticuli, and ••
Spermatical preparing, and leading Veels, which <> uppoed to conduce to the Generation of the
<> .

But for my part I wonder much, how they fan
•• that o elaborate, concocted, and quickening
•• men, can arie from o imperfect and obcure <> , o that, that of theirs (when the controverie concerning the preeminence and overruling •• wer is in debate; namely, whether the Males or • eirs commands in chief, and which of the two •• to be reputed the Efficient, or Agent, or the Mat
•• , or Patient) hould exceed the Males in power, <> , and generative ability; and hould ubject the Males eed under it, inforcing it to ubmit it elf to upply the place of the Material Caue, notwithtanding it is digeted by o quick & active • heat, refined in uch variety of Veels, and daring it elf with o much activity. But of thee more hereafter.

In the mean time it is mot certain, that the hen-egge is generated by no uch conjugal Profu
••• : though the Mother after recreation (as one • ihed with delight) hakes her feathers for Ioy, • nd as if he grew proud from the Boone he received, compoeth and rectifieth all her extravagant <> : like one that adored the deity for the
grand benediction of multiplying iues. Tha •
Pigeon (epecially that kind of Pigeon which <> tranported hither out of Africa) expreeth wonderful content from the enioyment of her Male, leaping, and preading her taile, and weeping the low earth with the britles of it, and them combing and rectifying her Plumes with her Bill; as though he deemed nothing comparable to the bleing of fertility.

We have aid before, that the firt matter of the Egge is not formed of Blood, as Aritotle thought; nor yet as the Phyitians conjecture, out of the commixture of the Males and Females Geniture. But from whence we do derive it, is partly already hewen in our Hitory, and hall be more largely explained hereafter, when we treat in generall of the matter which doth contitute every foetus.

div.head: How far the Henne is an Efficient Caue in the Generation of the Egge, according to Aritotle: and why the aitance of the Male is required.
EXER. XXXV.
div.p:
WE have already proved the Cock and Henne to be the two Principles of Generation in regard of the Egge, though we are otherwie p ••• waded of the manner how it comes to pae, <>
Aritotle and Phyitians are. For we have made it manifet out of the generation of the Egge, that the Hen as well as the Cock is an efficient caue, and hath in her a principle from whence the mutation suceeds, and alo a contituting faculty: though •
Coition, neither the Cock doth confer matter to •• e Egge, nor doth any profuion of eed reult •• om the Hen, by which the Egg hould arie. It •• therefore evident, that nature (amongt ome Animals at leat) did not therefore intitute a ditinction of Sexes; that the one (as an Agent) hould contribute the form, and the other (as the Patient) the matter, as Aritotle did conceive: nor that a emen hould reult from both in coition, that about of the mixture of them, a Conception, or Egg hould be framed, as Phyitians imagine.

Now ince thee two opinions doe comprehend the whole Legend of Antiquity, concerning the caues and principles of Generation: it appears that all men were hitherto ignorant of the reaon, doth why the female doth not generate alone by her elfe (as Plants doe) but requires the aocition of the male: and alo how the conception, or
• gge is procreated both by male and female thus enjoyned: and likewie in what either of them enduce to the work, and to what end and purpoe coition was intituted.

Aritotle, contrary to his own univeral Hypotais (namely, That the male is the Agent, and the female only for the matters ake) perceiving the egg
•• proceed from the Hen without any help of the
• ack at all, was inforced to ubcribe, that the female alo is an efficient caue: and that the Egge,
• hen it is excluded, doth conerve, nourih, and •• ment it elfe, and produce a foetus out of it <> : (as the egges, or pawn of fihes doe) and
therefore he concludes, that there is alo a oule even in a ubventaneous, barren egg. And how far forth the Female is an Efficient, and alo a ubventaneous egge informed by a oule, he attempts to explain, where he aith. Subventaneous eggs admit Generation as far as they may; but that they
de gen. an. l. 3. c. 7. hould be compleated to the very fecundity of an Animal, is quite impoible; for to that a enitive oule is required. But even females, and all things that live at all do obtain the vegetative faculty of the oul, as hath bin often repeated. And therefore this barren egg conidered as the conception of a Plant, is compleat, but conidered as an Animals, it is incompleat. By which words he eems to conent, that the Vegetative oule is alo in the very ubventaneous egge, becaue that oule is in all living things; now an egge doth live. He alo allowes the Hen a creating Prerogative, and a power of inducing a Vegetative oule: becaue all females have that priviledge: and therefore a ubventaneous egge conidered under the capacity of a Plant, and living as that doth, is tiled a perfect conception, but under the rank of Animals, an imperfect one. A • if the male were no whit requiite to the being of the perfect conception or egge, but onely that, out of that egg an Animal might proceed: Not to the complement of the egge, in order to any perquiite relating to its own perfection (for the conceptions of plants themelves are in this ene compleat) but that it may be endowed with a •
Animal principle. So then, the Egg is made by the Hen, but is made prolifical by the Cock. Aritatle in the ame place goes on: In all the Genealogy •• Birds, there is a male and a female; o that a Hen may make her conception perfect, as a Plant, though is be unalterod by coition: but as an Animal, he cannot
perfect it; nor can he impower it to produce any other thing out of it. Nor is it rendred as the fruit of a Plant imply, nor as of an Animal, by coition. He reaks of a ubventaneous egg: and addes further: But thoe eggs which are conceived by coition, and are <> dicovered to have obtained ome portion of the White, they becom fruitful by virtue of that Cock who was firt concerned in coition; for they are now furnihed with both Principles.

Whereby he eems to confes, that the Female alo is an Efficient in Generation, or hath a generative power; becaue every female hath a vegetative •• ule: now generation is a faculty of the vegetative oule. And upon this ground, when he propounds the difference between the male and female, he even there owns them to be Generative
<> : for he aith, We call that animal the male, which begets or generates in another, and that the female, which generates in it elf. And therefore according to Him, both doe Generate; and as have is in both a vegetative oul, o is there in both Generative power. But how thee differ, hath been •• ved before in the Hitory of the Egge. Name
•• the Hen, alone by her elf, without any aitance of the Cock, Generates a ubventaneous egg, (as <> do from themelves produce a fruit) but he <> not produce a fortile egge, with out either •• antecedent, or ubequent Coition of the Cock. the female doth generate, but it is only in ome <> ; and the males coition is required, that that •• rative faculty hould be perfected in the female: that o he may not only bring forth an <> , but uch an egge that may produce a chicken.
<> for this defect in the females generation, the <> eems to have been created (as hall herein appeare) that o what the female cannot
compleat alone, (namely the eed, or fertile egge) that the male hould upply by coition; wherein he doth impart that power either to the Hen, or the Egge.

div.head: A perfect Henne-egge hath two Colours.
EXERCIT. XXXVI.
div.p:
ALl eggs therefore are not perfect eggs; but ome are reputed imperfect, becaue they have not yet attained their jut magnitude, which they afterwards doe receive abroad: And others, bebecaue they are yet improlifical, and afterward doe borrow a prolifical power from without; as Fihes eggs, or the pawn of fihes. Other eggs alo, are by Aritotle counted imperfect, becaue they are of one colour onely; but thoe that are of two colours, perfect, as being contituted of a Yolk and White: which are conceived to be more ditinct, better concocted, and endowed with more heat. And therefore thoe that are called Ov • Centenina, which Fabricius conceits to be onely contituted of the Reliques and Remainders of pag. 10. the White, are only of one colour, and rep ••••
imperfect, becaue of the defect of their heat, and their own imbecillity. But amongt all the egg • that are, there is none more perfect then the Hen, which is till produced perfect, and adorned with
all its liquors and accoutrements, and of a convenient and jut magnitude.

Now Aritotle gives this reaon why it comes to De gen. an. l. 3. c. 1. pas that ome Eggs are of two colours, and others of one only: becaue, aith He, in hotter Animals thoe things out of which the rudiments of Generation, and thoe out of which the Aliment is derived, are always ditinct and apart: and of them one is white, and the other yellow. As if the Chicken took its life from the White, and were onely fed by the Yolk. And in the ame place he aith. That part of it which is hot, doth more reemble the complexion of the parts that are to be made; but that which is the more terrene part, affords onely upply to the body, and keeps at greater ditance from it. And therefore in eggs that have two colours, the Animal aumes its beginning from the White. For the Animal rudiment is in the White, and the nourihment is derived from the Yolk. Therefore we ee his opinion is, that the foreaid Liquors are ditinct, and that eggs are produced party-coloured.

And thee Aertions of his, are partly true, and partly fale. For it is fale, that the Chicken is made out of the White, and fed by the Yolk. For by our Hitory of the Fabrick of the Chicken, both from the diemination of the Umbilical Veels, and the ditribution of their propagations, which without all quetion doe erve for the attraction of the Aliment, it is mot manifet that both the contituting matter and the Aliment, are from the firt original upplied both from the yolk and white; for ome part of both thee liquors doth melt and diolve. And alo the Macula, by whoe firt dilatation the Colliquamentum is made, which is alo tiled by us the Oculus, or Eye of the
Egge, is plainly een to be imprinted into the <> of the Yolk.

And yet for all this, the ditinction of the egg into the yolk & white doth eem to be very neceary: becaue thoe two Liquors, as they are without all doubt of a divere nature, o doe they erve to a divere ue. And that is the reaon why they are ditinct in every perfect egg; one of them being the Aliment which is next at hand, and the other, that which is farther off: with the one the foetus is utained at its firt formation, with the other in ucceeding time. For it is mot unquetionable (as Fabricius affirmes truly, and we alo hall explain anon) that both the Yolk and White are the Aliment of the chicken, and th •• the White is firt pent. Wherefore I agree with Aritotle againt the Phyitians, that the White is the mot incere, mot concocted, and elaborate part of the Egge: and therefore as being the better part, it encompaeth the whole circumference of the egge, which is yet in the Wombe, whilet the Yolke as the more terretrial part doth reide in the Center. For the White eemes to containe <> plenteous animal heat in it, and therefore to be the neerer and firt nourihment. And o alo upon the ame account, the exteriour part of the White, eems to be more imple, and better concocted, then the interiour.

In that Phyitians affirme, that the Yolke is the hotter part of the egge, and mot nourihing, I conceive they undertand it, in relation to us, as it is become our nourihment, not as if it doth upply more congruous aliment to the chicken in the Egge. And this appeares out of our Hitory of the Fabrick of the Chicken: which doth firt <>
upon and devoure the thinner part of the white, before the groer: as if it were more proper diet, and did more eaily ubmit to tranmutation into the ubtance of the future foetus. And therefore the yolk eems to be a remoter and more differred entertainment then the white; for all the white is quite and clean pent, before any notable invaion is made upon the yolk. Nay, the yolk is found in the Abdomen of the Chicken, even after his excluion, as if it were reerved for the Infant-chicken intead of Milk.

The two-coloured egges therefore are mot perfect, as being more ditinct and wrought up by a more vigorous heat. For ince there ought to be treaured in the egge not onely the matter of the Chicken, but his firt feeding too: that which is provided for a perfect animal, ought it elf to be perfect too; and uch is that egge which conits of two ditinct complexioned parts: whereof the one is the former, and more imple, and therefore of gentler digetion; the other the latter, or more remote, and therefore tranlated into the ubtance of the Chicken with more difficulty; (now the yolk and white are thus different amongt themelves) and therefore Perfect egges are Party-coloured, compounded of a white and yolk: as containing and toring up in them everal proviions of harder or more friendly digetion, according to the everal age and ability of the Chicken.

div.head: How the Egge is upplied with its White.
EXER. XXXVII.
div.p: IT appears by our Hitory that the primordia of the eggs in the Ovary are wondrous litle, reembling mall whelks, and lee then the eed of Millet, being full of a white watry moiture: and that thee Papulae, or whelks do at length hoot up into yolks, and that thoe yolks are at lat inveted and cloathed with a white.

p.U:
eemes to be of opinion, that the white is generated out of the yolk by way of Separation. Let us read his words: The Sex, aith he, is not the
de gen. an. l. 3. c. 1. caue of the party-colours, as if the white did proceed from the Male, and the yolk from the Female; but both are derived from the female or Hen. But one is hot, and the other cold. And in thoe creatures that have good tore of heat, they are ditinguihed from one another; but where that heat is fainter, they are not ditinguihed. And for that reaon the conceptions of uch Animals are of one onely colour, as is aid. Now the Males eed onely doth contitute the egge: and therefore at firt the conception of all Birds is white, and mall, but in proces of time, it is all yellow, becaue now a larger quantity of blood is admixed; and latly, the heat abating, the whiter part environs it round, as being a humor equally tempered on all ides. For the white part of the egge is naturally moit, containing in it an animal warmth, and therefore it is placed about the egge, and the yellow earthy part remains within.

div.p:
But Fabricius conceives, The White of the Egge to grow to the yolk by a juxt apoition meerly. For while, pag. 12.
aith he, the yolk rowleth through the econd Uterus, and falls down by degrees, it doth by degrees gather to • a part of the White, which is purpoely generated in the Uterus, that it may cleave to the yolk; untill the •• lke having now paed the intervening or middle •• ires, and arriving at the lat of all; it is together with the White encompaed with the membranes alo, and thou aumes a hell. He conceits therefore, that the egge attaines its increae in a twofold manner; partly by the Veines, as it is with the yolke, and partly by an additional accesion or appoition, as it is with the White. And this perhaps did induce him to be of that judgement; namely, becaue the White being boyled hard, doth eaily part and ditinguih into •• kes, whereof the one lyes above the other. But his alo doth befall the yolk not yet departed from the Ovary, if it be hard boyled as the former. And therefore being otherwie intructed by Experience, I rather join in opinion with Aritotle; for the White is not adjoined (as Fabricius would •• ave it) but bred alo, and furniht with the Chalazae, and ditinguihed by everal membranes, and divided into two white liquors: and all this, by the ame vegetative oul, by whoe indutry the Egge it elf is ditinguihed into two liquors, (a yolk and a white.) For every part of the Egge is formed and contituted by the ame faculty which frames the whole Egge. Nor is it true, that the yolk is firt made, and then the white adjoyned to it. For, what wee ee in the Ovary, is not the yolke of an egge, but rather ome compound, comprehending both liquors mixed together. It reembles the yolk indeed in complexion, but the white in conidence: for being boyled hard, it is not friable (as the yolk is) but concrete and glutinous, and coniting of everal flakes, as the White, and hath as it
were a white Papula, or whelk in the <> .

p.U:
eems to erect this eparation from <>
Ibid. divere nature of the yolk and white. For, aith <>
If you cat divere egges into a baon, or uch like <> el, and prepare them over a Chafin-dih of coals in <> ort, that the force of the fire be not nimbler the •
<> ditinction of the eggs; the ame thing will befall all the heap of eggs, as happens to every particular eggs namely all the yolks will gather and aemble themelves into the middle, and the Whites get round about th •• .

div.p:
And this I have often experimented; and, what ever will, may try it: provided, he hake the y •• and whites together, and with a piece of butter
•• get them temperately into a Cake, having mingled them between two dihes, placed over a Chafin-dih of coales, or in an Oven; for he hall pl •••
ly ee the whites cover the yolks which are aembled at the bottom.

div.head: What the Cock and Henne do conferr • to the Generation of the Egge.
EXER. XXXVIII.
div.p:
BOth Cock and Hen are to be reputed the Chikens Parents; for both of them are necery principles of the Egge, and both alike Efficient caues. For the Egge it elf is the Henns work, a • the Fertility the Cocks. Both are therefore Intruments of the platick virtue, by whoe meanes th •
pecies is continued to the world.

But ince in ome Animal pecies (as if the <>
were a ueles thing, and the Female alone did •• ffice to the perpetuity of the pecies) there are no Males to be found at all, but the whole race is female, as in ome pecies there are Males onely, and no Females at all to be found; for they do all by an emiion of omething out of them into the
•• d, the earth, or water, progenerate, and preerve their pecies: Nature eemes in thee and the like creatures to have atisfied her elfe with one ex only, uing that alone (as an intrument) for procreation.

And now again ome other creatures have a eed provided for them, caually as it were, without any ditinction of ex at all; namely thoe creatures whoe Birth is pontaneous. For as ome things
Arit. phy. l. 1. c. 1. are the productions of art, and the elf ame things are the iues of chance too, as Health, for one: So likewie ome kinde of Animal eed is not imply produced from an univocal Agent (as a Man from a Man) but onely in ome ort univocal; (namely in all thoe creatures whoe extract and matter out of which they pring, is caual in relation to them, and yet undergoes a mutation of it elfe, as the eed doth) namely, Thoe Animals that are not produced by coition, but are born of their own accord, are produced from uch an original as Inects have, which breed a worm. For as ome Artificers
de gen. an. l. 3. c. 9. work with their bare hands, but others again ue intruments in all their operations; and the better ort and more excellent Arts do imploy intruments of everal figure and magnitude, to the execution of everal, and epecially of the more curious and ubtile Operations: (for the more eminent and more laborious works, are made for the mot part of everal motions, and doe require everal ubordinate productions and ends; & in this thing,
as in all other, Art is Natures Ape, and Mimick) o in like manner Nature doth of neceity et a work more intruments, and thoe too of divers faculties and abilities, in the production of the more perfect, and more excellent Animals. For the Sun, or the Heavens (or what ever ele is undertood to be a common and general Father in the production of living creatures) do produce ome things by themelves, by chance, and as it were without imploying any intermediate Intrument, by an equivocal generation, and yet beget ome onely by an univocal procreation: namely all thoe, that are begotten by ome other of the ame kinde, which doth contribute both Matter and Form to them.

And thus in the Generation of the mot perfect Animals, where thee Principles are ditinguihed, and thee eeds of the Animals are ditinct: the Male and Female are the two neceary requiite Intruments to the production. And in this manner is our Hen-egg produced from the Cock and Hen.

The Henne generates in her elf, and therefore communicates place, materialls, nourihment, and cherihing to the conception; but the Cock conveighs fecundity: For the Male, aith Aritotle, doth ever
Gen. an. l. 2. c. 3. complete the generation, and caueth a enitive oul to be introduced, and from an egge creates an Animal.

And therefore proper Organs for both faculties are dipered among the Cocks and Hens. Namely in the Hen, all the Genital parts are commodious for reception, and containing; and in the Cock for transferring and immiion, or preparing of that thing which doth conveigh fecundity to the Henne, he being one that generates in another.

Now, having made trict dicovery, by Anatomical diection, of the parts acred to Generation, we well know, what both Male and Female doe
conferre to it. For the knowledge of the Intruments doth lead in a traight line, to their functions and ues.

div.head: Some things worthy obervation concerning the Cock.
EXERCIT. XXXIX.
div.p: THe cock (as we have hewed you) is the Primary Efficient of the perfect or fertile egge, and the main caue of Generation. For were it not for the cock, a chicken could never pring from the Egge; nor the Egge it elf have any being in many Oviparous creatures. And therefore we mut make farther earch concerning the Action and ue of the cock, namely what advantage he brings to the egge, and the chicken, as well by Coition, as other offices.

It is evident that the cock (though, as I uppoe, he wants a Yard) doth emit his Geniture, commonly called Seed, as may be collected from his Genital Parts; for the Teticles are furnihed with it, and there is great abundance of it dicoverable in the long and ample Leading Veels. But whether it leap out, capering, and frothy by the activity of the pirits, and at everal ejections (as in hotter Viviparous creatures) I am not yet able to reolve. But becaue I can finde no Veicles containing the Geniture, by which it hould be fermented, and dart forth, heightned by the pirits into a Spuma, or froth: and alo finding no Yard
through whoe narrower channel it being protruded, it might leap, and reult, verberating the Interiours of the Hen, epecially eeing coition in Cocks o oon over; I rather believe, that there is onely a light tincture of eminal humour, uch as doth onely moiten the Orifice of the Pudenda; and that the eed is peedily dilodged without any prightly exilition: o that, what other Animals do ejaculate by everal reverberations at one and the ame Inition, Birds (which do not long init upon venereal undertakings) do expedite by many repeated Coitions. For thoe creatures that dwell long in venereal offices, do make but feldom repetitions: and uch, among Birds, are the Swan, and the Otrich: Becaue the Cock therefore cannot tay long in his performances, he doth execute that at everal returnes, which other creatures do at everal impules. And though he neither have Glans, nor Ponis, yet the extremity of the deferent Veels growing turgent by pirits (in Coition) doth extuberate after the manner of a Glans, by which he doth compres the Orifice of the Uterus of the Henne, it being bared and expoed by the apertion of the Fundament; and o bedewing it with genital moiture, he tands in no need of a Yard for the immiion of his Geniture.

Now, we have hewed you, that the Cocks Seed is of o great vertue, that it doth render not the Uterus onely, but the Egge in the Uterus, the Papula in the Ovary, and latly the whole Hen her elf, and all the Rudiments of the Eggs, either already in being, or to be produced hereafter, fertile and Prolifical.

And therefore Fabricius rightly oberved, that tore of Geniture was intruted to the Teticles, and
deferent Veels of the Cock: not that the Hen tands want of much of it to fructifie each ingle egge; at that one Cock may approve himelf ufficient •• his everall Concubines, and repeated performances.

Now the brevity and rectitude of the Cocks permatical Veels do conduce to the nimbler dicharge of the Seed: for that which travels through long and perplexed Meanders, makes lower paage, and needs a more copious impulive pirit to quick
•• its Exit.

Amongt the Males, none more jovial, none more haughty, nor of tiffer garbe, nor more effectual in concocting his food, then the Cock, a great part of whoe Aliment is transformed into
• eniture; and therefore Polygamy is convenient for him, as ten or twelve obedient Hens. For in ome pecies of Animals, one ingle Male can treat • boudance of Females, as we may ee Stags, Bucks, and everal Cattel: and there are others againe there the luty Female is not atisfied by everal Males; as the Bitch, and the Wolf; upon which • ore Meretrices Lupae dicuntur, Protitutes are called Wolves, and Brothel-houes Lupanaria. And • gain ome Creatures are more chat, and reerve, • s it were, a Conjugal integrity: o that one Male keeps faith with one Female, and both pro
•• d vertuouly to propagate their kind. For •• ce Nature requires, that the Male hould upply the defects of the Female in Generation, and that •• alone is not ufficient to utain, cherih, and defend her iue, the Male is added as a Conort • o her, who hould joyn in the task of generating, and nurturing the Young. Thus the Partridges enjoy a Conjugal Life, and becaue their <> cannot hatch o many egges at once, nor attend
the education when the Young are excluded they are reported to build each of them a N •• . And o the cock-Pigeon takes his turnes of Incubation, and joynes in the erection and fabrick of hi • net, and likewie in laying in proviion for he off-pring. And o in like manner you may dicover many examples of a Conjugal life among bruit beats, of which more hereafter.

But thoe Males that erve many Females (a • the cock) their Teticles are much lined with Seminal moiture, and they are provided with long and large deferent Veels. And at that time, and age that the cluter in the Ovary begins to ripen and become mature, and tands now in need of Fructifying, that the Papulae may be perfected into Egges, the cocks eed begins to encreae, and hi •
Teticles grow turgent and tumorous, and are alo eated in the ame place (namely neer the Diaphragma) into which they intil fertility. And this is evident in fihes, birds, and all other Oviparous creatures, whoe males are all replenihed with eed, at the ame time, and place, whereat their females do conceive their egges.

And therefore all thoe parts of the Hen which are deigned to Generation, namely, the Ovary, Infundibulum, the proces of the Womb, and the Womb it elf, and the Privities: and alo the cituation, fabrick, quantity, and Temper of all thee, and what oever ele relates thereto: they are all inervient, and handmaids either to the procreation of the Egge, or to its Augmentation, or ele to Coition, and fertility received from the Male, or to the foetus: to which they conduce either necearily and principally, or as a Caua ine qua non, or ome way or other to the better being.

For there is nothing made either vain or rah in
all the operations of Nature. So likewie all the Genital parts in the Cock are contrived for preparing or concealing, or ele tranmitting the geniture into the Hen.

But uch males as are o vigorous, that they can upply many females, thee do much exceed heir females in their growth, and tature, as alo in their
•• naments, courage, and weapons; which is not o eminent in thoe that are conjugal and chater. For a cock-Partridge, Crow, or Pigeon, are not o much uperiour and different from their conorts, as the Cock is from the Hen, or the Stag from his Hindes.

And therefore the Cock, as he is well appointed in his weapons, brave in his plumes, haughty, ambitious, valiant, and a famous Duellit; o doth he alo abound in Seed, and is wift in his chamber-offices, and of o unbounded a luxury, that (except he have his Seraglio for his concubines) • e will tire out his wives by frequent invitations, • nd compreions, and (as we have oberved in the Pheaant, the Turkey-cock, and others) will cruelly handle them, with uneaonable advancings, and moletations. I have een Hens ometimes o tired and torn by the inolency and incivility of the inatiate Cock, that all their backs have been deplumed, and they themelves by deep ex
••• erations piercing to the bare bone, have mierably expired.

div.head: Of the Henne.
EXER. XL.
div.p: THere are two firt Caues and Intruments of Generation, the Male and Female. For the Hen eems to be the Author of the Egge, as the Cock of the Fertility: and therefore by the coition of thee two, that which renders the egge fruitful, is traduced from the Male into the Female, or generated in the Female by that coition.

But what that is, is no les difficult to be known then to what it is communicated: namely, whether to the whole Henne, or to its Uterus, or to the Eggs already made, or ele to all the Egges not begun in the Ovary, or to be begun hereafter? For it is probable, according to our former dicoure • and alo by Fabricius his experiment, that a <> coitions, and the commerce of the Henne with the Cocke for a few dayes, doth ufficiently fructifie her, or her womb at let, for a whole year together. And I my elf, informed by experience, can parth affirm the ame thing; namely, that the twentieth egge layed by the Hen (after her divorce from th •
Cocke) hath been fruitfull, and prolifical. That a • from the geniture of the Male-fihes cattered in ••
water, a great family of eggs is endowed with the lifical virtue; and as in Bitches, and Sowes, and alo other Animals, ome few coitions have atisfie to the fertility of everal foetues: (inomuch the ome think it an approved Maxim, that in cae Bitch be oftner compreed by the dog then th •• or four times, it will wrong her fertility, and make her births degenerate mot into females)
••
alo the Cock by ome few familiarities with the Hen, doth not only render the egge now being in
• he Ovary, but the entire Ovary, and Hen her elf prolifical (as hath been often repeated.) Nay, what • s more then this, and admirable indeed; In a cer
•• in part of Peria (aith Aritotle) if you cut up a
Hit. an. l. 6. c. 37
<> -Moue, you hall finde even the young ones within •• , that are females, to be great with young themelves: being made mothers before they are born: as if
• he male did not onely fructifie his female, but all
• he females alo of which he labours; as our Cock
• oth not only render his henne fruitful, but all
• he eggs alo that he is to lay.

Now this Phyitians do confidently deny, who •• me the conceptions of Animals to be produced by the mixed geniture of both Sexes. And there
•• e Fabricius, though he pronounce the Cocks eed
• ver to enter, nor to have any poibility of en
•• ance pag. 38. 39. into the hollow of the womb, (where either •• egge is made, or increaed) and though he •• inly aw, the egges now newly begun in the Ovary, to be made fertile by the ame coition, as • ell as thoe egges which were already made; •• particle of which could be made by the eed of • t Cock; yet he will needs have the Cocks eed • s if its preence and continuance were abolute
•• neceary) to be locked up for a whole year together in the pouch of a prolifical Hen, and there to •• reerved in a blinde chink. Which perwai
•• we have formerly rejected, and that becaue • t cavity is indifferently found as well in a Cock, in a Hen; and alo for that we could never cover uch a tanding pool of Geniture, either that cavity, or any other cranny in a Hen: but oon as the Geniture hath delivered her meage, •• d performed her trut, by imprinting a prolifical
virtue in the Hen, it either retires back again, or is diolved, and rarified into air, and o vaniheth. And though Galen, and all Phyitians with Arit. de gen. an. l. 2. c. 3. him, do trongly oppoe this diolution of the Genture, yet having thoroughly conidered the fabrick of the genital part by Anatom cal adminitrations, and having likewie pondered other mot invincible arguments, they mut necearily acknowledge, that the eed of the male, as it is derived from the Teticles by the leading veels, and contained in the permatical veels, is not prolifical, unles by the fervency of Coition, and deire, it become aerial, and rarified into a pume. For (witnes Aritotle) it is not the corpulency of the eed, or Ibid. its fire, that renders it prolifical, or any quality like to thoe, but the pirit which is incloed in the eed and pumous body, and the nature which is in that pirit, being anwerable and like in proportion to the Element or ubtance of the Stars. Wherefore, though wee hould indulge Fabricius in his opinion, that the Seed is reerved in that pouch; yet notwithtanding, after the prolifical effervency, or the pirit is reolved, it would grow ueles, and improlifical. And from hence may Phyitians take notice, that the geniture of the male is not therefore the architect of the foetus, becaue the firt cenception aumes its body from it, but becaue it is pirituous, and boyling, as being inpired with a fertile pirit, and turgent like a thing poeed. For otherwie Averrhoes his fable, of the woman that conceived in a Bath, might have ome title to true tory. But of thee things more in their proper place.

As therefore the Egg is made by the Hen, o i • it alo very likely that all the firt conceptions (a • hall be hown hereafter) doe aume both their Matter and Form from the female; and that alo
after the males geniture is immitted, and now for ome time quite departed and vanihed away. For the Cock doth not conferre any fertility to the Hen or Eggs, by the bare emiion of his geniture; but onely o farre forth as that geniture is prolifical, and impowered with a platical virtue; that is to ay, piritous, operative, and proportionable to the ubtence of the Stars. The male therefore is no more to be prized as the chief principle of the conception, and foetus, by reaon he can concoct and emit eed, then a female, which can produce an egg without his help. But he therefore rather claims prerogative, in that he impowers his eed with pirit, and divine efficacy; and o, that in a moment it can perform its affaires, and conveigh fertility. For as we ee things immediately et on fire, and infamed by a park truck from a flint, or by a flah of Lightning from a cloud; o the geniture of the male doth immediately affect the female with the touch, and transferres fruitfulnes unto her, which doth not onely virtuate the eggs, but the womb alo, and the Hen herelf, and all in an intant: for to combutible ubtance is ooner et on fire by the approach of the flames, then the Hen is made pregnant by the coition of the Cock.
But what it is that is transferred from him to her, we hall have occaion to dicover in its order, then we hall determine the matter more perpicuouly and in general.

In the mean time we mut take notice, that if it be derived from the oul (for it is mot likely that whatoever is fruitfull, the ame is alo animate, and we have aid before, that an Egg in Aritoiles opinion is indowed with a vegetative oul, as alo all the eed of Plants) that oul (at leat the vegetative) mut of neceity be ex traduce, and derived

in a Prolificall Conception as after it) as it is in the Generation of the Chicken out of the Egge, and jut in that manner as Plants do pring from eeds of their own kind. For it doth not appear that the Male is required, to the intent that hee hould be as an Agent, Operatour, or Efficient per e, nor that the Female, is required that he hould contribute the matter; but both Male and Female are to be eteemed in ome ort the Operatour, and Parent: and the foetus is procreated a mixt imilitude, and reemblance, as if it proceeded from both mixt together. Nor is it true which Aritotle often affirms, and Phyitians take for granted, namely, that preently after Coition, there is omething to be found of the foetus, or conception, (as the Heart, or the Tres Bullae, or ome other Principle part) or omething at leat in the cavity of the Womb, as ome Coagulum, or Spermatical mixt ubtance, or the like. But on the contrary, in cae the Female prove fertile, and pregnant, it happens that the eggs, and conception in the mot, and mot perfect creatures, is firt begun long after coition. And that the Female alo is prolifical, before any thing of the conception be at all contained in the Womb, many indications do conpire to acertain, as hall be afterwards dicovered in the Hitory of Viviparous Animals: as the enlargement of the Breats, and the turgid welling of the Womb, by which and other Symptomes we may perceive an Alteration in the whole Body.

But as for the Hen, though he have for the mot part the Rudiments of eggs in her before coition, which are afterwards by the Tread made prolificall, and therefore he then hath omething in her preenly upon coition, or treading: yet when it falls
out o with her, that like other creatures, he hath nothing at hand ready in her Ovary, or hath already layd all the egges he formerly had there; he being afterwards trod (though ome time pas between and intervene) as if he were then both Principles her elf alone, or did poes the power of both Sexes, doth after the manner of Plants generate egges by her elf, and thoe too (I peak it knowingly) not ubventaneous, but prolifical.

For if you take all the eggs from under a Hen that is now itting, in cae that very Hen was a fruitful Hen in former time (though he have now already layd all the eggs he hath, and have not o much as one remaining in her Ovary) he wil lay again, and thoe eggs hal be fructifying, prolifical eggs, having the principles of both Sexes in them.

div.head: In what repect the Henne may be called the Primum Efficiens, the firt or Chiefe Efficient. And alo of her iue.
EXERCIT. XLI.
div.p:
WE have already pronounced the Hen, to be an Efficient Caue of Generation, or natures Intrument in that employment; (but he is not abolutely, and per e; but by commiion, and by vertue of the Male rendered prolifical.) But as the Male is by Aritotle counted the firt principle of
Generation, uo merito, upon his own core, becaue the firt Motus or progres towards Generation proceeds from him; o the Hen alo may in ome repect be eteemed the firt caue of Generation; inomuch as the male by the approach and preence of the female, like one poeed, is inflamed to Venery. The female-Fih (aith Pliny) at the time of
Lib. 9. c. 50. coition will purue and follow the Male, punching his belly with her head: And again, about the time of bringing forth, the Male will do the like to the Female. I my elf have ometimes een the male Fihes follow the female that was ready to pawn, (jut as Doggs doe a alt-Bitch) all in troops, that they might princkle her eggs o oon as he had laid them, lacte uo, with their milkey ubtance, or eed. But that is mot enible in wanton and lacivious females, which will tirre up Cupids low and drowie fires in their tame males, and intill a ilent love into them.

And hence it is, that the Dunghill-cock, o oon as ever he ees his own poue whom he hath mied never o litle a while, or any other tranger-Henn, being preently arreted at Cupids uite, he mounts her. And likewie when he is Victor in fight, though he return wounded and wearied from the battel, yet he till delights to ravih his captives wives. And that he may kindle this declining park of lut, which now lyes expiring in his breat, into a vigorous flame, with everal geticulations, incitements, and Love-cenes (while he often crows, aembles his Henns, and now approaching circuits about them, and trailes his tiffe wings at their feet) he enticeth his Females, as by a pell or enchantment, to port with him. Now thee are the Cocks projects and arts: but ometimes the coynes and moroity of the Hen
doth not a litle conduce to roue and heighten the males leepy heat, and languihing appetite, to quicken and encourage his performance. But of thee provocations and allurements, o farre as they erve to promote conception, we hall peak more anon. For if you carefully ponder Natures works, you hall finde none of them made in vain, but all directed to ome end, and for ome good.

Almot all females are pleaed & delighted with the act of coition, and rejoyce at their great bellies, but many groan at their delivery. But the thing is quite contrary in Hens, which in coition complain, and hang back; but in laying, though the Egge be very great in comparion of their own bulk and the treights of the Uterine Orifice, and the Egge brings no furtherance at all to his own releae, (as the Iues of Viviparous animals do) yet he brings forth without any pain, and till rejoices as oon as he hath layd, and raiing a loud laughter, invites in the Cock to hare in her triumphs.

But though there are many rudiments of eggs, of different magnitude, and degree, in the Hens Ovary, inomuch that ome are augmented and come to maturity before others, yet they all eem to be fructified alike, and receive the prolifical tamp together, by the Cocks coition.

And though a good pace of time pas away (namely, thirty dayes or more) before the Common-hen or Partridge-hen disburden all the Egges in their Ovary, yet when ever the Hen its upon them, they bring forth all their chickens almot together, at the et time (namely, in the compas of twenty, or two and twenty daies) and they are all likewie no les complete, then if they had all taken
the ame rie and original at the ame intant of coition (as the Bitches whelps do.)

And being upon this contemplation, while I conider how mall the prolifical ground-works of Eggs are, namely litle whelks, and exudations, les then the eeds of Millet; and meditating the tature, magnanimity, and furniture of the Cock who is born from thence; I cannot but admire, that Nature hould intrut uch great abilities to o lender beginnings: and oberve, how the Omnipotent Creator is pleaed to manifet his greatnes mot, in the mallet originals.

For the Hen, and the Cock, that haughty and magnificent Animal, prings from a mall and almot inviible whelk. A vat Tree ries from a litle Acron. Nay, from the mallet bud and point of an Acorn, how doth the Aged Oak diplay her preading armes? how lofty a cret doth he exalt to heaven? and how deep a root doth he end down to fathom the earth? It is indeed (aith Pliny) an incomprehenible miracle, that a ubtance
Lib. 17. c. 10. which defies the axe, that prees, undaunted at the huget weights, that mats patient of the larget ails, and ramms unbattered by the hock of Towers, and Bullwarks, hould proceed from o mean principles. But this is Natures power, this her ability. Now there is uch a litle prout in the eeds of all Plants, whoe bare top of all no bigger then a point, if it be once pared away, all hope of generation preently dies, as if the entire platical virtue that is to fahion and compoe the whole Tree, did take up its abode in o mall a point. And therefore the provident Ant, eating of this mall particle before hand, doth afely treaure up the grains and eeds of corn in her barns that lye under ground, cunningly,
providing by this meanes againt the inconvenience which he might uffer in their growing afreh. The Cypres-Tree (aith the ame Pliny) beareth a eed exceedingly affected by the Ant; and this enlarges the miracle, that o inconiderable an Animal hould devoure and detroy o vat a Tree in its cra • le. But of thee alo in general we hall peak more, when we hall hew that many Animals themelves, epecially Inects, do germinate and pring from eeds and principles not to be dicerned even by the eye, by reaon of their contract inviible dimenions, (like thoe atomes, that fly in the aire) which are cattered and dipered up and down by the winds: all which are eteemed to be Spontaneous iues, or born of Putrefaction, becaue their eed is not any where een. And this peculation is ueful to that Philoophy, which teacheth, that all things are made out of nothing; for between the Original, and the Complement of any Living creature, there is almot no commenurable proportion.

Nor are we o much to admire, what it is in a Cock, that doth conerve and govern o perfect and noble a creature, and is the firt caue of his exitence, which we ay is his oul: but farre more what it is in the egge, nay in the very whelk, which hath o grand an authority to produce o gallant an animal, and advance its own renown to o high a tretch of glory. Nor are we only to admire, how great the Artit is that doth ait and cooperate in o great a work; but rather the manner of conveighance, it being by the contagion of onely a momentany coition: namely, what the thing is that paeth from the Male to the Female, from the Female to the Egge, and from the Egge to the Foetus? What it is, that is hoc Traducis, this Derived
eence, which cannot be perceived to be either remaining, or touching, nor any enible contained thing; and yet doth operate with a vat dicretion and providence, beyond all the bounds of Art: & which doth render the Egg prolifical, even when it elfe is fled and vanihed, not becaue it now doth, or hath touched before; not fructifying only the perfect, and abolved eggs, but even the imperfect and intended only, when they are yet but whelks and puhes: nay the Henne her elf before he have yet produced any whelks at all, and that o nimbly, as if the Almighty himelf hould ay, Let there be a production, and trait there is one.

Let Phyitians therefore ceae to wonder at what they do not finde, but with atonihment; namely, at Contagious, Epidemical, and Petilential Dieaes, how they do foment and dipere their infection through the air, and propagate ditempers like to themelves in other bodies, and by a ecret coure, as it were, by a olemne generation tacitly multiply, and grow ometimes o detructive, that (if God would leave the reins in their own hands) they would pread a weeping deolation over Men, and Beats: for greater things then thee are the dayly reults of the generation of Animals. For more, and abler operations are required to the Fabrick and erection of Living creatures, then to their diolution, and plucking of them down: For thoe things that eaily and nimbly perih, are low and difficult in their rie and complement. Seneca (as he is wont) elegantly Nat. quet. l. 3. c. 27. aith: How long a time is required to ripen the conception for the Birth! With how great care and tendernes is it trained when now it is an Infant! With what choice of aliment is it cherihed to a Youth! and yet how obnoxious is this carkas at lat! how lot
without any paines! An age builds Towers, which one hour levels with the ground. With great caution things continue, but perih at an eaie rate. The Forret which is growing long, one active park and moment turns to cinders. Nay, not o much as a park; for the conflagration of the vatet bodies, will put us onely to the expence of a Burning-glas, where the Sunne beames being aembled, and directed in a Cone, will raie a nimble flame to peed the michief. So that nothing is difficult to Natures Royalty, which to the production of things is paring of her power, and warily dipeneth it with a great deal of thrift, by inenible acceions; but he is quick to detroy, running in full peed. In the generation of things, the bet, eternal, and omnipotent God, or Natures deity, is evidently een; but all mortal things finde out a thouand wayes to ruine, of their own accord.

div.head: How the generation of the Chicken is procured out of the Egge.
EXER. XLII.
div.p:
WE have thus farre conidered the Egge, as the Fruit, and End: it remaines, that wee now treat of it, as the Seed, and Principle. Now pag. 28. we mut enquire (aith Fabricius) how the generation of the Chicken follows out of the Egge; taking our rie from that Principle or Poition of Aritotle and Galen, and approved by all: namely, That all things that are made in this world, are produced of thee three;
the Agents, the Intruments, and the Matter. But becaue in natural Productions, the Agent is not without, but either exitent in the Matter, or Intruments, he concludes, That we are to conider of the Agent, and Matter only.

But becaue we are here to hew after what manner the Chicken is made out of the Egge, I conceive it not ueles, to demontrate, how many everal wayes one thing may be aid to be made out of another: for by that means it will more clearly and ditinctly appear, how many everal wayes generation doth proceed from an Egge, and what is to be reolved, concerning the Matter, Intruments, and Efficient.

Aritotle hath taught, that one thing is made out of another four manner of wayes: Firt, when we ay the
De gen. an. l. 1. c. 18. Night is made out of the Day, and a Man of a Boy; becaue this is after that. The econd, when a Statue is made out of Bras, or a Bed-tead out of Wood, or whatoever we affirm to be made of matter, that o a whole may reult, from omething that is formed, and in it. Thirdly, when of a Muical, a man unskilled in Muick, or of a Sound, a Sick man, or one contrary of another. Fourthly, as Epicharmus makes his exaggeration: of Calumnies, Curings; of Curings, Conflict. All which are referred to the firt beginning of the progres; for the Calumnies are a certain part of the whole Broile. Since therefore one thing may be made out of another o many wayes, it is apparent, that the Seed is in another, two of thee wayes. For that which is begotten, is out of it, either as out of its matter, or as its firt mover. For it is not barely, as this thing is after that, as Navigation after the Panathenaea, nor as one contrary out of another; for a contrary is begotten out of the corruption of a contrary, and there mut needs be ome ubject matter, out of which, as out of a firt
immanent thing it hould be made. By which words Aritotle truly inferres, that the Seed proceeding from the male, is the efficient caue of the Foetus, or ele the Intrumental; becaue it is no part of the Foetus, neither according to the Firt, nor third acceptation (namely, as this thing out of that, or as out of its contrary) nor is it the ubject matter.

But, as he aith in the ame place, that which proceeds from the Male in coition, is not truly and properly called Seed, but Geniture rather, and doth differ from Seed properly o called. For that is called Geniture, which proceeding from the Generant, is that firt caue which obtains the beginning of the generation; namely, in thoe creatures which Nature hath deigned to generation: but the Semen is that thing which takes its original from the coition of thoe two (namely, the Male and Female:) and uch is the eed of all Plants, and of ome Animals, in whom there is no ditinction of Sex: as being that which is firt mixt by the Male and Female, as it were a promicuous conception; and uch as we have formerly in our Hitory declared the Egge to be, which is called both a Fruit and a Seed. For the Seed and the Fruit are ditinct things, and differ ratione prioris & poterioris, under the notion of that which is firt, and that which is after; for the Fruit is that which proceeds from another, the Seed is that out of which another doth proceed; otherwie they were both the ame. It remaines therefore that we enquire, how many of the foreaid wayes the Foetus doth proceed, not from the Geniture of the Male, but from the true Seed, or Egg, or Conception (which are truly the eeds of Animals.)

div.head: How many waies the Chicken may be aid to be made out of the Egge.
EXERCIT. XLIII.
div.p: IT is therefore granted, that the Chicken is made out of a prolifical Egg, as out of its Matter, and as by its Efficient; and that the ame Egge is both the Caues of the Chicken. For as it deduceth its original from the Hen, and is eteemed the fruit, it is the Matter: but in as much as it containeth in it, throughout all its ubtance, a platical, and prolifical virtue infued by the Male, it is called the Efficient of the Chicken. So that not onely (as Fabricius would have it) thee things are ineparably joyned together in one and the ame Egge; namely, the Agent, and the Intrument, but it is alo neceary, that the ame place hould alo containe Aliment, by which it hould be nourihed. So that in a prolifical Egge thee four things are to be found together; namely, the Efficient, the Intrument, the Matter, and the Aliment, as appears plainly in our Hitory.

Wherefore we affirme, that the Chicken is made out of the prolifical Egge all the fore-aid waies; namely, as out of its Matter, Efficient, and Intrument: and alo as a Man is made out of a Boy, and the Whole out of a Part: and alo tanquam ex Alimento, as a thing may be aid to be made of its nutriment; and likewie as a contrary is made out of a contrary.

For when by Incubation (by the Internal motive principle) ome clear part is liquefied (which we call Ovi Oculum the Eggs-Eye) we ay that very
thing is made tanquam ex contrario, as a contrary out of a contrary: as we uppoe the Chyle to be made out of contraries by concoction; (namely, out of crude, unconcocted meats) and in the ame ene, as we our elves are aid to be nourihed by contraries. Jut in that manner is the Colliquamentum and the Oculus Ovi made of the White, and augmented: and in that manner likewie is the Blood and the Veicula pulans (which are the firt particles of the Chicken) made, nourihed and augmented, out of that white liquor, or Colliquamentum: nourihed I ay, the Nutriment being aimulated by concoction (as out of its contrary) by the power of the innate heat; for that which is crude and unconcocted, is contrary to that which is concocted and aimulated: as a Man unskilled in Muick is contrary to a Muitian; and a Sick man, to a Sound.

And when Blood is made out of the white Colliquamentum, or the Colliquamentum out of the Yolk or White, it is called the generation of the one, and the corruption of the other: there being an alteration made from the contrary to the contrary, the ame ubject matter remaining till. For the proceeding form of the White being corrupted, the Colliquamentum arieth: and from the privation of the form of the Colliquamentum, reulteth the form of Blood: in the ame manner as nourihment is turned into the ubtance of that which is nourihed.

Therefore in this ort the Chicken is aid to be made out of the egge, tanquam ex Contrario, as out of a Contrary. For the Chicken being nourihed and increaed in the Egg, both the Yolk and the White are corrupted and conumed, and afterwards all the ubtance of the Egg. It is therefore manifet
that the Chicken is made out of the Egg, as out of a contrary, namely, as out of Aliment: and alo, tanquam exprivatione, & non ente, as out of a Privation and non Ens. For the firt particle of the Chicken, (namely the Blood, or Punctum aliens) is made ex non anguine, of that which is not blood, and altogether its contrary, the ame ubject Matter till remaining.

The Chicken alo is made out of the Egg, icut vir ex puero, as a Man is made out of a Boy. For as out of Plants Seeds are made, out of Seeds, Bloomes, Sprouts, Stems, Flowers, and Fruits: o alo out of an Egge, (which is the Hens Seed) is made the dilatation of the Macula, the Colliquamentum, the Blood and Heart, as the firt particle of the fatus (or fruit.) And that, tanquam ex nocte dies, as the Night is made out of the Day; the Sommer out of the Spring; and a Man out of a Boy: Where this thing, is after that. So that as the Fruit doth arie in the ame Stem after the Flowers; o likewie, after the Egge the colliquamentum; and after that, as out of the Humor Primigenius, out of the radical firt moiture, the Blood, after the Blood, and out of it, the chicken; as the Whole out of a Part. And again, as by Epicharmus his Exaggeration, ex calumniâ fiunt maledicta, & ex maledict is pugna, out of lander come curings, and out of curings fighting. For the Blood together with the Punctum aliens is firt exitent; and doth likewie eem to be a part of the chicken, and a kind of Efficient, or Intrument of its Generation, ineparable from the Agent: (as Fabricius uppoeth) Now, in what manner the Egge may be called the Intrument and Efficient of Generation, is in part hewed already; and hall appear more at large hereafter.

It is evident out of our Hitory, that the Punctum
aliens and the Blood, (while they increae) do aemble the ret of the body and all the other members of the chicken to themelves: as the Yolk in the Womb, decending from the Ovary, encompaeth it elf with the White, and that by way of concoction, and Nutrition. Now all men conceive calor. innatus, aut calidum innatvm, the innate or primigenial Heat, or Spirit diffued through the whole, and the Soul in that Spirit, or the faculty of that Soul, to be the common Intrument of the Vegetable Operations. The egg therefore without all quetion hath its Operative oul, which is all in the whole, and all in every part; and containes a pirit, or Animal heat in it, which is the immediate intrument of that oul.
If any man therefore ask, how a chicken is made out at the egge? We reply, after all thoe ways recited by Aritotle, or invented by any ele, after the which, one thing may be made out of another.

div.head: Fabricius is mitaken concerning the Matter of the Generation of the Chicken out of the Egge.
EXER. XLIV.
div.p:
AS I decreed with my elf from the beginning, o I hal continue to take Fabricius along with pag. 28. me in my progres: and therefore we hall conider with him of thoe three things, which he aith are to be inquired after in the Generation of the
chicken, namely, the Agent, the Matter, and the Aliment of the chicken. All which ought to be in an egge, concerning which he propoeth ome doubts, together with the opinions of Authors, who are of another mind. The firt doubt relates to the Matter and Aliment of the chicken. Indeed Hippocrates, Anaxagoras, Alcmaeon, Menander, and De Nat. pueri. all the ancient Philoophers, did conceive the Chicken to be born out of the Yolk, and nourihed by the White. And Aritotle and Pliny, contrary Hit. an. l. 6 c. 3. and De gen. an. l. 3. c. 1. & 3. l. 10. c. 53. to that opinion, did believe, that the chicken did aume its body from the White, and its Aliment from the Yolk. But Fabricius for his own part, conceived neither Yolk nor White to be the Matter of the chicken: endeavouring to confute the former opinions, and to hew, that both Yolk and White did erve to nourih the Chicken. And this, beides other Arguments (which I conceive to be of les force) with this which is evincing enough, namely that the propagations of the Umbilical Veels (by which without doubt the chicken doth attract his Aliment) are dieminated both into the Yolk and white, and that both thoe liquors (accordingly as the chicken encreaes, and doth expend a greater tock of nourihment) are quite exhauted. And hereupon Fabricius for confirmation pag. 34. of his opinion, aith: There are three onely ubtances which do conduce to the fabrick of the egg, and the generation of the chicken, the White, the Yolk, and the Chalazae: the White and Yolk are the Chickens ubtance; therefore the Chalazae onely are the ubject matter of the chicken. But that the mot excellent Fabricius is in an error, we have demontrated before in our Hitory. For after the chicken is well nigh compleated, when his Head and Eyes are ditinctly to be een, the Chalazae are till
found in the Egg far remote from the Chicken, and till entire, being then depreed from the two ends of the egg to the ides, and do execute (as he alo confees) the office of Ligaments, to keep the Yolk in its true poition within the White. Nor is that true neither, which Fabricius addes to jutifie his perwaion; namely, that the Chalazae are eated directly under the Obtue Angle of the Egge. For after the firt days Incubation the Liquors hift their tations; the Yolk is exalted, and the chalazae are depreed from both ends, as hath been aid.

He is alo deceived, when he aith that the chalazae are parts of the Egge: for in truth, the egge is contituted onely by the Yolk, and the White; but the chalazae, as alo the membranes, are onely certain litle Appendixes of the White, and nothing ele but meerly the extremities of the membranes contorted and twited, (as filaments or trings are twited into a Rope) that o they may the better preerve the Liquors in their proper places, by a firmer tye.

And therefore his Inference is infirme, when he aith: The chalazae are found to be in that part of the egg where the chicken is made, and therefore the chicken is made out of them. For even according to Fabricius himelf, that can no wayes be: who confees, that the chalazae are to be found in the two extremities of the egg, and yet denies, that the chicken is any where made, but onely in the Obtue end of it: in which end truly, from the very firt etting out towards the Generation of the Chicken, there is no chalazae to be found at all. Nay, if you make tryal in a New-layd Egge, you hall find that the uperiour chalaza is not directly eated under the Obtue end, or the cavity thereof,
but inclining omething to the ide; nor on that ide neither, where the cavity doth tend, but rather on the contrary ide. Moreover, it hath been hewed before, that the cituation of the Liquors immediately upon Incubation is hifted, becaue the Oculus, or Eye of the egge being enlarged by the colliquamentum, is exalted to the cavity in the Obtue Angle, upon which the liquors and chalazae at each end do remove to the ides. For the Macula or Speck, which before Incubation, was eated in the middet between both the extremities of the egge, now being inlarged into an Oculus, or Eye, is adjoyned to the cavity in the Obtue end; and one of the chalazae is depoed from the Obtue Angle, and the other is exalted (o much as the other is depoed) from the Acute Angle; (jut as the Poles of the World are eated in an Oblique Hemiphere) and at the ame time, the greatet part of the White, epecially of the groer part of it, doth inck down to the Acute Angle.

Nor is that true neither where he endeavors to infer a probable argument to prove the chalazae to be the Matter of the Pullus, from the likenes & imilitude of their conitence, alleadging, that the chalazae pag. 35. do repreent the firt formation of the Chicken, by their figure and longitude, and have alo as many twits or knots, as there are principle parts in the Chicken.

Nor is that corpus Rubrum (which he alo took for the Liver) or red ubtance in the chalazae, or any thing neer them, but in the middle of the colliquamentum candidum; and it is the rudiment of the Heart onely. Nor doth the example of the Tadpoles alleadged by him, quare to his purpoe, of which, aith he, you can onely dicern their Head and Taile, that is, their Head and pine of the Back,
having neither fore-legs nor hinder-legs. And he proceeds, that whooever eeth a Chalaza, and one of thee conceptions, will think he ees one and the ame body.

Now I have made many diections of thee Tadpoles, and have een a pretty large Belly in them, and in that Belly Guts, and a Liver, and a Heart panting; and alo I have dicovered their Head and Eyes too. But that which Fabricius takes for their Head, is their round figure, from which they are called Gyrini; becaue their form or figure in gyrum vertitur, curles into a round. They have alo a Taile by which they wim, but legs indeed they want. Yet about the Soltice, they loe or cat their Taile, having then hinder-legs, and fore-legs beginning to trut out. Now there is nothing in the firt diviion of a Chicken into his Head and Spine, that any way reembles this; which hould any way induce us to believe that the Chicken is made out of the Chalazae, in manner of a Tadpole.

To proceed farther in the confutation of this matter, the worth of Fabricius (a man o exceedingly well skilled in Anatomy) forbids: nor indeed is there any great need, ince the thing is o evident in our Hitory. He at lat concludes, that this his opinion is wondrous old, and was on foot in Aritotles dayes. But I rather think the opinion of Ulyes Aldrovandus to be old, by which it is thought, that the Chalazae are the Cocks Treddle, out of which, and by which the chicken is procreated.

But neither of thee opinions is true: for that the Grandines, or Chalazae (the Italians call them Galladura, and our Country-men the Treddle) do either proceed from the Cock, or are his eed, is a
vulgar error, and an old Wifes tale, both heretofore, and in our times.

The Grandines (aith Aldrovandus) are the Cocks perme, becaue no fertile Egge is without them. No nor infertile Egge neither; which he or knew not, or did not declare. And this Fabricius indeed acknowledgeth; but while he denyeth the Cocks eed to enter into the womb, or to be any where found in the Egge; yet he till contends, that the Chalazae, before any other parts of the Egg, are chiefly tocked with fecundity from the power of the Males eed, and do contain a prolifical virtue; though he could not oberve that there is no difference or ditinction at all between the Chalazae of the barren & the fruitful egge. But eeing he hath granted, that the very rudiments of Egges in the Vitellary are as well fructified by the Cocks treading, as thoe Eggs which are encompaed with the white. I uppoe the occaion of his o able a mans error was this: It was hitherto (as we have often aid) the received opinion of all Philoophers and Phyitians, that the Geniture of the Male, or Female, or of both together, was the ubject matter in the generation of Animals: out of which reiding in the Uterus (after coition) the Animals are generated (in like manner as Plants are made, and pring out of the eeds owen in the ground:) nor was Aritotle much ditant from this opinion, who would needs have the mentruous blood to be the womans, which the Males geniture doth coagulate, and o contitute the conception.

Now the fore-aid Error being granted by all, (for an infallible principle) it is no great wonder, if afterwards (according to every mans particular conjecture) many fale opinions do creep in. For
they are quite beide their mark, who conceive that after coition ome kinde of ubtance or matter doth remain, fit and convenient for the production of the foetus, or firt conception; or that any thing ele is formed in the cavity of the womb, which may be of like ue with the eed which is owen in the bowels of the earth. For it is mot certain, that in the Uterus of a Hen (and the ame thing hall be afterwards evidenced of all females whatoever) upon coition, nothing is to be dicovered, more then was there before.

And therefore it is clear that Fabricius is out, when he aith, As a Viviparous animal is incorporated of a litle quantity of eminal matter, but that which pag. 35. utaineth him afterward is in a great aboundance: o alo the litle Chalazae are ufficient for the generation of the Chicken; but all the other parts conteined in the Egge, erve onely for his nourihment.

By which words he declares, that he conceived uch a kinde of ubtance was at hand in the Egge, for contituting the model of the foetus: let hee hould eem to recede any thing from the definition of an Egge, delivered by Aritotle; namely, An Egge is that thing, out of part of which an Animal is produced, and the remainder of which becomes the
Hit. an. l. 3. c. 8. de gen. an. l. 2. c. 1. nourihment for it when it is produced.

And this therefore eemed an invincible Argument to Fabricius; Since there are three onely parts in the Egge; namely, the White, the Yolk, and the Chalazae: and the two firt do only adminiter nutriment to the Chicken; it mut needs be that the Chalazae only are the matter, out of which the Chicken is contituted.

Thus then it fell out, that this able Anatomit (while he ought in the Egge ome convenient matter, out of which to contitute the Chicken) being
benighted by a vulgar Hereie, lot his way. And this inconvenience doth likewie befall many men more, who foraking that light, which the frequent diection of bodies, and the familiar convere with Natures elfe would help them to, doe yet perit to make dicoveries out of their owne conjectures, or ome conceived probable arguments, or the Authority of former Writers; when they themelves ought to look into the matter, and aent to it by their own ene. No wonder therefore that infinite errours, which were delivered over by common conent from the firt dawning of Antiquity, are handed down even to our times: and that o by that means, men otherwie very ingenious, are egregiouly deluded; becaue they conceive it plentifull atisfaction of minde to them, that they finde it in Books, and have their memories well loaded with age entences. For they that are thus Philoophers extraduce, by decent and derivation, are jut as wie as their owne Libraries.

To conclude therefore, there is in an Egge (as we have often aid) no ditinct part, or dipoed matter, out of which the foetus may be formed and fahioned: but as in the eeds of Plants, there is a litle point or budding hot out; o is there in an Egge, a mall Cicatrice, or Macula, which being inpired with platical endowments, enlarges it elf into the Oculus or Colliquamentum, out of which, and in which, the primordia of the Chicken (namely the Blood and Punctum aliens) are ingendered, nourihed, and augmented, till they become a complete Chicken. Nor is Aritotles definition of an Egge true, where he will have it to be that, out of part of which the Chicken is made, and nourihed by the ret; unles you undertand it thus: An Egg
is that, out of part of which a Chicken is framed, not as out of its Matter, but as Vir ex Puero, a Man is made out of a Boy: or thus; An Egge is a perfect conception, out of which the Chicken is aid partly to be made, and partly to be nourihed: or latly thus; An Egge is that thing, whoe liquors do erve both for the Matter,
de gen. an. l. 2. c. 4. and Nourihment of the parts. And in this ene Aritotle teacheth, That the matter of the foetus in women is mentruous Blood, which (while it is poured into the womb by the veines) Nature emploies it to another ue; namely, to the ue of Generation, that uch another creature may be made, as it would have been; for it is already uch in potentiâ, in poibility, as the bodies from whence it was eparated; that is, the Mothers.

div.head: What the Matter of the Chicken is, and how the Chicken is formed in the Egge.
