EXERCIT. XLV.
div.p: SInce therefore the truth cannot, as I uppoe, be attained out of the opinions of other men, (whether they be confirmed by either their naked authority, or probable argumentations) unles wary experience be imployed in the dicovery: we hal declare to you out of Natures own Volum, and clear Obervations, what the Matter of the Foetus is, and how it is formed thence.

I have declared that one thing is made out of another (as out of its Matter) two everal wayes, and that as well in artificial, as natural Productions, but epecially in the Generation of Animals.
The Firt is, when one thing is made of another thing that is pre-exitent; and thus a Bedtead is made out of Timber, and a Statue out of a Rock, where the whole Matter of the future fabrick was exitent and in being, before it was reduced into the ubequent hape, or any tittle of the deign begun. But the other way is, when the matter is both made, and receiveth its form at the ame time. As therefore Artificial productions are perfected two everal waies; one, when the Artificer cuts and divides the matter which is provided to his hands, and o by paring away the uperfluous parts, doth leave an Image remaining behinde, as the Statuary doth: the other, when the Potter formes the like Image of Clay, by adding more tuff, or augmenting, and o fahioning it, o that at one and the ame time, he provides, prepares, fits, and applies his materials: (and in this way an Image or Figure may be rather aid to be made, then fahioned) o likewie in the Generation of Animals; ome are formed and transfigured, out of matter already concocted and grown; and all the parts are made and ditinguihed together per metamorphoin, by a metamorphois, o that a complete Animal is the reult of that Generation: but ome again, having one part made before another, are afterwards nourihed, augmented, and formed out of the ame matter; that is, they have parts, whereof ome are before, and ome after other, and at the ame time, are both formed, and grow. Now the Fabrick or contitution of thee, proceeds from ome one part, as from its original, and by the help of that, the other members are produced, and thee we ay are made per Epigenein, by a pot-generation, or after-production; that is to ay, by degrees,
part after part; and this is more properly called a Generation, then the former.

After the former way doth the generation of Inects proceed, as when by a Metamorphois a Worm is made of an Egge; or as when out of a putrifying matter (the moiture drying, or the dry part growing moit) the primordia or rudiments are generated, out of which (as out of a Cankerworm now grown to its jut magnitude, or out of the worm called Aurelia) by a Metamorphois arieth a Butter-flie, or common Flie in its jut magnitude or tature, being nothing augmented ince its firt birth. But the more perfect Animals which have blood, are made by an Epigeneis, or uperaddition of parts, and do grow, and attain their jut tature or < in non-Latin alphabet > , after they are born. In thoe other, Caus eu Fortuna, Chance or Fortune, eemeth chiefly to promote the generation; in which the form arieth ex potentiâ materiae prae-exitentis, out of the power or potentiality of the pre-exitent matter; and the matter is rather the firt caue of the Generation, then any external Efficient. And hence it is, that thee kinde of Animals are more imperfect, and do les continue their kinde, or are les durable, then Terretrial or Aquatile creatures that have Blood, which attain a Perpetuity from an Univocal principle: (that is, from the ame Species) the chief caue whereof we acribe to Nature, and the Vegetative Virtue.

Some Animals therefore uâ ponte nacuntur, are born of their own accord, out of a Matter digeted of it elf, or ele caually, as Aritotle eems to aert: Whoe Matter is capable of mutation of it elf, undergoing that mutation by Chance, which eed
Metaphy. l. 7. c. 9. doth, in the generation of other Animals. And the ame thing falls out in the generation of Animals,
as in Art: for ome things are accomplihed by Art, and thoe very things, by chance too; as Health: and other things againe are never produced without Art, as a Houe.

Bees, Wapes, Butterflies, and all thoe creatures, that are generated out of a Worm by a Metamorphois, are aid to be Cau orta, creatures bred by chance, and therefore things not preerving their kind: but a Lyon, or a Cock, are never made by chance, or of their own accord, but have their exitence from Nature, or a more divine operative faculty; at whoe hands they rather require, that it produce a Species like to themelves, then upply a fit Matter.

In Generation by Metamorphois, creatures eem to be fahioned like things wrought off with a Mould, or the Print of a Seale; where the whole Matter is transformed. But an Animal produced by Epigeneis, attracts, prepares, concocts, and applies the Matter at the ame time, and is at the ame time formed, and Augmented. In thoe the Platical vertue divides the ame fimilar Matter, and being divided, dipoes, and reduces it into members; out of a imilar Matter making a diimilar; or out of a imilar ubject Matter, diimilar Organs. But in thee, while it produces divere parts, and thoe parts diverly dipoed, one after another; it requires and makes a divere Matter, and that Matter diverly dipoed, or qualified, uch as may be convenient to the production of different parts. For which caue we conceive, that the Perfect Egge is contituted and made up of everal parts.

It therefore is clear by our Hitory, that the generation of the Chicken out of the Egge, proceeds rather per Epigenein, quam per Metamorphoin, by
an Epigeneis, then by a Metamorphois; and that all its parts are not contituted at once, but ucceively, & in Order; and that while it is augmented it is alo formed, & while it is formed, it is alo augmented; as likewie that ome parts are uperadded to others, and ditinguihed from others; and that the beginning, increae, and perfection of it do proceed by way of growth, till at the lat the Foetus doth reult. For the forming Faculty of the Chicken, doth rather acquire, and temper its own Matter, then find its Matter ready tempered, and fitted to its hand; and the Chicken eems more to be framed, and increaed by his own elf, then by any other. And as all things are increaed or nourihed by the ame things, out of which they are made; o likewie the Chicken is in all likelyhood made by the ame thing, (be it the Soule, or ome faculty of the Soul) by which he is preerved, and utained. For the ame Efficient and Preerver, is found both in the egg & in the Chicken; and out of the ame Matter of which it doth contitute the firt particle or rudiments of the Chicken, it nouriheth, augmenteth, and uperaddeth all the other parts. Latly, in Generation by Metamorphois, the whole is ditributed and ditinguihed into parts; but by Epigeneis the whole is contituted, and made of parts, by a certain order and ucceion.

Wherefore Fabricius did erroniouly eek after the Matter of the Chicken, (as if it were ome ditinct part of the egge,) which went to the imbodying of the Chicken) as though the Generation of the Chicken were effected by a Metamorphois, or transfiguration of ome collected lump or mas, and that all parts of the body, at leat the Principal parts were wrought off at a heat, or (as
himelf peaks) did arie and were corporated out of the ame Matter: and not by Epigeneis, in which an order is oberved according to the dignity, and worth, and ue of the Parts; where firt a mall foundation is laid, which at the ame time while it doth increae, grows ditinct, and formed, and o attains all its parts by degrees, according to their proper order, which are upergenerated, and born to it.

For as the litle top or point which jets forth or protuberateth from the Acorne, taking heat and encreaing, multiplies into a Root, Wood, Sap, Bark, Shoots, Tendrels, Boughs, Blooms, and Fruits, and at lat arieth into a compleat Tree: uch is the progres of the Chicken in the Egge; the Cicatricula or mall peck, which is in the foundation of the future Pile, increaes in Oculum, into an Eye, and at the ame intant is ditinguihed into a Colliquamentum, or diolved ubtance, in whoe Center is born the Punctum anguineum pulans, the Bloody panting point, together with the Ramifications of the Veins: from thee doth by and by reult the Nebula, or litle cloudy Subtance, and firt concrete Matter of the future Body, which alo as it grows, is divided, and ditinguihed into parts, but not all at once, but uch as give place and elderhip to one another.

To conclude therefore, in the Generation of thoe Animals, which are produced by Epigeneis, (as the Chicken in the Egge is) we are not to enquire a particular or ditinct matter, out of which the productions hould be imbodyed, different from that out of which they are nourihed and increaed: for it is nourihed and encreaed by the ame matter, whereof it is made, and o on the othe hand, the Pullus in the Egge is contituted out of
the ame matter, by which it is uteined and augmented. And potentiâ animal, an Animal in potentiâ, is one and the ame thing, with Alibile and Augmentativum, a creature fedde, and augmented in potentiâ, (as we hall hew hereafter) and do differ onely ipo ee formally, (as Aritotle aith) but otherwie are the very ame. For, for as much as this particular thing is, and is convertible into ubtance, Nutritivum et, it is Nutritive: and for as much as it is quantum, indued with quantity, it is Augmentativum, Augmentative: for as much as it is ubtituted in the room of a ubtance that is lot, Nutrimentum appellatur, it is called Nutriment: for as much as it is added to a ubtance already in being, Incrementum dicitur, it is called Growth. And the ame thing is Materia, the Matter in the Generation; Alimentum, the Sutenance in the Nutrition, and Incrementum, the Increae in the Augmentation of the Chicken. But that is formally and imply aid to be generated, whereof no part was exitent before, but that to be nourihed and grow which was, and had an exitence or being before. That part of the Foetus which is firt made, is aid to be begotten or born: that which is ubtituted or uperadded to it, is aid to be annate, aggenerate, or born to it. There is in al things the ame generation, and tranmutation from the ame into the ame: which is performed in repect of a part, by Nutrition and Augmentation, but in repect of the Whole by Generation: ele it is the very ame in both. For from whence the firt exitent matter proceeds, from thence alo doth Nutriment and Growth accrew unto it.

And it hall alo appear by that which hall be delivered hereafter, that all Parts of Bodies are nourihed
by the ame Nutritive ubtance diverly transformed or altered. For as all Plants do indifferently pring, grow, and are uteined from the ame Common Nutriment, diverly varied and digeted (whether it be Dew, or the juice and moiture of the ground) o likewie out of the ame Liquors of the Egge (namely, the White and Yolk) the whole Chicken, and all its parts are procreated and encreaed.

We will then alo explaine, what Animals are begotten by a Metamorphois: and what kind of pre-exitent matter that of the Inects is, which pring from a Worme, out of which, all the parts are together contituted and concorporated, and at lat a perfect Animal born, by Tranmutation onely: as alo what Animals have any order and degrees in their production, and have their Parts produced ucceively: and what kind of creatures they are which are firt borne imperfect, but afterwards hoot up, and attain to perfection, as all thoe that are produced out of an Egge.

Thee, as they are together made, and augmented, growing, and transformed; and are by a propoed method and order ditinguihed into parts; o have they no immediate pre-exitent Matter (uch as is uually deigned them; namely, the commixture of the feminine and maculine eed, or the Mentruous Blood, or ome litle portion of the egge) out of which the foetus hould aume his body; but o oon as ever the Matter is made and provided, it grows alo, and takes ome hape; o oon as there is a Nutriment, there is a creature to be nourihed by it.

And this Generation is rather by Epigeneis (as a Man is out of a Boy) that is, the fabrick and tructure of the body is out of the Punctum aliens, as
out of its foundation: as out of the Keel the Ship is built: and rather as the Potter forms an Image, without any pre-exitent Matter; then out of any ubject matter: as the Carpenter forms a Bench out of Boards: and the Statuary a Statue of Marble. For out of the ame matter whence the firt particle of the Chicken, or its leat atome aries, thence alo doth the whole Chicken proceed: whence the firt mall drop of Blood, thence alo is the whole tream or current of it generated in the egg: whatoever gives a conitence or being to the members or organical parts of the body, doth alo afford the ame to all the imilar parts likewie; as, to the Skin, the Fleh, Veins, Membranes, Nerves, Cartilages, and Bones. For that very part which was oft and flehy, at firt, is afterward upon its increae, made a Nerve, Ligament, Tendon, by the ame Aliment; that which was onely a Membrane, becomes a Coat; and that which was a Gritle, is afterwards advanced into a Skin or Bone; and this by the ame imilar matter variouly altered. For a imilar mixt body (which is commonly conceived to be framed out of the Elements) is not made of the Elements firt ubiting apart by themelves, and then afterwards compounded, united, and altered, but out of this particular mixt body being altered, another mixt body is born and produced, that is, Of the Colliquamentum is the blood made, of the blood the bulk of the body; which bulk at firt doth appear imilar, and like the Spermatical Gluten, or clammy ubtance; but from it the parts are delineated by an obcure indicernable diviion at firt, but afterwards become organical and ditinct.

Thoe imilar parts, I ay, do not arie from the diimilar, and heterogeneous Elements, united together,
but are framed and dicriminated by Generations out of a imilar ubtance, and o become diimilar. As if by the Omnipotents command, or fiat, the whole Chicken were created.

As thus: let there be a imilar White lump, and let that lump or mas be divided into parts, and increaed; and while it is increaed, let there be a ecretion and delineation of the parts; and let this part be harder, thicker, and whiter; and that ofter, and well coloured; And it was o. For thus doth the tructure of the Chicken in the Egge proceed daily; out of one and the ame matter are all its limbs and utenils made, nourihed, and augmented. From the Spine firt do the Ribs grow out, and the Bones are ditinguihed from the Fleh, by their mot white lender Lines: three Bullae are dicernable in the Head, which are all fraught with a Crytalline Water, being the Rudiments of the braine, After-braine, and (as by a princkled black treak is implyed) of one of the Eyes: The ubtance which at firt reembleth coagulated milk, becomes at lat gritly, pinous, and bony: and that which at firt was white, and gelly-ih: paeth at length into a bluhing fleh, and Parenchyma. That which was formerly mot tranparent and pure Water, is transformed anon into the braine, Afterbraine, and eyes. For there is a far greater, and diviner mytery in Generation, then a bare aembling, altering, and compounding of Parts: for the Whole is made and dicovered before its parts; the Mixt body before the Elements. But of this more hereafter; when alo its Caues, and Principles come to be aigned.

div.head: Of the Efficient Caue of the Generation of the Chicken, and Foetus.
EXER. XLVI.
div.p: THus far of the Matter, out of which the Chicken prings in the Egge: it remaines now that we enquire a little with Fabricius, concerning the Efficient caue of the Chicken. But becaue it is a perplext buines, and Authors do no where more cavil and contend; and Aritotle himelf is wonderful intricate in explaining it; and alo many doubts, not to be depied, do interpoe; I conceive it worth the while, (as we have done in making earch after the Matter) in the firt place to et down, how many ways a thing may be aid to be Efficient, or Effective: that o it may more certainly and ditinctly appear, what is to be enquired after under the name of Efficient; as alo what is to be reolved concerning the opinion of Authors about this matter: and that it may likewie appear out of our own obervations, what is to be truely and properly called an Efficient.

Moreover, becaue ome things from which mutation doth proceed, are neerer caues of it, and ome more remote: thereupon ometimes media, the things between the firt efficient, and the lat effect, and alo the Intruments are counted Efficients: as alo ubordinate ends, or the principles of ubequent things, are ranked amongt efficient caues; and hereupon is it, that ome parts are called Genital parts; as the Heart, from which Aritotle affirms the other parts to proceed, as is clear alo by our Hitory, I ay the Heart, or at let the rudiment of the Heart; namely, the Veicula, and Punctum aliens, doth erect and et up the ret of the Body, as a future habitation for it elf: and when it is built, takes poeion, enlivens, and wayes it, and fortifies it with the uperaddition of the Ribs, and Breat-bone, as with a Bulwark: and becomes, as it were, a Tutelar God, the firt chamber that entertaines the oule, the firt receptacle of the primigenial heat, and the Vetal animal-fire; the ource and fountain of all the Faculties, and the only olace in Afflications.

Again, ince the Efficient is o called, in order to the Effect; eeing by Epigeneis ome parts are after other in order, and divers alo pring from
thoe that are before them: it is therefore probable, that as the Effects, o the Efficients are alo divere; which produce divere works, from which alo divere mutations do proceed. So Phyitians, in the Phyiological part of Phyick, do contitute ome Intruments of Chylification, ome of Sanguification, and ome of Generation: and ome Anatomits, an Oifical, Carnifical, and a Nervifical faculty; which they depute to make the Bones, the Fleh, and the Nerves.

But in the Generation of the Chicken, the efficient caues mut needs differ, by reaon of the everal actions relating to it, which differ very much; which, though they may eem Efficientes per accidens, contingent Efficients of Generation, yet are they necearily required, ince nothing could be done without their aociat ayd. For while they remove external Impediments, or do cherih, or awaken the conception, and de potentiâ in actum deducunt, raie it from poibility into actual being, they are jutly tiled efficients. And in this Rowle, the Incubation of the Hen, the temper and warmth of the Place, and Air, the Spring-time, and the approach of the Sun by the Zodiack, may be well lited: as alo the preparing caues, which caue the Yolk to acend, the Macula to be dilated, and the reolution, or melting of the humours in the Egge, may be mutered amongt efficients.

And then the Generative and Architectonical faculties, which Fabricius calls parts, are to be numbred with the efficient caues; as, the Immutatrix, Concoctrix, Formatrix, & Auctrix, the Altering, Concocting, Forming, and Augmenting faculty; as alo thoe caues that are efficients in the Accidents relating to the Chicken, as that, by which the Chicken is either a Cock
or a Henne, reembling the He or Shee-parent: and that in relation to the form of the Cock which was concerned in the former, or latter coition: whence it comes to pas that the Chicken is an animal, and that an entire one, and not dimembered, turdy, and ound, not dieaed, and craie, but a long liver; and retaining the Species, or degenerating from it; or proves a Monter, or of a mixt race.

Latly, ince in treating of the efficient caue of the foetus, we dicover the notable tructure of it, and the actions, functions, ues, and benefits of all the parts and members, and with what prudence, skill, and judgment, by how divine an inpiration all things are managed, and artificially compoed for the advantage of Life: we mut not only amue our elves in inquiring, which is the Efficient, Architect, and Projector, but alo adore, and admire the Omnipotent Author and Preerver of o great a Fabrick (as jutly merits the title of a Microcome.) We alo enquire, when, and whence it proceedeth; and where this divine Vicar, and Vice-Roy of the deity, which is analogous to the ubtance of Stars, and neer allyed to Art, and Intellect, takes up its reidence, and keeps its Court.

It is apparent therefore by what hath been aid, that it is a difficult thing to enumerate all the efficient caues of the Pullus: and we mut needs referre the fuller diquiition of the thing to a general conideration; nor is it poible to treat fully and profitably of thoe things which agree to all in general, out of the ingle generation of the Chicken (without a clearer light borrowed by experience from other Animals.) And that the rather, becaue Aritotle himelf hath recounted o many various efficient principles of Animals: For ometimes
he ordaines Metaphy. 1. 2. & 4. 1. the Male the chief efficient caue, as in whom the Ratio pulli, the Reaon or ground of the Made Chicken conits: according to that, Meta. 7. 10. all things are made by the ame Univocal. Sometimes, De par. an. 1. 1. the Males eed: or De gen. an. 1. 20. the Nature of the Male ejecting eed. Sometimes, Ibid. l. 2. c. 3. that which is in the eed, cauing eed to be fruitfull; namely, the Spirit, and the nature in that Spirit, anwerable in proportion to the ubtance of the Starres. Ele where, l. 5. c. 3. heat,
l. 4. c. 2. moderate heat,
l. 4. c. 4. a certain proportionable degree of heat,
De par. an. 2. 2. the heat in the Blood; and in ome places, the heat of the Ambient Aire. Likewie De gen. an. 4. 2. the Winds, the Sun, the Heavens, Jupiter, the Soul, and in general, Nature, which is the Principle of Motion and Ret. And o by the ame rule, Any of the Stoicks, who thought the Soul to be fire, may decree fire the efficient caue of Animals; becaue fire doth nourih and augment it elf, and eems in ome ort to live at its own dipoe De gen. & corrup. l. 2. c. 30. and liberty: though not our detructive culinary fire, but the Natural, Celetial, Vegetative, De gen. an. l. 2. c. c. Generating, and Healthy fire, which the Heathen worhipped by the name of Jupiter, whom they called the Father of Men and Things; not his lame Brother Vulcan, (whoe ayd and benefit we notwithtanding daily ue in everal employments to our great advantage) but the divine, Animal Spirit, the Author of Living creatures.

And therefore Aritotle aith, That this quetion concerning the Efficient is very dubious; namely, Whether it be an extrinecal thing, or omething inerted in the Geniture or Seed: and Whether it be a part of the oul, or the oul, or omething which hath a oul.

Wherefore that we may deliver and rid our elves of the maze and labyrinth of the manifold Efficient caues, in this diquiition of the Efficient
of the Chicken, we have need of Ariadnes Clew, woven and cunningly wrought of the Obervations of almot all Creatures living. And therefore it is to be deferred to a more general Inquet. In the mean time, we hall recount thoe things, which relating to the particular generation of the Chicken out of the egge, do manifetly appear, or are trangers to the common perwaion, or ele do require any further earch.

div.head: How the Efficient caue of the Chicken doth operate, according to Aritotle.
EXERCIT. XLVII.
div.p:
ALl men generally confes the Male to be the primary efficient caue in Generation; as in whom the Species or Form reides: And they farther affirm, that his Geniture being emitted in coition doth caue both the being, and fertility of the Egge. But how the eed of the Cock doth produce the chicken out of the Egge, neither the Antient nor Modern Philoophers and Phyitians have ufficiently explained, nor yet olved the quetion propoed by Aritotle. Nay Aritotle himelf hath not done it. He aith, The Male doth not conduce to the Quantity, but the Quality; and is Principium Motûs, the
De gen. an l. 1. c. 20. Principle of Mutation; but the Female contributes the matter. And a while after: Every Male doth not emit eed, nor is it any part of the Foetus, in thoe that do emit it: As nothing which paeth from the Carpenter
contributes to the matter of the Wood; nor is there any part of the Carpenters art in that which is made, but the form and pecies doth exit in the matter per motum ab illo, by the motion or mutation which proceeds from him. Now the oule in which the form and knowledge is, moves the hands, or other members, by the motion of a certain quality; which motion is either divere, in uch as make a divere thing, or the ame in uch as make the ame. But the hands and intruments move the matter. So the Nature of the Male which emitteth eed, imployes that eed, as an Intrument, and having motion actually in it, as in the productions of Art the Intruments are moved; for in them, in ome ort, the motion of Art is implanted.

By which words he eems to imply, that Generation is made by the motion of a certain Quality. As in Art, though the firt caue (namely ratio operis, the reaon or ground of the work) be in the oul of the Artit; yet afterward the work is effected by the motion of the hands, or other Intruments; and though the firt caue be removed (as in automatis, things that eem to move of themelves) yet is it in ome ort aid to move that, which at preent it doth not touch, but hath touched formerly, o long as the motion goes on in the Intruments.

And in the following Book he hath thee words: The eed of the Male when now it hath acces
Lib. 2. c. 4. into the womb of the Female, it doth coagulate, and caue a conitence in the puret part of the excrement (meaning the mentruous blood reiding in the womb) and doth tranmute the matter which lies ready in the womb by uch a motion or mutation, that at lat, though the eed vanih after the motion is performed, ome part of the foetus is exitent, and that an animate
part (as the heart) which now doth augment and dipoe it elf, as a Son who is free from his Father, and hath taken a houe of his own. It is neceary therefore that there be ome principle by which afterwards the order of the members may be delineated, and all things dipoed, which pertain to the abolution and complement of the Animal; and from which growth and motion may arrive to the ret of the parts, and be the author of all the imilar and diimilar parts, and of their lat aliment. For that which is now an Animal, doth increae; but the lat aliment of the Animal is blood, or omething proportionable to blood, whoe veels and receptacles are the Veines. Now the principle or original of the veines is the Heart. But the Veines like Roots extend even to the womb, by which the Foetus draweth his aliment. The Heart alo being the beginning of the whole nature, and alo the containing End, ought to be made firt, as being a genital part of its own nature; which mut needs be the firt, as the original of the ret, and of the whole Animal, and of Sene: in whoe heat (becaue all the parts are in the matter potentially) ince the principle of motion did abide, that which follows afterwards, is tirred up by it, as in thoe elf-moving miracles; and the parts are moved, not hifting their places, but altering in oftne, hardne, heat, and other ditinctions of imilar parts, being now actually made, which were potentially before.

This is Aritotles opinion almot word for word, by which he conceives the foetus to be made of eed by motion; though it do not at preent continue touching it, but hath touched it formerly: a nice opinion, and of a fine thread; and according to thoe things which are dicovered in the order of the generation of the parts, not improbable. For the heart, together with the ramifications
of the Veins, is dicerned firt; as being an animate principle, in which both ene and motion reide; and being alo like a free Son, and a Genital part, by which the order of the member is delineated, and all things conducing to the accomplihment of an Animal, are dipoed, and having all thoe attributes which Aritotle betowes upon it.

But it eems impoible that the heart hould be made in the egge by the males eed; ince that eed is neither in the egge, nor doth touch, nor ever did touch it: becaue it neither enters the womb (where the egge is made) as Fabricius confeeth, nor is any way attracted by it; and beides this, the mothers blood is not in the egge neither, nor any other prepared matter, out of which the males eed might form this firt genital part, the author of all the ret. Nor yet preently upon coition (while the eed as yet remaines within, and is tangent) doth any particle of the chicken exit, but many dayes after, upon Incubation. And it is likewie improbable too, that in fihes, where the males geniture only toucheth the egge on the outide, but doth not enter into it, that the geniture hould have any more operation and power upon it, (ince it is meerly an external Agent) then the Cocks eed hath upon the Hennes egges which are now perfectly formed.

Again, ince preently after coition there is no track of the egge extant, but that it is afterwards generated by the Henne by her elf, and that prolifical too, when now the Cocks eed is clean gone and vanihed; it is unlikely that the foetus hould be made by that eed in that egge, by one ingle motion, or by ucceive motions.

And by the generation of the chicken it is alo manifet, that whatoever be the principium vitae, the firt caue of life, and vegetation, was firt of all in the heart. Wherefore, if it be the oul of the Chicken, it is plain that it alo was in the Punctum aliens, and in the Blood; becaue we dicover motion & ene there: for it moves and dances like an Animal; o that if the oule do exit in the Punctum aliens, building, nourihing, and enlarging the ret of the body, (as we have hewed in our Hitory)
Then it flowes from the Heart as from the Springhead into the whole body.

Likewie if the Egge be therefore Prolifical becaue de gen. an. l. 2. c. 4. it hath a oul, or (as Aritotle would have it) a part of the Vegetative oul; it is plaine, that the Punctum aliens, and the Genital animate part, doe proceed from the Soul of the egge; (for nothing is the Author of it elf) and that the oul is derived from the egge into the Punctum aliens, by and by into the Heart, and at length into the Chicken.

Adde to thee, if the egge have a prolifical vertue, and Vegetative oul, by which it erects a Pullus; and do owe them (as it is plain it doth, and all men confes it) to the eed of the Cock; it is then certain that this Seed is Animate: For o Aritotle: Whether the eed have a oul or no; there is the ame reaon
Ibid. l. 2. c. 1. to be given for it as for the Parts. For no oul can be in any thing but in that whoe oul it is; nor can there be any part which is not partaker of the oul: unles it be an aequivocal part, as the eye of a dead man. That therefore the eed hath a oul, and a being in potentiâ, is clear.

It therefore follows out of what hath been aid, that the Male is the Primary Efficient, in which Ratio, & forma, the Reaon and Form is; which Efficient begets a prolifical eed, or Geniture rather, and that Geniture endowed with a Vegetative oul, (with which alo its other parts are endowed) he doth tranmit into the female. This Geniture being tranmitted, it moveth the Matter in the Hen, that o an Animate egge may be produced; by which means the firt particle of the Chicken is animated, and afterwards the whole Chicken. So that according to Aritotle, either the ame oul is conveied by a Metempychois, from the Cock into
his Geniture, from his Geniture into the ubtance of the Hen, from thence into the egge, and from the egge into the Chicken; or ele is raied up in the ubequent by the precedent things, namely by the Male, in his proper eed; by the eed, in the egg: and at lat by the egge, in the Chicken, tanquam lumen de lumine, as light derived from light.
The Efficient therefore which is ought for in the egge, from whence the Chicken is born, is a oul; and the oul of the Egge: for according to Aritotle, the oul is onely in that thing, whoe oule it is.

Nor is it transferred by a Metempychois, or certain tranlation of the oul from the Cock and his eed, into the egge, and thence into the Chicken? For how can it be tranlated into the Egges that are yet to come, and to be conceived after Coition? Unles ome Animate Seed do lurke in the Hen all the while; or ele the oul onely without eed be tranlated, that o it may be afterwards infued into the Egge when the Egg hall be made. But neither of thee is true. For the eed is
no where found in the Hen: nor is it poible that the Hen hould after Coition poes two ouls; namely, her own, and the oul of the future eggs, and Chickens: for the oul is never aid to be, but in that whoe oul it is: much lee can one, or more ouls lye lurking in the Hen, that o they may attend the future eggs and chickens which are to be born in their order.

We have deduced thee paages out of Aritotle, that from them it might appear, how the Cocks eed doth, according to him, produce the Chicken out of the Egge, that o ome light might be afforded to this perplext diquiition. But eeing they do not explaine how this buines is accomplihed, nor yet alve his own objections; we are till ticking in the ame mire, and involved in the ame doubts, (concerning the Efficient caue of the Foetus, in the Generation of Animals) nay o far are we from receiving any clear atisfaction, that we are rather more perplext, and to eek, then we were before. And therefore no wonder this excellent Philoopher was in the treights concerning this matter, and did therefore range together o many everal orts of efficient caues of Animals, and ometims betake himelf to examples drawn from Automata, things eeming to move of themelves, ometimes to coagulatedmatter, ometimes to Art, Intruments, and Motion; ometimes to the oul in the egge, and in the eed of the Male, (to illutrate the thing) and where he eems to be poitive and ettle upon ome determination, concerning what it may be, that hould render the Seed, (be it of Plants, or Animals) fertile; he renounces Heat and Fire, as improper Agents; nor doth he admit any uch like faculty; nor can he find out any thing in the eed
it elf, which hould be fit for the undertaking; but is compelled to admit of a certain Incorporeal extrinecal thing, which hould (like Art, or the Minde) form the foetus by wiedom and providence, and ordain and intitute all things relating to it, to ome end and purpoe, and to its better ubitence. He takes, I ay, anctuary, in an obcure and ignote thing; namely, in a pirit contained in the eed and frothy ubtance, and a certain nature in that pirit anwerable in proportion to the ubtance of the Stars. But what that hould be, he no where reveals.

div.head: Fabricius his Opinion concerning the Efficient caue of the Chicken is confuted.
EXERCIT. XLVIII.
div.p: SInce I have propoed Aritotle, the chiefet of the old Philoophers, and Hieronymus Fabricius ab Aquapendente, an eminent Anatomit amongt the Modern, to be my Leaders, that from them I might chiefly be enlightened concerning the generation of Animals, and ince I cannot better my elf by Aritotle, I have reolved to et upon Fabricius, to ee what account he can give of it.

Now he attempts to give reolution to three doubts ariing in the cae: namely, Firt, What is the Efficient of the Chicken? and that he concludes to be the Males eed. 2. How this appears in the egg to be o, and by what means the Cocks eed doth
rinder the egge fertile? Latly, In what Order are the parts of the Chicken procreated?
As for the firt, it appears out of our Obervations, that the Cock and his eed are indeed the Efficicient caue of Generation, but not the adaequate caue; but that the Henne alo comes in for a hare.
In this place therefore we mut chiefly enquire, how the Cocks eed doth fructifie the Egge, and raie a Chicken out of it, which would ele be ubventaneous, and improlifical.

But let us give ear to Fabricius: Thoe creatures, pag. 38. aith he, that are produced out of an egge, are different from thoe which are born out of eed; in this, that Oviparous creatures have a matter, out of which the Chicken is corporated, ditinct and eparate from the Agent: but Viviparous creatures have both the material and efficient caue adjoyned, and concorporated together. For the Agent in Oviparous creatures, is the eed of the Cock in the feathered kind, which neither is, nor can be in the Egge: but the matter out of which the Chicken is corporated, is the Chalaza. Thee two are much ditant one from another; for the Chalaza is in the Yolk now formed, and fallen into the econd Uterus, and is adjoyned intimately to the egge: on the contrary, the Cocks eed remains neer the fundament, and is removed from the Chalaza by a large chame, and yet by its irradiating faculty it fructifies both the Uterus, and all the egge. But in a Viviparous animal, the eed is both the Matter, and the Efficient too, both being contracted into one body.

He eems to have introduced this difference between Oviparous and Viviparous Animals; that o he might countenance the opinion of Phyitians concerning the Generation of Man, or at leat not ubvert it; who conceive that the eeds of both
Sexes, ejected together in coition are mingled, and according as the one prevailes over the other, o the one approves it elf the Efficient, and the other ubmits it elf to become the Matter; o that they both conpiring together, do contitute the conception in Viviparous Animals.

But when he had oberved, that neither Seed nor Blood is attracted by means of coition into the womb of the Hen, nor contained there, and could not believe, that any thing emitted from the cock in coition, could poibly arrive o farre, nor could finde any thing in the Egge, that is adjoined to the males eed, he was enforced to doubt, how the eed (which is no where preent with, nor mingled amongt the feminine geniture, nor is adjoined to it, nor doth o much as touch it at all) hould contitute the Chicken, or fructifie the Egge? epecially when he had before delivered, that from ome premied coitions, all the eggs that were to be layed that year, were made prolifical. For how could it chue but eem impoible, that from the eed of the cock received in the Spring (but now departed, lot, and conumed) the pothume eggs (layed poibly in Summer or Autumne) hould be rendered fruitfull, and produce chickens?

That he might rid his hands of this grand difficultie, he coined the fore-aid ditinction; and to ratifie his opinion, he adds three farther Aertions: Firt, that though the cocks eed were neither in the Egge, nor at any time in the Womb, nor adjoined to the material caue, (as it is in Viviparous Animals) yet it continues for a whole year in the hen. Secondly, to reerve this eed in, he invents a dark perforation, neer the door of the Womb, wherein the cock hould depoite his eed, and in which (as in a pouch) it hould be concluded;
that thence all the eggs might receive their fertility. Latly, though the eed in that pouch, neither touch the womb, the egge, nor the Ovary, that by that means it might fructifie the egge, or raie a Chicken out of it; yet, he aith, that it gains addrees into the very egge, by the ininuation, or irradiation of a certain piritual ubtance in it, and by thoe arts doth fructifie the Chalazae, and o model a Chicken. And yet by that aertion lie eems to confirme Aritotles opinion (who aures us that the female contributes the matter, and the male the efficiency to generation) which is contrary to the Phyitians poition concerning the commixture of eeds: for whoe ake he eems to have introduced his fore-aid ditinction between Oviparous, and Viviparous Animals. And that this his opinion may eem more probable, he recites what changes and alterations the eed reerved in the Teticles and eminary Veicles, not yet emitted, doth procure in Animals.

But to take no notice that all this makes litle to his purpoe: (for the quetion in chief is not, How the Cocks eed doth render the egge fertile? but rather, How it doth frame and erect a Chicken out of the Egge?) all thoe things which he hath conjured up to guard his opinion, eem for the mot part fale, or very upicious; as appears by our Obervations delivered in this Hitory. For neither is that blinde perforation in the root of the rump (which he calls the pure, or pouch) detined to cubbard up the Cocks eed, nor is there (as we have aid) any eed at all found in it: but it is an empty unprovided thing both in the Cock, and Henne.

But what he would have by his piritual ubtance, and irradiation, he is yet to acquaint us, as
alo what ubtance hee undertands that to be, which he affirms, doth by its virtue vivifie the egg, Whether a corporeal, or formal ubtance, which hould proceed from the irradiation of the eed, (which lies at root in the pouch) and (which is chiefly required) hould fahion the Chicken out of the egge.

To conclude, in my minde, he aith no more in ubtance then this: It makes the Chicken, becaue it irradiates the Egge; and forms it, becaue it vivifies it: and o he labours to reveal and illutrate the obcure manner of formation, by one more obcure then it elf. For the ame cruple returns entire; namely, how the Cocks eed, a meer nontangent, an external efficient, and disjoyned by place, remaining in the pouch, can fahion the interiour parts (that is, the Heart, Liver, Lungs, and Guts, &c.) in the egge out of the Chalazae, by Irradiation? Unles he will have it itting in its chair of State, like the Creator of all, only by this word of comman, Fiant, Let all things be o; (namely the Bones for Support, the Mucles for Motion, the Organs for Sene; the Members for Action, the Intrals for Concoction, and the like) and o order, and by its beams or influence contitute all things to their proper end, with providence, widom, and art. For neither doth Fabricius expound the manner, nor yet demontrate the eed to be of uch force and virtue, that (without coming neer) it can effect all this; epecially ince an egge can, by Incubation of a tranger fowle, or any other fotering warmth; as in dung, in a matt, or an oven, though never o remote from the pouch of its own mother-hen, be quickened, and produce a foetus.

The ame difficulty therefore lyes till upon our hands; namely, How the Cocks eed is the Efficient
caue of the Chicken? nor is it any whit alved by the influence of this piritual ubtance. For though we hould grant, that the eed is reerved in the pure, and that by a Metamorphois, and Irradiation, it did corporate the chicken out of the Chalazae: yet the cruple would tick no les by us; namely, How the Intrals of the Chicken are modelled. But thee things are long ince confuted by us.

Wherefore, when we are in quet of the efficient caue of the Chicken, we mut look for it in the Egge, and not dormant in a pouch; and for uch a one, which, though the egg now grown tale, were ditant many miles from the Hen, and laid under an other Hen (as a Turkey-hen, or African-hen) to be hatched; or (as in Aegypt) under warm and, or dung, or in an Oven proper for the purpoe, would till raie up a chicken, of the ame pecies, and very like the Cock and Hen that were its natural parents; or ele (in cae the Cock were of a different kinde) a mungrel of-pring, of a mixt pecies, and reemblance.

Wherefore the knot remains to be united, which neither Aritotle nor Fabricius have looened; namely, How the eed of the Male, or Cock, doth produce the chicken out of the egge, or is to be named the Efficient caue of the chicken, epecially, ince it is neither preent, tangent, nor adjoined to the Egge? And though almot all men conclude, that the Male, and its eed are the Efficient caue of the Foetus; no man yet hath ufficiently declared, how it can be done, epecially in our Hen-egg.

div.head: The Efficient caue of the Chicken, is hard to be found out.
EXER. XLIX.
div.p: THe diquiition of the Efficient is exceeding difficult; (as we have aid) and that the rather, becaue o many names are attributed to it. Whereupon Aritotle doth recount very many efficient caues of Animals: And many controveries are rien amongt authors; chiefly, between Phyitians and Aritotelians, who contend very earnetly about it; endeavouring by different opinions to explain both the Efficient caue, and the manner of its Efficiency.

And indeed the Omnipotent Creator, doth in none of his works more manifetly reveale the preence of his Deity, then in the Fabrick and Structure of Animals. And though it be a known thing, ubcribed by all, that the foetus aumes its original and birth from the Male and Female, and conequently that the Egge is produced by the Cock and Henne, and the Chicken out of the Egge: yet neither the Schools of Phyitians, nor Aritotles dicerning Brain, have dicloed the manner, how the Cock and its eed, doth mint and coine the Chicken out of the Egge. For it is evident enough, by what we have delivered, concerning the Generation of Oviparous Animals, and others, that neither the Opinion of Phyitians, deducing Generation from the mixture of the Seeds of both Sexes, nor Aritotles neither, etablihing the eed of the Male for the Efficient, and the Mentruous Blood for the material Caue, are to be embraced:
becaue that neither in Coition, nor preently upon Coition, any thing doth part from the Female into the Cavity of the Uterus; out of which, as out of the Matter, any thing relating to the Foetus hould be uddenly produced: nor doth the Geniture of the Male (whether it be animate it elf, or an animate Intrument) enter into the Womb, or is attracted thither, or any where ele reerved in the Female, but doth either vanih, or retract: nor is there any thing ele to be found in the Uterus preently after Coition, which iuing either from the Male or Female, may be fanied to be the Matter or Original of the future Foetus. Nor is the Cocks eed urviving in Fabricius his Pouch, or any where ele in the Henne; that thence, either by the irradiation and influence of piritual ubtance, or by contact the egge is made, or a Chicken out of the Egge. Nor doth the Hen contribute any other eed, then the Papulae, the Yolk, and the Egge. And therefore the contemplation is rendered more intricate by our Obervations; becaue by them all thoe uppoitions, upon which both the other opinions were upported, are thrown down to the ground. But epecially, when we hall anon demontrate, that all Animals are alike generated out of an Egge; and that in Coition (whether of Viviparous, Brutes, or Men) no Seed or Blood, proceeding from either Male or Female, is entertained in the Hollow of the Womb, or drawn up thither before Coition, or in Coition, or after Coition is found in the Womb, which may be conceived to be the Matter Efficient, or Principle of the future Foetus.

Daniel Sennertus, a late learned Man, and a careful Inquirer into Nature, having firt ballanced other mens opinions, attempts at lat to reolve
the buines; concluding that the Soul is in the Seed, and that it is the very ame Soul with that, which afterwards informs the Infant: o that he makes no cruple to affirm that the Rational oul of man, is preent in his Seed: and that therefore the Egge poees the Soul of the Chicken: and that the oul is conveied with the Seed into the Womb of the Female: and from that eed of both Sexes conjoyned (as one flame to another) but not mixed (for mixture, aith he, repects things of divere Species) but indowed with a oul, a perfect Animal doth reult. And therefore, aith he, the Seed of both Sexes is required, both to the contitution of an Infant, and of an egge. And thus, (like one that had ubdued all difficulties) He conceives, he hath delivered a certain and perpicuous Truth.

But, granting that there is a Soul in the egge, and that oul united and made up of the ouls of the Parents, and ometimes proceeding from Parents of of everal kinds, as from a Mare and an As, from a Dunghil-Hen and a Cock-Pheaant; and that it is not Mixed, but United; and that the Chicken (after the manner of the Seed of Vegetables) is made by that efficient oul, being afterwards preerved by it, all its life long: o that it be counted aburd to affirm, that the foetus is cherihed by one oul out of the Uterus, or egge; and by another in the Uterus or egge: uppoe, I ay, we grant all this (though it be invalid, and doubtful) yet our Hitory of the Generation out of the Egge, doth utterly ubvert, and confute as fale the very foundation and bais upon which all his doctrine leans, and relies: Which is this, That the egge is contituted of the Seed of Cock and Hen: or, that the eed is tranmitted from both into the Uterus: or
that the foetus, or any part of it is formed of the eed o entertained by the womb, or cat into it: or, that the eed of the Cock (as an Efficient caue, or Operatour) is any where reerved in the Hen, which (as he conceives) draws matter and nutriment from her into the Womb, to upport the foetus which it hath made. For the conditions which he himelf according to Aritotle reputes neceary, will be found wanting: namely, that the foetus ought to be made of that which actually is in being, and doth pre-exit: and that the Chicken is nourihed by that which is preent with it, and in the ame place where it elf is firt contituted: As alo, that it hould be made by that which doth operate being immediately conjoyned to it; and ought to be the ame thing, by which the chicken is preerved, and augmented all its life-time. For the cocks eed (whether Animate, or Inanimate, it matters nothing) is not at all in the Egge, not in the Uterus, preent, and conjoyned; nor in the matter whence the chicken is framed, as neither in the Chicken it elf now begun, that o it may either frame, or perfect it.

He micarries likewie, when he goes about to illutrate his opinion concerning the Animal eed, by alluion to that of Plants, and Mat: becaue he did not undertand the difference alledged by Aritotle, between the Geniture proceedings by coition, and the firt conception made out of both Sexes; nor did oberve that an egge might be firt conceived in the Cluter of the Vitellary (without the tranlation of any Geniture from Male and Female into the Uterus.) Nor did he apprehend that the Uterus, even for ome time after Coition, is quite void of any matter at all, either tranmitted from the Parents, or made by Coition, or occaioned
any other way. Nor had he read, or at leat oberved Fabricius his experiment; namely, that after ome Coitions of the Cock, the Hen may be o fructified, that from that time for the whole ucceeding year he may lay all Prolifical Egges: though he have not in the interim convered with the cock, whereby each particular egge might receive fecundity; nor yet retained o long the eed he formerly received.

This is agreed upon by univeral conent; that all Animals whatoever, which arie from Male and Female, are generated by the coition of both Sexes; and o begotten as it were per contagium aliquod, by a kind of contagion. In like manner as Phyitians oberve, that contagious dieaes (as the Leproie, the Pox, the Plague, and Pthiick) do propagate their infection, and beget themelves in bodies yet ound and untoucht, meerly by an extrinecal contact; nay ometimes onely by the breath, and per
< in non-Latin alphabet > , by inquination; and that at a ditance, through an inanimate medium, and that medium no way enibly altered. So that, that which had the firt touch, begets an Univocal like it elf, not as touching at this intant, nor yet now actually in being, nor as preent, or conjoined, but meerly becaue it once hath touched. Of o great operation and energy is Contagion. And perhaps the ame thing obtains in the Generation of Animals. For Fihes egges, which acquire their growth abroad at their own dipoe, without any Male-eed, (and therefore do without all doubt live without it) being beprinkled with the Males prolifical milkey ubtance, and only tinctured from without, do generate fihes. Tis not, I ay, an intromiion, or intimate reception of the maculine eed into each particular egge,
which ets it a work about the fabrick of bodies, or introduces the oul, but a bare contact. Whereupon Aritotle calls lac maris, the Males milk, or Hit. an. l. 6. c. 13. genital eed cat into water, ometimes genital, and propagating liquor: and ometimes Vital Venom. For aith he, The Maculine fih princkles the egges with genital eed, and thoe egges which that Vitale Virus, Vital or quickning Venom touches, out of them are born fihes. It being therefore laid down as an undoubted principle, that the foetus is made by Contagion, there will a weighty doubt arie; namely, how bare Contagion can be the author of o great a work? and how the parents can by that generate iues like themelves; or the males eed produce an Univocal like that creature from which it proceeded? ince after contact it bids adieu, and is no longer in being, or touching, or preent at all, but clean corrupted, and a Non-ens. How, ay I, can a Non-ens act? or a Non-tangens erect a fabrick like it elf? or that which is dead it elf, impart a life to another thing, and meerly upon this account, that the time was when it did touch.

For Aritotles argumentation eems fale, or de gen. an. l. 1. c. 6. lame at leat, where he contends: That Generation cannot be without an Agent and a Patient: and thoe things cannot act and uffer, which do not mutually touch each other: but thoe things do mutually touch, which having each their particular magnitude and place apart, have their extremities meeting one another.

But ince the cae is plain, that Contagion (where the things touch not, nor have their extremities kiing one another) can detroy living creatures, what hould hinder, but that it hould be as powerful, to conduce to the life and generation of animals.?
The Efficient in an Egge, by a platical vertue (becaue the male did but onely touch, though he now be far from touching, and have no extremity reached out towards it) doth frame and et up a foetus in its own pecies and reemblance. And this author of fecundity, this peircing power is tranlated through o many mediums or intruments, that one cannot pattern it, neither by that mutation procured by intruments (as in the productions of Art) nor by Aritotles Automata, nor our Clocks or Watches; nor by the intance of a King in his own dominions, where his command is every where a law; nor can you ratifie this our doctrine, by introducing a oul into the eed or geniture.

And hereupon many controveries, and problemes are tarted concerning the attractive power of the Load-tone and Jet: concerning Sympathy, and Antipathy, concerning Poyon, and the contagion of petilential dieaes: concerning Alexipharmacal Medicines, and uch as cure or kill from an occult (or rather ignote) quality and propriety: all which eem to execute their pleaures without any touching. And chiefly this. What is there in generation, that by a momentany touch (nay not touching at all, unlee through the ides of many mediums) can orderly contitute the parts of the Chicken by an Epigeneis, and produce an Univocal creature, and its own like? and for no other reaon, but becaue it touched heretofore. How, I ay, can that which is not preent, and did onely touch outwardly, contitute, orderly dipoe and limne all the members of the Chicken, in an egg which is now expoed to the wide world, and oftentimes tranported a great way off. For nothing can make and generate it elfe into anothers likenes.

div.head: What the Efficient caue of Animals is; and what its Conditions.
EXERCIT. L.
div.p: THat therefore we may in ome proportion dive into the knowledge of the efficient caue, (o far forth as concerns our preent contemplation) we mut take notice firt of the Intruments or Mediums which pertain to the efficient or forming caue: and into this rank is the Male and Female for to be reduced, likewie the Geniture, and the egg, and its firt rudiment. For ome males (and females too) are barren, or unfruitful. And likewie the males geniture is ometimes more, and ometimes les fertile: for the Semen Virile as it is barely conteined in the Seminal Veicles (except it be rarified into froth by the pirits, and forceably leap out) is unfruitful. And this too, poibly is not always uccesful. Nor are the Papulae, or Yolks bred in the Cluter of the Ovary, or the Egges conteined in the Womb, all preently fruitfull.

Now I call that fruitful, which (except ome impediment happen from without) will attaine its deigned end, by the efficient power implanted in it, and compas that, for whoe ake it is ordained. So that Cock is reputed fertile, who caues his Hens to lay oftner, and more contantly, and alo renders their egges generative.

So likewie that Hen is fruitful, which is ueful in laying egges, and hath a good retention in order to the prolifical vertue imparted to her from
the Cock. So the Cluter of the Papulae, and Ovary it elf are counted fertile, when they are well fraught with tore of rudiments and foundations of egges, and thoe mature.
Likewie that egge is fertile, which is farthet from being ubventaneous or addle, and doth les faile in producing a Chicken, howoever you dipoe of it, either to Incubation, or any other fotering-heat.

Therefore uch an efficient of the Chicken is required, as may impart virtue to all thee, by which they may be fructified, and obtain an efficient power; for the ame thing, or at leat omething proportionable to it, is in them all, betowing fecundity upon them. And the Inquiry is the ame, namely, what it is in the Egge, that renders it fertile: what in the Ovary, and what in the Papula; likewie what in the female, and latly in the eed and Cock himelf, &c. What in the Blood, and Punctum aliens, or firt genital particle, from whence afterwards the rie, fabrick, and order of all the other parts is derived: as alo, what is it in the Chicken it elf, from whence it grows turdy and active, attains its youth and maturity, lives a healthy life, and a long.

Nor is that inquiry unlike this, which demands, what both male, and female (Cock and Hen) confer to the fertile egge; or what it is which proceeds from both, towards the perfection and imilitude of the chicken; as whether the egge, conception, matter, and nutriment proceed from the female, and the Operative virtue from the male; whether a certain contagion ent forth by coition, or created by it, or received from it, remaining in the Hen or Egges, work upon the matter of the egge; or attract a nutriment from the Hen, concocting
and ditributing it, to the encreae of the egge, and afterwards to the production of the chicken: Or latly, whether all that which relates to the form, oul, and fecundity, do proceed from the male; but from the female, whatever relates to the matter, contitution, place, and utenance. For in animals (whoe Sexes are ditinct) it is o contrived, that becaue the female cannot alone generate, nourih, & protect the foetus, the male is joined as yoke-fellow in the task (as the Superior, and more eminent progenitor) to upply her failings; and o to correct the infirmity of the Subventaneous eggs, and inpire them with fertility.

For as a chicken born of an egge, is indebted to that egge for his body, oul, and principal or genital part: So is the egge for all it has, to the Henne; and the Henne alo for her fecundity to the Cock.

But whether the male be the firt and principal caue of the progeny, or whether the male and the female are intermediate and Intrumental caues et awork by nature, or the firt and Supreme Genitor, we have here an occaion offered to enquire; and it is a very worthy and neceary one, becaue all perfect cience depends upon the knowledge of all caues: and therefore to the plenary comprehenion of Generation, we mut acend from the lat and lowet efficient to the very firt and mot upreme, and know them all.

But as for the firt and highet Efficient of the chicken, we hall determine what that is afterwards, (when we treat of the Efficient of all other Animals) but what kind of one it is, we will here declare.

The firt condition, or qualification, of the firt and primary Efficient properly o called, is, that
it be the firt & principal fructifier, from whence all intermediate caues aume their derived fecundity. For intance, the chicken is derived from the Punctum aliens in the egg, not only in regard of its bulk, but alo, and that chiefly in regard of its oul; the Punctum aliens, or Heart is derived from the egg, the egg from the Hens, and the Hens fertility from the Cock.

Another requiite or condition of the primary Efficient is deumed ex opere facto, from the production it elf, viz. the Chicken: becaue that is the prime efficient, in which the reaon of the effect doth chiefly appear. But becaue every Generative efficient doth generate its like, and the iue is of a mixt nature; the firt efficient mut needs be mixt too.

Now I therefore pronounce their iue to be of a mixt nature, becaue, the mixture of both parents is refulgent in it, both in the figure and lineaments of the body, and all its parts; as in complexion or colors, moles or pots, dieaes, and other accidents of the body. Likewie in the oul and actions, and functions (as in like manners, docility, gate, and voice) uch a kinde of temperature is dicoverable. For as we ay that a imilar mixt body is made of the Elements, becaue their virtues, heat, cold, moiture, and • ccity, are found compounded in the ame imilar body: o likewie the paternal and maternal handy-work may be tracked and pointed out both in the body, oul, and other accidents of the Chicken: (which follow the temperature, or happen unto it) for intance; In a Mule, the oul, body, manners, and voice of both parents; (viz. of the Mare, and the As) are apparent. So alo in thoe Chickens which are the Ofspring of the dunghill-hen, and Cock-Pheaant: and in that mungrel Curre, which is produced by the odomie of a Wolf and a Bitch.

Since therefore the Chicken reembles both parents,
and is a mixt Effect: the generant primary caue (which it reembles) mut needs be mixt likewie. Therefore that which frames the Chicken in the Egge is a mixt nature (as being united, or compounded of both) and the work of both parents. And if any contagion do arie or remain in the female upon coition, (in which they two are mixt, and become as it were one Animal) that alo will be of a mixt nature or power, by which the egge hall afterwards become fertile, and atchieve a platical virtue, which is an Agent of a mixt nature, or a mixt efficient-Intrument, producing a Chicken of a mixt nature alo.

The contagion, I ay; becaue Aritotles perwaion is altogether refractory to experience her elf: namely, where he aith, that ome part of the Foetus is intantly made upon coition. Nor is that true neither, which ome of the Moderns averre, namely, that the oul of the future chicken is in the egge: for that is no whit the chickens oul, which is in no part of the chickens body. Nor can the oul be aid either to be begotten, or left behind preently upon coition: for otherwie there hould be two ouls in a Woman with child. Therefore till it be determined what the efficient of the egge is, which is of a mixt nature, and ought to remaine preent upon coition: give me leave to call it contagium, Contact, or contagion.

But where the contagion lurks in the female after coition, and how it is communicated and derived to the egge, requires a more exact Diquiition: and we will afterwards fall upon it, when we treat generally of the conception of females. It hall uffice, in the mean time to have taken notice, that it mut needs be the fate of the firt efficient (in which the reaon of the future off-pring doth abide)
that, ince its off-pring is mixt, to be of a mixt nature it elfe; and either to proceed from both Parents, or from omething which makes ue of both (as animate Intruments, cooperative, and mixt, and moulded into one by coition.)

The third condition of the Primary Efficient is, that either it impart motion ucceively to all its intermediate intruments, or ele employ them otherwie, but that it elfe be ubervient to none: whence a doubt aries, whether the Cock be the Primary Efficient in the Generation of the chicken, or have any before, or uperior to him. For all generation eems to be derived from Heaven, and iue from the motion of the Sun, and Moon. But we wil be poitive in this matter, when we have firt declared, what an intrument, or the intrumental efficient caue is, and how divided.

Now Intrumental Efficients are of divere kinds; ome, according to Aritotle, are factiva, Making, and ome, activa, Doing; ome do not operate, but when they are conjoyned with a prior efficient, as the hand, foot, and genital parts; others operate, dijoined, as the Geniture and the Egge: ome Intruments have not motion or action, but what is given them by the firt Efficient; others have proper internal principles of their own, to which nature affords no motion in generation, but yet employs their faculties, and ets them the rule, and law of their performances; as the Cook employes fire, and the Phyitian herbs, and the vertues of medicines to cures.

Sennertus, to maintain his conceipt, concerning the oul in the Seed, and the formative faculty in the Egge, affirms, that not onely the Egge, but the Cocks eed alo, is indowed with the oul of the future Chicken, and is not the Intrumental Agent, but
the principal; abolutely denying that any eparate Efficient, is Intrumental: but pronouncing, that onely that is to be reckoned an Intrument in propriety of peech, which is conjoined with the primary efficient: and that, that onely is an Intrumental efficient, which hath no other motion, or action, then that which is immitted, or continually and ucceively received from the primary efficient, by whoe power it acts. And upon that account, he rejects the intance concerning things cat or hurled, which receiving their force from the thing that doth hurle, do yet notwithtanding move, even when they are eparated from it. As if the Sword and Speare were to be counted Intruments of War, but not Arrows, and Bullets. Hee alo rejects the intance drawn from a Republick, and denies that the Magitrates, Counellors, or Officers of a Common-wealth, are the Intruments of a Nation: And yet Aritotle reckons a Counellor for Polit. l. 1. c. 4. an Efficient, and calls on Officer an Intrument, in plain termes. He likewie decries the intance of the Automata, and many other things, that o he may ratifie the eed (or egge) to be Animals, and not an Intrumental, but a Principal Agent. And yet (as if he were enforced by the truth) he laies down uch conditions for a Principal Agent, as do abolutely prove contrary to his own fore-mentioned opinion. Whatoever produceth a work, or effect more noble then it elfe; or ele an effect lake to it elfe, is not an Efficient, but an Intrumental caue. Which being granted, who will not conclude, that Seed and an Egge, are Intruments? Since a chicken is an effect nobler then the egge, and neither like an Egge, nor Seed. Wherefore, when this mot Learned Man denies the Seed or Egge, to be an Intrument, becaue they are eparated from
the Primary Agent, he tands upon a fale bottom. For ince the firt generant produceth its off-pring by everal mediums, whether any of thoe mediums be conjoined to it, as the Hand to the Artit; or whether it be eparated from it, as the Arrow hot from the Bow; yet both are called Intruments.

From thee recited Conditions of the Intrumental caue, it may eem to inue, that the cock, or at leat the cock with the hen, are the Primary efficients in the Generation of the chicken: for the chicken is like them; nor can it be thought to be more noble then its Efficients or Parents. I hall therefore adde one condition more to the Primary efficient, by which perhaps it may appear that the Male is not the Primary, but the Intrumentall caue; namely, that it is required of the Primary efficient in the fabrick of the Chicken, that he employ Skill, Providence, Widome, Goodnes, and Undertanding, far above the capacity of our rational oules; as that, in which the Reaon or Idea of the future work, ought to conit, and which ought likewie to act for ome detinated end, dipoing and perfecting all parts, forming the mallet and mot inconiderable appendixes of the Chicken for ome ue, and employment: not providing onely for the tructure of the creature, but for its wellfare, ornament, and defence.
Now the male, or his eed, either in, or after coition, is not o qualified, that Art, Undertanding, and Providence, may be attributed to it.

Which things being pondered, the Male eems to be an Intrumental efficient, as well as his eed, and the Hen likewie as well as the Egge he laies. And therefore we mut take our flight to a more Primary, Superior, and more excellent caue; to which we may jutly attribute Providence, Undertanding,
Art, and Goodnes; and uch a one as is as much uperiour to its effects and Workmanhip, as an Architect is better then a Barn he ets up; a Prince then his Officers, or an Artit, then his owne hands.

And therefore both Male and Female are but Intrumental efficients, ubervient to the high Creator, or Protogenitor. And in this ene it is truly aid, that the Sun, and Man, beget an Animal, becaue the Spring and Autumn do inue upon the Approaching and Receding Sun, at which times commonly, the generation and corruption of Animals happen. So the chiefet of Philoophers. The firt
De Gen. & Corr. l. 2. c. 10. Movers motion is not the caue of generation and corruption, but the motion of the Oblique circle: for that is continual, and hath alo two Motions: for if generation and corruption were to be always continual, it were neceary that omething hould be always moved, leat thoe mutations hould fail; but yet it mut have two motions, leat one onely of the two mutations hould ucceed. The caue therefore of the continuity is the motion of the Univere, but the declivity it elfe is the caue of the Approach, and the Recees. For it comes to pas, that He, (namely the Sun) is ometimes neerer, and ometimes farther from the earth. And when the Interval is inequal, the motion mut be inequal too. If then he therefore generate becaue he approaches neerer: and caue corruption, becaue he remotes and recedeth farther from the earth: Then it follows that if he often do generate, it is becaue he often approacheth: and if he often caue corruption, it is becaue he often recedeth. For contraries have contrary caues.

And therefore in the Spring all things flourih and grow; (namely, from the Approach of the Sun, who is the Common Father, and Parent: or
at leat the immediate and Common Intrument in Generation imployed by the high Creator) and that not Vegetables onely, but Animals too: nor they onely which are Spontaneous iues, but thoe alo which are generated by Male and Female. As if at the approach of this noble Planet, oft Venus did decend from the Skie, with Cupid and the Graces entertained for her Retinue, inciting and provoking all living things, by their Allegeance to Love, to propagate their kind. Or (as it is in the Fable) as if Saturne did then become an Eunuch, and threw his maculine evidences into the Sea, to raie a Foam, which might give birth to Venus: For in the Generation of Animals, Superat tener omnibus humor; A gentle dew doth moiten all (as the Poet hath it) and the genital parts doe foam and trut with Seed.

And therefore the cock and Hen are chiefly fruitfull in Spring, as if the Sun, or Heavens, Nature, the Soul of the Univere, or the Omnipotent Deity (for thee are Synonoma's) were a Superiour and Diviner caue of Generation then they. So, Sol & homo generant hominem; The Sun, and Man beget a Man (that is to ay) the Sun by Man as its Intrument. And o, the Creator of all things, and the cock, beget an egge, and out of an egge a chicken: namely, by the contant approach and recee of the Sun: who according to the will, and decree of the Almighty, is emploied in the generation of all things.

We conclude therefore that the male (though he be a Primary and more excellent efficient then the female) is only an Intrumental Efficient: and doth himelfe, no les then the Female, owe his fecundity, or generative Virtue to the Sun his Creditour: and therefore the artifice and providence
(which we dicover in his workmanhip) doth not proceed from him, but God. For the Male ues neither counel, nor undertanding in generation: nor doe Men generate by any part of their reaonable oule, but by a faculty of their vegetative: which is not inrouled amongt the primary, and more devine powers of the oule, but the meanet, and baet.

Since therefore in the tructure of a chicken, Art and Providence are no les viible, then in the Fabrick of Man himelfe, and the creation of the Univere: we mut needs acknowledge, that in the generation of Man, there is an Efficient caue more excellent then man himelfe: or ele that the vegetative faculty, or that part of the oule, which raieth this pile of man, and doth conerve it, is much more divine and excellent, and doth more peronate the Image of God, then the Rational part it elfe: whoe worth and dignity we more cry up, then all the faculties of the oule beide; though he were Regent and Empres of the ret, and held them all as Tributaries to her. Or at leat wee mut confes, that there is neither prudence, nor skill, nor undertanding in the workes of Nature, but they eem uch onely to our apprehenions, who iudge of the divine productions of nature, by our owne Arts, and Faculties, (or copies drawne by our own fancies) as if the active principles of Nature did o produce their effects, as we do our artificial iues: namely by conultation, and rules deumed from the Minde and Intellect. But Nature, which is the Principle of Motion and Ret, in all thoe things wherein he is: and the vegetative oule, which is the primary Efficient caue of every generation, doe move and act by no acquired faculty (as we doe) which may be ditinguihed
by the name of Art, or Providence, but work by a certain Detiny, and Mandat according to rule, after the ame manner, and contraint, as light things fly up, and heavy pres downwards. The Vegetative faculty of Parents doth generate, and the eed arrives at lat at the forme of the foetus, after the ame manner as the Spider preads her Net, the Bees and Ants build their Cottages, and furnih their tore-houes for future exigences, Birds compile their Nets, hatch, and protect their young: namely, Naturally, and by their Motherwit, not by any dicurive providence, dicipline, or conultation. For that which is in us the Principle of Artificial operations, & is called Art, Undertanding, or Prudence: is in thoe naturall effects, Nature, (which is < in non-Latin alphabet > , her own Tutor, and taught by no man) and what is acquired, and a purchae in us, is in them inbred, and a Birthright. And therefore they who look back to Art, are incompetent and partial Judges of natural things: for we are rather to judge of the contrary, and compare artificial productions to their Sampler in Nature. For all Arts are attained by an imitation and peronating of Nature; and our Reaon, or Intellect is derived from the divine undertanding, exercied in its works. And when it is rooted in us by a compleat habit, like another adventitious acquired oul, reflecting a reemblance of the highet and divinet Agent, it produceth like effects and operations.

Wherefore (in my opinion) he is the right and pious Philoopher, who deduceth the generations of all things from that eternal and Omnipotent Deity, upon whoe pleaure the Univere dependeth. Nor do I think we ought to contend, by what notion we call, or adore this firt Agent, (to whom all
the names of veneration are mot due) whether that of Deus, or Natura naturans, or Anima mundi. For all men undertand him to be that Beginning and End of all things, which is Omnipotent, and everlating, the Author and Creator of all things, preerving, and perpetuating the fluxibility of mortall creatures, by the everal viciitudes of generations: which being every where preent, is no les aitant to the particular operations of natural things, then of the whole Univere; that o he may propagate all Animals by his Deity, Providence, Art, and divine Undertanding. Whereof ome are pontaneous births, without any Univocal efficient; ome born by the aociat operations of male and female, ome from one Sex onely; others by other intermediate Intruments, which Intruments are ometimes fewer, ometimes more, ometimes univocal, and ometimes equivocal, and ex accidenti caual.

But all natural bodies whatever are both the productions, and Intruments of that Great God; and are either onely natural, as Heat, Spirit, the tepidity or warmth of the Air, or Putrefaction, &c. or animate alo; for he makes ue in ome ort of the motions, faculties, and ouls of animals themelves, in order to the perfection of the Univere, and procreation of Animals.

It appears therefore in ome proportion, what the males contribution is towards generation; namely, the cock brings that ame virtue to the egg, by which of a ubventaneous it becomes a fertile one, as vegetable Fruits borrow from the Summer heat to ripen themelves, and fructifie their eeds; and which induceth fertility into pontaneous productions, by which from worms they become a Canker-worm, and from a Canker-worm, they become the worm called Aurelia, and from an Aurelia,
Butterflies, common Flies, and Bees, &c.

And in this manner the Sun by his acces to the earth, is the Beginning of the motion and tranmutation in the Increae of Fruits; and the End alo, when he becomes the author of the fertility of their Seeds. And as in the early Spring he is the primary efficient of Leaves, Blooms, and Fruits, o is he the lat compleater of the maturity and fecundity of the Seed in the trength of Summer. For confirmation of which, amongt many other obervations, I hall inert this one: There are ome amongt us who manure their Orange-trees with a great deal of care and husbandry; o that the Oranges which the firt year grew to the bignes of the top of ones thumb, are the next Summer mature and complete, ave onely that they have no kernels, or eeds. While my thoughts were bent upon this contemplation, I fanfied thee Oranges to be a Specimen of the Subventaneous eggs, which are produced by the Hen, without the Cocks aitance, having all the enible appearances or requiites of fruitful eggs, bating onely the fecundity, or propagating eed. As if the ame thing were conferred by the Cock upon a ubventaneous egg, to make it fruitful, which the Sun contributes in hotter climats, whereby the fruit of their trees are produced with kernels. And as if the Englih Summer were no farther uefull to ome fruit, then the imple Hen to the Egge, and were onely like the female, an impotent progenitres: which Summer in other Countries, where they enjoy a greater bounty from the Suns preence, were a maculine Summer, and did complete her productions.

This, by the by, that by the eggs example it might appear, what qualifications are required to a primary efficient in the generation of Animals.
For it is clear, that there is in an egg an operator (and alo in every conception, and rudiment) which is not only infued into it from the fentale, but is firt communicated from the male by the gemture in coition, but yet firt of all contributed to the Male, from the Heavens, the Sun, or the Almighty Creator.
