It is likewie manifet, that this Operator or Agent, which is exitent in the egge, and in every eed, is o inpired with power from the Parents, that it fahions the chicken to the likenes of the Parents, not of it elf; and that a mixt likenes too, as proceeding from them both united in coition: and ince all things are tranacted with an admirable providence and widom, the preence of the divine Deity is clearly implyed.

But of this we hall more largely treat elewhere, when we hall endeavour to hew, what remaines in the Female preently after coition, and where it abideth: and likewie (becaue nothing at all is dicoverable in the cavity of the womb after coition) what that prolifical contagion, or firt conception is? Whether it be any corporeal thing, any where reerved in the female, or omething incorporeal? And whether the conception of the womb be like the conception of the Brain, and o Fecundity be attained, as Science is? (for there are arguments not wanting to prove it) and as Motion, and Animal operations, do take their rie from the conception of the Brain (which we call the deire, or appetite) o whether do Natural motions likewie, and the Operations of the Vegetative faculty (epecially Generation) depend upon the conception of the womb? Again, how that prolifical contagion is of a mixt nature, and transferred from the Male into the Female, and from her into the Egge? And latly, how the contagion, or infection of all preternatural
dieaes, and ditempers do pread, and propagate inenibly.

div.head: Of the Order of Generation, and firt, of the firt Genital Particle.
EXER. LI.
div.p: WHat that is which is produced in the Female immediately upon coition, or doth remain in her, which we hitherto do comprie under the name of contagion, by which, as by Infection, the female is rendered fruitfull by the male, and afterwards doth generate a foetus of her own accord, hall be aid in its place, where we hall make a tricter diquiition and examination of that matter. In the mean time, we hall ignifie to you, all uch things as do openly diplay themelves in the order of the production of the parts, and are worth the Obervation.

And firt of all, becaue it is plain that the chicken is built by Epigeneis, or the additament of parts budding one out of another, we will dicover what part is firt founded before all its company, and what is obervable concerning it, and the manner of its generation.

That which Aritotle affirms concerning the generation
de gen. an. l. 2. c. 1. of perfect animals, is an undoubted truth, and mot apparent in an egge; namely, that all the parts are not framed together, but one after another in order; & that the firt in being is that genital
particle; by virtue of which afterwards (as from their original) all the ret of the parts do arie. As we ee in the eeds of Plants (as Beans and Acorns) a budding, or protuberant point, which is the foundation of the future Tree.

And this particle is like a Son et free, and dwelling
Ibid. c. 1. in a mannour of his own, and a principle ubiting of himelf; whence afterwards the order of the parts is delineated, and all things ordered and regulated which conduce to the complement of the Animal. For ince, no part is its own parent, but when it is once begotten, doth provide for it elf: therefore that part mut of neceity be firt made, which doth contain the principle of encreae (for be they Plants or Animals, they have all that in them which contains a power of vegetation and utaining;) and ditinguiheth alo and formeth Ib. c. 4. all the other parts in their due order and rank: therefore the Soul is primarily in that primogenit particle; which Soul is the fountain and author of Sene, Motion, and Life of the whole. That therefore is the principal particle, from which the vital pirit, and native heat do decend into all the ret; in which the Phyitians calidum Innatum ive implantatum, innate or implanted warm ubtance, doth firt diplay it elf; and the dometick houhold-God or lating fire inhabits; from whence Life floweth into the Body in general, and each particular part; from whence Nutrition, Ayde, Growth, and Comfort derive their treames: Latly, where Life firt arieth to the born, and etts to the dying creature.

Thee indeed are all true of the firt genital part, and do evidently appear in the generation of the chicken; and therefore, as I conceive, being moved thereunto by undry Obervations, the opinion of ome Phyitians, whoe Philoophy is ill founded,
is to be rejected (whereby they decree that the three principal and eldet parts, the Brain, the Heart, and the Liver, do together pring out of the mall bladders or bubbles) o neither can I aent to Aritotle himelf, who concludes that the Heart is this firt genital and animate particle. For the truth is, I am perwaded that this Prerogative is onely due to the Blood: for the blood is it which is firt een in Generation. And that not onely in an Egg, but in every Foetus, and animal conception whatoever: As hall plainly appear anon.

There appears, I ay, from the beginning, Punctum Rubrum aliens, Veicula pulans, Fibraeque inde deductae, the Red capering Point, the Panting Veicle, and the Fibers deduced thence, which contain blood. And o farre as I could poibly dicern by accurate Inpection, the Blood is formed before the Punctum aliens, and is endowed with vital heat, before it moves by pule; and in it, and from it doth the pulation begin. For I have found it true by undry experiments both in an egge, and elewhere, that the blood is it, in which (o long as the vital heat is not quite extinct) reideth the poibility of reviving.

And ince the Veicula pulans, and the Fibres containing blood which are derived from it, are een before any other parts; I conceive it cononant to reaon, that the blood is made before his receptacles; that is to ay, the thing contained, before the thing containing; for the latter is made to be erviceable to the former. And therefore it is mot probable, That the Veines, and Fibres, and then the Veicle, and after it the Heart, as being Intruments detined to receive and houe the blood, are erected for the tranmiion, and ditribution of it, and that the blood is the primary particle of the body.

And this is manifet by many Obervations; but chiefly, in that ome living creatures (and uch too as have blood) live a good while without any pule at all; and ome become like Anchorites all the Winter long, and yet urvive, though their Hearts within them do repite all their motions, and their Lungs make Holy-day, and forbear repiration; like thoe perons, who in a Syncope, Lipothymia, or Hyterical paions, lie half-dead without the motion of the Pule.

Being therefore acertained out of thoe things which I have oberved in an Egge, and the diection of Animals while they were alive, I conclude (againt Aritotle) that the blood is the firt Genital particle, and that the Heart is its Intrument deigned for its Circulation. For the Hearts buines or function is the propulation or driving forth of the blood, as appeares in all Animals that have blood: and the office of the Veicula pulans is the very ame, (in the generation of the Chicken) which I have hewed to many perons, in the firt conceptions of Animals, (as well as in an Egge) when it hath been les then a Spark, panting, and in its motion, drawing it elf together, and o queezing out the blood contained in it, and by relaxing it elf again, receiving and entertaining blood afreh.

And hence the prerogative and antiquity of the blood appeares, eeing that the Pule proceedeth from it. For there being two parts of Pulation; (Ditention, and Contraction, or Sytole, and Diatole) and the firt of thee motions is Ditention, it is manifet that that action proceeds from the blood; but the Contraction is made by the Veicula pulans in an Egge, (as by the Heart in a Chicken) by its proper fibres; as by an Organ detined to that ue.
And it is alo certain, that the aid Veicula, as alo the Auricula cordis, the deaf-eare of the Heart, afterwards (from whom the Pulation firt begins) are incited to the contrictive motion, by the blood ditending them. The Diatole, or Dilatation, is made by the blood boyling or welling by the pirits within it: And o Aritotles Opinion concerning the pulation of the Heart, (namely, that it is made by a kinde of Ebullition) is in ome ort true. For as in Milk et upon the fire, and in Beere, we ee dayly a Fermentation, working, or Intumecence; o is it in the pule of the Heart, in which the blood, as by a kinde of fermentation working up, is ditended, and then ebbs, or falls down againe: and that which befalls them per accidens, from an external agent (namely, an adventitious heat) that is accomplihed in the blood, by its own internal heat, or innate pirit; and is alo regulated by the oul in a natural way, and for the preervation of living creatures.

The Pule therefore is performed by a twofold Agent; namely, the Ditention or Dilatation proceeds from the Blood; and the Contriction, from the membrane of the veicula in the Egge; (but in the Foetus when it is born, from the Deaf-eares, and Ventricles of the Heart) and by the mutual performance of this alternate and interchanging motion, the blood is driven round the whole body, and o our lives continued.

Nor is the Blood therefore onely to be called the Primigenial and principal part, becaue that in, and from it the fountain of motion and pulation is derived; but alo, becaue the Animal heat, or vital pirit is firt radicated and implanted, and the oul takes up her firt manion in it. For whereoever the immediate and principal Intrument of the
vegetative faculty is firt found, there in probability the oul firt reides, and takes her Beginning; as being ineparable from the pirit, and the calidum innatum.

For however in Artificial Operations (as Fabricius rightly admoniheth) the Artificer and the Intruments pag. 28. are eparated; yet in the works of Nature they are conjoyned, and one and the ame: o the Stomack is both the Author, and the Intrument of chylification. So in like manner, the Soul with the Spirit (her Intrument) is immediately conjoyned: and therefore be it in what part it will, that heat and motion firt begin, there alo the Life doth firt arie, and lat expire; and out of quetion, the mot intimate dometick Deities, and Soul it elfe, are there enhrined.

Life therefore conits in the blood, (as we read in Holy Scripture) becaue in it the Life and Soule
Levit. 17. 11. & 14. do firt dawn, and lat et. For I have experimented in the diection of many live Animals, that when the body was now a dying, and breathing done, the Heart continued its pule a while, and kept up life in it. And when the Heart hath now given over, you hall dicern a motion yet urviving in the Auriculae, or Deaf-eares; and though the other faile, yet the Right will till be tirring; and when that ubmits to Fate too, yet you hall perceive a kinde of undulation, or waving to and fro, and obcure trepidation, or palpitation in the champion-blood, proclaiming that he gave the lat blow. And any man may plainly ee, that the blood retaines heat, (that deriver of Life and Palation) when all the other parts are chilled, and cold: which heat when it is quite extinct, as the blood is then no longer anguis, ed cruor, Blood, but Gore; o now no longer hope of returning back to lie.
But, both in an Egge, and in gaping Animals, after all pulation is expunged, if you apply a gentle warmth either to the Punctum aliens, or the right Auricle of the Heart, you hall preently ee the motion, pulation, and life et on foot again by the Blood; except he have quite fore-gone all his innate heat, and vital pirit.

By all which it is mot evident, that the blood is the Genital Part, the fountain of Life, Primum vivens, & ultimum moriens, the Firt-born, and the Longet Liver, and the chief Palace and Court of the oul: in which (as in its Spring-head) the heat doth firt and chiefly flow, and flourih: and from which all the other parts of the Body derive their life and influent warmth. For that heat treaming with the blood, doth princkle, cherih, and preerve the whole: as we have heretofore demontrated in our Booke, de Motu anguinis.

And hereupon the ruddy anguine parts alone,
are called the Hot parts, as the Fleh; but the white and bloodles parts, as the Nerves and Ligaments, the Cold. And as Sanguineous Animals exceed the bloodles; o even in the parts, thoe that are more liberally indowed with Blood, are counted the Eminent parts. And the Liver, Spleen, Reins, Lungs, and Heart it elf (if you train all the blood out of them, for whoe ake they are chiefly called Vicera) they preently grow pale, and wan, and are to be regitered amongt the colder parts.

The Heart himelfe, I ay, doth by the Coronary Arteries receive the Blood, its influent heat and life, both which it enjoyes upon no other account, then the meer bounty of the Blood. Nor can the Liver proceed in its publick office, without the influence of blood and heat from the Coeliacal Artery. For there is no where any affluence of heat, without an Influence or influx of blood by the Arteries. And therefore in the firt Confirmation of all the parts, before they put themelves into publick undertakings, they are to be dicovered pale, and blood-lee: hereupon the old Phyitians and Anatomits uppoed them to be permatical parts, and this peech was wont to obtain amongt them, that in Generation, Aliquot in Lacte dies abumuntur, ome daies are pent in the Milk, that is about the Contitution of the white; Spermatical parts. The very ubtance of the Liver it elf, the Lungs, and the Heart, at their firt appearance are exceeding white. Nay the Cone of the Heart, and the walls or ides of its Ventricles, are even then white, when the Auriculae are full, and dyed with Scarlet-blood, and the Coronary Vein looks ruddy. So likewie the Parenchyma of the Liver is it elfe white, when the branches and propagations of its
Veins are bluhing with blood: nor doth it execute its publick office, untill it be throughly drenched with blood.

And latly, the blood doth o urround, and peirce into the whole body, and impart heat and life to all its parts, that the oul may jutly be counted reident in it, and for his ake, Tota in tota & tota in qualibet parte, to be all in all, and all in every part, (as the old aying is.)

But it is o far from truth (which yet Aritotle and all Phyitians affirm) that the Liver, or Heart is the Author of the Blood: that the contrary, out of the fabrick of the chicken in the egge, is mot manifet: namely, the Blood rather is the Author of the Heart, and Liver. And this alo Phyitians before they are aware eem to acknowledge, while they conclude that the Parenchyma of the Liver is a certain affuion, or conflux of Blood: as if it were nothing ele but blood congealed. Now it mut have a being before it can be affued, or coagulated: and that it is o, experience her elf openly diplayes; for blood appears in the egg, before there be any track or Rudiment of any uch thing as the Body, or any of the Vicera. And yet no blood can come thither from the Mother to the Fatus, (as people commonly phanie in Viviparous productions.)

The Liver of Fihes is alwaies whitih, though their Veins are purpled, and dark. And our Hens the better they are crammed, o much the more do their Livers impair, and grow pallid. Greenicknes Virgins that are Cachectical, as the habit of their bodies is pale, o is their Liver: an evident igne of the penury and dearth of Blood. Therefore the Liver borrows his heat and complexion from the blood, and not the blood from him.

Hence it is plaine, that blood is the prime genital Part, whence the oul primarily reults, and out of which the primary animate part of the Foetus, which is the fountain of all the ret, both imilar, and diimilar is derived, which by that means attain their Vital heat, and become ubervient to it: And the Heart is erected for this end and purpoe onely, that it may by continual pulation (to which the Veins and Arteries are miniterial and ubervient) entertain this blood, and pout it out again up and down through the whole body.
All which is the clearer dicovered by this, that the Heart hath not a pulation in all Animals, nor yet at all times; when yet the blood, or omething proportionable to blood is never wanting in any.

div.head: Of the Blood, as it is the Principal Part.
EXER. LII.
div.p:
IT is therefore evident, even to the Eye, that the blood is the Primigenial, and o the Genital part: & that all thoe attributes recited in the precedent Chapter are conitent with it: namely, that it is the builder and preerver of the body and principal part wherein the oul hath her Seion. For (as we newly aid) before any particle of the body appear, the blood is born, and groweth, having a palpitation (as Aritotle aith) within the Veins moving
De hit. an. l. 3. c. 19.
to and fro with a Pule, and is above all the humours dipered through the whole body. And o long as life doth lat, the Blood alone is Animate, and hot.

Moreover, by his various motions, in celerity, or lownes; vehemence, or feeblenes, &c. He plainly dicovers his reentment of the affronts which any thing cats upon him, and the friendhips of uch as cherih him. We therefore conclude, the blood lives and is nourihed of it elfe, no way depending upon any other part of the body, as elder or worthier then it elf. But whether the whole body depend upon it, as being potgenit, adjoined, and a kind of appendix or retainer to it, is not the buines of this place. I hall only adde, what Aritotle confees, Truly the nature of the blood
De part. an. l. 2. c. 4. is the caue, why very many things befal Animals, both in order to their manners and ene. So that hence we may perceive the Caues not of life onely in general, (for you can never dicover any other Calidum innatum aut influens, innate or influent heat which may be the immediate intrument of the oul, beides the Blood) but alo of longer or horter life, or leep, and wakefulnes, of Wit and Strength &c. For by its tenuity (aith Aritotle in the ame place) and cleannes or purity, creatures are wier, and have quicker enes: and likewie are either more timorous, or couragious, angry and furious: according as their blood is more dilute and thin, or more compact and groe by fibres.

Nor is blood the Author of life onely, but according to its everal dicriminations, it is the caue of health, or dieaes. And Poyons themelves, which aault us from without, (as poioned darts or bullets) did they not infect the blood, would do us no prejudice. So that our life, and wellfare is derived unto us from the ame pring. If the
Hit. an. l. 3. c. 9.
blood be over liquid, aith Aritotle, men grow ick; for it degenerates into o erous a gore, that ome have wet Blood. If too much of it tream out, they die. For by want of blood, all the parts do not onely languih preently, but the Animal it elf oon expires. I conceive it inconvenient to et down Experiments to confirm this, becaue they require a peculiar Tract. I perceive that the wonderful Circulation of the blood, firt found out by me, is conented to almot by all: and that no man hath hitherto made any objection to it, greatly worth a confutation: Wherefore if I hall ubjoine the caues, and benefits of that Circulation, and lay open ome other ecrets of the blood, as, how much it conduceth to the happines of the creature, as alo to both oul, and body, that o men may be cautious to preerve their blood pure and clean, by commodious diet, I conceive I hall perform an office, not more new, then ueful, and acceptable to Philoophers, and Phyitians: nor will this opinion eem o improbable and aburd to any, as once to Aritotle; namely, That the Blood, like a Tutelar
De Anima. l. 1. c. 2. Deity, is the very oul in the body, as Critias of old, and others thought, uppoing ene to be the chiefet property of the oul, and that ene to be in her by the nature of the Blood. Now ome concluded it to be the oul, becaue it hath a power of moving by its owne nature: As Thales, Diogenes, Heraclitus, Alcmaeon, and others.

But that both ene and motion are in the Blood,
De hit. an. l. 1. c. 19. & de part. an. l. 2. c. 3. is conpicuous by many tokens, though Aritotle denied it. For if he himelf compelled by the truth of the thing it elf, did confes, that there was a oul in an egge, though the egge were addle: and that in the Geniture and Blood was found a divine ubtance, proportionably anwering to the Matter of
the Stars, and that it was the Creators Vice-Roy: If ome of the Moderns ay, that the eed of Animals ejected in Coition is animate, Why hould we not upon as good reaon ay, that there is a oul in the Blood? and eeing it is the firt begotten, firt moved, & firt nourihed, why hould we doubt to affirm, that the oul is firt raied, & kindled out of it? Blood is that, wherein the Vegetal and enative operations firt hine forth: in which the primary and immediate officer of the oul, is bred; which is the common tye of oul and body; and in which, as in her Chariot, the oul viits and cattereth influence upon all the parts of the body.

Beides, ince the contemplation of Geniture is (as we have een already) o difficult, (namely, how the fabrick of the body hould be built by it, with providence, art, and divine undertanding) why hould we not by the ame right, admire the excellent nature of blood, and harbour as worthy thoughts concerning it, as eed? epecially eeing the Geniture it elf (as appears by the egge) is made of the blood; and all the whole body (as from its Genital part) eems not onely to deume its firt Foundation, but Preervation alo, from it.

Thus much by the way concerning this matter, being to treat more fully and exactly of it elewhere. Nor do I conceive it worth the trouble, to dipute here, whether the definition of a part in its proper acceptation agree to blood? which ome deny upon thee grounds chiefly, becaue it hath not ene, and becaue it flowes and ininuates into all the parts of the body, to cater convenient dyet for them. But I have found many things about the manner of Generation, by which being convinced, I hall etablih the contrary to thoe things, (which Philoophers & Phyitians commonly
affirm, or deny.) At preent I will onely ay, that in cae we hould conent that the blood hath not ene, yet it cannot be thence inferred, that it is no part of the enitive body, and that the chifet too. For neither the Braine, nor the Spinal Marrow, or the Crytalline, or Glaie humour of the Eye have any ene, and yet all Philoophers and Phyitians do to this day with one conent, allow them to be parts of the body. But Aritotle did number it amongt the imilar parts, and Hippocrates alo; for while he contitutes the Animal body, out of conteining, and conteined parts, and impetum facientibus, pirits, he did necearily own the blood amongt the conteined parts.

But of this more at large, when we enquire what a part is, and how many everal acceptations there are of it. In the mean time, we will not conceale this Admirable Experiment (by which it hall appear that the mot principal member of all, namely, the very Heart it elf, may eem to be inenible.)

A Noble young Gentleman, Son and Heire to the honorable the Vice-Count of Mountgomery in Ireland, when he was a childe, had a trange mihapp by an unexpected fall, cauing a Fracture in the Ribs on the left ide: the Bruie was brought to a Suppuration, whereby a great quantity of putrified matter was voided out, and this putrefaction guhed out for a long while together out of the wide wound. I deliver it from his own mouth, and the tetimony of other creditable perons, who were eye-witnees. This peron of Honour, about the eighteenth, or nineteenth year of his Age, having been a Traveller in Italy and France, arrived at lat at London: having all this time a very wide gap open in his Breat, o that you might ee and touch
his Lungs (as it was believed.) Which, when it came to the late King Charles his ear, being related as a miracle, He preently ent me to the Young Gentleman, to inform Him, how the matter tood. Well, what happened? When I came neer him, and aw him a prightly Youth, with a good complexion, and habit of body, I uppoed, ome body or other had framed an untruth. But having aluted him, as the manner is, and declared unto him the Caue of my Viit, by the Kings Command, he dicovered all to me, and opened the void part of his left ide, taking off that mall plate, which he wore to defend it againt any blow or outward injury. Where I preently beheld a vat hole in his breat, into which I could eaily put my three Fore-fingers, and my Thumb; and at the firt entrance I perceived a certain flehy part ticking out, which was driven in and out by a reciprocal motion, whereupon I gently handled it in my hand. Being now amazed at the novelty of the thing, I earch it again and again, and having diligently enough enquired into all, it was evident, that that old and vat Ulcer (for want of the help of a skilfull Phyitian) was miraculouly healed, and skinned over with a membrane on the Inide, and guarded with fleh all about the brimmes or margent of it. But that flehy ubtance (which at the firt ight I conceived to be proud fleh, and every body ele took to be a lobe of the Lungs) by its pule, and the differences or rythme thereof, or the time which it kept, (and laying one hand upon his wret, and the other upon his heart) and alo by comparing and conidering his Repirations, I concluded it to be no part of the Lungs, but the Cone or Subtance of the Heart; which an excrecent fungous Subtance (as is uual in oul Ulcers)
had fenced outwardly like a Sconce. The Young Gentlemans Man did by dayly warm injections deliver that flehy accretion from the filth & pollutions which grew about it, and o clapt on the Plate: which was no ooner done, but his Mater was well, and ready for any journey or exercie, living a pleaant, and ecure life.

Therefore, intead of an Account of the Buine, I brought the Young Gentleman himelf to our late King, that he might ee, and handle this trange and ingular Accident with his own Senes; namely, the Heart and its Ventricles in their own pulation, in a young, and prigtly Gentleman, without offene to him: Whereupon the King himelf conented with me, That the Heart is deprived of the Sene of Feeling. For the Party perceived not that we touched him at all, but meerly by eeing us, or by the enation of the outward skin. We likewie took notice of the motion of his Heart; namely, that in the Diatole it was drawn in and retracted, and in the Sytole came forth, and was thrut out; and that the Sytole was made in the heart, when the Diatole was enible in the wret; and alo that the proper motion of the heart is the Sytole; and latly, that the heart then beats upon the breat, and is a litle prominent, when it is lifted upwards and contracted into it elf.

Nor is that other Controverie (namely, whether the Blood do onely erve to nourih the Body) to be much inited upon in this place. Aritotle indeed doth in everal places contend, that the blood is Alimentum ultimum, the lat Aliment, and with him the whole School of Phyitians give uffrage. And yet many things hard to be unfolded, and of bad coherence, will enue upon that opinion. For, when Phyitians treat of the Blood in

totle, did contitute the blood out of parts and differences in ome manner alike. Phyitians indeed do onely take notice of humane blood, and of that as it pins into a Sawcer in Phlebotomy, and o coagulates. Aritotle contemplates the blood of all creatures in general, or that which beareth an Analogy with blood. But laying aide all cavil, and omitting the inconveniences which do purue their opinion, I hall briefly touch upon thoe things, which they both conent in, and are plainly dicovered by ene it elf, and are more pertinent to our buines: intending elewhere to examine them at large.

Though (as I have informed you) the blood is called a part of the body, and that the primigenial and principal part; yet if it be conidered in the whole lump (as it is in the Veins) nothing hinders, why we may not ay, that it conteins Aliment, concocts it, and doth apply it to all parts: and that being one and the ame thing, yet in that acceptation it may be aid, both to feed, and to be fed, as alo to be both the material and efficient caue of the Body: and naturally to have that very contitution, which Aritotle conceived to be neceary in the primigenial part; namely, that the blood is partly of a imilar, and partly of a diimilar contitution. For, aith he, Since for enes ake it is necearily ordered, that there hould be imilar members in Animals; and ince both the power of enation, motion, and nutrition, are all comprehended in the ame member, (namely the Primogenit) it is neceary that that member (which conteins uch principles in it) hould both be imple, that it may be capable of all enible objects; and alo diimilar, that it may move, and act. Wherefore, he goes on, in the race of creatures that have blood, the Heart is counted
uch a member: but in the bloodles, that member which is proportionable to the Heart.

Now if by the Heart he undertand that particle which is firt een in the Egge; namely, the Blood, together with its receptacles (the Veiculae pulantes, and the Veins) as one and the ame Organ; I then conceive he peaks mot true: for the Blood as it is dicovered in the Egge and the Veicula, is partly imilar, and partly diimilar. But if he undertand it otherwie, that which is een in the egge, will eaily confute him: for the ubtance of the Heart, being conidered without the Blood (namely, its Cones, and the Walls or partitions of its Ventricles) is generated long after: and continues o long white, without any irrigation of blood upon it, untill the Heart be fahioned into an Organical form, uch as may pout the blood through the whole body. Nor doth the Heart, then, appear of a imilar or imple contitution (as is fit for a Primogenit part to do) but fibrous, flehey, and muculous: and indeed (as Hippocrates would have it) a plain Mucle, or Intrument of motion. But, the blood, (as it is firt een, and as it beats being yet comprehended in the Veicula,) is plainly of that contitution, which Aritotle judgeth neceary to a Principal part. For the blood, while it is in its natural contitution in the body, is altogether imilar. But o oon as it is dilodged, and out of its receptacles, and puts of its native heat; it preently degenerates into everal parts, as ome diimilar thing.

But if the blood were naturally deigned onely to the nourihing of the body, it would be onely of a imilar contitution; like the Chyle, or White of an egge; or at leat it would be a mixt body, being compounded of the foreaid parts or juyces,
and yet truly one: as thoe other juyces; namely, the Choler and Phlegme, which after death, even when they are taken out of their habitations, remain the ame, as when they were een in the live body: but are not o oon changed.

Wherefore, what Aritotle attributes to a Principal part, that very ame thing is proper to blood. For blood, as it is a Natural body, being an Heterogeneous, or Diimilar ubtance, is compounded of thoe parts, or juyces. But as it lives, and it the chief Animal part, compounded of a body and oul. But when that oul, by reaon of the expiration of the native heat, doth vanih, and its native ubtance is preently corrupted, and is diolved into thoe parts, of which it was formerly made: namely, firt into a Watry Blood, next into Red, and White parts: and the Red parts, which are uppermot, are mot florid: but thoe that inck downwards grow dark, and black. Now ome of the parts alo are fibrous, and thicker, as being the tye, and connexion of the ret; others are ichorous and erous, upon which the coagulated lump ueth to float. And into this Serum almot all the blood degenerates. Now thee parts are not in the live blood, but onely when it is now corrupted and diolved by death.

Beides the recited parts, there is een in hotter and tronger Animals, as in Hores, Oxen, and Men alo of a more lively contitution, another part of blood, which when the blood is let out and grumefieth, eating it elfe in the upper part of the redder blood, doth condene, and plainly reemble a Gelly made of Harts-horn, or kind of Mucilage, or thicker white of an egge. The vulgar count it the Phlegme, and Aritotle the crude and unconcocted part of the blood.

I have oberved this part, to differ, as well, from the erous, (upon which the coagulated gore ueth to wim) as from the other parts, as likewie from the Urine, which is dreined by the Kidnies from the blood. Nor is it to be thought the cruder and colder part of the blood, but the more pirital, as I uppoe, and that by two experiments; Firt, becaue it wimmes above the florid and brighter part of the blood, (which is vulgarly conceived to be the Arterial blood) as being hotter, and fuller of pirits then it, and upon the digregation of the blood, obtaines the upper place.

Alo in breathing a Veine, this ort of blood (where of there is plenty in perons of a hot temperature, that are trong and flehy) it darts it elf out in a longer tream, and more vehemency (as if it pirted out of a Syringe) & hereupon we count it hotter, and more pirital: as that geniture is counted mot fertile & fraught with pirits, which leaps farthet and mot forcibly.

And that this gelly doth much differ from that ichorous and watry ubtance, which (as being colder then the ret) inketh down to the bottom of the awcer, is evident for two reaons: for the watry and wahy part is more crude and inconcocted, then that it may be wrought up into perfect blood. But the gelly, which is thicker and more fibrous, wimming above the lump of blood, appeareth more concocted and elaborate then it. And therefore in the olution or partition of the blood, this gelly keeps aloof, the whey or anies lowet, but the lump and red parts (as well the brighter as the darker) poes the middle region.

Now is it mot certain, that not onely that part, but all the blood, nay the very fleh it elf (as
may be oberved in Bodyes hanged in Chains) may may be corrupted into ichorous whey. As being reolved into that ubtance, of which they were firt compounded: o Salt is reolved into Lie, from whence it firt prung. So likewie in every Cachexie, the blood that is let, abounds with plenty of Serum: o that ometimes there carce appears any grumous part at all, but all the blood eems to be one entire wahy gore; as we finde in that kinde of Dropie called Anaarca: and it is alo natural in creatures that are bloodles.

Likewie, if you breath a veine immediately after you have eat and drank, (before the econd concoction be finihed, and the Serum decended through the Kidnies) or upon the firt approach of a fit of an Ague, you hall finde the blood to be wahy, inconcocted, and mingled with much whey. But on the contrary, if upon an empty Stomack, or dicharge of the Urine, or a large Sweat, you open a Veine, you hall finde the blood thick (as being quite detitute of Serum) and being almot all condened into a lump.

And as when the blood growes raw and crude, you hall perceive but very litle of this gelly floating a top. So if you poure out the Serum eparated from the lump or mas, and let it imper upon a gentle fire, you hall oon ee it changed into this gelly: which is a manifet igne, that that wahy or erous ubtance, which is now divided from the ret of the blood, is perhaps ome matter of the Urine, but not the Urine it elf, though in colour and conitence it look like it. For the Urine being boyled, is not thickned into a fibrous Gelly, but rather into a Lie: but this wahy or erous part being a while gently heated, condeneth into a gelly like that above: as on the contrary,
that
• u • ago, or gelly, degenerating into more crudity by corruption, is diolved into Serum.

And thus farre have I brought this part of the blood (which is my own Obervation) upon the Stage; of which (and the other parts of blood, which are apparent to ene, and allowed by the authority of Aritotle, and Phyitians) I hall more copiouly dicoure hereafter.

In this place, not to digres farther, I conceive the blood to be taken (with Aritotle) not as it is De gen. an. l. 2. c. 3. imply undertood, and called Cruor, but as it is a living part of an Animal body. For o Aritotle: The blood is hot in uch a ene, as if we could call hot water by one onely word, and not as a ubject receiving heat into it. For heat is in the eence of the blood; as whitenes, in a white man. But when blood is made hot by any ditemper, or paion of the Minde, it is not then calidus pere, hot, by its own heat. And thus we may ay of that which is moit, or dry. Wherefore, partly a hot, and partly a moit ubtance is in the nature of uch kinde of things; but if you divide them, they then grow cold, and congeale; and uch is blood.

Blood therefore as it is a living part of the Body, is of a doubtfull nature, and falls under a two fold conideration. And therefore materialiter & per e, it is called nutriment; but formaliter, as it is endued with heat, and pirits, (which are the immediate intruments of the Soul) and with the Soul it elf: it is to be counted the Bodies Genius, and Conerver, the Principal, Primogenit, and Genital part. And as a Prolifical egg is the Matter, Intrument, and Efficient caue of the Chicken, and as all Phyitians count the geniture of both Sexes mingled in the womb after coition, both for the material and efficient of the Foetus; o, upon a better right, may we affirm, That the Blood is both the Matter and
Preerver of the Body, and not the bare Aliment. For it is a known thing in Creatures that are tarved by hunger, and Men alo that dye of Conumptions, that a great quantity of blood remains in their Veins even after death. And alo Young men that are in their growth, and Old men that are declining, have a proportionable quantity of blood; namely, according to the increae, or diminution of their Fleh. So that the blood is a part, and not the nutriment onely of the Body. For if that were the onely ue of it, no man would be tarved, o long as any drop of the blood remains in the veins, as the flame of a Lamp doth not expire, o long as any oyle at all remains to upport it.

But while I affirm the oul to reide firt, and principally in the blood, I would not have any man hatily to conclude from hence, that all Blood-letting is dangerous, or hurtfull; or believe with the Vulgar, that as much of blood, o much of life is taken away, becaue Holy-writ placeth the life in the blood. For dayly experience hewes, that Letting blood is a afe cure for everal Dieaes, and the chiefet of Univeral Remedies: becaue the default, or uperfluity of the blood is the eminary of mot ditempers; and a eaonable evacuation of it, doth often recue men from mot deperate maladies, and Death it elf. For look how much blood is according to Art taken away, o many years are added to the Age.

Nature her elf was our Tutor here, whom Phyitians trancribe: for She, of her own accord, doth many times vanquih the mot mortal Infirmities by a plentifull and critical evacuation, either at the Noe, Haemorrhoids, or by mentruous Purgations. And therefore young people, who feed high, and live idlely, unles about the eighteenth or twentieth
yeare of their age (at which time the tock of blood encreaes, together with the bulk of their bodies) they be disburdened of the load and oppreion of their blood, either by a pontaneous releae at the Noe, or Inferiour parts, or by breathing a Vein, they are dangerouly et upon by Feavers, Small-pox, Head-aches, and other more grievous Ditempers and Symptomes. Alluding to which, the Farriers, do begin almot all Cures of Beats with Letting blood.

div.head: What Obervations are to be collected from the Ramifications of the Umbilical veines in the Egge.
EXERCIT. LIII.
div.p:
WE ee the Blood is made in the Egge and Conception before any thing ele; and neere upon that time, doe its Receptacles, that is, the Veines, and Veicula pulans appear. And therefore if we admit the Punctum aliens, together with the blood and veines, as one and the ame Organical part, viible in the firt dawning of the Foetus, to tand for the Heart (whoe Parenchyma doth afterwards, in the formation of the Foetus, grow to the Veicula;) it is clear then, that the Heart under this acceptation (namely, as an Organ compounded of a Parenchyma, Ventricles, Deaf-ears, Veels, and Blood) is truly (according to Aritotles owne
minde) the principal and primary part of the body: and yet its firt and chief part is blood; and that not onely in order of Nature, but of Generation too.

The parts next in Generation to the blood, are the Veines: for the blood mut needs be kept in veels. And therefore (as Aritotle oberved) there are found two venal Channels neer upon the very beginnings of all, which do afterwards (as we have taught in our Hitory) contitute the Umbilical veels.

From their Scituation therefore and Ramification, ome things come to be oberved. The Firt is, that all the Veins and Arteries arie from the heart; for they are as o many retainers belonging to the Heart, or as certain parts of it. If therefore you diligently oberve a (humane or any other) foetus new born, and cutting in under the Vena Cava between the right Auricle of the Heart, and the Diaphragma, if you mark it as it looks downwards, you hall dicover three Holes, whereof the greatet and hinde-mot tending towards the Spine of the back, is the Hole of the decending Vena Cava; the fore-mot, and leer, is carried into the Root and Trunk of the Umbilical veels; the third, and the let of all, paeth into the Liver, and is the Fountain and Trunk of all the branches dieminated into the Gibbous part of the Liver. By which it is evident, that the veins do not (as ome would have it) proceed from the Liver, as from their Original, but from the Heart: unles they will obtinately affirm, that the Trunk and body of a vein aries from ome litle branch of the vein, and not the branches from the Trunk.

Moreover, ince the fore-aid veels in the Egg, are alike dieminated into the Yolk and White
(after the manner as Plants work in their Roots into the Ground) it appears, that both their liquours are the nutriment of the Foetus, and that that nourihment is by thee Veels conveyed unto it: and that againt Aritotle, who every where affirmes, that the Chicken aumes nourihment by the Navel,
De hit. an. l. 2. c. 3. De gen. an. l. 3. c. 1. & 3. onely from the Yolk, but is made of the White. The White indeed is firt pent, and the Yolke, though late, doth yet at lat become the Nutriment, and upplies the place of Milk when the Chicken is now hatcht: to the intent, that Nature might afford to Oviparous creatures uch an aliment as he holds out to Viviparous by the Breats, or Udder. Hereupon it falls out, that when all the White is exhauted, the Yolk continues almot entire, even when the Chicken is conummate, and complete; nay, even after his Excluion.

Aritotle, indeed, ten dayes after the Chickens excluion, found ome remainder of the Yolk in the Chicken: but I have oberved even after ix weeks time, ome part of it fatned to the Guts in the Chickens belly.

Yet upon the reception of the Yolk into the Abdomen of the Chicken, (which while the Foetus is forming, and growing, doth not abate o much as the White, but continues almot entire, when both the Whites are now quite wated) and alo upon the Obervation at the Ditribution of the Veines through the ubtance of the Yolk: all which being collected into one Trunk, do pas into the Vena Porta, and do carry part of the Yolk thither, to receive a further concoction in the Liver; upon thee, I ay, and uch like grounds, I cannot but acknowledge with Aritotle, that the Yolk doth nourih the Chicken, and hath ome analogie to Milke.

The Yolk doth not remain entire after the Conummation of the Foetus, for a portion of it is diolved in the firt conformation of the Chicken; and it likewie doth admit the propagations of the Veines (as well as the White) by which after it is now prepared, it becomes the Nutriment of the Foetus: yet certain it is, that the greatet part of it doth urvive the wated white, and that urviving part is entertained into the belly of the Chicken; and being attracted by the mall branches of the Vena Porta, is at lat conveyed into the Liver.

It is therefore a clear cae, that the Chicken newly hatched, (while it is yet weak and tender) is nourihed by the yolk. And as while he remained within the Egge, he was partly fed by the yolke, and partly by the whites, but chiefly by the hopitality of the whites, which as they are in greater quantity, o are they ooner exhauted: o in like manner, when he is now hatched, (at which time all his aliment paeth through his Liver, and there receives a farther preparation) he is nourihed partly by the yolk attracted from the Guts, and partly by the Chyle, which the everal propagations of the Meeraick Veines uck into themelves; when there is in the yolk onely one propagation of the Vena Porta ditributed into it, and a litle onely of the yolk remaining. For Nature, as Nures, being about to wean their Infants by degrees, gives them other meats ometimes, that o they may the better endure the decay of the milk: o the Chicken is trained by degrees, from meat of eaier concoction, to harder (as from the Yolk, to the Chyle.)

Therefore what we ee of the propagation of the Veines in the Egge, is done upon exceeding good grounds. For as oon as the Chicken begins firt to be modelled, the Veines are then extended only into
the Colliquamentum; by which the blood being fed and grown, adjoyns the ret of the body to himelf, to be brought up with him. Afterwards, the veines reach into the thinner white, from whence the Chicken receiveth his utenance, (while he yet reembleth a Gelly, or Mucilage, and a Maggot) afterwards they pread into the thicker White, and anon into the Yolk, that by that alo it may be entertained; and being as yet but tender, it is fed in part by the yolk (as by milke) hoarded up in the abdomen, and in part by food provided and prepared by the Hen, till it be able to eek abroad for nourihment convenient, and can diget it. So that through the whole eries of Generation, Nature hath mot prudently conidered of various Aliment proportionable to the various abilities of the Digetive faculty of the future Foetus. For while it is yet feeble, he hath provided it milder diet, and olider meats for its tronger capacity: and when it is now hearty enough, and can away with courer cates, it is erved with commons anwerable to it. And hereupon I conceive, that perfect eggs are not onely party-coloured, but alo furnihed with a double White.

And what we have found out by Experience,
De gen. an. l. 3. c. 1. eems alo to agree with Aritotles opinion, where he aith, That Part of it which is hotter, comes neerer the form deigned to the intitution of the members, but that which is earthier, yeelds matter to frame the body, and is more unlike. As in party-coloured eggs, the animal aumes the Rudiments of its generation from the White, (for the animals beginning is in the hot part) and its aliment from the yolk. Therefore in hotter animals, thoe two are reerved apart; namely, that from whence they take the beginning of their being, and that
from whence they derive their aliment, and one of them is white, and the other yellow.

It appeares by what hath been aid, that the Chicken (and the ame thing hall afterwards be demontrated of all conceptions) as he reults, or is framed from the implanted principle, or oul of the egge, o he alo obtaines his nourihment from the Egge too: wherefore he hath no need of a mother, as the Plants have of the Earth.

And it is no truer of him, that he is nourihed by his mothers blood, or lives by her pirits; and o his own heart lies fallow and idle the while, then that he moves and perceives by his mothers organs, or is enlivened and takes growth from her oul. But the cae is plain, and all men acknowledge, that the Foetus is fed by the Umbilical Veels; and that the Venal branches dieminated into the White and Yolk, do hence derive utenance, which they impart to the Foetus.

It is likewie clear, that when the Chicken is now hatcht, or excluded, he is upplyed with proviions, partly from the Yolk, and partly from the Chyle; and that they both pas into the Liver by the ame Vena Porta, though by everal branches of it.

It is alo clear, (to peak by the way) that the Chyle which nouriheth all living creatures, is tranported by the Meeraick Veins out of the Guts; and that there is no need to earch out new wayes (namely the Venae Lacteae) or to fanie any other paage in grown bodies, beides what we finde in the Egge and Chicken. But as for the Inconveniences of that invention, we hall elewhere dicover them.

Latly, by the contitution of the Umbilical Veels in the Egge, (whereof we have declared ome
to be Veines, and ome Arteries) we may tollect a Circulation of the Blood, (uch as we have long ince demontrated in our Book, de Motu Sanguin is in Animalibus) and that for vegetation, nutrition, and augmentation ake: and therefore the Umbilical Veels are dieminated into both the Liquors, that they may lead utenance from them to the foetus; and the Arteries are derived thither too, that by a plentifull affluence of heat they may concoct, diolve, and render the aliment uefull to nutrition.

And hence it comes to pas, that whereoever the veines (and under that name the Arteries alo are here comprehended) do arrive to the ubtance of the White or Yolk, thoe parts eem to be diolved, and put on a different look or appearance from the ret. For o oon as ever the branches of the Veines hoot forth, the uperiour or exteriour part of the White (into which they are inerted) grows tranparent, and melts into a Colliquntion; but the inferiour part remaining till thick, and compact, is confined to the Lower angle of the Egge. So likewie there eem to be two parts (a uperiour and an inferiour) of the Yolk, which do as much differ from one another, as melted from unmelted wax; namely, that part which hath entertained Veines into it, from the other which is yet detitute.

Hence alo we are acquainted with the Exordium, and firt inherent principle of the Egge. For it is clear, that the Cicatricula or Speck, is the principal particle of the Egge, to which all the ret are to be referred, and to which (if to any part before another) whatoever it be, which makes the Egge prolifical, is to be imputed, as alo the firt onet towards the generation of the Chicken. And therefore (as we have hewed) preently after the Incubation
of the Hen, the Cicatricula is firt of all dilated, enlarged, and makes a Colliquation; wherein forthwith the blood moves, the veines are cattered, and the operations and effects of the native heat, do by the help of the formative Operatour, betray themelves; and by how much the deeper the mall Filaments of thee veines do take rooting, by o much the wider is the Empire of the Vital faculty advanced, and the Majety of the Vegetal Soul revealed. For indeed every Effect is a cleare tetimony of its Efficient.

In a word, upon the Cicatricula (wherein the firt twy-light of native heat doth dawn) the whole Generation doth depend: Upon the Heart, the whole Chicken, and upon the Umbilical Veels, all the Membranes involving the Foetus (which we call the Secundine) do rely. Wherefore we conclude, that the parts of the Foetus are in ubordination one to the other, and do firt borrow life from the Heart.

div.head: Of the Order of parts in the Generaration out of an Egge, according to Fabricius.
EXERCITATION LIV.
div.p: IT being now reolved, which is to be eteemed the firt part, namely the Blood, with its Receptacles, the Heart, Veins, and Arteries; it now follows, that we dicover in what order all the parts of the Body are generated.

Fabricius (whoe teps we trace in the Generation of the Pullus) ere he proceed to the order of the Parts, doth firt recite the actions dicovered in an Egge, and by whoe aitance the Parts are formed; repeating alo in order their Faculties: as if out of them the order alo of the Generation of the Parts may be more clearly dicovered. There are three actions, aith he, which appear firt in an Egge upon which the Hen its: the firt is, the Generation of the Chicken; the econd, its Growth; the third, its Nutrition. The firt, that is, the Generation, is the proper action of the Egge; the econd and third (namely accretion and nutrition) do for the greatet part come to a height out of the egge; yet they are begun in the egge, and perfected there too. Which actions, as they flow from three faculties, (the Generative, Augmentative, & Nutritive) o three Effects do enue upon them: For from generation do all the parts of the Chicken reult; from accretion and nutrition, Growth, and Increae: treating firt of the Generation of the Chicken, we may dicover, that by the help of Generation the parts of the Chicken (which were not before) are produced, and o the Egge is transformed into the body of the Chicken. Now while any part doth commigrate into another, it mut needs pas through a commutation of its own proper eence; (for otherwie it mut continue the ame thing till) and alo mut be fahioned into a figure, cite, and magnitude convenient and conitent with its nature: and in thee two things is the Procreation of a ubtance abolved, namely, Commutation, and Conformation; therefore the Immutative and Formative faculties, are the caues of thee functions: Whereof the One hath produced each particular part of the body, jut as we ee it, out of the Chalaza of the Egge; the Other conferred the figure, cite, and compoition convenient for all the everal ues of it.
The firt of thee Faculties, which is the Immutative or Alterative faculty, is wholly natural, and doth act without any knowledge at all; and taking to it elf, the hot, the cold, the moit, and the dry parts, it alters the whole ubance of the Chalaza throughout, and by altering, it doth change it into the parts of the Chicken; that is to ay, into Fleh, Bones, Gritles, Ligaments, Veines, Arteries, Nerves, and into all the other imilar and imple parts of the Animal, or Chicken: and the Cocks eed doth by its proper ingenit heat and pirit, generate, create, and produce them out of the Egge (that is, the Chalaza) by Alteration and Commutation; imparting to every one of them its proper ubtance, and the proprieties belonging to that ubtance. The Other faculty which is called Formative, and which makes the imilar parts diimilar (betowing their beauty upon them, from convenient figure, jut dimenion, proper cite, and competent number) being much more noble then the former, and full of incomparable widom, doth not act Naturally, but by Election or Choice, Knowledg, and Undertanding. For truly this Formative faculty eems to be tored with mot exact knowledg, and praeviion, both of the future Action, and alo of the Ue of every particular Part, and Organ. And thus of the firt Action of the Egge, which is the generation of the Chicken, to whoe celebration, both the eed of the Cock, as Agent, and Fructifier, and the Chalaza, is required, as the ubject Matter. Next comes Accretion, which is done by Nutrition; whoe Faculties are the Attractive, the Retentive, the Digetive, and Expulive faculties: and latly, the Faculty of Appoition, Agglutination, and Aimulation.

But as for this ditribution of the Actions, I conceive it neither to be right, nor ueful, nor pertinent in this place. Not Right; becaue thoe actions, which he eems to hold to be ditinct, in
their pecies, and time; namely that the parts hould be firt made imilar, by the Immutative faculty; after that, formed, and made Organicall by the formative; and then augmented by the augmentative) do no where appear o in the Generation of the Chicken; for the parts are all generated, ditinguihed, and augmented together. For though it be otherwie in the Generation of thoe Animals which are framed by a Metamorphois; where all the parts are transformed, and lineated out of a pre-exitent matter, which is large enough, and prepared before hand, (as when out of a Worme is made a Butterfly, and out of another Worme a Silk-Worme) yet in Generation by Epigeneis, the buines is much otherwie, nor is the proceeding there, as it is in Nutrition, which is performed by the divers actions of divere parts, joining their confederate forces and helps together: namely, where the Aliment is firt attracted and retained; then concocted, then ditributed, and at lat agglutinated. Nor is the imilar contitution produced by the Alterative faculty, without all kind of providence (as Fabricius would have it) And the Organical, by the Formative, which imployes knowledge and providence in her undertakings. For Generation and Accretion, are not made without Nutrition, nor Nutrition, or Augmentation, without Generation. For to Nourih, is to ubtitute into the place of that which is lot, as much, and uch as is lot: namely, Fleh, or Nerves, into the roome of that Fleh, and thoe Nerves, which are impared. And what is this other, then to make Fleh, or Nerves? So likewie Accretion is not without Generation: For all Natural bodies, are Augmented, by a new acceion of thoe parts, of which they did conit
before: and that according to all dimenions: So that they at once do grow, are ditinguihed, and organized together,

And now, to Generate a Chicken, is nothing ele, but to contitute all its parts, members and organs: which though they are made in order, and ome are pot-genit, or later productions then others (as the lee principal parts, compared with the more principal) yet while the organs themelves are ditinguihed, their generation doth not proceed in uch order, that the imilar parts mut be firt made, and the organical be afterwards compounded out of them: as if the compounding parts were firt to exit, and then the Compoition to be raied out of them. For though the Head of the Chicken, and the ret of its Trunck, or corporature (being firt of a imilar contitution) do reemble a Mucus, or a oft glewey ubtance: out of which afterwards all the parts are framed in their order: yet by the ame operation, and the ame Operatour, they are together made and augmented: and as that ubtance reembling glew doth grow, o are the parts ditinguihed. Namely, they are Generated, Altered, and formed at once: they are at once imilar and diimilar: and from a mall imilar, is a great organ made. In the ame manner as out of the traw, the pike, reeds, and graines do arie, and are ditinguihed: and as the Trees, when they hoot forth their young buds, do out of them, expand and produce flowers, leaves, fruit, and at lat, eed.

And this we have learnt out of thoe things which are conpicuous in an egge, by diligent obervation of them. For by the effects, the actions, or operations are perceived; by the operations, the faculties, and by them, the Operatour
or Efficient. Wherefore in the Generation of the Chicken, the actions or faculties of the Generant (which Fabricius recites; namely, the Immutative and Formative) do not differ Specie, nor yet ecundum prius & poterius, but (as Aritotle ueth to peak) ipo ee, and ratione olum: not as it befals the actions of the nutritive faculty, after the birth, (to wit, Attraction, Concoction, Ditribution, and Appoition) which performe their duties in everal places, and at everal times. For otherwie the Generative faculty her elf, hould be inforced alo to ue divere intruments to perform her everal operations.

Wherefore Fabricius affirms amie, that the Immutative Faculty doth operate by the qualities of the Elements, namely, Heat, Cold, Moiture, and Drynes: (as being its intruments) but that the formative works without them, and after a more divine manner: as if (forooth) he did finih her task, with meditation, choie, and providence. For had he looked deeper into the thing, he would have een, that the Formative, as well as the Alterative faculty makes ue of hot, cold, moit, and dry, (as her intruments) & would have deprehended as much divinity and skill, in Nutrition and Immutation, as in the operations of the Formative faculty her elf. For nature hath intituted all thoe faculties for ome end; and doth every where work with providence, and undertanding. Whatoever it is which makes the eed of Plants fruitful, and doth exercie a platick virtue in it: and that which in an egge executes the office of a mot skilful Workeman, doth produce and build the parts, and by Calefying Refrigerating, Moitning, Drying, Concocting, Condening, Hardning, Softning, Diolving, both Fahion, and
Augment them; doth alo ditinguih them, by Figure, Scite, Contitution, Temperature, Number, and Order: dipoing and compleating all things, with like providence, election, and undertanding, (no lee in the alteration, then nutrition, augmentation, and formation of them.)

I ay the Concocting, and Immutative; the Nutritive, and Augmenting faculties; (which Fabricius would have to buie themelves onely about Hot, Cold, Moit, and Dry, without all knowledge) do operate with as much artifice, and as much to a deigned end, as the Formative faculty: which he affirms, to poes the knowledge and fore-ight of the future action, and ue of every particular part, and Organ.

As the Art of Phyick, the Bakers and the Cooks light (which et on work, the hot, cold, moit, and dry, and uch like natural Intruments) doe no les require the exercie of reaon, then Mechanical Trades, which either work with their own hand, (as the Smith, the Statuaries, and the Potters) or other artificial intruments. But as in the greater world, we ay, Jovis omnia plena, All things are full of the Deity, o alo in the little edifice of a Chicken, and all its actions and operations, Digitus Dei, the Finger of God, or the God of Nature, doth reveal himelf.

Therefore if it be lawful for us to judge of the faculties by the operations; the Vegetal Operations do rather eem to be executed by Art, Election, and Providence; then the very actions of the Rational oul, and the Mind, though in a mot perfect man, the top and pinnacle of whoe Knowledge and Undertanding, conits chiefly (according to Apollos verdit) in this, ut no eat e ipum, that he know himelf. A more ublime, and
diviner Artificer therefore (then man is) eems to make and preerve man: and a nobler Agent then a Cock, doth produce a Chicken out of the Egge. For we acknowledge our Omnipotent God, and mot high Creator, to be every where preent in the tructure of all creatures living; and to point himelf out by his Workes; whoe Intruments the Cock and Hen are in the Generation of the Chicken. For it is mot apparent, that in the Generation of the Chicken out of the egge, all things are et up and formed, with a mot ingular providence, divine widom, and an admirable, and Incomprehenible Artifice.

Nor can thee Attributes appertain to any, but to the Omnipotent Maker of all things, under what name oever we cloud and veil him: whether it be, Mens divina, the divine Mind, with Aritotle, or Anima mundi, the oul of the Univere, with Plato; or with others, Natura Naturans, Nature of Nature her elf; or ele Saturnus, or Jupiter, with the Heathen; or rather, as befits us, the Creatour, and Father of all things in Heaven, and Earth: upon whom all Animals, and their births depend: and at whoe Beck, or Mandat, all things are created, and begotten.

Moreover (as I have oberved) this ditribution of the Actions, or faculties of the Soul (which Fabricius doth premie to the order of Generation of the parts) as I apprehend it to be faulty, o alo I conceive it to be unprofitable and inconvenient, or impertinent to our buines. For we doe not attain to the knowledge of the Effect, by the knowledge of the actions or faculties, but rather on the contrary, from the Effects we acend to the Faculties; for the effects or workes are notiora nobis, more known unto us, then the faculties
from whence they pring: and the parts (which we ee made already) are more intelligible in Generation, then the actions which framed them.

Nor do thoe things which are to be conidered and determined in the general obervation of all Animals, fall properly within the compas of the particular generation of the Chicken out of the Egge. But of them more hereafter.

In the mean time, we hall proceed to the Order of the Generation of the parts. It remaines, aith Fabricius, that we conider and contemplate in what Order, that is, which part is made firt, and which after in the Egge. In proecution whereof there are two foundations to be laid: one in repect of the body: the other in relation to the incorporeal ubtance, as, the Nature or Soul. I call that (aith he) the Corporeal foundation, which depends upon, and flowes from the Nature of the body: and whereof an intance is eaily deduced from things made by art: For, as every edifice doth firt require a foundation, upon which the whole frame is to be laid and upported: whence the walls are et up, which do utaine the Floors and Roofe: and then the Houhold-tuff, and other furniture are introduced; o doth nature proceed in the Fabrick of Animals. For firt he laies the Bones as the foundation, that all the parts of the Body may grow to, hang, upon, and be etablihed by them. Which bones are firt made under another capacity. For ince Bones take their firt rie from a mot oft and membranous ubtance, and doe afterwards attaine their induration; therefore much time mut be allotted to the Generation of the Bones, that o they may become the hardet parts; and hereupon they are begotten firt. And for this reaon Galen did not compare the tructure of an Animal to every kind of building, but chiefly to that of a Ship. For, aith he, as the foundation
and original of the Ship is the Keel, from which the ides, or planks imbowed, and placed at a ditance one from the other (like a Hurdle) are et up on both ides, that o the whole frame of the Ship may be afterwards finihed out of the Keel, as a convenient foundation; So in the fabrick of an Animal, Nature firt tretcheth out the Chine bone, with the Ribbes drawn round it, as the Keel, and congruous principle, whereon he foundeth and finiheth the whole Pile.

But Experience doth abundantly confute this phanie: for it is evident, that the Bones are rather made lat of all. For the Bones of the Limbs, the Skull and Teeth, are not made before the Brain, the Mucles, and flehey parts; but even after the nativity, in the tender, and (otherwie) perfect foetus, they are onely Gritles, and Membranes, and afterwards in tract of time arrive to the olidity of Bones, as doth appear by Infants Skulls, and the Ribbes and Joints of Embryo's.

And though it be true, that the firt platforme of the body appears like a Bent or incurved Keel, yet is it of a oft, mucous, and glutinous conitence, no way reembling either the Nature, Contitution, or Office of a Bone. As alo the mall Globous bodies which are its appendixes (deigned for the parts of the Head) have no olidity at all in them, but are onely Veicles tuffed with clear water, which are afterward transformed into the Braine, After-braine, and Eyes; and are at lat fenced with the Skull, namely, after the Bill, and Clawes have attained olidity, and obduration.

Wherefore this Contemplation of Fabricius is a leepy, and injurious one; He not conidering what really is done by nature in the order of Generation, but rather what nature according to his
phanie, ought to have done; as if Nature did imitate Art, and Art were not rather Natures Ape. Which comming into his head, himelf afterwards aith, Satius fuerit dicere, &c. It is a more diliberate pag. 44. aertion to ay, that Art was Natures Scholar, and wrought by her Copy: becaue as Galen every where pronounceth, Nature is of more Antiquity, and wier in her productions then Art.

And though the bones are the foundation of the whole body, without which it can nor tand nor move: yet it is ufficient for them, if they are made together with thoe parts, which do rely upon them. For where the things which are to be upheld are not in being, the Props are provided to no purpoe. But nature doth nothing rahly; nor contitutes parts, before there is ue of them. But all Animals attaine their parts, o oon as action and uefulnes is required of them. And therefore this firt foundation of Fabricius his laying, countenanced by his own obervations in the Egge, and Galens imile, is clean demolihed.

He eems to come neerer the Mark, when hee aith, The other foundation of producing the parts in order, is deumed from Nature, that is, the oul; which is Queen Regent of the animal body. For ince there are two degrees of the oul, the Vegetal and Senative; and the Vegetal is, tempore & naturâ prior, firt both in time and nature, becaue it is common to the very Plants; doubtles the Intruments ubervient to the Vegetal, are firt to be made and fitted, before thoe that attend the enitive and motive faculties: epecially the more principal ones, and where the Queen keeps Court. Now thee are chiefly two, the Liver, and the Heart: the Liver as the throne of the Vegetal or Nutritive: and the Heart as that Miniter of State,
who by his heat and warmth, doth enliven and compleat both the Vegetal, and other Faculties, and therefore holds a trong league and confederacy with the Vegetal. Wherefore if after three dayes Incubation, you dicern in that part of the egge where the Chicken is bred, the heart panting, (as Aritotle alo tetifieth) mue not at it, but conclude that the heart relates to the vegetal Faculty, and is therefore the firt begotten. Now it is alo cononant to Reaon, that the Liver alo hould be Twinne to the Heart, and born with it, but doth not appear, becaue he wants a palpitation, which the Heart hath. For even Aritotle himelf aith, That the Liver and the Heart are contituted in the body upon like grounds; o that if there be a Heart, there mut be a Liver too. If therefore the Liver and Heart are firt begotten, it alo followes, that the other Organs that are menial ervants relating to thee two, hould be begotten together with them; as, the Lungs for the Heart; and for the Liver, almot all the parts which are contained in the Lower Belly.

But all this is very wide from that order and progres which we ee in the Egge. Nor is it true, that the Liver is born together with the Heart: nor will that hift erve his turn, where he pretends, Latere Jecur, quia non palpitat, that the Liver lyeth concealed, becaue it is not expoed by palpitation. For the Eyes, the Vena Cava, and the Carina, the Keel, are dicerned even from the very firt, yet have they no palpitation. What impediment then to barre the Liver and Lungs (if they are then in being) from being een? Nay, he himelf, in his Figure or Table, repreenting the fourth day, hath decribed a mall Point in the midt, and yet he hath not ignified any palpitation belonging to it; nor did he own it for the Heart, but uppoed it to be the firt rudiment of the body: wherefore
he peaks onely out of conjecture, and preentertained opinion, when he proclaims the Principality of the Liver: as other men have alo done, (namely, Aldrovandus, and Parianus) who caually lighting upon two Points, and could not dicover a Pule in both, at one and the ame time, conceived the one to be the Heart, and the other the Liver. As if the Liver had any pule at all; but thoe two Points are the two Veiculae Pulantes, returning anwer to each other in alternate contractions; as hath been noted in our Hitory.

Wherefore, either Fabricius is deceived, or doth deceive, where he aith, Preently in the firt progres of generation, the Liver, Heart, Veines, Arteries, Lungs, and all the parts contained in the lower belly; likewie the Keel, that is, the Head, with the Eyes, and the whole Spine and Chet, are born and framed. For the Heart, Veins, and Arteries, are perfectly ditinguihed, for ome time, before the Keel; and the Carina, or Keel, before the Eyes; and the Eyes, the Bill, and Sides, before the Members contained in the lower belly: and alo the Stomack, and Guts, before the Liver, or Lungs, are dicerned. And that order is oberved in generation, which we hall preently decribe.

He is likewie deceived, when he decrees the Vegetal part to have a being both in time and nature before the enitive and the motive. For that which is firt in Nature, is for the mot part after, in the order of Generation. In time, indeed, the Vegetal part is before, becaue the enitive oule cannot be without it. For it cannot actually exit in the body without Organs, it being Actus corporis Organici, the Act of the Organical body: but the enitive and motive Organs, are the workmanhip of the vegetative; and the enitive
oul (before it actually exit) is tanquam Trigonus in Tetragono, like a Triangle in a Quadrangle. But Nature firt intends that which is mot principal and noble; and therefore the Vegetal faculty is after in the order of Nature, as being ubervient to the enitive, and motive Faculty.

div.head: Of the Order of Parts in Generation, according to Aritotle.
EXER. LV.
div.p:
THat which relates to the order of Generation, according to Aritotle, is thus: When the Conception
De gen. an. l. 2. c. 4. is ordained, it proceeds as Seeds do. For Seeds alo have a firt Principle in themelves; which being firt contained in potentiâ, when by and by it is evered, it ends forth a bud, and a root, whereby it attracts aliment; for it requires growth. So in ome ort in a conception, where the parts are all in potentiâ, the Principle is chiefly active.

This Principle in an Egge (analogous to the bloom of Plants) we with Fabricius call Macula, a Speck, or Cicatricula, a mall Cicatrice: which we have avouched to be the principal particle, in which all the other parts are in potentiâ, & whence afterwards they arie in their order. For in it is contained that thing (be it what it will) which renders the Egge prolifical; and there is the firt effect of the vegetal heat, and operation of the Forming faculty firt dicovered.

Macula ithaec, that Speck (as hath been hewed) is preently dilated after incubation, and divided
into Circles; in whoe Center a mall white Point (like the Cicatricula, in the ball of the Eye) doth diplay it elf: where by and by the Punctum rubrum, the Red point, is dicovered panting, with the capillary branches of Veines containing blood; and that preently, o oon as ever the Colliquamentum by us mentioned, is framed of that Macula.

Wherefore Aritotle proceeds; The Heart is firt actually dicerned; and that not onely dicoverable to Ibid. ene, but according to reaon. For ince that which is begotten is now disjoyned from both parents, it ought to demean, govern, and dipoe of it elf, as a Son et free by his Father, and eated apart. And therefore a Principle, and that an Intrinecal one, mut needs be had, by which afterwards the order of the Parts is to be precribed, and all things relating to the complement of the Animal, managed, and dipoed. For if it were Extrinecal at any time, and afterwards began to enter in, you would not only be in upene, and quetion when it went in, but conclude, that ince each part is ditinguihed, it was neceary that part hould ubit, out of which both growth and motion is conferred upon the other parts. In another place he aith, The firt Principle is a part of the whole, and not any eparate thing, which is contained apart from it. For, aith he, when the Animal is now generated, is that Principle corrupted, or doth it remain? Now nothing eems to be in, which is not a part of the whole, be it Plant, or Animal. And that it hould be corrupted, when it hath been at the expence of making all, or ome of the parts, is very aburd; for what hall make the remainder? Wherefore (he proceeds) who ide with Democritus, aying, That the exteriour parts of the Animal are firt made, and then the interiour: as if they were to build a wodden or tony Animal, do not ay well; for uch a creature as that hath no Principle in it elf. But all Animals
have, and contain one within them. Whereupon the Heart is firt een in all Animals, in which there is blood; for that is the Principle of the imilar, and diimilar parts. Now that thing which requires Aliment, ought already to have received that principle of an Animal, and contituted Foetus.

Which words do plainly declare, that Aritotle did conclude of an Order in the Generation of Animals, and of a Principal part, namely, the Heart, which (like a Son at liberty) is the firt animate, and primogenit part of the Animal, contained, and abiding in it: whence not onely the method of the parts is et down, but the Animal it elf, preerved, and relyes upon it, receiving continual life and utenance; and that thence, whatoever is neceary to the perfection of the Animal, is derived. For, (as Seneca aith) in the Seed is the whole
Nat. quet. l. 3. c. 19. accompt of the future Man comprehended. And the Infant yet unborn hath a Standard and Commiion for a Beard, and a Gray-head. For the dimenion of his body, and enuing yeares, are already deciphered in a mall, myterious character.

Now whether the Heart be the Primigenial part, or no, we have determined above. To wit, if Aritotles peech be undertood of that part, which (in the Anatomy of Living creatures) is een by the eye to be before the ret, (that is, of the Punctum aliens, together with the Veines treaming with blood) we cheerfully embrace his judgement. For we believe, that the Blood, together with the Veels, and Intruments; namely, the Umbilical Veines, (by which, as by Roots, the Nutriment is attracted) and Veiculae pulantes (to whom it is ditributed for the life and growth of the parts) is contituted before any other. For (as Aritotle aith) the matter by which any thing is augmented,
and out of which it is firt made, is one and the ame.

But they are much abued, who conceive, that the divere parts of the Body are utained with a divere aliment. As though Nutrition were nothing but a bare choice, and attraction of aliment: and that no concoction, aimilation, appoition, and tranmutation, were required of the particular parts which are to be nourihed: which was the opinion of Anaxagoras of old. Lucret. l. 1.

lg.l: Principium Rerum qui dixit Homoeomeriam;
Oa videlicet è pauxillis atque minutis
Oibus; ic & de pauxillis atque minutis
Viceribus, Vicus gigni: anguenque creari,
Sanguinis inter e multis coeuntibu' guttis.
Who aid, that Things from their Likeparts begin;
That Bones from les, and fewer Bones do pring;
And Intrals rie from Intrals, Blood from Blood,
Where the Confederate drops make up the Flood.

div.p:
But Aritotle mot truly aith: Ditinction of parts is not, as ome uppoe, upon that ground, that Like is In the place before cited. of its own nature tending to its Like: for beides many other difficulties which beet that opinion, it will follow, that every imilar part mut be ordained apart by it elf: as for intance; Bones by themelves, Nerves, and Fleh by themelves, in cae that opinion be admitted. But, indeed, the Nutriment of all parts is common and imilar, as the Yolk in the Egge; and not heterogeneous, and compounded of divere parts. And therefore what we have aid concerning
the matter out of which the Parts are made: we pronounce the ame of the matter out of which they are augmented; namely, that the parts do aume their Nourihment out of that matter, in which all the Parts are in potentiâ, but none actu.

As out of the ame Showre all kinds of Plants take growth, becaue that moiture, which was before like in potentiâ to them all, is now made like them actu, being transformed into their ubtance; And is alo bitter in Rue, harp in the Mutard, and weet in Licorie; and o in the ret.
