He goes on, to explain what Parts are generated before others; and that with a reaon not much unlike Fabricius his Fundamentum ecundum, his econd ground or foundation, aying, Id cujus causâ, & quod ejus causâ, differunt; & alterum generatione, alterum eentiâ prius et; namely, the End is firt in Nature and Eence, in repect of that thing which is made for the Ends ake; but That which is made for the Ends ake, mut needs be firt in Generation. And by that Argument Fabricius rightly inferrs, that thoe Parts which are ubervient to the Vegetative oul, are all made before thoe which are intrumental to the enative, becaue that is ubordinate to this.

After this, he ubjoines the differences of uch things as are made for any End; namely, that ome things are intituted for ome End by nature, becaue the End doth enue upon them: but ome, becaue they are Intruments which the End makes ue of: and thoe he calls Genitalia, but thee, Intrumentalia. For the End, aith he, in ome things is after, and in ome, before thoe things which are their caues. For the Generant himelf, and that which he imployes in Generation, mut needs exit before that which is generated by them.
And therefore the Parts ubervient to the Vegetative oul, are before thoe which are retained by Sene, and Motion. But the Parts dedicated to Motion and the Senes, are after the enitive and motive Faculties; as being intrumental, and made ue of by the enitive and motive Faculty. For by Natures Law, no Parts or Intruments are made and contituted, before there be imployment for them, and a faculty be ready at hand, to et them to work. So neither the Eye, nor the Intruments of Motion are et up, till the Brain is built, or the faculty be already provided, which is to See, or Move.

In like manner, becaue the Veiculae pulantes do (as Intruments) miniter to the motion of the Blood; and likewie the whole Frame and Fabrick of the Heart (as we have evidenced in our Book de Motu Sanguinis) is Intrumental; (namely, that the Blood may be continually hurried round the Body in a Circle) the Blood eems to have a being both in Order of Nature and Generation before the Heart; which he imployes as an Intrument, having begotten it alo, and doth perit to nourih, and convey heat, pirits, & life unto it by the Coronal Artery.

But how this General Rule of Aritotle concerning the prae-ordering of the Parts, doth appear to be true by Anatomical Obervation, we hall declare hereafter. In the mean time, we will enquire, after what manner he himelf doth ufficiently deduce the Caues of Priority, as I may o ay, in Generation, according to this Rule.

After the Principle (namely the Heart) are the Interiour parts begotten, before the exteriour; the uperiour, before the inferiour: for the inferiour are for the uperiours akes, as being their intrument: after the pattern oberved in Plants, which hoot forth their Roots, before their Branches.

But Nature doth not ue that method in Generation; nor is the intance alwayes true; for in Beanes, Ciches, and other Pule, alo in Acornes or Mat, and Corne, it is apparent that at the ame time, the Stalk hootes upward from the ame Bud, and the Roots downward. Likewie Onions, and other bulbous plants, do germinate upwards before they fix downwards.

But he adjoines another caue of this order; to wit, Nature makes nothing uperfluous, nor nothing in vaine, whence it appears, that nothing is made by her, either before or after another, otherwie then need requires. Namely, thoe parts are firt generated, whoe ues and functions are firt required: ome alo are ooner begun, becaue they call for more time to perfect them, that o they may be ready for the birth, together with others that are forwarder then they. As the Cook being to provide a feat, where ome proviions (by reaon of their olidity) aske a lower fire, and longer time to prepare them, he laies them down to the fire firt: but to thoe that are ooner dipatched, and are dreed with a gentler heat, he applyeth himelfe lat: and uch alo as are to be erved up in the firt coure, he makes ready firt, but thoe in the econd, lat. So likewie nature, in the generation of Animals, is late ere he delineate the moit, oft, and flehey parts, (as being quickly cooked, and reduced into hape) but for the hard and more olid (as the bones) becaue they exact a large Evaporation, and Exiccation, and their matter continues long indigeted, to them he addrees her elfe firt of all. For in the Braine alo, aith he, the ame falls out, namely, that at firt it is very moit, and great in quantity: but anon, the humidity evaporating, and being concocted, it growes
more olid, and o the quantity of the Head, and Eyes, do abate. In the beginning therefore, the Head eems very bigge (in comparion of all the ret of the body, which it much exceeds in bulke) by reaon of the Braine: and the eyes very large, by reaon of the humour conteined in them. But yet the eyes are perfected lat; becaue even the Braine it elfe is long ere it grow to a conitence. For it is long ere it get the matery, and drein the water, and epecially in a Man. For the Sinciput is lat confirmed of all the Bones; for that bone is yet oft, even when the Child is born into the World.

He alo proceeds to another reaon; namely, that the parts are framed of different materials. The more noble parts, (aith he) and thoe that participate the worthiet principles, are contituted of the concocted, puret, and chiefet aliment: the other neceary parts, made for their akes, are fahioned out of the baer matter, the reliques, and dregs. For Nature, like a prudent Mater of a Family, loeth nothing, out of which he can make any advantage, but o manages the matter in his houe, that his Children may fare bet, his Servants harder then they, and the craps or refue thrown to the Dogs. As therefore, Incremento jam addito, mens advena facit haec, that is, (as I interpret it) a prudent man grown to years of dicretion, dipoes thus of his Charge; So in the framing of things, Nature (by an inbred widome and prudence) formes the fleh, and ubtance of the intruments of ene, out of the mot refined matter, but the Bones, Nerves, Hair, Nailes, Hoofes, and the like, out of the Dregs, (that is the refue, remainders, or fragments) And therefore thee are made lat, when nature hath now good tore of coure materials. And after this, he ditinguiheth of two orts of Aliment; one of Nutrition, the other of Augmentation.
That of Nutrition, aith he, doth upply a being to the whole, and all the parts, that of augmentation procureth an acceion to the magnitude.

According to what we finde in the Egge; where the White (as the more refined Aliment) relates to the firt Nutrition of the Chicken; the Yolk to its augmentation. And the thinner White (as hath been hewed) conduceth to the formation of the Firt, and nobler Parts; but the Courer, and the Yolk, to the augmentation of the Nobler, and formation of the more Ignoble. For, he aith, the Nerves are framed as the Bones, out of the eminal and nutritive excrement. But the Nailes, Haire, Spurres, and all like thee, are formed out of augmentative, and adventitious meats; which the Foetus both receives from the Mother, and alo doth provide of it elfe. And after this he at lat gives the reaon, why Man (ince other Animals are provided with their Garments, and Weapons at Natures price) hould be borne naked, and unarmed; namely, that thoe kind of parts are contituted of the excrementitious parts, and reliques, but the materials of Men are purer, in which there is very litle terrene, or crude excrement to be found.

And thus far have we made ue of Aritotle, concerning the Order of Generation: where all eems to be bottomed upon one foundation; namely, Natures Perfection; which in all her Workmanhip, hath nothing hort, nor nothing uperfluous, but always dipoeth matters for the bet. And therefore no parts had been precedent or ubequent to one another, if it had been more advantagious to have formed them altogether; which is to be undertood of Her, as often as he acts freely, and by choice. For ometimes he acts otherwie,
being as it were under contraint, and put beide her purpoe; which happens, when either by defect of matter, or uperfluity thereof, or by the default of her intruments, or ome outward impediments, he is hindered in her work, and frutrated of her aime, or end. And hence it comes to pas ometimes, that the final parts are generated before the Intrumental: I call thoe final parts, which employ others, (as their intruments.)

And becaue ome parts are Genital parts, which Nature ets to work about the Generation of other parts, or ele to remove ome Obtructions in her proceedings, which in cae they continue, the Generation may be retarded: and others are under another capacity: therefore it comes to pas, that according to the dipoition of the matter, and other requiites, the parts are diverly made ome after other, and ome of them are in hand before, but are not finihed till afterwards: ome are begun and finihed before others are begun, and others are as oon begun as their fellows, but finihed after them. And therefore in the generation of ome Animals, the ame order is not always oberved, but it is much different and various; and in ome no order at all: but all the parts are begun, and finihed at a heat: namely by a Metamorphois, as we hewed. And latly, hence it happens that the Primogenit part is uch, that in it is concluded both the Beginning, and the End; as well that for whoe ake all are made (namely the oul) as alo that which is its caue in chief, and Genital part. The Heart therefore (or, according to my perwaion, the Blood) is the firt throne of the Soul; the fountain of life; the Vetal fire; the Genital warmth; and the very Calidum Innatum; the firt Efficient of all his minitring
parts, having atcheived the oul for his end, which commands them all as her leige-people. The Heart I ay, (as Aritotle will have it) is he, for whoe ake the whole Fabrick and Family of the parts are provided, and who alo is the Fountain, and Father of them all.

div.head: Of the Order of Parts in Generation, as it appears by our Obervations.
EXER. LVI.
div.p: THat we may at lat propoe our own opinion of the Order of Parts, as we have collected it out of everal Obervations of our own; we intend to ditinguih the whole work of Generation (in all Animals whatoever) into two Fabricks.

Whereof the firt is that of the Egge; namely, of the Conception, and Seed, or of that, whatoever it is, which (in Spontaneous productions) anwereth in proportion to Seed; whether we undertand it under the notion of Calidum nativum coelete in humido primigenio, the Innate celetial ubtance, in the Primigenial moit, with Fernelius, or with Aritotle, of Calor Vitalis in humors comprehenus, the vital heat concluded in moiture. For the Conception in Viviparous Animals (as we have aid) is anwerable to the Seed and Fruit of Plants; as alo the Egge, in Oviparous; in Spontaneous productions, the Worme, or ome Bulla teeming by the Vital heat of the conteined moiture. In all which the ame thing is
comprehended, which may truly call them Seeds; namely, out of which, and by which (as the matter, and Efficient, and pre-exitent Organ) every Animal is firt made and borne.

The Other Fabrick is of the Foetus, born out of the Seed, or Conception. For the Matter, and the Final, and Efficient caues, and the Intruments neceary to the worke, mut firt be, before any part of the Production can begin.

The Fabrick of the Egge we have already een: but that of the Foetus (o far as we could dicover out of diections) is perfected (epecially in the more perfect race of Animals, and uch as have blood) chiefly by four degrees, or proceions: which according to the everal times of generation, we hall reduce into as many Orders; demontrating withall that the ame thing which is dicerned in the Egge, is alike in every conception and eed.
The Firt progres is of the Primogenit, and Genital part, namely of the blood, with its receptacles, or if you will have it o, of the Heart and his Veins.

Now this part is firt begotten, chiefly for two reaons, both becaue it is the principal part, which makes ue of all the ret, as its Intruments; and for whoe ake the other parts eem to be produced: as alo, becaue it is the Chiefe Genital part, the Fountain and Author of the ret; The part in which is concluded both the Beginning and End of Generation; the ame being Pater & Rex, Parent, and Sovereign.

In the Generation of thee Parts, (which is determined in the Egge the Fourth day) though I could not oberve any Order; becaue all its particles (Blood, Veins, and Veicula pulans) appear
at once; yet I believe (as I aid) that the blood is in it, before the Pule: and that it alo in Natures Law, is before it receptacles, the Veins: for the ubtance and tructure of the Heart (namely the one with its Ventricles and Auricles) as it is generated long after with the other Intrals, o ought it to be regitered in their Clais, which is the Third.
In this tructure, the veines are conpicuous before the Arteries, at leat, as farre as we could oberve.

The Second Journal, which ets out after the fourth day, dicovers a certain Concrementum, or coagulated ubtance, which I call Vermiculum, eu Galbam, the litle Worm, or Magot; (for it eems to enjoy the life and obcure motion of a Galba) and this, as it congeals into a gelly, is divided into two parts; whereof the upper and the larger is conglobated, and ditinguihed into three Veicles; namely, that of the Brain, After-brain, and one of the Eyes: but the leer, carinam referens, reembling the Keel of a Ship, is uperinduced upon the Vena Cava, and is extended according to its length.
In the tructure of the Head, the Eyes are firt dicerned, and anon a white pot tarts up for the Bill, and the filme drying about, it becomes protected by a membrane.

At this time alo the adumbration, or rough draft of the ret of the Body eems to ucceed; where firt upon the Carina the ides or plancks, as it were, of a Boat eem to arie; being at firt of a imilar conitence, but afterwards by mot white treaks they are ignified to be the lines of the Ribs. After this, the members of Motion, namely, the Wings and Legs do appear: and at lat the Keel, and Limbs born by a kinde of Superfoetation, are
ditinguihed into Mucles, Bones, and Joints.

Thoe two firt mihapen materials of the Head and Body, do together appear, and are together ditinguihed: but afterwards, when they tend towards growth and perfection, the body gets the tart, and is much ooner grown and haped; o that the Head which did at firt out-trip the whole body beide, in bulk and magnitude, is now very much hort of it. And this is likewie natural to humane productions.

The like Diparity is between the Body it elfe & the Limbs; for in an Infant (from that time that the Embryo exceeds not the length of the Nail of the litle Finger, till he be encreaed to the tature of a Frog, or a Moue) his Arms are o hort, that if you tretch out his fingers over his breat, to their farthet extent, they will not be able to touch one another; and his thighs are o hort, that being reflected upon his Abdomen, they will hardly reach to his Navel.

Nay, in Children lately born, the proportion of the bulk of the Body is a pretty deal larger then that of the Limbs, untill they are able to tand, and go. And therefore Infants are firt Dwarfs, and crawle like beats, & attempt to move on, though upon all four: but go upright they cannot, till the prolixity of their Legs and Thighs exceed the longitude of the ret of the Body. And hence is it, that their firt venture to foot it, repreents them a prone kinde of Cattell, which can carce exalt themelves to the erection of a Cock.

And therefore amongt grown perons, the long limme Fellows, (whoe Thighs, but epecially their Shanks, are longer then ordinary) can tand, walk, run, or vault longer, and at more eae, then quare, and well trued men.

In this econd Proces, everal actions of the Formative faculty puruing one another, may be oberved; (as in the Automata, or engines that go of themelves; where the fore-going wheel ets his follower upon motion too) and all the parts pring from the ame gelly, and imilar ubtance. Not as De gen. an, l. 2. c. 4. ome Natural Philoophers expound it, who ay, that Like is hurried unto its like: but we mut ay, That the parts are moved not by changing their tation, but remaining where they were, and altering in oftnes, hardnes, complexion, and thoe other differences of imilar parts; being now made thoe things Actu, which they were before in Potentiâ: that is, the Limbs, the Spine, and the ret of the Body, are altogether formed and encreaed, are together decribed, and complexioned: alo the Bones, Fleh, Nerves, and Gritles, which were all imilar at firt in the ame members, and of one kinde of ubtance, in progres of Time are plainly ditinct; and being conjoined, make up Organical Parts, by whoe mutual connexion and continuity the whole body is compiled. So in the Head, the membrane growing every where light, the Brain arrives to its conitence, the Eyes are polihed out of a fluid intable moiture.

Nature doth feed and enlarge all the Parts, out of the elf ame Nutriment, whereof the firt did frame them, (not as many will have it, out of a divere one, and uch as is like to every particle) namely, by augmenting her ame gelly, or worm: and like a potter, firt he divides her materials, and he allots to the Trunk, the Head, and the Limbs, every one their hare or cantlin: as Painters do, who firt draw the Lineaments, and then lay on the Colours: and as a Ship Carpenter, firt layes the Keel for a foundation, and then ets up the Ribs, and Breat-bone, or Deck: and as he builds a boat, o
doth Nature the Trunk of the Body, and hap on the Joints. And in her work, he begins all the imilary part out of the ame Primitive gelly, or glutinous mas, (namely, the Bones, Gritles, Fleh, Nerves, &c.) For at firt there appears nothing of the Bones, but a kinde of filaments, or threddy fibres; which afterwards become nervous, anon Gritles, after that, like thorns, and at lat down right Bones. So likewie the thicker Membrane inveting the Brain, proceeds firt to be gritly, and afterwards into a Skull: while the thin Membrane doth improve into a Coat, or Pericranium, and Fleh. And in the ame Order the Fleh, and Nerves, out of a yeilding gelly, do concoct and trengthen, into Mucles, Tendons, and Ligaments: The braine, and after-braine, from a thin Water, coagulate into a Callous Curd; for the braine of Infants, before the bones of the Synciput are confirmed, appears oft and fluid, and hath no more coherence, then coagulated Milk.

The third Proces is of the Intrals; whoe generation is dicovered in the Chicken, after the delineation of the body; (namely about the ixth or eventh day) and neer upon the ame time, they all appear, that is, the Liver, Lungs, Kidnies, the Cone of the Heart and its ventricles, and alo the Guts. But their firt original is from the Veines, and are bred growing to them, (like Wens to the barke of Trees) and at firt they appear white, bloodles, and like a gelly; and o continue till they are ripe for publick imployment. The Guts with the Stomack eem at firt like white threads, waved or contorted, extended through the longitude of the belly: and together with them the Fabrick of the Mouth is dicovered; from which to the Fundament in a continued proceion, the top
is united and linked to the bottom: the Genitals alo are about this time viible.

Yet hitherto the Bowels and Guts are not hut up within the hollow of the body, but being fatned as it were to the Veines hang forth: and thus doth even the Heart himelf. For the trunk of the body hitherto reembles a Skiff without a deck, or a Houe without a roof; as being hitherto no way covered over by the anteriour parts; namely, the Breat, and Abdomen.

But o oon as the Sternum, or breat-bone is framed, the Heart enters into the breat, as into a habitation of his own etting up, and furnihed purpoely for him; and being now retired, like the Genius of the place, he undertakes the patronage of the whole Manion; and there dwells, with his ervants the Lungs. After this, the Heart and Stomack retreat too; & at lat the Guts hrowd themelves in the Belly. So that in a Hen-egge after the tenth day of Incubation, the Heart admits no pectators without diection.

About this time the top of the Bill, and the Claws break forth, being all exceeding white; and now a chylous matter is viible in the Stomack, and a kind of Excrement in the Guts; and the Liver being now begun hath the Gall, which appears green adjoined to it. By which it appears, that a different Concoction, and Preparation of the Aliment is now made, (whereof thee are the Excrements, from that which is performed by the Propagations of the Umbilical Veels: o that a jut doubt may hence arie, how Choler (the Excrement of the Second Concoction) can be eparated from the ret of the Humours by the Livers help, when it is it elf in being at the ame time with the Liver.

The Interiour parts are Univerally generated, after the Order propoed: for in all Animals (which I ever diffected) they are framed after the ame Manner, and Order: and epecially in the more perfect, in Four-footed Beats, and o in Man himelf; In whom the Heart, Liver, Lungs, Spleen, and Guts, appear framed, and augmented in the Second, Third, and Fourth Moneths, at which times they are white, as alo the whole Body. And hereupon the firt days are not improperly called in lacte dies, the Dayes in the Milk; for the Bowels, and all the other parts appeare permatical, except onely the Veines, and chiefly thoe of the Navel.

The Umbilical Arteries are, I conceive, framed after their Name-akes, the Veines; becaue they are carce to be found in the firt moneths, and take their Original from the Branches which decend to the Thighes: And therefore, I conceive, they are not contituted before that part of the body, (from whence they are derived.) But the Umbilical Veines are conpicuous long before any part of the Body is in hand.

What I have now delivered, hath been ratified out of many diections of humane Embryo's of (almot) all izes: for I have oberved them from the bignes of a Tad-pole, till they became of the longitude of even or eight fingers breadth, and o upwards to the Birth. And epecially in the econd, third, and fourth moneths; at which times the greatet Alterations befall them, and the progres of Generation is mot evident.

Therefore, in a humane Embryo of two moneths old, thoe very things which we have related in the econd Proces, do appear begun. For in the firt moneth I conceive there is litle or nothing of the
foetus extant in the womb; at leat I never found any thing. But that moneth expiring, I have frequently een a conception cat out (like to that which Hippocrates relates to have fallen from the Mintrell) of the bignes of a Pheaants, or Pigeons egge, and it was of an Oval figure, jut like an Egg with the Shell pilled off; but the thicker membrane (called Chorion) encompaing it, was plaitered on the out ide, as it were, with a mucous ubtance, (epecially in the obtuer end) but within it was lippery, being full of clear and tiff water, containing nothing ele at all.

In the econd moneth, I have often een uch a kinde of Egg (but larger) ejected upon indications of Abortment, namely the Lochia ichoroa; and it hath been ometimes entire, and ometimes broken, covered over with clotted blood. Within, it was mooth and lippery, the blood adhering without, and its form was like the other. In ome of thee ejectments I have found a foetus, in other, none. That foetus hath been of the length of the nail of the litle finger, but the hape was like a litle frog, ave onely that the head was great, and the leggs extremly hort: jut like the Tadpoles in June, which when their limbs begin to hoot out, they looe their tail, and put on the hape of Frogs. All its ubtance was white, and o oft and gellyih, that unles it were cat into clear water, you could not hold it in your hand. The face was like that of other Animals, as of a Dog, or Cat, without lips, and a wide mouth from one care to the other.

Divers Women, whoe Conception (like an addle Egge) is fruitles, and without a Foetus, do uffer abortion the third moneth. I have often diected an abortion of that age (being of the bignes of a Gooe-egg) wherein was a foetus, ditinct in all its
parts; though their form was rough, and unhapen, The Head, Eyes, and Limbs appeared, but the Mucles were confued: having no bones, but in their places, certain Lineaments, and ofter Gritles, as it were; the ubtance of the Heart was mot white, having two Ventricles of equal magnitude and thicknee, and a double Cone, like two mall Twin-kernels of a Nut; the Liver was wondrous litle, and alo white. All this time, namely, for three moneths pace Vix quicquam Placentae, ive hepatis Uterini, carce any thing of the After-burden is to be een.

In all thee kinde of Conceptions (as many as I have een) I till found the ambient membrane fraught with a vat quantity of watry ubtance: in which the floating Embryo is o exceeding mall, compared with the place where his abode is, and hath withall o long and winding a Navel; that thoe waters ought not upon any tearms to bee thought the weat, or Urine of the Embryo; but more probably, his nutriment, provided by nature (like the Colliquamentum in the Egge.) For I could finde no indication to induce me to believe, that that conception, or Egge had any connexion to the Womb: onely the outward uperficies of the obtuer end, looked omething more wrinckled and thick; like the firt intention of a future placenta.
Moreover thoe Conceptions appeared to mee, like certain egges, which were onely to be harboured within the Womb, but to be nourihed (like the Henne-egge) by their owne projection, or indutry.

Now in the fourth moneth, you would admire how much the Foetus is improved; for by this, it is encreaed from a Thumb-length to a Span: and
all his members appear ditinct, and have a tincture of Blood; the Mucles of the Limbs, and the Bones are now apparent; and alo the Rudiments of the Nailes; and the Embryo begins to betirre himelf oundly. Yet the Head is till very bigge; and the Face without Lips, Cheeks, or Noe: the cham of the Mouth is very large, whoe pace is half upplied by the Tongue; the Eyes mall, and without Lids; the middle part of the Fore-head, and all the upper-part of the Head is covered with a Membrane, which is not as yet cartilaginous, o far is it from being Boney: but the hinder part of the Head is omething hard, and Cartilaginous, implying that the Skull beginnes to grow olid.

The Genitals likewie did appear, but the Teticles were eated within the Abdomen (where in females the Uterus reideth) the Scrotum remaining empty. The Feminine parts were imperfect, and the Uterus with its litle Tubuli, did repreent formam bicornem, the two horned hape of the Uterus of a Lamb.

And now the Placenta was enlarged, and affixed to the Womb; comprehending almot halfe the Conception; appearing to my eye like a Tumor, or flehey excrecence of the Womb: its Gibbous part did tick o fat, even throughout its whole extent, to the Womb, which was now grown thicker. Into this Placenta the litle Umbilical branches (like lender rootes into the Earth) did ininuate themelves: and by its mediation the Conception was now firt tyed to the Womb.

The large and fluid Braine reembled Cheee-Curd, and was embroidered with larger Veines. The two Ventricles of the Heart, both of the ame magnitude, and their walls equally thick. In the
Region of the Breat within the Ribs, I aw three hollow places, and thoe not much unlike each other: the lowet of which, the Lungs having Blood in them, and of like complexion with the Liver and Kidnies, did inhabit: the middle was poeed by the Heart and Pericardium: but the upper was filled with that large Glandule which we call Thymus, the Sweet-Bread.

In the Stomack was Chyle, of like ubtance to that in which the Embryo wims: There was alo a coagulated ubtance which was white, like to thoe white curded pollutions which the Midwife waheth off from the Infant (epecially from the foulds of the Skin) o oon as it is borne. In the uperiour Intetines was Excrement, or ome part of the Chyle, in the inferiour a litle dark excrement. In the Bladder was Urine found: and Gall in the Veicle deigned for its reception. Intetinum Cacum, the blind Gut (jut as it is in grown perons) like an empty uperfluous appendix of the Colon; and nothing like what it is in other Animals, (as the Hogge, the Hore, and the Hare) in which it is like a Second Stomack. The Omentum, or Kell, did like a Caule, or thin tranparent cloud, lye floating upon the Guts.

The Reines at this time are not formed into a gibbous figure, as it is when men are grown, but are moulded of everal gobbets (as you ee in a Calfe, and in a Sturgeon) as if to every prig or divarication of the Ureters, there were a gobbet or Teat, out of which their Orifices did draine the Urine. Upon the Kidnies there are the two Glandules (which Eutachius firt found out) wherin tore of blood lies; and their Vein, which Anatomit call Adipoe, eems not much les then the Emulgent it elf. The Liver, and Spleen, are equally full of blood (according
to their everal proportions.)

And here we mut oberve by the way, that in every Humane Foetus that is lively and well, perfect Milk is found; wherewith chiefly the Glandule Thymus, or the Sweet-bread is tored. It is alo found in the Pancreas, and almot all along the Meentery, in certain Venae Lacteae as it were, and the Glandules placed between the divarications of the Meeraicke Veins. Nay ometimes it may be milked out at the breats of New-borne Infants, and ometimes alo it tarts out of it elf: which ome Midwives ay, doth make for the Infants Health.

And that it may plainly appear, that the water (which is o plenteous in the Conception) is no excrement dicharged by the Embryo, as either his Sweat, or Urine; it is lee (in proportion) neer the birth (when the foetus is now more grown, and upon that account doth accumulate more excrement, becaue he requires more nourihment) then in the firt moneths of pregnation. And moreover, at that time his bladder is full, and ditended with Urine. And to ay truth, that paage, (which Anatomits call the Urachus) which hould (as they phanie) convey the Urine from the bladder, through the Navel, could never yet be found out: but I have often een the bladder, preed or griped with the hand, dicharge the Urine out at the Yard, but never at the Urachus.
And let this uffice, concerning what we have oberved in a humane Foetus, o farre forth as it relates to the knowledge of the Order of the Parts.

In the Fourth and lat Proces, the parts of meaner rank and condition are formed: uch as do not imply relate to the very being, and preervation of the Animal, but onely ad tutelam, to
its afe-guard againt forreign injuries: or ad ornatum, vel pugnam, to its Ornament, or for Defence.

For that kind of Safe-guard or Defence, the utmot part (namely the Skin) is chiefly contituted, and all that proceeds out of it, as the Scarfeskin, the Haire, Wool, Plumes, Scales, Shells, Clans, Hoofs, and the like. And indeed it is a prudent contrivance of Nature (who never makes any thing indicreetly,) to beget thoe parts lat of all, whereof he hath no ue till after nativity. And therefore the Chicken is borne with down onely on him, and not Feathers (as other Birds are, who are preently fitted for flight) becaue by wandring to and fro, he earns his utenance with the indutry of his Legs, rather then his Wings: And o again young Ducklins, and Golins, who prey in the water, have their Plumes, and Wings later perfected then their Legs: which is clean contrary in young Swallows, which, becaue they are to fly about to glean up a living, are ooner vered in flight, then walking.

Now the Down tarts up in the Chicken after the Fourteenth day, when the Foetus is now compleat, and provided with all his parts. But in many of them, at their firt nativity, it lookes like dark pots or points; and after that the Feathers prout up like Grae in the Field, and at lat expatiate, and cloath the body round, protecting it from the inclemency of the Aire.

The Feathers differ from Quills, in form, ue, and place of Production. For Chickens are Feathered ere they have Quills: for Quills pring only in their Wings, and Rump; and tick deeper in the bottome of the fleh, or the very Periotium it elf, and are ueful to motion: but the Feathers
rie out of the uperficies of the Skinn, and erve for protection.

Nailes, Hair, Hornes, and the like, aith Aritotle,
De gen. an. l. 2. c. 4. are bred out of the Fleh, in o much that they change colour with the Fleh: for the white, and black, and divere coloured, are made o, according to the different complexion of the Skin. But in our Chicken, all this is clean otherwie, for what various colour oever the Feathers be of, the Skin beneath them is of one onely. And many times one and the ame Feather is diverly painted and dicoloured, for the pomp and beauty of the Fowle.

Likewie in the Humane Foetus, the Cutis and all the skinny parts are lat perfected. And therefore at the beginning, there are neither Lips, nor Cheeks, nor Ears, nor Eye-lids, nor Noe to be een: and that line wherby the upper-lip is united into one, doth cloe the lat of all.

The Humane production is alo borne naked and unarmed; as one whom Nature had intended for a ociable, political, and peaceable creature: and to be ruled more by reaon, then contrained by force. And therefore he hath furnihed him with Hands, and Undertanding, that having provided properties, he might cloath, and defend himelf. For thoe Animals whom Nature hath made trong, he hath alo armed with weapons agreeable to their trength: but where he hath denied trength, he hath betowed wit, and cunning, and an admirable dexterity to evade affronts.

The Ornaments, as the Tuft upon the Head, the Comb, the Gills and the like, wherewith the haughty Animals wagger, are for the mot part imparted to the male, more then the female: as alo all weapons too, as Teeth, Hornes, and Spurs, &c. which appoints them for the Battail. And they are then
compleatet in the male, about that time when the female is in her prime, and provoked to leave an Heir behind her. For they are yet to come in the younger Animals, and in the aged they wither, and decline (as uelee.)

Our Dunghil-Cock (that famous Champion) o oon as he is trong, and ripe for generation, is provided of his Spurs, Comb, and Plumes; by which he becomes amiable in the fight of his Concubines: and combats other Cocks not from any vaine Itch of Otentation, but to perpetuate his own Linage, that o he that is bet able to protect himelf and his Charge, may have the prerogative to propagate the Species. For all thoe Animals which are well appointed with armes, and more Martial creatures then the ret, do ground their quarrels, either upon the Recue of their Young, or their title to their habitations, or their husbandry for their proviions, but in chief, upon Rivalhip in their Loves (and that, for poterities ake) and being ubdued, as they lay by their pomp, and didainful demeanour, o they urrender their claim to their Wives; and with dejected pirits languih out their days; while the Victor flehed with the conquet, riots in the injoyment of the Captives Females.

Nor is this their bravery any acititious Wardrobe, or ome few daies Pageantry, or Maquingtuff, but a lating one, and Natures liberal Dowry, which delights not onely in the Embroidery of Animals (and chiefly of Birds) but hath imploied her Pencil upon Flowers, and Plants, adorning them with wonderful Art and variety of colours.

div.head: Certain Paradoxes, and Problemes to be conidered of, concerning this Subject.
EXEECIT. LVII.
div.p: THus far have we poken concerning the Order of Generation: by which the difference between thoe creatures which are produced by a Metamorphois, and thoe which are borne by an Epigeneis, hath been dicovered: as alo, between thoe that pring from a Worme, and thoe that arie from an Egge: for thee are bodied out of one part of the prepared matter, and fed with the other; But they take up the whole matter in their frame, or Contitution: thee are together augmented and formed; they are augmented firt, and from a Canker-Worme grow into an Aurelia, and are afterwards formed and made conummate Animals, as Butterflies, Silk-wormes, and uch like Animals.

And therefore Aritotle (as Fabricius oberves) as he contitutes a kind of twofold nature of the egge, and a kind of twofold Egge in thee creatures; o he laies down a twofold action, and a twofold Animal produced by it. For (aith he) out of the firt egges, which are the firt rudiments of the Generation, a Worm contantly doth proceed: namely, out of the Egges of Files, Ants, Bees, Silk-wormes, &c. in which a certain fluid matter is conteined, and out of all that fluid matter is the Worme made. But out of the econd Egges, which are layed by the Worm himelfe, the Butterflie is born, and proceeds; that is, a Volatile
Animal, which is concluded in a kind of Shell, Skin, little bag, or egge, and when that bag is broken it departs thence as Aritotle delivereth concerning the Locuts egges. Latly thee are perfected by a ucceion of parts; but they (namely, uch as are generated by a Metamorphois) are made intire at once. And in the ame manner, are both Spontaneous productions generated, which obtain their firt matter, and firt extraction from putrefaction, filth, dew, excrements, or out of the parts of Plants, or Animals; as alo thoe iues which proceed from the eed of Univocal Animals. For it is common to all Animals, to deume their Original from eed, or an egge: whether that eed proceed from other Animals of the ame pecies, or happen there caually from ome thing ele. For as it ometimes befalls in Art, o alo in Nature; namely, that the ame things are ometimes cauall, which at other times are effected by Art: as Aritotle doth intance in Health, o in like manner is the Generation of any Animals; (as far as they proceed from Seed) whether their eed be cauall, or ele proceed from an Univocal Agent of the ame kind. For even in cauall eed, there is a motive principle of Generation, which can generate out of it elf, and by it elf: and the ame thing is found in it, as in Univocal Animals; namely, a power to form a living creature. But of this more at large hereafter.

Now ome Paradoxes do here arie to be examined. For ince the Macula is dilated, the Colliquamentum concocted, and prepared, and many other things (not without great providence) ordered, towards the formation, and growth of the Chicken, before any particle of the Chicken appear; what hould hinder the Innate beat, and vegetative
oul of the Chicken to be exitent before the Chicken it elf? For what can produce the effects and operations of Life, but that which is the caue and efficient of thoe Effects and Operations; namely, the heat, and faculty of the Vegetal oul? And therefore the oul doth not eem to be Actus corporis Organici vitam habentis in potentiâ, the Act of an Organical body, which hath life in it in potentiâ: for we conceive the form of the Chicken to be uch an Act. Now in what can we imagine the form, or oul of the Chicken to be, but in the Chicken it elf? unles we allow the forms to be eparate, or grant a Metempychôis.

But this is mot manifet, where the ame Animal lives by a ucceion of forms; (as Aritotle peaks) as for example, Out of a Canker-worm, an Aurelia, and then a Butterfly. For the ame Efficient, Nutritive, and Preerving principle, mut needs be in each of thee: unles we will place one oul in the Boy, another in the Young man, and a third in the Old: or affirm, that the Canker-worm, and that worm which becomes a Silk-worm, alo the Silk-worm, and the Butterfly, have the ame form, of which matter Aritotle hath accurately written, and whereof more largely hereafter.
Again, it eems a Paradox, that the blood hould be made, and move, and be endowed with Vital pirits, before any anguifying, or Motive Organs are contituted at all.

Nor is it les new and unheard of, that there hould be Sene and Motion in the Foetus, before his brain is made; for the Foetus moves, contracts, and extends himelf, when there is nothing yet appears for a brain, but clear water.

Beides, the body is nourihed and encreaed, before the Organs dedicated to Concoction (namely
the Stomack and Liver) are formed. And likewie Sanguification (which is the econd Concoction) is performed before the firt, (which is by the Stomack) and called Chylification.

The Excrements of the firt and econd Concoction (namely in the Guts, and the two bladders, of Urine one, the other of Gall) are coetaneous to the concocting Intruments themelves. Latly, there is a Minde, Providence, and Undertanding, not onely in the Vegetal part of the oul, but even before the oul it elf; procuring, dipoing, and ordering all things, and artificially molding the future foetus to a reemblance with his parents, even from the very firt original; and all this, to advance the being, and well being of the Foetus.

Concerning which Reemblance, we may enquire, what hould be the caue why the Foetus ometimes reembles the Father, ometimes the Mother, and ometimes alo the Progenitors, and thoe either of the Father or Mothers ide? And this the rather, ince upon one ingle coition, and at the ame moment of time, many Egges are fructified together. This alo is a wonderful thing, that the Virtues, and Vices, the Dieaes, the Marks, the Moles or Spots hould be transferred to Poterity: and that into ome onely of the Progeny, and not unto all. In the race of Cocks, ome are of a generous pirit, and born to battle; who will dye rather then turn their backs upon their Adveraries: and yet their Nephews, unles they proceed of like parents, do by degrees forfeit their galantry; according to that aying, Fortes creantur fortibus. In many other Animals (and epecially in Man) the Bravery of the Succeion, or Family is obervable: and many of the Indowments both of body and oul are derived down to it ex traduce.

This I have often admired, that when the Iue hath obtained a mixt fabrick or compoition from both Parents, and that in all other parts of the body, yet it hath not been o in the Genitals; but that it commonly proves either Male, or Female, and very eldom an Hermaphrodite.
Latly, many things are in the foetus ere they appear at all; and ome things are begun with the firt, but perfected with the lat: as the Eyes, Genitals, and Bill.

And hence there arie debates concerning the pre-eminence, or dignity of the Parts; in which the Wits of uch as are curious in thee caes, may imploy themelves. As, Whether the Heart betow life and vigour upon the blood, or the blood rather upon the Heart? Whether the blood be made for the bodyes ake, as the Matter, Nutriment, and Intrument; or ele the body, and all its parts for the blood, and the oul which doth firt and principally reide in it? Likewie, Whether the Ventricles, or Auricles of the Heart are mot honourable? For we finde that the Auricles have life and pule firt, and do expire lat. And farther, Whether the left Ventricle of the Heart, which is deeper in a Man, and is fenced with a thicker and more carnous wall, and is conceived to be the fountain of the Spirts, be the more excellent, hotter, more fraught with Spirits, and livelyer of the two: or the Right, which doth lat languih and ubcribe to Death, containing a large quantity of blood: and where the Dying mans blood doth lat congeal, and is deprived of life and pirit? and whether alo the Umbilical Veels do tranport the blood (as to their fountain) and whence alo they derive their extraction?

Now thee things do reult out of the Obervation
of the Order of the Generation of the Parts, as alo other things which may be hence deduced, and do not a litle clah againt the Phyiology commonly approved. Namely, (when we plainly ee that there is both Sene & Motion, before the brain is begotten) it is evident that all Sene and Motion is not derived from the brain: for it appeares by our Hitory, that Sene and Motion do clearly dicover themelves in the firt mall drop of blood in the Egge, before any particle of the body is framed. And likewie, the firt platform or contitution (which we call gelly) is laid before any part is dicerned; and when the brain is now nothing but a clear water: which firt rudiment of the Body, if it be lightly pricked, will, like a Worm or Magot, obcurely move, and contract it elf: which is a plain tetimony of its ene.
There are alo other Arguments deduced from Sene and Motion, by which we may conclude (with Aritotle) That the Heart, and not (with Phyitians) that the Brain is the firt Principle.

Thoe Motions and Actions, which Phyitians call Natural, becaue they proceed whether we will or no; and we cannot moderate, accelerate, retard, or refrain them at our own pleaure: & which therefore are Independent in regard of the brain; yet even they are not performed without all ene, but do imply ene, as by which they are excited, provoked, and altered. For we conceive, that in the Heart it elf, its Palpitation, Trembling, Fainting, Sowning, and all the changes in the pule, either in magnitude, celerity, order, rhythme, or the like, do proceed from morbifical caues indipoing it, and offenive to its ene. For whatoever by diverity of motions makes warre againt thoe things that enrage and molet it, mut needs be indowed with ene.

The Stomack and Guts provoked by injurious humours, do raie a Naueating, Belching, Rumbling, Vomiting, and Flux; and as it is beyond our power, either to raie or lay thee combutions, o are we to eek for any uch ene retaining to the brain, which hould excite thoe parts to uch Expreions.

It is very trange, that upon the Infuion of Antimony taken in a Vomit, though we neither ditinguih it by tate, nor finde any digut in it, either wallowing it down, or in returning it back again; yet there paeth a cenure upon it by the Stomack, which dicerns between what is uefull and prejudicial, and o provokes to Vomit.

Nay, the Fleh it elf doth eaily ditinguih a poionous wound from one that is not poionous; and thereupon contracts it elf, and condeneth; upon which enflamed tumours arie: as we may ee in the tingings of the Bee, the Gnat, and the Spider.

I my elfe once, for experiment ake, pricked my hand with a needle; and preently rubbing the ame needle upon a Spiders tooth, I pricked my hand in another place, o that I my elf could not ditinguih between the two pricks. But there was omething in my Skin that did ditinguih; for in that place where the poioned prick fell, it preently contracted it elf into a pimple, and preently grew red, hot, and inflamed; as if it fortified it elf, and tood upon its guard, to oppoe, and ubdue the malice of the Venom.

The Offences undergone by the Matrix, as its Contorion, Decenion, Falling down, Riing, Suffocation, and other Maladies and Provocations, do no whit depend upon the Brain, or Common ene; nor yet can they be conceived to befall it inenibly. For that which is plainly void of Sene, cannot
eem any way to be porovked, or heightened into any motion, or action. Nor have we any other igns to ditinguih an animate and enitive creature, from a dead and eneles one, then by its motion provoked from ome offenive object, which doth alwaies follow, and argue Sene.

But of this more at large, when we treat of the Actions and Ue of the Brain. But the Reverence due to the Antients, and Antiquity her elf, doth advie us to uphold their doctrines, o farre as they are true. Nor can it beeem us rahly to reject, and dicountenance their Labours, and Decrees, whoe light hath been our direction to the Shrines of Philoophy; wherefore I conceive we ought to think thus. We perceive we have Five Senes, by which we give judgement upon outward things; but becaue it is not the ame ene, by which we perceive, and by which we perceive our own perception; (for we ee with our Eyes, but we do not by them know we ee) but by another ene, which employes another enitive Organ (namely, the Internal Common ene) by which we give judgement upon all thoe things which we perceive by our external Organs, and o ditinguih white from weet, and hard: This common Senorium, or Organ of Sene (whither all Species are conveyed from the outward Organs) is plainly the Head; which, together with all his Nerves, and outward Organs adjoined to them, is undertood to be the adequate Organ of Senation. And it is like the Senitive Root, from which everal Fibers reult; whereof one ees, another hears, a third toucheth, and the other mell, and tate.

Yet as there are certain Actions and Motions, whoe Regiment or Juridiction relates not to the Brain, and they therefore are called Natural:
o alo mut we conclude, that there is a certain ene of Touching, which is not conveyed to the Common ene, or any way communicated to the brain; and therefore in that kinde of ene, we do not perceive our enation: but jut like men whoe undertanding is perverted, or ele are ditracted by ome violent Paion, inomuch that they are inenible of all pain, and takes no notice of any thing that meets their enes: So we mut conceive it to be in this ene, which we therefore ditinguih from Animal ene. Having oberved uch a kinde of ene in the Zoophyta, or Plant-Animals (as the Senitive Plant, Sponges, and the like.)

Wherefore, as many Animals have both Sene and Motion, without the Common ene, or a brain; as the Worms in the Guts, alo thoe Worms which turn into Silk-worms, and the like, o alo do ome actions befall the Embryo, and us alo without any aitance from the brain, and a kinde of enation doth proceed, without ene. And as Phyitians teach, that Natural Actions differ from Animal; o upon like reaon, the Natural Touch eems to differ from the Animal ene of Touching, and contitute a ditinct pecies of Feeling: o that the one is communicated to the Common ene, or brain, and the other not.

Moreover, it is one thing for a Mucle to be moved or contracted, and another thing for it to perform an Action, at ditinct regulated contractions and relaxations; as to go forward, or receive any thing in the hands. Doubtles, the Mucles, or Motory Organs, in the Cynical ditortion, or Convulion proceeding from ome caue that diturbs them, are no otherwie moved, then a Cock or Hen, which when the Head is quite chopped off, is diturbed with many convulive motions of the Leggs and Wings: but
uch as are altogether confued, and diordered, becaue the way of the brain is dethroned, and the common ene depoed, under whoe Government formerly, thoe motions were regulated by rhythm and harmony, either to walking, or flight.

We conceive therefore, that it ought to be aid, That all Natural Motions proceed from the power of the Heart, and are as his Retinue: but the Spontaneous, and uch as perfect any Action, (which Phyitians call animal) are not produced but by the brain and common ene controuling them. For as by this common ene, we perceive our own Senation, o alo we perceive our own motion; and that whether it be regular, or pervere.

We have a clear Intance of both thee motions in Repiration; for the Lungs (as the Heart) are continually moved up and down by a natural motion, and alo provoked to cough, and frequent Agitation; but produce or hape a voice, or ing they cannot, without help, and commiion from common ene.

But thee things are to be more fully handled, when we hall fix our contemplation upon the Action and Ue of the Brain, and the Conideration of the Soul. But thus much hath been delivered by the way, that we may delare our deire and inclination to pay our Maters the repect we owe them.

div.head: Of the Nutrition of the Chicken in the Egge.
EXERCIT. LVIII.
div.p:
HOw much the Authority of the Ancients is not rahly to be rejected, appears even in this: It was of old an opinion much prized (which yet many at this day diclame as erroneous; and Fabricius decryes it as a meer deluion, and fond perwaion) that the Embryo did uck, in its mothers
De form. foet. p. 19. or 134. l. de carn. & de nat. puer.
Womb: and it had Democritus, Epicurus, and Hippocrates himelf for its Abbettors. And Hippocrates doth etablih his opinion chiefly upon two arguments; For, aith he, unles it had ucked, how could it depoit any excrements: or know how to uck o oon as it is born.

Now in other caes they ue to ubcribe to every word pronounced by this o famous, and ancient Oracle, and his < in non-Latin alphabet > was warrant enough: but here (becaue he delivers things dionant to what is commonly received, Fabricius doth not only renounce his bare aertion, but tands out in defiance againt his proofes. Therefore I appeal to the judgement of the mot skilful Anatomits, and mot learned Phyitians, whether our Obervations concerning the Generation of Animals, do not onely cat a probability, but inforce the neceity of this opinion of Hippocrates.

All in general acknowledge, that the Foetus while he abides in the Womb doth wallow in abundance of Water, (which Liquor, we, in the Hitory of the Egge, tile the Colliquamentum, and the
Moderns ay that Water is the Sweat and Urine of the Foetus; affording this advantage, that the Foetus floating in it (while the Mother runs, leaps, or ues any other violent motion) doth not eaily offend the Womb, nor is himelf wronged by alliion againt the bones eated there round about him, or ome outward blowes; and the rather, for that at this time, his body is but tender, and infirme.

Fabricius adjoines other benefits ariing from pag. 137. thee Waters; namely, Their moitning and lubrifying all the paages round about, and rendering the neck of the Matrix capable of the larget dilatation; and all thee commodities, aith he, do no les arie from that thick white Excrement, anwerable to that of the third concoction, which is Unciuous, Oily, and Fat, and neglected by the Ancients. Which it alo performeth, leat the Sweat which may ometimes tranpire, harp, and altih, hould erode the tender Infants body.

I willingly acknowledge the everal benefits aigned to this water, by all Writers; namely, that the tender Foetus in order to his indemnity from any uddain, and violent motions of his Mother, is thus ecurely netled in alis vepertilionum, in the Bats Wings, as they call them, and moated round with tore of water, o that he cannot eaily, by every (though violent) motion dah himelfe againt his Mothers ides; (becaue of thoe tyes which faten him on every ide) at leat this circumambient liquor being equally poied in the midt doth protect him from all outward harme. But my own Obervations, as they do in many other matters, o alo in this enforce me to be of a contrary opinion to Fabricius: for I am mot certain, that the aid liquor, is not the Sweat of
the Foetus. Nor can I believe, that that water doth perform thoe offices in the birth, which he commemorates: and much lee, that it is o harp and Briney, that the foetus mut tand in need of an oily unctuous fence to ecure him from it, epecially that foetus, which is either cloathed with Wool, Hair, or Feathers. For this liquor is of a good avour, and like a kind of watry Milk; and therefore, almot all Viviparous Animals, o oon as they have brought their Young into the world, fall abord and eat it up, and lick their new born iues clean, greedily wallowing the humour which they receive in, when they will not o much as touch the excrements of their foetus.

Fabricius conceived this water to be harp, and alt, becaue he thought it to be the weat. But what injury, I pray, can the weat do to the foetus now cloathed in feathers? if at leat he ever aw uch a creature as a weating Chicken.

And I uppoe he will not ay, that the ue of that water in an egge, is by its moiture and lubricity to expedite the Chickens birth. For the dryer and older the hell is, by o much the frailer, and britler it becomes. Latly, were it the Chickens weat, it would mot abound neer the Excluion; for the larger the Chicken is, and the more Aliment he takes in, o much the more weat mut he necearily create. But a litle before his Excluion (about the ninteenth or twentieth day) there is none of this kind of humour dicernable; whereby, he hould have rather reputed it an Aliment, then an Excrement: (had he rightly conidered the matter) epecially, eeing he allows the Chicken in the Egge, the ue of Repiration, Voice, and Crying, which, were he begirt with water, could not have been.

Nor are thee Waters of any great ue, to the Expedition, or Lubricity of the Delivery (as experienced Midwives know full well) though Fabricius would have it otherwie. For the neighbour Parts are about that time, (without any profuion of thoe Waters, mellow and relaxed by a certain maturity of their owne: epecially, thoe which may be an obtruction to the work: namely, the Oa pubis, & Coccygis; about which the chiefet care of the Midwife is exercied in furthering the delivery: for he is les olicitous, to anoint the flehey parts, leat they rend in under, then in putting back the Coccyx; which if he cannot effect with her own hand, he calls in the Man-Midwife to procure her purpoe by the Speculum matricis; which intrument by its triple ides, whereof one is applyed to the Coccyx, the other two to the Oa pubis, doth ditend thoe parts by force.

For the Infant now jut at his Birth, while hee turnes himelf, and precipitates his Head downward, doth relax and open the orifice of the Womb: but if in his decent he light upon the top of the Bone, there he ticks; and hardly gets forth, and that not without danger, to himelf, and his Mother too. Now it is evidently natures intent, to mollifie and relax thoe parts. For, if the Midwife do dicover the Orifice of the Matrix become oft and looe, he laies it down for an infallible ign of the approaching delivery, though the Waters are not yet broken. Nay (I peak what I know by Experience) in cae any thing remaine after the delivery, which ought to be dicharged, or if at any other time there be any thing in the Womb, which it indeavours to be rid of, the Orifice doth not onely decend, but is alo oft and
relaxed: but if after the delivery, that Orifice be retired into its place, and be perceived to be grown omething hard, it is an evident ign that all is wel.

And by the like Experience, I pronounce, the Ossa pubis to be often looened one from another in delivery, their cartilaginous connexion being mollified, and all the Region of the Lower Belly miraculouly dilated; and this not by the profuion of the Watry ubtance, but of their own accord, as ripe fruits ue to revolt or open, to make room for the Excluion of their eeds. But how much the Coccyx may retard the delivery, is clear in fourfooted beats, that have Tailes; for they can neither bring forth young, nor diload the excrements of the Guts, unles they remove their Taile; which if you depres with your hand, you hinder the paage of the Excrement.

Moreover, that is accounted the mot Natural Delivery, when the Foetus and Secundines with the Watry ubtance (that is, the Entire Egge) get forth together. For if the Secundines be entire, and the waters not broken, the circumjacent parts are more ditended, & dilated by the Throwes, namely, by the ditention of the Membranes, whereupon, the foetus works his releae with les truggling; though the Mothers paines be the greater. In which condition, we know how the Woman in Labour is much relieved from the intollerable torment caued by ditention, upon the breaking of the Membranes, (whether it be done by Midwives nailes, or by a pair of Sciors) the Waters by that means being et a float.

And the skilful Midwives know very well, that in cae all the Waters be come away, before the natural opening of the Womb, the Woman with Child, continueth the longer in Labour, and her Travail
is the harder; which would yet be contrary, in cae thoe precedent Waters (as Fabricius would have it) did o much conduce to the mollifying, and Lubricity of the parts.

Beides that this humour, which we call the Colliquamentum, is not the weat of the foetus, is evident, both in the Egge and other Animals; for it is in being, before any part of the foetus is contituted, or any rudiment of him extant. Nay o oon as he is dicernable, and is yet but gelly, and very mall, o great a quantity of Water is to be een, that it is utterly impoible, o inconiderable a bulk hould afford uch plenty of Excrement.

Adde to this, that the fibres of the Umbilical veels are cattered and terminated in the membrane conteining this Water, as in the Yolk and White of the Egge: to give evidence clearly (if you conider the thing, as it truely is) that this humour, is rather to be conceived the Aliment, then the Excrement.

Wherefore Hippocrates his opinion eems to me more probable then that of Fabricius, and other Anatomits, who count this Liquor the Sweat, and Prejudice of the foetus. For I believe that this Colliquamentum, or Water wherein the foetus wims, doth erve for his utenance; and that the thinner & purer part of it, being imbibed by the Umbilical Veels, do contitute and upply the primogenit parts: and the ret, like Milk, being by uction conveyed into the Stomack and there concocted or chylified, and afterwards attracted by the Orifices of the Meeraick Veins, doth nourih and enlarge the tender Embryo. And to fortifie my perwaion, I hall lay down ome arguments, that prevaile with me.

So oon as the foetus attains any perfection, he preently tirres his Limbs, and proceeds to make tryal of thoe actions, to which his Intruments of motion are deigned. Now we ee the Chicken in the Egge, open his mouth amidt this Water; whereby he mut needs wallow it down. For it is mot certain, that whatoever is gone beyond the roote of the Tongue, and is arrived at the top of the Gullet, no creature can return (but by Vomition) whereupon the Farriers, which adminiter medicinal Potions, Boles, or Pills, to Cattel, taking them by the tongue cat it in beyond the protuberance of the Tongue, jut at the Root, that o they cannot avoid the wallowing. And if any of us, convey a Pill o far as the root of the tongue, he hall find himelf neceitated to wallow it down, unles a Vomit meet, and repel it. Wherefore ince the Embryo wallowing in the fore-aid liquor, doth open his mouth; it follows likewie that it mut enter in; and ince he moves his other mucles, why hould we doubt, but that he imployes the Intrument of his throat likewie, and o imbibes the humour.

Moreover it is certain, that in the Craw of the Chicken (and the like is alo found in the Stomack of all Embryo's) there is een a ubtance mot like in colour, tat, and conitence to the aid liquor; which being a while digeted in the Stomack, reembles coagulated Milk; and we have alo found it like to Chyle, in the upper Gut, the lower Guts being then tuft with Excrements.

So alo in the foetus of Viviparous creatures, the thicker Guts are full of uch an Excrement as that, wherewith they do abound all the while they are ed with Milk. Alo in Sheep and other beats which divide the Hoof, the dried dung is manifetly to be een.

About the eventeenth day, I have evidently found excrement in a Chicken, neer the fundament; and have alo een it, when it hath been dicharged into the Secundines, a litle before the excluion. And Volcherus Coiter, a diligent and skilful Anatomit, records the ame obervation. Why then hould we cruple to ay, that the foetus in the Womb doth uck; and that a Chyle is made there; when we have both the apparent principle, and rejectments of it.

Beides, at that time when we ee both the bladders, one full of Gall, and the other of Urine (both which are excrements of the econd concoction) why may we not conclude that Chylifaction, which is the firt concoction, went before it.

The Embryo therfore ucks, and receives nutriment in at the Mouth. And this you hall oon dicry, if o oon as ever he is borne, you put your finger into his mouth. Which according to Hippocrates, would not be, had he not ucked before in the Womb. For we ee young Children make eays, and attempt upon all performances: namely, moving their Limbs, crawling along, and indeavouring to peak: all which they attain at lat with dexterity, by long practice, and education. But o oon as ever they are born, nay before they are born, they will uck. For we have found by experience, that while they yet tick fat in the Birth, before they can either cry or breath, they will eize upon the finger extended to them, and uck it.

Nay, A New-born Child is more exact at ucking, then a grown body, or himelf either if he dicontinue it but a few days. For the Infant doth not compres the Nipple, and uck at the rate that we do by gulping down: but as if he would devour
the Nipple, he till draws it into his mouth, and by the aid of his tongue, and palate, he ucks the milk, as if he chewed it; with farre more earnetnes, and light, then a grown body. Wherefore he eems to be good at it of old, and to have practied it in the womb; for we ee how oon he unlearns it by dicontinuance.

By thee and other Obervations it is probable, that the Chicken is fed two waies in the Egge, namely, both by the Umbilical, and the Meeraick Veiues: by the former, he attracts well digeted aliment, whereby the Blood, and primogenit parts are contituted, and encreaed; by the other, Chyle, which conduces to the fabrick, and augmentation of the other parts.

Now, perhaps the reaon may eem obcure, wherefore the ame Agent hould out of the ame Matter proceed to a divere manner of Nutrition: (when Nature doth nothing in vain) yet we will endeavour to dicover the reaon.

That Part which is attracted by the Umbilical Veines, is the purer and incerer part: But the remaining Colliquamentum wherein the Foetus floats, is a kind of crude milk, without cream, deprived of its purer part. The more pure part therefore tands in no need of farther concoction, as the other doth, which therefore is received into the Stomack, and there chylified. The thin, and crude milk, uch as is found in the breat preently after delivery, is like this. For the diolved White of an Egg, and the crude and watry milk in the breat or udder, are of the elf ame colour, tate, and conitence. Alo the firt milk given, is erous, and watry; and Women in Childe-bed do milk a kinde of water out of their breats, before the milk is concocted, and perfectly white.

And therefore the Colliquamentum found in the Chickens crop is a kinde of crude Milk; and the very ame afterwards found in the Giard, is concocted, white, and coagulated. So likewie in Viviparous Animals, before their milk is digeted in their breat, it looks like a kinde of Dew, or Colliquamentum; and o on the contrary, the Colliquamentum, after it is concocted in the Stomack, puts on the likenes of Milk. Whence it comes to pas, according to Aritotles opinion, that the firt and mot principal parts are fahioned out of the finer and purer materials: but of the courer, (by a new concoction in the Stomack) refined, the meaner and inferiour ort of parts are made: o that Nature like a kinde, indulgent mother, would rather abound with Supernumeraries, then be canted in Necearies. Or rather, we mut affirm it cononant to reaon, that the foetus now grown more perfect in himelf, hould alo be utained after a more perfect manner (viz. by the Mouth) and attract his aliment more refined, and rendered more devoid of dreggs, by the two precedent Concoctions; (As being thereby cleaned from two everal orts of Excrements.) At firt, indeed, being utained by the Umbilical Veels, he lives like a Plant upplyed by its root; and hereupon his body looks indigeted, white, and imperfect; and like a Plant, he remaines fixt, and immoveable. But o oon as he enjoyes the ame aliment more elaborate, as now inpired with a diviner pirit, and triumphing in a higher pitch of Vegetation, the former Gelly is transformed into fleh, the Organs of motion are ditinct, the pirits are enricht, and he himelf begins to move: and now no longer is cherihed like a Plant by his roots, but lives the life of an Animal, and is nourihed at the Mouth.

div.head: Of the Ues of the whole Egge.
EXER: LIX.
div.p: HAving declared thoe mutations, and everal proceedings, which are required in a Hen-egg, in order to the production of the Chicken; Fabricius proceeds to dicoure of the ues of the whole Egge, and of its Parts: and this not onely in a Hen-egge, but in all other kindes of Eggs. Where he alo demands, Why ome Eggs are heterogeneous, and compounded of divere parts; and others are homogeneous, and imilar? uch as the Eggs of Inects are, and of thoe creatures, which are contituted out of the whole Egge, (by a Metamorphois) and not generated out of one part of the egge, and nourihed by the other, as the Chicken is.

But my buines is not to treat of all Eggs in general (as not having in this Tract delivered their hitory) but onely of Hen-eggs, and the benefits or advantages ariing from their parts: all which ought to tend to that, to which the Action of the whole is directed; which Fabricius truly oberveth, pag. 50. to be nothing ele but the Generation and Augmentation of the Chicken.

And amongt thoe things which relate to the Whole Egge, Fabricius doth recount the Figure, Quantity, and Number of the Egges. The Figure of the Egge, aith he, is round, that the whole bulk of the Chicken might be contained in the leer pace; for
l. 10. de u. Part.
which caue God made the Univere Round, to comprehend all things: and for the ame caue, this Figure, aith Galen, appeared alwayes mot lovely, and convenient to Nature. Beides, in that it hath no angle
expoed to outward injuries; it is therefore eteemed the afet figure, and mot convenient for the Excluion of the Chicken. Now Fabricius upon this ground, ought to have aigned the reaon, why Hen-egges are not pherical (as the fry, or eggs of fihes, worms, and froggs are) but acuminated and oblong. What impediment is there which hinders them from this perfect figure? Therefore, in my judgement, the figure of the egge hath no influence at all upon the Generation of the Chicken, but is meerly accidental; which I the rather conceive, becaue there are o many everal varieties of figures, even in the Hen-eggs only. For the figure differs according to the diverity of the Uterus, in which (as in a Mould) it receives its form.

Aritotle, indeed, aith, That oblong eggs produce
Hit. an. l. 6. c. 2. Hens, but the rounder, Cocks: But I have never yet oberved any uch thing. And Pliny affirmes the clean contrary: The rounder ort of eggs, aith he, l. 10. c. 52. exclude Hens, and the ret, Cocks. And, to ay truth, if there were any certainty to be collected hence, ome Hens would ever generate Cocks, and other, Hens: for ome do lay eggs which are alwayes of one and the ame figure, that is, ever oblong, or ever round. And the oblong would rather exclude Plin. ibid. Cocks, becaue they are the more perfect, and better concocted; and therefore Horace eteemed them to be more pleaant then the round.
The Reaons alledged by Fabricius for the figures of the Eggs, we willingly pas by, becaue they are invalid.

As for the Magnitude of the Egge, that indeed doth eem to conduce to the largenes of the fatus, which is thence to be generated; for your great Hens lay fairer eggs. And yet the Crocodile layes egges no bigger then Gooe-eggs: no living creature
Id. l. 8. c. 25
preading into o large a bulk from o mall an Original. It is alo probable, that the largenes of the Egge, and the plenty of the liquours contained in it, do conduce omething to the fecundity of the Egge: for the very mall eggs (called Centenina) are all of them addle.

The Number of Eggs affords the ame benefit, as plenty of Conceptions do in Viviparous creatures; that is, they are ueful to the continuation of the pecies. For Nature doth commonly betow a plenteous iue upon thoe Animals which are weak, and lyable to the inolences of other Creatures: recompening the hortnes of their lives, with the number of their ofspring. Nature, aith Pliny, hath bequeathed this legacy to the Race of Birds, that the
l. 10. c. 52. more fearfull amongt them, hould be more fruitfull, then the more valiant. For ince all Generation is deigned by Nature for Perpetuity ake, it befalls thoe Animals more frequently, which are horter lived, and obnoxious to outward injuries, that o their pecies may not decay. Hereupon, Birds of Prey, which excell in trength, and thence maintain their lives the longer, and remain in more ecurity, do eldom lay above two eggs. Indeed, the Pigeon, Turtle, and Ring-dove, hatch but two egges at once; but the frequency makes atisfaction for the paucity, for they hatch ten times a year. So that they Generate Much, though not Many.

div.head: Of the Benefits or Ues of the Yolk and White.
EXERCITATION LX.
div.p: AN Egge, aith Fabricius, properly o called, is pag. 47. compounded of everal parts, becaue it is the Organ or Intrument of the Generant; and Galen affirms, That every Organ conits of everal parts. Which gives an occaion of doubt, whether every egge be not Heterogeneous, eeing every egge is an Organ. And indeed, every egge eems to be contituted out of everal parts, even the very eggs of Inects, and Fihes: for they all conit of Membranes, Coverings, and Muniments: and the Matter alo contained in them, is not altogether detitute of a diimilar contitution.

Fabricius doth alo farther conclude truly, with Galen, That ome parts of the Egge are the chief Intruments of Action; others, uch Intruments as the Action cannot be performed without them; others, as conducing to the better performance of the Action; and latly, others, as uefull to the afety and preervation of all the ret. But he is deceived, where he aith; If we peak of the chiefe Action of all, which is the Generation of the Chicken, the chief caue thereof is the Seed, and the Chalaza; for thee two are the prime caue of the generation of the chicken: the Seed being the Efficient caue, and the Chalaza the material onely. For, as Aritotle affirms, he mut of neceity acknowledge, that the Generant mut be within the Egg. But he denies the Cocks eed to be within the Egge.

Nor is he les mitaken concerning the Material
caue, out of which the Chicken is made by the artifice of the eed. For it is neither made of both the Chalazae, nor yet of any one of them, as hath been dicovered in our Hitory. Nor is the Generation of the Chicken accomplihed by a Metamorphois, or delineation and diviion of the Chalazae, but by in Epigeneis, as we have explained. Nor is the Chalaza principally fructified by the eed, but the Cicatricula rather, or the Eggs-eye, as we call it: out of which being enlarged, the colliquamentum doth reult: and afterward in the colliquamentum, and out of it, the Blood, Veines, Veiculae pulantes, and the whole Body is at lat contituted. And upon his own confeion, the eed of the Cock doth not o much as pas into the womb of the Hen at all: and yet notwithtanding it doth fructifie, not only the Eggs already formed, but thoe alo that hall be formed hereafter.

To the Eggs econd Action (which is the Nutrition, and Augmentation of the Chicken) Fabricius calls in the White and Yolk. The Quantity of the yolk and white, aith he, is proportioned to the better performance of the former action, as alo to the abolution and jut encreae of the chicken. The Egg-hell, and Membranes, are contituted for the afeguard of the whole, and alo of the action of the Egg. But the veins, and arteries, which do convey the aliment, are uch as without them the encreae and nutrition could not proceed.

But yet he leaves us in upene, not knowing whether he mean the Umbilical Veels of the foetus it elf, or the veines and arteries of the mother, as thoe intruments by which the egg is augmented. And yet upon as good ground, both the Uterus, and the Incubation it elf, may be reduced into this clais.

Come we then to the Liquors of the Egge, namely the Yolk and White, for thee are, rather then the other parts, intituted for the ake of the foetus, and alo in them the econd action of the Egge is mot remarkable.

Hen-eggs are of two colours, and contituted of two liquors, which are fenced by ditinct membranes, and kept apart the one from the other: and likewie, ince they are ditinguihed by a twofold propagation of Umbilical Veels (whereof the one paeth to the Yolk, the other to the White) they themelves are in all probability of a different nature, and therefore of a divere ue and advantage. The Yolk and White of Eggs, aith Aritotle, do obtain a contrary nature; not onely in regard
Hit. an. l. 6. c. 2. of Heat, but Power: for the Yolk is condened by cold, but the White is not onely not condened thereby, but liquified the more. So on the contrary, the White is condened by fire, but the Yolk is not condened by it, but continues oft, unles it be very much burned: And is more condened, and dryed by being odden, then roted. The Yolk being now warmed by Incubation, becomes more moit; for it reembles melted wax, or diolved fat: whereupon alo it fills a larger room then before. For by degrees, as the foetus is enlarged, the White is conumed and thickened: but the Yolk on the contrary, when the foetus is now compleat, eems to have lot litle or nothing of its dimenions, but eems only to be more liquid and moit, even when the belly of the foetus begins now to be covered over with the Abdomen.

And Aritotle gives the reaon of this differences De gen. an. l. 3. 5, 2. Becaue a Bird cannot compleat her of spring within <> own bowels, he produceth the Aliment alo together i • the Egg. For in Viviparous creatures the nourihment of the foetus, which is called milk, is provided in a ditinct
part of the body; namely, in the Breats. But Nature hath implanted this aliment in the Eggs of Birds: but yet contrary to the Opinion of mot men, and the Aertion of Alcmaeon Crotoniates; for the White is not the Milk of the Egge, but the Yolk. For as the foetus of Viviparous Animals, adhering hitherto to their parent (as the Plant doth to the ground) attract their firt aliment from her womb: but after their birth, being then eated without the Uterus, they uck milk from the breat, and o encreae: o the Chicken findes omething proportionable to both thee aliments in the Egge it elf: for as the Uterus of Viviparous Animals is within the parents themelves; o on the contrary, in Oviparous, the parents themelves may be aid to be within their Uterus. For an egg it as it were an expoed womb; wherein there is a ubtance concluded, as the Repreentative, and Subtitute or Vicar of the Breats. For the Chicken in the egg is firt nourihed by the White, which being exhauted, it is afterwards utained by the Yolk, as by Milk. And therefore the Navel or Umbilical propagation, which is derived into the White, when the white is pent, doth fade, and break off before the Chicken is hatcht, leaving no track or relique remaining, but quite vaniheth, before the Lower belly is hut up in the Abdomen (when yet in the race of Viviparous Animals the Navel-tring continues till:) But as for that other propagation of the Umbilical Veels, which is dieminated into the yolk (when the abdomen is now drawn over the guts) it is, together with the yolk it elf, laid up in the belly, & thence attracts nutriment for the tender foetus; till the bill, being now confirmed, & hardned, is able to pick up, and break its meat into pieces, & the Stomack, or Giard, be fortified to diget it: As
the production of Viviparous Animals is utained with milk from the Dug, till it be provided of teeth, by which it may chew and grind its food. For the Yolk is intead of Milk to the Chicken: and therefore a Hen-egge (being to upply the office both of the Womb and Breat or Udder) is furnihed with a party coloured juice, namely the Yolk and White.
