And as for thee two ditinct Liquors all men living do admit them; But I, as I lately told you, have dicovered even two ditinct Whites in an egg, divided by two ditinct Membranes, the uperior White comprehending another within it; jut as the Yolk is comprehended by the White. And thee two Whites are of a different nature: being reerved in a ditinct place, and conteined or concluded in a ditinct Membrane, and therefore deigned to a ditinct ue and intent. And yet both are deigned to Nutrition: but the exteriour is firt devoured, as having the propagations of the Umbilical Veels (which are derived to the Whites) firt dieminated into it, before they pas into the other White which is thicker then it: jut as thoe very propagations do firt aault both the Whites, ere they et upon the Yolk which is incompaed by them, and which is reerved for the lat nourihment of the foetus.

But of this more hereafter, when we come to explain the manner, how the foetus of Viviparous Animals is formed, & augmented in the Womb, and alo to demontrate, that every foetus what ever doth derive its original from an Egge; and is uteined by a twofold Albugineous Aliment in the Uterus. For one of thee is thinner, and conteined within the Egge (or Conception) it elf: the other is attracted and drawn by the Umbilical Veels from the Cotyledones, or Orifices of the Veels dieminated
into the After-birth, and the Womb. That ubtance is conteined in the Conception it elf, doth reemble the thinner White, both in colour, and conitence, for it is glewy, liquid, and pellucid, and very like that ubtance, which we call the Colliquamentum in the Egg, and in this the foetus wims, & is fed by it at the mouth. But that which the foetus attracts by the aid of his Umbilical Veels from the Placenta or After-burden, is more thick and mucous, and very like to the thicker White of the egge. By which it plainly appears, that the foetus is no more uteined in the Womb by his mothers blood, then the ucking Child is afterwards nourihed by it, or the Chicken in the egge: but is fed by an Albugineous Matter, which is concocted in the Placenta or Cake of the Womb; and doth reemble the White of an Egge.

Nor is the contemplation of that divine providence lee profitable, then wonderful; by which nature both in the Generation and Growth of the foetus (as taking into her conideration their age, and abilities) provides a convenient aliment for each of them, accommodating meats of more eaie to ome, and of more difficult digetion to others. For as the foetus attains a greater trength and ability to diget; o is a groer and tougher aliment provided for him. And this may be oberved even in the divere kind of Milk in Animals: for when the Infant is new born, the Mothers Milk is thinner, and of more facile digetion; but in proces of time, and the trength of the foetus being now improved, it growes thicker and more coagulated. And therefore thoe choice and delicate Dames, which do not uckle their Infants themelves, are injurious to their Childrens welfare; for ince mercenary Nures are for the mot
part of a ranker contitution, then they: and o have older Milk, and more coagulated, and conequently of harder digetion; it often falls out, that the Infants which are born of uch Mothers cannot away with the Milk of uch Nures (epecially about the time of breeding their Teeth) but by reaon of crudities, or corrupted Milk, are tormented with Feavers, Loones, Vomitings, Paines in the Guts, Coughs, and Epilepies, and the like.

That which Fabricius affirms, and indeavours to trengthen with certain arguments: namely, that the Chalazae are the ubject matter of the pag. 34. Chicken, we have formerly diproved in our Hitory, and have withal made it appear, that the ubtance and firt lineaments of the chicken are laied, while the Chalazae are intire, and unaltered: as likewie in a ditinct place of the Egge.

Nor is it true that the chalazae (which he conceivs the cocks eed doth fructifie) do upply the office pag. 54. of eed, that o the chicken might be made out of them. Neither do the chalazae o repreent the eed, in colour, ubtance, or propriety of body (as he would pag. 57. have it) or o reemble the picture of a chicken in an egge that is boiled, that we ought of right to conceive all the permatical parts to be thence extracted. But we are rather to conceive that the colliquamentum mentioned by us, or the thinner part of the white reolved, and concocted, doth put on the nature of eed, and upply its place, as our eyes may evidence.

And therefore that contemplation of this reverend age is too upi • e, where he aith: Since the pag. 54. whole ubtance of the Animal is contituted of two different, and contrary bodies; namely, hot, and cold, (all the red and anguineous parts being hot, as the Liver, Heart, Spleen, Reins, Lungs, and in hort all
the flehy, and muculous parts: and on the contrary, all the White and Bloodles, as the Ligaments, Nerves, Bones, Gritles; and all the Membranous parts, as the Stomack, Guts, Womb, the Pericardium, or Pure of the Heart and the like, are cold) thee two divere kind of parts, do, without quetion, require a divere, and yet a like Aliment to utein them; if that poition be true, namely, ex iidem nutrimur, ex quibus contamus, we are nourihed by the ame ubtances, out of the which we are made. Therefore of right, do the Spermatical cold, and white parts, require a white and cold Aliment; but the Sanguineous, the red, and hot parts, require a red and hot utenance. And therefore of good right is the White of the Egg, which is cold and bloodles, deputed to nourih the cold; white, and bloodles parts; but the Yolk, as being a hot, red, and anguineous Liquor, ubtituted to the hot, and anguineous. For by this means all the parts of the Animal, may cater and procure for themelves a convenient and familiar nutriment. For we do by no means conent, that the divere parts of the egge, are ordeined to nourih the divere parts of the chicken, having formerly hewed, that the Heart, Lungs, Reins, Liver, Mucles, Ligaments, and all the parts of the whole body, do appear white and bloodles at the firt.

And upon this argument of Fabricius, it would inue, that the Heart, Lungs, Liver, Spleen, &c. are not Spermatical parts, or contituted out of the Seed: (which he will upon no terms conent to) becaue they alo are afterwards fed, and increaed by Blood; for all things are made, and nourihed by one and the ame thing; becaue nutrition is onely a ubtitution of a like ubtance into the room of that which is lot.

Nor will it les ditract him to make anwer,
how (when the white is now clean exhauted) the cold, and white parts (namely, the Ligaments, Bones, Brain, Spinal-Marrow, &c.) are likewie nourihed, and inlarged by the Yolk, the Yolk being no les a diproportionated aliment to thee, then the White is to the hot, red, and anguineous parts.

Nay, according to the fore-cited opinion, the hot, and anguineous parts are to be the pot-genit parts, or born lat: that is, the Fleh after the Bones; the Liver, and the Lungs after the Ligaments and Guts: and the cold parts of the body are to be upon the Forge all the while the White is conuming; and after them the hot, when the Yolk begins to decline and wah it elf away to upply their growth: o that all the parts could not poiby arie out of the ame Whites. But all thee matters are confuted by ocular experiment.

To confirm this: the Egges, or Spawn of Cartilagineous Fihes (namely, the Ray, the Fork-fih, and the Dog-fih) are partly coloured, and have a well complexioned Yolk; and yet all the parts of thoe very fihes (even the Parenchyma of the Liver it elf) appears white, cold, and bloodles. And on the contrary, I have een a race of Hens and Cocks, which are of a large tature, their feathers blackih, their fleh full of blood, and their Liver more ruddy then ordinary; and yet their egges, even the fertile ones, have exceeding pale Yolks, of no deeper a yellow then the traw of ripe Barly.

Fabricius in the ubequent words, eems to retract his former peeches: aying, But one thing is pag. 55. very wonderful both in the Yolk and White; that neither of them being blood, yet they are o neer of kin to blood, that they are but little different from it, and
a mall matter keeps them from being, very blood it elfe: and therefore a little paines, and a lender concoction ufficeth to convert them into blood. And this is the reaon why we alwaies dicover thoe Veins and Arteries which are propagated into the membranes of the Yolk and White to be full of blood; and yet the Yolk and White abide till in their own nature: but o oon as either of the two is attracted into the Veels, it preently tranforms into blood; o neer allyed are they to blood.

Now if it is mot certain, that blood is no les conteined in thoe propagations of the Veins which are dieminated into the White, then in thoe that are derived into the Yolk: and each of thee Liquors is o neerly related to blood, that a very mal matter will procure their tranmigration into it; who will deny, that the blood, and conequently all the Sanguineous parts are as well nourihed and inlarged by the White, as by the Yolk.

Hereupon Fabricius provides for his retreat: aying, Though all this be true, yet we are to conceive, Ibid. that this ubtance, which is attracted from the Yolk and White by the Veins, is blood in that maner only, as Chyle is in the Meeraick Veins; in which there is nothing dicoverable but meer blood; whereas the Chyle hath onely received the hadow of blood, and is to be compleated in the Liver; o that ubtance attracted by the Veins out of the Yolk and White, preently puts in the hadow and reemblance of blood, &c. Well, be it o: yet though he lurk in this hadow, he doth not alve the doubt, which is, why the Blood, and anguineous parts may not, for the fore-cited reaons, be as well nourihed by the White as the Yolk.

If he had aid, that the hotter parts, are rather
nourihed by that blood (or Aliment conteined in the blood, which is proportionable to the Chyle) which is attracted out of the Yolk, then out of the White: and o on the contrary, that the cold parts are upplied rather by that Nutriment which the Veins tranport from the White, then from the Yolk, I hould not have much oppoed him.

The main thing that diturbs him in this buines, is this, how the Blood can be made in the Egge; or what Artificer can transform the two Liquors into blood, when there is yet no Liver in Being? For he could not ay that the blood in the Egge is derived from the Mothers blood. But aith, This blood is rather wrought in the Veins then in the Liver: but it becomes a bone, a gritle, or fleh, &c. in the parts themelves, where it is exactly concocted, and aimulated, without any farther addition at all; not ignifying by whom the blood which is in the Veins dipered both into the Yolk and White, is concocted, elaborated, and made perfect, when as yet no Liver at all is extant, or any particle of the body, that might concoct or compleat it. And when he had formerly aid, that the cold parts are nourihed by the White, the hot by the Yolk; not mindful of his aertion, he here concludes the quite contrary, viz. that the ame blood doth tranmigrate into bones, gritles, fleh, and other parts.

But he lets that grand difficulty, which o much diouiets the Phyitians minds, glide by in ilence, without taking any knowledge of it: namely, how the Liver can be the Original and Author of the blood: eeing that blood is not onely found in the egge, before any one of the bowels are framed at all: but Phyitians themelves do teach,
that all the ubtance or Parenchyma of the bowels themelves, are meerly o many affuions; or confluxes of blood. Is the Effect, the Author of its own Efficient? If the Parenchyma of the Liver is made of blood, how can the Liver be the caue of blood?

And the inuing paages are of the ame batch, where he aith: There is alo another ue of the White, when it is now egregated from the Yolk: namely, that the foetus may wimme in it, and o be uteined, let tending downwards by his own weight, hee might incline to one part rather then another, and o drawing the Veels along with him, might break them in under: and to this ue the purity and tenacity of the White do conduce. For if the foetus hould take up his reidence in the Yolk, he would eaily decend down into the bottome, and o diorder and break the Yolk alo.

A very weak contruction this! For what doth the purity of the White availe to the utentation of the Chicken? Or how can the White which is more thin, better upport the Chicken, then the Yolk which is thicker and more gros then it? Or what danger is there, that the Chicken hould fall down? Since the egge in Incubation lies always ide-long, o that there is no fear of acent, or falling down. True it is, indeed, that not only the Chicken, but every foetus whatoever (while it is forming) doth wim: but that innatation is in the Colliquamentum poken of by us, and not in the Yolk or White: and we have rendered the reaon thereof elewhere.

Aritotle (aith he) Writes, that when the Chicken is conceived, the Yolk acends to the Obtue Angle of the Egge, and the reaon is, becaue the Chicken is formed out of the Chalaza, which adhereth to the Yolk; whereupon it behooves the Yolk, which is
placed in the middle to mount up to the larger part of the Egge; that o the Chicken may be there made, where there is a natural cavity, very neceary to the welfare of the Chicken. But the Chalaza is more fatened to the White, then to the Yolk.

But the reaon of that acent of the Yolk is this; the Macula or litle cicatrice which appears in the coat of the Yolk, is by reaon of the pirituous colliquamentum which is bred in it, dilated; and thereupon requiring more roome, doth tend towards the Obtue Angle of the Egge: and o likewie that portion of the Yolk and White which is melted, is ditended, and being now grown more concocted and pirituous, doth wimme upon the other parts that remaine crude: as thoe parts of water which are warmed in any veels, arie from the bottome up to the top: an experiment approved by all Phyitians, who holding the Urinal conteining a thick and troubled Urine in warm water, do perceive the upper part thereof, to clear and grow tranparent firt. This following Intance will explain the matter. There is a device known to mot men, which is intended rather for a jocular bable to gaze upon and laugh at, then for any ueful implement; namely, a certain Glas-globe, which is almot filled up with clear water, wherein everal Glas-balls which are fraught with nothing but Air, do wim upon the urface of that water, which by reaon of their levity do upport everal figures (of quivered Cupids, armed Centaures, Chariots of the Sun, and the like) which ele would all ink down to the bottom. So in like manner, this Oculus pulli, this Eye of the Chicken as I terme it, or firt Colliquation, being dilated by the heat of the Sitting-Hen, and the Genital vertue in the Egge, and o made
lighter, acends to the top, and draws up the Yolk to which it adheres together with it. Hereupon the thicker White gives place to it, and the Chalazae retire to the ides of the Egge, becaue the Cicatricula, which was formerly fituate in the ide of the egge, now mounteth directly upward.

div.head: Of the Ues of the other parts of the Egge.
EXER. LXI.
div.p: THe Shell is hard and thick, that o it may fence the Liquors, and the Chicken which dwells in them, from outward injuries. But yet it is brittle, and epecially in the Obtue end, and neer the time of the excluion of the Chicken, let it might obtruct the Chickens Exit. This Shell is alo porous, for while an egge (epecially a new-laid one) is in roating before the fire, it doth breath out a kind of weat, trickling down, as it were, drop by drop. Now thee pores are ueful for Ventilation, as alo for the more eaie penetration of the heat which reults from the Sitting Hen; and likewie that the Chicken may attract aire from without: for as we have aid before, the chicken doth, without all quetion, both breath, and cry before his excluion.

The Membranes erve to contein the Liquors, and therefore they are as many in number, as the liquors are. And the Colliquamentum alo, o oon
as it is in being, is preently inveted in its owne proper tunicle: as Aritotle did imply in thee words. A membrane alo, variegated with anguineous
Hit. an. l. 6. c. 3. fibres, doth now incompas the white Liquor, &c. But now when the excluion of the Pullus is at hand, and the White and Colliquamentum are exhauted, all the Membranes (excepting onely that which embraceth the Yolk) are dried away, and vanih: but that membrane is together with the Yolk drawn into the Peritonaeum, and concluded in the lower Belly. Now of thee membranes, two are common to the whole egg, which they do immediatly comprehend next under the Shell; but the other are proper membranes, relating to the White, the Yolk, and the Colliquamentum: but they all of them erve to the preervation, and ditinction of thoe parts which they embrace. Of the two Common coats, the exteriour which doth tick to the Shell, is the tighter, that o it may not uffer violence by the neighbourhood of the Shell, but the interiour is mooth and oft, that o it may not prejudice the Liquors, as the Meninges or membranes called dura and pia mater, do defend the Braine, from the roughnes of the Scull. The interiour, and proper membranes do, (as I have aid) embrace, and ditinguih the Liquors: whereupon they are very thinne, tranparent and fraile.

Fabricius doth indeed highly extoll the Chalazae, (as thoe parts out of which he conceived the Chicken was framed) but as for the Macula, or litle Cicatrice, which is bred adhering to the tunicle of the yolk; he concludes it to be a ueles thing, eteeming it to be no more then a bare relique or remainder of the talk broken off from the Vitellary, or uperiour Uterus of the Hen. For (according to his perwaion) the yolk did formerly
attract its utenance through that talk, or the Veels paing through it; but the yolk being now no longer nourihed by the Hen, but disjoined from the Ovary, there till continues a ign or track of the former conjunction, and the benefits received thereby.

But I on the contrary apprehend, that there is no other ue of the Chalazae, beyond that which I formerly oberved; namely, that they hould be as the Poles of that Microcome, and the ends or connexions of all the membranes wound up together, whereby the liquors are not onely continued each in their proper places, but alo retain a jut and convenient poition in relation to one another. But as for the fore-aid Macula, I am certain, that it is of the greatet concern and conequence of all; as being the chief Center of the Egg, wherein the Innate heat hovers and lurks, and out of which, as out of the firt park, the oul her elf is lighted; and latly, for whoe ake, all the liquors, and their repective coverings are contituted, and made.

Heretofore, indeed, I was of Fabricius his mind, deeming this litle Cicatrice to be nothing ele but the remainder or track of the talk broken of; but afterwards, upon more accurate obervation, I dicovered, that the talk, whereunto the yolk is annexed, is not inerted into any litle cranny or cavity of the yolk (as it is with the talks of Apples, and Plumms) and that o ome track or print of the connexion or dependance which the yolk once had upon the Ovary, hould continue in it; but that the talk, before it arrives to the Yolk from the Cluter, is all the way dilated into a round, (like a litle trumpet) that o it may encompas
the horizon, or the circle of the Yolk, which divides it into two parts; (as the Tunica Amphibletroides, or tunicle which reembleth a litle round Cating-Net, doth the Egg) o that the uperiour part of the Yolk, or Hemiphere, which looketh towards the Cluter, is quite free from any contact or coherence of the talk, & yet the fore-mentioned Macula, or litle Cicatrice, is eated upon the uperiour part of that litle cup, or portion of the membrane of the Yolk; (omething inclining towards the ide) o that this Macula can upon no terms be aid to be the print of the talk broken off from the Yolk. But of how great importance this macula is in the generation of the Chicken, hath already been dicovered in our Hitory.
It now remains, that following the tepps of Fabricius, who was formerly my Tutor, and is now my Guide, I hould declare the ues of that Cavity which is in the obtue part of the Egge.

Fabricius recounts everal conveniences ariing from it, according to its everal magnitude: which I hall declare in hort, aying, It contains aire in it, and is therefore commodious to the Ventilation of the Egge, to the Repiration, Tranpiration, and Refrigeration, and latly to the Vociferation of the Chicken. Whereupon, that Cavity is at the firt very litle, afterwards greater, and at lat greatet of all, according as the everal recited ues do require.

And thus farre have we dicoured, concerning the Generation of the Egge and Chicken, and the Ues of all the parts of the Egge; according to which dicoure, we are to conclude and give judgment concerning all kinds of Oviparous productions. We are now to declare the manner of the Generation of Viviparous animals, according to
the example and pattern of the Generation of ome one Viviparous Animal which is perfectly known, and dicovered, by us.

div.head: That an Egg is the Common Original of all Animals.
EXER. LXII.

p.U:
aith Aritotle, have this in common together with Plants; that ome do pring out of
Hit. an. l. 1. c. 1. eed, and ome of their own accord: for as Plants do either arie from the eed of other Plants, or ele pring up of their own accord, having attained ome principle fit for their production: and ome of them do attract aliment to themelves out of the earth, and ome again are bred in other plants: o ome Animals are generated by the cognation or affinity of their form; and ome of their own accord, no eed at all proceeding which is of kin to them: whereof ome are generated out of putrefied earth or plants, (as everal Inects) others are begotten in Animals themelves, and out of the excrements of their parts. But this is common to all thoe (whether they be generated of their own accord, or ele in other Animals, or out of the putrefaction of their parts, or their excrements) namely, to arie out of ome principle fit for that purpoe, and by ome efficient contained in that principle: o that All living creatures mut of neceity have a principle out of which, and by which they are begotten. Give me leave to call this principle, Primordium vegetale, the vegetal principle;
namely, ome corporeal ubtance, having life in it in potentiâ, or omething ubiting of it elfe, which is apt to be transformed into a vegetative form, by ome internal principle acting in it: Namely, uch a principle as the Egge, and the eed of Plants is: uch is the conception of Viviparous Animals, and the Worm of Inects, as Aritotle calls it: the principles of divers Animals being alo divere, according to the diveritie of which principles, the manner of the generation of Animals is divere likewie: and yet they all conent and agree in this, that they pring from a vegetal principle, as out of a matter indowed with an efficient or productive virtue; but differ, in that this principle doth either reult caually, or of its own accord, or ele proceed from omething pre-exitent, (as the fruit thereof.) Whereupon thoe Animals are called ponte nacentia, pontaneous productions, thee à parentibus genita, ofsprings derived from their parents. They are alo ditinguihed from their manner of Birth; for ome of them are Oviparous, others Viviparous: to which Aritotle addeth Hit. an. l. 1. c. 5. Vermiparous. But if we may ditinguih them, as they fall under ene, there are onely two Species or orts of productions; namely, thee: all Animals do either produce an Animal Actu, actually; or potentiâ, potentially. Thoe Animals which produce an Animal actu, are called Viviparous; and thoe that produce an Animal in potentiâ, Oviparous. For every principle which is only alive in potentiâ, we (with Fabricius) do conceive, ought to be called Ovum, an Egge: and as for that principle which Aritotle calls Vermis, a Worm, we do not at all ditinguih it ab Ovo, from an Egg; and that becaue it looks like one to the eye, and alo becaue that inditinction eems cononant to reaon.
For that Vegetal Principle, which is alive in potentiâ, is alo an Animal in potentiâ. Nor is that ditinction which Aritotle puts between an Egge, and a Worm, to be allowed of; for he calls that an Egge, ex cujus parte fit Animal, out of part of which an Animal is made: quod autem totum mutatur,
Gen. an. l. 3. c. 7. Hit. an. l. 1. c. 5. nec ex parte ejus Animal gignitur, et Vermis: and that a Worm, which is wholly transformed, and doth not produce an Animal out of ome part of it only. But now thee two do both agree in this, that they are productions not yet alive, but Animals onely in potentiâ; and therefore are both Eggs.

div.p:
And Aritotle himelf calls the very ame things Hit. an. l. 5. c. 29. Ibid. c. 30. Worms in one place, and Eggs in another: And treating of Locuts, aith, There eggs are corrupted in Autumn, when it is wet weather: and (peaking of Grahoppers) When the litle worm, aith he, groweth in the ground, it becomes Tettigometra, a Grashopper-matrix: and a litle after, The females tate the weeter after coition; for they have white egges. Nay, in that very place, where he had raied a ditinction between a Worm and an Egge, hee adds; Gen. an. l. 3. c. 9. But all this kinde of litle worms, when it hath attained the end of its magnitude, is made a kinde of Egge; for their hell doth harden, and o long they continue without motion: which is apparent in the worms of Bees, and Waps, and alo in the Canker-worm. And indeed every body may ee, that the firt rudiments of Spiders, Silkworms, and other Inects, are to be no les ranked in the clais and cale of Eggs, then the pawn, or Egges of Fihes which have ofter hells, or of Fihes which have no hells at all, and almot of all ort of fihes whatoever: which Spawn of theirs is not actually an animate body, but yet Animals are begotten out of them. Since
therefore thoe creatures which do produce actu Animal, a Creature actually alive, are called Viviparous: doubtles, thoe Animals which do bring forth a creature which is alive in potentiâ, mut be called Oviparous Animals, or ele they cannot be comprehended under any Common notion; epecially, eeing uch Productions are vegetal Rudiments, proportionable to the eeds of Plants, uch as an egge alo is allowed to be. We mut therefore conclude, that all Animals are either Viviparous, or Oviparous.

But becaue there are everal pecies of Oviparous Animals, therefore the difference of Eggs is alo everal. For any kinde of Rudiment is not a competent Recipient of every kinde of animal form. Though therefore Eggs in a large or general acceptation do not differ, yet ince ome are perfect, and ome imperfect, they are jutly ditinguihed. Perfect Eggs we call thoe, which are perfected in the Uterus, and obtain there a requiite magnitude, before they are layed: as the Eggs of Fowle. But thoe we call Imperfect, which are excluded ere they are ripe, and have not yet attained their jut bulk, but do expect that abroad, after they are layed; as the Spawn or Eggs of Fihes, that have a ofter hell, and of Fihes which have none at all; and likewie the Rudiments of Inects (which Aritotle calls Worms) are to be lited in this rank: as alo the Rudiments of thoe Creatures which are pontaneous productions.

Moreover, though ome kindes of perfect Egges are party-coloured, as being compounded of a yolk and white; yet ome of them are only of one ingle colour, as contituted of a white alone: o alo amongt imperfect Eggs, others are properly o called, as out of which a perfect Animal is produced,
as out of the Egges of Fihes: and others improperly, from whence an imperfect Animal proceeds; namely, a Worm, or Canker-worm; which is a kinde of Medium between a perfect, and an imperfect Egge: which in repect or comparion of its own egge, or Rudiment from whence it prung, is an Animal indowed with Sene and Motion, and doth nourih it elf; but in comparion of a Flye, or Butterflie, whoe rudiment is in potentiâ, it is to be counted no better then a crawling-egge, utaining it elfe: like to a Canker-worm, which having now attained its perfect magnitude, is transformed into an Aurelia, or perfect Egge; and now ceaing to move any longer, like a very Egge indeed, is an Animal in potentiâ.

In like manner, though there are ome Eggs, out of whoe whole and entire ubtance (by a Metamorphois, or Transformation) a perfect Animal is formed, which is not fed by any remaining portion of the Egge, but intantly eeks out for its maintenance abroad: and other Eggs, out of part of which a Foetus is contituted, and nourihed by the remainder; though (I ay) there are o many everal orts and diverities of Eggs, yet nothing tands in the way, to forbid thoe to be called Eggs, which Aritotle tiles Worms, (if we may give judgement upon things, according as they dicover themelves to our ene and reaon) ince they are all Vegetal principles, not actually Animals, but in potentiâ, & the true eeds of Animals, proportionable to the eeds of Plants; as we have long ince demontrated in a Hen-egg. All Animals therefore, are Viviparous, or Oviparous; becaue they either produce an Animal actually alive, or ele an Egge, or Rudiment, which is an Animal, not actu, but in potentiâ.

The Generation therefore of all Oviparous Animals may be reduced to the example of Hen-eggs, or at leat be eaily deduced from thence: becaue the ame things which are related in their hitory, may be dicovered in the ret of Viviparous creatures.

But hereafter, when we treat of the Generation of Inects, and of Spontaneous productions, we hall dicover how each of them are either differenced amongt themelves, or do ele agree. For ince every generation is a path-way to the attaining of the form of every Animal: according as Animals are either like, or unlike one another, o that their parts do neither pecifically, nor generically agree; o likewie is it uuall in their Generations. For Nature, who is a Perfect Operatrix, and cononant to her elf in her Operations, doth deign Parts that are alike, to Operations and Functions that are alike and agree; and o likewie to the attainment of the ame form, and the ame end, he treads the ame teps, and perits alwaies in the ame method in the Generation of Animals.

Hereupon, in every perfect party-coloured egge of any fowle whatever (which is compounded of a Yolk and White, and fenced with a Shell) as we have till oberved the ame parts, as are in a Hen-egg, o have we ever found the ame order and method of generating, and contituting the foetus (as in a Hen-egg.) And the elf ame things may alo be oberved in the Eggs of Serpents, and all Oviparous four-footed Animals, as the Tortoie, Froggs, and Lizards; as from whoe perfect and party-coloured egges, the foetus is framed and produced, the ame way, as in others of the like kinde. But how Spiders, and the ofter Shell-fih, as Lobters, and Shrimps, and the race of Fihes that have cales and
no hells, as the Cuttle-fih and the Calamire do get out of their Eggs, or Spawn; as alo how Worms, and Catterpillars do firt creep out of the Eggs of Inects, out of which, at length retreating into the worm or vermine called Aurelia, (as into other new eggs again) at lat a common Flie, or Butterflie is generated; how thee Creatures, I ay, doe differ in their Generation out of Eggs, from the brood ariing out of Hen-eggs, hall be declared in its due place.

Latly, though all party-coloured egges are not generated and fructified the ame way; but ome become prolifical by the Coition of a Male and Female, and others by other meanes, as the egges or frie of Fihes; and though there be alo a difference in the manner of the growth of Egges, inomuch as ome are nourihed and encreaed within their parents bowels, and others abroad: yet nothing hinders, why a foetus may not be produced out of any egge whatoever, (in cae it be a perfect egge) as well as out of a Hen-egge. Wherefore, the Hitory wherein we have already unfolded the generation of a Hen-egge, is atisfactory and full enough for the knowledge of the Generation of all other Oviparous creatures beide; as likewie to the knowledge of all thoe things which doe thence enue, by way of Corollary, or Deduction.

div.head: Of the Generation of Viviparous Animals.
EXER. LXIII.
div.p: THus farre have we proceeded in the Generation of Oviparous Animals; it follows, that we now produce our Obervations, concerning the other pecies of Viviparous productions: wherein we have found very many things which are altogether the ame with thoe which occurre in the Egge; which we have reduced hither to be conulted, and come lat to be delivered. Which, though they are paradoxical, and run counter to the common received tenets, yet are they, if my judgment fail me not, entirely cononant to the Truth.

Amongt Viviparous Animals, Man is the chief, and mot perfect of all: next him (that we may proceed from uch as are more known) are ranked thoe creatures that are more ociable & obvious: (whereof ome are olidipeda, whole-hoofed; as the Hore, and As: ome are Biulca, cloven footed; as the Oxe, the Goat, the Sheep, the Hogg, and the Deer: others fiipeda, ive digitatis pedibus, Creatures whoe feet are ditinguihed into Toes; as the Dog, the Cat, the Cony, the Moue, and the like; out of the manner of whoe generation, we may conclude concerning the generation of all other Viviparous Animals. Wherefore, (as we have done in the Hitory of the Egge, o) we hall ingle out ome one kinde of thee, as an Exemplar or Repreentative of all the ret; which, as being mot known to us, will give light to the ret, and
become a platform, to which all the other may be reduced, by way of Analogy.

I have already given you the reaon, why I have drawn out documents concerning all other Egges, from the Egges of Hens: namely becaue thoe are cheap, and every mans purchae; and upon that core we our elves had the advantage to make the more diligent diquiition, and others alo have the better opportunity to experiment the truth of our doctrine.

But there is more difficulty in the earch into the Generation of Viviparous Animals: for we are almot quite debarred of diecting the humane Uterus: and to make any inquiry concerning this matter, in Hores, Oxen, Goats, and other Cattel, cannot be without a great deal of paines and expene. But thoe who are deirous to make tryal, whether we deliver truth, or not, may aay the buines, in Doggs, Conies, Cats, and the like.

Fabricius ab Aquapendente, as if every Viviparous conception were a kind of egge, begins his Tract with that; (as being the general exemplar of Generation) giving this amongt other, as the chief ground of his proceedings; namely, becaue the contemplation of the egge, is of the larget extent:
De form. Ovi & Pulli, c. 1. for the greatet part of Animals, aith he, is generated out of Egges. But we in the entrance of thee our Obervations, have concluded that all Animals are in ome ort produced out of an Egg: For the foetus of Viviparous creatures is produced after the ame manner and order out of a pre-exitent conception, as the Chicken is formed and contituted out of an Egge: There being one and the ame pecies of generation in them all, and the exordium or firt principle of them all is either called an egge, or at let omething anwerable and proportionable
to it. For an Egge is an expoed conception from which a Chicken is produced; but a conception is an egge retained within, untill the foetus have attained its jut bulk, and magnitude: in other matters it quares with an egge: for they both are Vegetal rudiments, and alo Animals in potentiâ. Wherefore the ame Theorems, and Corollaries, (though contrary to the received perwaion) which we have already inferred in the Hitory of the Egge, are mot true: Likewie of the generation of all kind of Animals. For it is a confeed and plain thing, that all foetues, even humane ones alo, are procreated out of ome conception, (or certain ground-work.) And this is alo as true: that that thing which is called Primordium, the firt rudiment in pontaneous productions, emen, the eed in Plants, and Ovum the Egge, in Oviparous (as being that corporeal ubtance, out of which moving and operating by an intrinecal principle, that which is produced is either a Plant or an Animal:) that ame thing in the Generation of Viviparous Animals is conceptus primus; the firt Conception: and this is approved to be true both by ene and reaon.

What we have formerly affirmed of the egge, namely, that it is the perme and eed of Animals, proportionable to the eed of Plants: the ame do we now pronounce of the conception, which is the reall eed of Animals, and therefore alo called An Egge. For that is true eed according to Aritotle,
De gon. an. l. 1. c. 18. which takes its Original from two Animals joined in coition; and obtaines the virtue or power from both Sexes; uch is the eed of all Plants, and of ome Animals which know no ditinction of Sexes: as it were that which is firt mixed from. Male and Female, being a kind of promicuous conception, or Animal:
for thee creatures have that in themelves alone, which is required of both Sexes: namely, a fit matter to feed the foetus, and alo a platical, or formative, and operative vertue able to produce it. So in like manner, the conception is the fruit of the Male, and Female joined in coition, and alo the eed of the future foetus; wherefore it differeth not from an egg.

But that, which proceeding from the Generant, is the caue which firt obtains the principle of Generation Ibid. (viz. the Efficient) ought to be called the Geniture, but not the eed (as it is micalled by the common people, and Philoophers too at this day) becaue it hath not in it that thing which is required of two in coition, neither is it proportionable to the Seed of Plants. But whatoever doth poes the foreaid condition, and is anwerable to the Seed of Plants, that alo doth deerve to be called an Egge, and a Conception.

Alo the definition of an Egge, delivered by Aritotle doth fully quare to it: aying, An Egge is
Hit. an. l. 1. c. 5. that thing in perfect productions of part whereof an Animal is made, and uteined by the remainder, after it is made. Now the ame things agree to a Conception, as hall afterwards appear by the diection of Viviparous Animals, our Eyes themelves being witnees thereunto.

Beides, as a Chicken is hatched out of an Egg, by the fotering heat of the Sitting Hen, or ome other acititious hopitable patronage, o alo the Foetus is produced out of the conception in the egge, by the oft and mot natural warmth of the parent.

In a word: that which Oviparous Animals afford by Incubation, or gathering under their Wings and Breat; that is exhibited by Viviparous, by the
Womb, and neeret, or inward embraces. And then, concerning that which relates to procreation, the foetus is produced out of the Conception, in the elfe ame manner, and order, as the Chicken out of the Egg; With this onely difference, that in an egge, whatoever relates to the Contitution and Nutrition of the Chicken, is at once conteined in it: but the conception (after the foetus is now formed out of it) doth attract more nourihment out of his Parents Womb; whereupon the nourihment increaes with the foetus. Moreover the Egge is quite emptied, when the Chicken is grown; and the Aliment which was in it conumed, nor doth the Chicken attract any more utenance from the Hen: but the Oviparous Foetus doth till finde out freh upplies, and uteineth it elf by Milk.

Now the Eggs, or Spawn of Fihes are upported by food procured from without; the Egges of Inects alo, whether they have hells or not, have their proviions from abroad, nor are they lee eggs for that, either really, or nominally: o in like manner the Conception deerves the title of an Egge, though it be uteined by a various kind of Aliment from without.

Why ome Animals are Oviparous, and all do not produce their Foetus alive, Fabricius offers this reaon: namely, becaue egges (if they were detained in the Uterus till the Pullus were hatched) would by their weight prejudice the flight of Birds. And alo in Serpents, or creeping things the multitude of egges would be an impediment to their winding motions. Nor is there compas enough in the narrow circuit of the Snailes hell, to afford room to the number & increae of eggs. So likewie the Fihes bellies are too canty to
contein their numerous Fry, hould they grow within them. And therefore thee everal creatures are inforced to exclude their births, ere they arrive to perfection. So that it eems mot natural for an Animal, to contein and cherih its conception within it elf, untill the foetus be quite perfected: but nature is ometimes contrained to expoe her iues immature, and imperfect, and to compleat them with proviions ought for from without.

For as much therefore as concerns procreation, All kind of Animals are generated after the ame manner out of an Egge-like Rudiment: (which we call Egg-like, not that every Rudiment of an Animal doth reemble an Egge in Figure, but in Nature and Conitence) For in all their repective Generations this they have in common, namely, that a certain Vegetal principle is pre-exitent (of like nature to an Egge, and anwering in proportion to the Seed of Plants) out of which the foetus is produced. And this Egg or Egg-like ubtance is in them all, poeing the nature and conditions required in an Egg: which conditions alo the eeds of Plants have common to them, as well as Animals. And for that caue the principles of any kind of Animals, are called their Fruits, and Seeds, and o likewie the Seeds of all Plants may in a manner be called Egges, and Conceptions.

And to this purpoe Aritotle peaks, aying: De gen. an. l. 3. c. 9. Thoe creatures which bring forth an Animal from within themelves, have omething formed in them upon the firt conception like unto an egge: for they have an humour conteined in a thin coat, uch as that in an egge when the hell is pilled off. Whereupon thoe depravations of conceptions which fall out about that
time, fluxus vocant, the people call, Fluxes, or micarryings.

Thoe Fluxes are chiefly obervable in Women, when they micarry in the firt or econd moneth: and uch I have often een dicharged about thoe times: and uch a one alo Hippocrates reports to have been dicharged, and fallen from the Mintrel.

The firt Conception, or Rudiment therefore of all Hit. an. l. 7. c. 7. Animals is in the Uterus: which according to Aritotle, is liks an egg covered over with a membrane when the hell is pilled off. And this hall appear more clearly by what hall be aid hereafter. In the interim we conclude with the Philoopher: All Animals, whether they be wimming, walking, or flying Animals; and whether they be born in the form of an Animal, or of an Egge: are all generated after the ame manner.

div.head: The Hitory of the Generation of Hinds and Does, is layed down as the Example of all other Animals: together with the reaon of our o doing.
EXERCIT. LXIV.
div.p:
OUr late Sovereign King Charls, o oon as he became a Man, was wont for Recreation, and Health ake, to hunt almot every week, epecially
the Buck and Doe; no Prince in Europe having greater tore either wandring at liberty in the Woods, or Forrets, or incloed and kept up in Parkes and Chaces. In the three ummer moneths, the Buck and Stagge, being then fat and in eaon, were his game, and the Doe and Hind in the Autumne, and Winter, o long as the three eaonable moneths continued. Hereupon (for the Rutting time, when the Females are luty, and admit the Males, whereby they conceive and bear their young) I had a daily oportunity of diecting them, and of making inpection and obervation of all their parts; which liberty I chiefly made ue of in order to the Genital parts.

We hall therefore dicloe the Generation of all Viviparous Animals, out of the Hitory of the Hind and Doe, as being the mot commodious Exemplar: treating thereof after the ame manner as we have already handled the Generation of all Oviparous productions, out of the Hitory of the Hen-Egge. And this not from any peculiar deign of my own, or for the ame caues for which I did prefer the Hen-Egge to all other: but becaue by the favour and bounty of my Royal Mater (whoe Phyitian I was, and who was himelf much delighted in this kind of curioity, being many times pleaed to be an eye witnes, and to aert my new inventions) I had great tore of his Deere at my devotion, and frequent opportunity and licene to diect and earch into them.

I intend therefore to et before you the Hitory of Hinds and Does, compoed out of my undry oberv ations for many years together, whereby I my elf am chiefly vered in them, and from whence alo omething may be infallibly concluded concerning the Generation of other Viviparous
Animals: which Hitory, whilet we faithfully compile, we hall alo inert all thoe obervable Occurrences, which we have either caually met withall, or ele attained by intended diections in other Animals; namely, uch as are cloven-footed, whole-hoofed, and thoe which have their feet ditinguihed into toes, as likewie in Man himelf: declaring the eries, or order of the Formation of the Foetus, according to the everal proceedings which Nature her elfe doth oberve therein.

div.head: Of the Uterus of Hindes and Does.
EXER. LXV.
div.p: BEing about to treat of the Formation and Generation of the Hinde and Doe, we mut firt dicoure concerning the place wherein thoe actions are performed, namely the Uterus; (as we have already done in the Hitory of the Hen) that o thoe things which enue, may be more eaily and rightly undertood. For in this very thing. Hitory hath the precedence of Romance and Fable; namely, in that he decribes events with their jut circumtance of et times and places, and o guides us unto knowledge by a urer way.

But that we may the better conceive the Deere's Uterus, we hall explain both the internal, and external fabrick thereof, taking our pattern from the womb of Women. For Man, who is the mot conummate or complete Animal of all other, as he hath obtained all other parts more perfect then
they, o are his Genital parts alo. And therefore the Uterine parts are mot ditinct in a Woman, and to us (by reaon of the pecial indutry of Anatomits about this Part) better known.

Now in the Uterus of Hinds, & Does, many things do occurr which you may dicover to be the ame in the womb of a Woman; but yet ome things do differ. In the external orifice, are neither the labra, nor the Clitoris, nor the Nymphae; but onely two Orifices (whereof one is the Orifice of the Bladder, adjoined to the Share-bone; the other of the Privity, eated between the fundament and the Urmary cavity.) The membranous Cuticle (like to that which we have noted in a Henne) tending downwards from the fundament, doth cover the veil, and upply the office of the Nymphae & labia of the Privity, in order to its defence from outward injuries: this veile is omething retracted in a Woman in coition, or at let forced to retreat by the entrance of the Yard into the Orifice of the Privity.

The Suture or connexion of the Share-bones being divided in Hindes, or Does, and the leggs laid wide open, the Bladder of Urine, and Vagina Uteri, or Privity wherein the Yard of the Male is entertained, as alo the neck of the Womb, and its cituation, are preently dicovered, together with the ligaments whereby it is fatened, as likewie the Veines, Arteries, and Tetieles, as they call them: alo the Horns of the Womb, even in thee creatures, are more remarkable then the other parts of it.

But as for the preparing, and the leading, or ejaculatory veels, there are no uch things to be found here; nor (as farre as I know) in any other Female whatoever: And Anatomits (who uppoe that the Female doth emit a eed in coition) make too indutrious an enquiry after them; for they
are not at all in ome; and in thoe in whom they are, they are never found in the ame manner, or agreeing. Wherefore it comes neeret to truth, which alo (as I have oberved) the greater part of Women acknowledg; namely, that they do not emit any eed in coition. And though the more alacious do dicharge a certain moiture in coition, yet I neither approve it to be fruitfull eed, nor necearily conducing to conception; for very many do conceive without any uch effuion at all: (and ome alo without any pleaure) but of thee more elewhere.

The Privity, or Vagina Uteri, which is extended from the outward Orifice of the ecret parts, to the inward Orifice of the Womb, is in a Doe, as in a Woman, eated between the Bladder of Urine, and the Rectum intetinum, or Right Gut, and is correpondent to the Yard of the male in form, largenes, and longitude. And being diected, is dicovered to be furrowed with oblong wrinckles and rugoities, and alo made glibb and lippery with a tiffe moyture. In its bottom, you may perceive a more narrow and cloed Orifice, which is the beginning of the neck of the Uterus, through which, whatoever is driven out from the cavity of the Womb, doth make its paage. And this is that Orifice, which Phyitians affirm to be o cloely compreed, ealed up, and concluded in a Virgin, and Woman with child, that it will not admit the point of the finet Needle, or Probe.

After this follows the Neck, or Proces of the Womb, which is a much longer and rounder paage in them, then in Women; and in its whole extenion, from the bottom of the Privity to the Womb it elf, is much more fibrous, thick, and nervous, then theirs. And if you make inciion into this
Neck, according to its longitude, you hall dicover not only its exteriour ingres, which is conpicuous in the bottom of the Privity, o exactly to connive, and cling together, that the air it elf though driven by ones breath, cannot arrive at the cavity of the Womb; but alo five alike treights more ranked in order, blocked up againt the acces of any outward approacher, and ticking firmly together by a glewy mucilage: jut as the mot compact and narrow orifice of a Womans Uterus is locked up by a yellow glutinous ubtance. And uch narrow treights as thee, are dicernable in the neck of the Sheeps, Cowes, and Goats womb, all which are cloe locked up, and forbid any admittance (which Fabricius alo oberved.) But thee five Recees are mot ditinguihable in a Hinde, and a Doe, appearing like o many everal ports or orifices of the Uterus tyed up, and ealed fat, which you may jutly eteem as o many Barracadoes oppoed to the admiion of any thing whatoever. So carefull doth Nature eem to have been, that in cae any inolent intruder hould have forced the firt gate, yet his rudenes hould be foiled by the next, making like proviion in the other Avenues, that o nothing might infinuate it elf into the womb. And yet for all this a Probe being put in from the Cavity of the Uterus outwards, doth with eae pas through all thee ports, and finde a way out. For it was convenient that a paage hould be afforded to the dicharge of Flatulencies, Mentruous Blood, and other Humours; but all entrance debarred to the entertainment of outward things, though they be never o litle (as to the air itelf, or the Seed.)

This Uterine Orifice is alike blocked up in all
other Animals, as it is in Women; whoe womb we have known o cloed ometimes, that their Coures, Purgations after delivery, and other humours, have for want of free disburdening, excited mot terrible Hyterical affections, inomuch that I have been fain to invent an intrument proper to this inconvenience, whereby the orifice of the womb being opened, the imprioned uperfluities might be releaed, and the recited caualties ubdued; as alo that injections might finde a reception in the cavity of the womb, by which I have ometimes cured the internal Ulcers of the Matrix, and alo Barrennes it elf.

The Cavity of the Uterus in Hindes and Does, is exceeding mall, as the ubtance of the Uterus is very litle both in magnitude and thicknes. For the womb in thoe creatures, is only as a Porch, or Fore-Gate, in the Cavity whereof lyeth an open way both on the right, and left hand, which leadeth to the Horns of the Womb.

For thoe parts are different in almot all other Animals which have Blood, from what they are in Women; in whom the chief part of the womb, is the Body thereof: but the Neck, and the Hornes, (as being onely Appendixes) are carce dicernable. For the Neck is hort, & the Horns litle, like round & long procees, extended upwards from the bottom of the womb, like two Trumpets; the Anatomits commonly conceiving them to be the Ejaculatory veels. But in the Hinde and Doe, as in all other Viviparous Animals which have blood (except only Women, he-Apes, and thoe Female Animals that are whole-hoofed) the chief part for Generation is not the Womb, but the Horns thereof. For in Women, and whole-hoofed Beats, the place of Conception is the Womb, but in other Animals, the
Conception is accomplihed in the Horns of the Womb. And therefore Authors generally call thoe Horns by the name of Uterus, the Womb, aying, that the Womb in ome Animals is bipartite, and in ome not; undertanding thereby the places of Conception, which are the Horns of the wombe, wherein almot all Viviparous Animals, praeertine multipara, epecially thoe that bring forth everal young ones at a birth, doe conceive: and unto which alo all the Uterine veins & arteries are conducted, and the other Genital parts are ubervient. Wherefore give us leave alo, in the Hitory of thoe Animals, to ue promicuouly the name of Uterus or Womb, and of Horns of the womb, for the ame thing.

In a Woman, as we have aid, the two Trumpets neer the proces of the Neck of the womb, which are perforated into the cavity thereof, are not commonly reputed proportionable to the Horns, but are conceited by ome Anatomits to be Vaa Spermatica, Spermatical Veels; by others, Spiramenta Uteri, the Pores of the Uterus; by a third ort, Vaa emen deferentia, aut reervantia, Leading Veels, or Veels reerving the Seed in them. As if they were a certain kinde of Seminal veicles; when, in truth, they are anwerable in proportion to the Horns of the womb of other Animals; as appears clearly, by their cituation, connexion, largenes, perforation, form, and function: for as other Animals do alwaies conceive in the Horns, o a Woman alo is ometimes found to bear her Foetus in Cornu ive Tubâ, in the Horn or Trumpet Anthrop. l. 2. c. 34. of the womb, as the mot learned Riolanus reports by the obervation of other men, and I have een with my own eyes.

Thoe Horns do terminate in the Common Cavity,
which (like a Porch or Threhold) is eated before them both; and is in Deer proportionable to the Womans uterus, as the trumpets of the Womans womb, are proportionable to the Horns of the Deers womb. But their denomination they aume from their figure; for as the Horns of a Ram or Goat are large at bottom, jutting out before, and again reflected backward; o alo thee Horns of the womb (in Hindes and Does) at their original are large and ample, and leening by degrees as they look upwards, are at lat retorted towards the Spine of the Back. And as thoe other Horns are inequal, knotty, and wrinkled in their forepart, but behinde appear mooth and even; o the Horns of the Deers womb, are below wrinckled, and gathered, by reaon of certain cells or rings bunching out, in manner like the Gut Colon: but above (where they repect the Spine) they are mooth and even, and recurved, as if they were tyed back by a kinde of fillet-like ligament, and o by degrees grow lender as Horns do. If you take an empty gut (uch a one as puddings are made in) keeping it contract, wrinckled, and treightned, by a tape or fillet which binds it all along on one ide, you hall ee it curled and ditinguihed into litle cells or windings (after the fahion of the Colick Gut.) And uch is the fabrick of the Horns of the womb of a Hinde, or a Doe. In other Females the cae is different, for they either have larger cells, or none at all. And in thee Horns of Hinds and Does alo, though there be everal cells or windings, yet are not all of equal magnitude, but the firt is much larger then any of the ret, and in it chiefly the Conception is contained.

And as in a Woman, the womb, and its trumpets (or Horns) with the ret of its appurtenances, are
tyed fat to the Share-bones, the Back, & the neighbour Parts, by the mediation of a broad and carnous Membrane, (as by a pendulous band or tye) which Anatomits do tile Vepertilionum alas, the Batts wings; becaue the Uterus hanging in this manner, doth reemble a Bat with its wings pread abroad: o alo in Hindes, and Does, the two Horns of the womb, together with the Teticles, and all the Veels of the Uterus, are by a thick membrane fatened to the circumjacent Parts, (but epecially to the Back) which membrane performs the ame office to the Uterine Parts, as the Meeutery doth to the Guts, and that which we call the Meometrion doth to the Uterus of the Hen. For as by the Meentery the Meeraick Veins and Arteries are derived to the Guts; o are the Uterine Veels dieminated through the fore-aid membrane: in which alo certain mall Bladders and Glandules are on both ides dicovered, which Glandules Anatomits commonly call the Teticles.

The ubtance of the Horns of the Hindes and Does wombs is cuticular or skinny, or ele a flehy skin or coat (like that of the Guts) beprinckled with certain lender Veins. This coat you may, as Anatomits ue to do, divide into everal coats, oberving the everal cituation of the fibers, which erve to everal functions, namely to Retention, and Expulion. For I have many times een thoe Horns moving jut like Earth-worms; in the ame manner as any man may perceive the Guts, in an Animal newly killed, and the abdomen or covering of the lower belly laid open, tirring to and fro, in a kinde of waving motion, whereby (as if they were cloe begirt and bound in by ome mall narrow ring, or preed and queezed between ones fingers) they crowd down and depres
the Chyle & Excrement towards the inferior Guts.

All the Uterine Veins do here (as in a woman) aume their original from the Hollow vein, neer the Emulgents: but the Arteries (which they alo do partake as well as Women) do arie from the Branches of the Great Artery, which pas into the Thighes: and as in a woman great with child, the Uterine Veels which contain blood, are more and greater then in the ret of her body; o is it alo with Hindes and Does which are with Fawn. But the Arteries (contrary to that Which we ee in the ret of the body) are much more numerous for their proportion then the Veines; and being blown into, they will ditend, & fill their neighbour veins, but the veins being in the ame manner blown into, will never do o much for them. And this alo I ee taken notice of by the learned Riolanus, and it is a prevalent argument for the Circulation of the Blood, which was my Invention; for it doth clearly evince a paage from the Arteries into the Veins, but no retreat from the Veins into the Arteries again: & there are likewie more Arteries then Veins, becaue the foetus requires great tore of utenance to upply his growth, the remainder whereof fewer Veins are ufficient to return.

There are alo Teticles dicernable in thee alo, as they are in Sheep, Goat, and all Animals which cleave the hoofe; but uch Teticles as reemble the Protatae, or eed Glandules, and the Kennels of the Meentery (whoe office is to ecure the divarications of the Veins, and retain a moiture in them whereby to keep the parts glib) rather then things deigned to the concoction of Prolifical eed, and the Reervation or treauring it up till it be fit for profuion in the time of Coition. And this is my opinion of them, both for
undry reaons elewhere alledged: as chiefly, becaue that at the time of coition (when the males Teticles are welled with eed, and full of eminal juice) the Horns of the womb indeed are in Hindes and Does, and all other Viviparous Animals (wherein they reide) much altered: but the Teticles, as they call them, (like things utterly unconcerned in the matter of Generation) do neither well, nor differ any way from the contitution they were of (either before, or after coition) affording no tetimony at all of their ue either in repect of Coition, or Generation.

It is a wonderfull thing to ee how great a quantity of geniture doth abound in the Teticles, and much ditended Seminal Veels of the very maculine Moles, and Mice, about the time of their coition (which we have alo formerly oberved in the Dunghill-Cock) and how vat an alteration is epyed in the Genitals of both Sexes; and yet thee Glandulae, or litle Kernels (which men conceive to be the Teticles of the Females) do till reerve their wonted appearance, without any variation at all.

What we have hitherto oberved, concerning the Womb and the Horns thereof in Hindes and Does, doth for the mot part relate alo to other Viviparous Animals, though they differ in a Woman; becaue he conceives in her womb, but all the ret in the Horns of the womb, except the Mare, and the he-As; and even they alo, though they eem to bear their Conception in the womb, yet that place of Conception doth more reemble the nature and contitution of a Horn, then of a Womb: for that place is not bipartite, but omething more oblong,, and different from a womb, both in cituation, connexion, fabrick, and ubtance,
and ought rather to be compared to the uperiour Uterus, or proces of the womb of the Hen, (wherein the Egge groweth, and is encompaed with the White) then to the womb of a Woman.

div.head: Of the Coition of the Hinds and Does.
EXER: LXVI.
div.p: THe Hitory of the Womb of Hinds and Does, is uch as hath been hewed. Wherein we have briefly declared thoe things which did eem neceary to Generation, namely, the place of Conception, and thoe parts which are ordeined thereunto. It remaines that we now treat of the Action and Function of this place, namely of Coition and Conception.

Hinds and Does do admit their Males at one only et time of the year; that is about the midt of September, after the Feat of the Holy Cros, and they bring forth after the middet of June, neer the Feat of Saint John Baptit. So that they goe nine moneths, not eight, as Pliny would have it: L. 8. c. 32. for they calve or bring forth, with us at let, the nineth moneth after their firt Rutting.

At Rutting time the males aemble themelves amongt the females, but at other times they feed apart: and the elder Deere (as the Staggs) do aociate with their own Sex, and the Hinds and Does keep company and feed among the other Hinds and Does, together with the younger ort of Ducks, and Fawns. About a whole moneth their
Rutting time continues, which doth begin later, if the eaon be dry, but if it be moit and rainey, ooner. And therefore in Spain (as I am informed) they eldom rut before the Calends of October, becaue moit weather comes not on there til then. But in England their Rutting time eldom lats beyond the middet of October.

At that time their lut enrages them o, that they will aault or Doggs or Men, when at other times they are hie and timorous, and uffer themelves to be chaed and put to flight upon the alarme of the leat barking curre that is.

Every Male Deer knowes all his Females, and will not indure any one of them to traggle, but will purue and bring her back to his Herd: and being now grown very jealous of them, he frequently urveyes them, and rangeth them together. And if perhaps a tranger Doe intrude among them, he is not very paionate in her expulion, but affords her a fair departure: but if another Male Deere addres himelf to this Herd, he bids him a peedy defiance, and charges him with his Head.

The Hind and Doe are numbered amongt the chater rank of Animals; becaue they do not willingly admit Coition (for the Stagge and Buck, like the Bull, do celebrate their Coition with violence) and unles they be over-matered, or tyred out with aaults, they hun the act. And this eemes to be the caue of the aembling themelves together in a Herd to their own proper mates, and chiefly to thoe that are the elder Deere, and are bet headed: for if a forraigner attempt their chatity, they preently fly to their own Herd and conort, for anctuary, as the refuge of their affrighted modety.
If a young Batchelour Buck finde a Doe traggling alone, he preently purues, and having tired her by his chaing, he takes advantage of her inability for reitance, and o enjoyes her by force.

All the Male Deer provide themelves a Rutting place at ome ditance from the Herd, by digging up trenches, or tanding behind ome convenient rie of ground, whither they contrain their Females to appear. She that is now about the act of Rutting, placeth her hinder feet in the furrow or trench provided for the purpoe, and (if occaion be) inclining her body doth omething depres her Hanches; by which means the Stag or Buck may at one inition (as Bulls do) preing her forward, finih his affaires.

The Elder, and abler Stags, and Bucks have a larger Herd of Hinds and Does, then the juniour and infirmer Deer: ome aemble to themelves ten, ome fifteen. Our Keepers ay, that the Females are ated at the econd coition, or third at the mot, and he, o oon as he conceives, admits the male no more.

The Male when he hath fructified all his Females, his lut cooleth; and having impared both his audacity, and his fleh, quits his Herd, traggles alone, and feeds greedily to repaire his broken trength, making no farther aault upon any Female all that year.
When the Buck growes firt ripe for Rutting, the Hair about his Throat and Neck growes black; as alo doth the extremity of his prepuce, which doth putrifie likewie, and tink extreamly.

The Does and Hinds are but very eldome compreed, and that too in the night time onely, and in obcure places, uch as are purpoely made
choice of by the Males for that performance. If the Stags or Bucks chance to contet (which is uuall) then the conquered his Females are all made the Victors purchae.

div.head: Of the Contitution or Alteration of the Uterus of the Hind and Doe in the moneth September.
EXERCIT. LXVII.
div.p: WE now come to the Alteration of the Geniral parts of the Hind, and Doe, after Rutting time, and alo to the conception it elf.

In September, when the Hinds and Does firt Rutting time is now arrived, their Uterus (I mean the Hornes of the Uterus, or the place wherein they conceive) is become more flehy, and thick, and likewie more oft and tender. In the cavity of each of the Horns of the womb (in that part which reembleth a wrinckled fillet; namely, where it reflects towards the pine of the Back) five Caruncles, or oft Warts, or Nipples, do jet out, being placed in order: whereof the firt is the bigget of all, and the ret as they lie in order, are till one les then the other; jut as thee Horns themelves do leen by degrees from the bottom upwards, to the very top. Some of thee Caruncles do grow out as broad as the middle finger, (appearing like a kinde of a luxuriant, fungous, flehy ubtance) being paler or whiter then ome, and more ruddy then others.

About the ix and twentieth, or eight and twentieth day of September (as likewie afterwards in October) the Uterus is grown thicker; and the caruncles being now more tumid, do reemble the Nipples of Womens Breats: o that you would believe they were deigned to yeeld Milk. Their top or uppermot part being cut away (for I divided the outward uperficies from them, to dicover their interiour contitution) I beheld them compacted and formed out of an innumerable company of white points, as out of o many britles et up tiff and erect, by a certain mucous vicidity or glewy ubtance, and pinching them hard from the roots upward, between my fore finger and my thumb, I queezed out of each of thoe white points a mall drop of blood. Whereupon by a more trict enquiry, I dicovered them to be nothing ele, but the Capillary productions of o many lender Arteries.

At Rutting time therefore, the Uterine Veels (epecially the Arteries) are dicovered to be more in number, and more conpicuous then at other times: Though (as I have noted before) thoe that are called the Teticles, are neither more large, nor more full then they were before, nor any thing changed from their pritine contitution.

The Cavity of the Uterus (that is, of the Hornes of the Uterus) and interiour uperficies thereof (which you may call the wall of the litle Cells) preents it elfe exceeding oft and glibbe to the touch, like to the interiour concameration of the Ventricles of the Braine, or the fleh of the Nut of the Yard, which is within the Prepuce. But in that Cavity, I could never dicover any Sperme ejected from the Male Deere, nor any other thing which relates to the conception, (though I have made
mot accurate diection through all the entire moneths of September and October.) And yet the Male Deere did go to rut daily, and I diected a great number of Does. And this is the reult of many years experience.

I have een indeed in ome the Caruncles o neerly eated the one to the other, as if they had made one continued protuberance out of all the five united together. And when upon frequent experiment, I never met with any other thing within the Cavity of the Uterus, I began at firt to conider, whether the maculine eed could by any means (namely either by way of Injection, or Attraction) ininuate itelf into the eat of Conception? and at lat my many repeated obervations did ratifie this concluion, namely, that no part or portion of the eed doth ever enter into thoe receptacles.

div.head: What befalls them in the moneth of October.
EXERCIT. LXVIII.
div.p:
HAving made everal diections in the month of October, as well before the expiration of the Rutting time, as after: I could never finde any eed, or blood, or the track of any other thing whatoever, in the cavity of the Uterus. Onely the Womb or Uterus was grown larger and thicker, and the Caruncles more tumid and florid then before, and out of them upon a cloe contriction
or pinching them between the fingers, ome mall drops of blood did iue out, as a watery kinde of milk is expreed out of the nipples of the breats of uch as are with Childe, about the fourth moneth of their pregnation. In the Uterus of one, or two, which was exceedingly impated and extenuated contrary to the coure of Nature, I found indeed a kinde of a green, ichorous putrified ubtance, like to impotumated matter, filling the cavity thereof; whereas thoe very Does were in all other points ound, and omething fat, no les then their fellowes which I diffected at the ame time.

About the End of October, and the Beginning of November, when the Rutting time is now concluded, and the Females and Males part company: the Uterus began to eem of a leer bulk (in ome ooner, and in others later) and the wall or ides of the inner cavity appeared to tumefie, as if it were puffed up; for in thoe places where of late the litle Cells were, there did now round gobbets extuberate inwards, filling almot the whole capacity: o that the ides now eemed to touch one another, and glewed as it were together, leaving no pace vacant between them. For as licorih Boyes (while they plunder the honey-combs, that they may greedily devour the honey) have their Lips o tung by the Bees, that they well and grow tumerous, and o treighten the gap of their Mouths; in the ame manner doth the interiour uperficies of the Does Uterus become turgid, and a mot oft and pulpous ubtance (like that of the Braine) doth fill the cavity, and involve the Caruncles in it. And as for the Caruncles themelves, they are no bigger then they were before, but only appear omething paler, and as it were maderated or tewed in warm water, as the Nures nipples
look preently after the Childe hath had the breat. But I could not queeze out any blood from them, as before.

This interiour uperficies of the Uterus being thus wolne; it is at that time o tender and mooth, as nothing can be more. It reembles the oftnes of the brain it elf, and when you touch it, did not your own eyes give evidence to that touch, you would not believe your fingers vere upon it. The cavity of the Womb being laied open immediately after the killing of the Deere, I have often dicovered a low waving motion, (uch a one as is een in the bottom of a creeping Snailes belly) as if the Womb were Animal in Animali, one living creature in another; and had a peculiar independent motion of its own.

Such a kind of motion as this, I have (as I mentioned but now) often oberved in the intetines of creatures diected alive: & the ame may be experimented both by the tetimony of the ight and touch, in live Dogs and Conies, though you diect them not. I have likewie oberved the ame kind of motion, in the Teticles and Scrotum of the Males; and I have known ome Women, whom uch palpitations have deluded with the hopes of being with Child. But whether in Hyterical affections (uch as are the Acent, decent, & contortion of the Uterus) the Womb of Women move and tir by uch a kind of agitation; as whether the Braine alo in its conceptions be in like manner moved to and fro, as the dicovery is very difficult, o is it vorthy the attempt.

A little while after the foreaid Extuberance of the interiour coat of the Uterus begins to hrink, and leen: and in ome, (but that is rare,) a certain purulent matter doth tick to the fides, (in
manner of weat) uch as is viible in wounds, and ulcers, when they are aid to be Concocted, and cat forth a white, mooth, and equall matter. When I firt dicovered this kind of ubtance, I was in upence, whether I hould conceit it to be the eed of the Male, or ome concocted ubtance ariing from it. But becaue I did oberve this matter but eldom, and in few onely, and alo eeing twenty days were now pat, ince any commerce with the male had been celebrated, and likewie for as much as this ubtance was not thick, clammy, or froathy, (as eed is) but more friable and purulent, inclining to yellow, I concluded that it arrived thither caually rather, or ele proceeded from over much weat, the Deere being newly quite pent in the chace: and o in a Rheume falling down into the Noe, the thinner portion of the Catarrh being thickened into a mucous ubtance, puts on a yellow complexion.

This alteration in the Womb when I had often dicovered to His Majeties ight (as the firt aay towards impregnation) and having likewie plainly hewed that all this while no portion of eed, or conception either was to be found in the Womb; and when the King himelf had communicated the ame as a very wonderful thing to divere of his followers, a great debate at length aroe: The Keepers and the Huntmen concluded, firt, that this did imply, that their conception would be late that year, & thereupon accued the drougth; but afterwards when they undertood that the rutting time was pat, and gone; and that I tood tiffly upon that, they peremptorily did affirm, that I was firt mitaken my elfe, and o had drawn the King into my error; and that it could not poibly be, but that omething at let of the
Conception mut needs appear in the Uterus: untill at lat, being confuted by their own eyes, they ate down in a gaze and gave it over for granted. But all the Kings Phyitians perited tiffly, that it could no waies be, that a conception hould go forward unles the males eed did remain in the womb, and that there hould be nothing at all reiding in the Vterus after a fruitfull and effectuall Coition; this they ranked amongt their < in non-Latin alphabet > .

Now that this experiment which is of o great concern might appear the more evident to poterity; His Majetie for tryal-ake (becaue they have all the ame time and manner of conception) did at the beginning of October eparate about a dozen Does from the ociety of the Buck, and lock them up in the Coure neer Hampton Court. Now let any one might affirm that doubtlesly thee did continue the eed betowed upon them in Coition (their time of Rutting being then not pat) I diected divere of them, and dicovered no eed at all reiding in their Vterus: and yet thoe whom I diected not, did conceive by the virtue of their former Coition (as by Contagion) and did Fawn at their appointed time.

In Bitches, Conies, and everal other Animals, I have certainly dicovered, that nothing after Coition is to be found in their Vterus, for many daies together. In o much that I am very well acertained that in Viviparous, (as well as in Oviparous creatures) the Foetus doth neither proceed from the Seed of Male and Female emitted in Coition, nor yet from any commixture of that eed, (as the Phyitians will have it) nor yet out of the Mentruous blood, as Aritotle conceits; and likewie that there is not any thing of the conception
necearily in being, preently after Coition. And hence it follows, that it is not true, that in a prolifical coition, any matter is ready at hand in the Vterus, which matter or ubtance, the Maculine eed hould concoct, coagulate and fahion, or reduce into an actual generation, or by drying its outward Superficies, Form, and After-birth to wrap it in. For nothing at all is to be found in the Womb for many days together, even to the twelfth of November.

It is alo evident, that all Females, in the Act of coition, do not effund a eed into the Vterus; for neither in Hinds, or Does, or everal other Viviparous Animals, is there any track or igne of either Seed, or Mentruous blood. But what it may be, which flowes from ome alacious Women in Coition, as well as from Men, which procures pleaure to them, and a kind of reolution of their Spirits; as alo whether it do necearily conduce to the Conception; likewie whether it do proceed from the Teticles, or whether it bee eed, and whether prolifical or not, we have elewhere dicovered.

And while I am in this dicoure, let the ingenious bear with me, (if being mindful of my great wrongs) I let lip a igh or two, grounded upon this my misfortune: namely, that while I did attend upon our late Sovereign in thee late ditractions, and more then Civil Wars; (and that not by the Parliaments bare permiion, but command) ome rapacious hand or other not onely poiled me of all my Goods; but alo (which I mot lament) have bereft me of my Notes, which cot me many years indutry. By which meant, many obervations (epecially thoe concerning) the Generation of Inects) are lot and imberelled to the prejudice (I may boldly ay it) of the Common-wealth of Learning.

div.head: What things happen in the Uterus of Deere in November.
EXER. LXIX.
div.p: ABout the twelfth or fourteenth day of November there is omething, which is then firt of all to be found in the Cavity of the Womb of the Deere, conducing to the future foetus, and this I truly avouch, and of many years Experience.

I remember indeed, that in the year of our Lord 1653, thee igns or rudiments of conception did appear ooner, becaue it was a cloudy, and wet eaon. In Hinds alo, which go to Rut ix or even days before the Does, I have till dicovered ome track of the future conception, about the eighth or nineth day of November. But what that is, and how it doth begin, I hall now declare.

A litle before any thing at all is to be een, the ubtance of the Vterus, or Hornes appear leer, then when the females firt went to Rut; and the white Caruncles are more flaggy (as I informed you before;) and the protuberance of the inward that doth a litle abate, growing more wrinckled, and moit. For about the time aforeaid, ome certain mucous filaments (like the Spiders threads) are led from the lat or upper angle of the Hornes of the Vterus, through the midt of both the Horns, and alo through the cavity of the Womb, which being joined together, do reemble a membra
