•• ns or filmy coat, or empty wallet. And as that implication or web of veels called Pleocus Choroides,
•• led through the Ventricles of the Brain, o this
litle oblong ack, or wallet is pun over all the pace of both the Horns, and the intermediate cavity of the womb. In which diemination, ininuating it elf into the rugoities of the flagging membrane, it doth inert lender fibres between the fore-mentioned round extuberances or nipples; after the ame manner as the membrane called Fia Mater doth work it elf into the convolutions of the braine.

A day or two being now over, this wallet is filled with a watry, white, tiff, albugineous ubtance, and being tuffed with that moiture, doth reemble a long pudding, ticking or cleaving a litle to the conteining ides of the Vterus by its exteriour glutinoity; and yet o, that it may be eaily eparated from them: for being taken in the narrow part of the Vterus (where it is tied to it as it paeth along) it may be brought away entire from both the Hornes, if it be warily handled.

This Conception now grown, and taken out, is of the figure of a wallet, or double pudding: being bemeared on the outide with a kind of purulent filth; but within it is glibbe, conteining in it a tiff moiture, much like to the more liquid White of an Egge.

Now this is the firt Conception of Hindi and Does. And eeing the nature and condition of an Egge, together with the definition is applicable thereto, for Aritotle defines an Egge, to be that thing out of part whereof an Animal is begotten, and
Hit. an. l. 1. c. 5. & de gen. an. l. 2. c. 1. de gen. an. l. 3. c. 9. the remainder is the food of that Animal which is begotten: and likewie, eeing it is the ground-work or rudiment of the future foetus, it is therefore alo called Ovum Animalium, the Animals Egge, According to that of Aritotle. Thoe creatures which beget an Animal within themelves, have upon
the firt conception omething formed in them in manner of an egge. For a moit ubtance is contained in a Membrane, jut as if you hould pill off the hell from the Egge: whereupon the depravations of thee conceptions are called fluxes. This Conception therefore, as we aid before of an Egge, is a true perme, or eed, embracing in it elf the virtue of both Sexes, and proportionable to the eed of Plants. Aritotle therefore decribing the firt Conceptions of Women,
Hit. an. l. 7. c. 7. aith they are, as it were, an Egg covered over with a Membrane, but the hell taken off: uch as Hippocrates records to have dropt from the Mintrel, and uch as I have often een fallen from Women in the econd Moneth, which was of the bignes of a Pige
•• egge, without any foetus at all in it: and ometimes about the bulk of a Pheaants, or Hens egg: and at this time the floating Embryo is of the longitude of the naile of the Litle-finger. But the Membrane involving the Conception, hath not yet attained any After-burden to which it may be fatened, nor is it fatened to the womb it elf; but onely at its obtuer and upper end, as if it were •• uck with mos or down; it preents to our view the firt deigns and rudiments of the After-burden, or Cake of the Womb: but the inner uperficies being mooth and glib, is divaricated with the everal propagations of the Umbilical Veels. At the third Moneth, this Egge exceeds a Gooe-Egge in magnitude, and infolds within it an Embryo of the length of two tranvere fingers. At the fourth Moneth, it is larger then the Egge of an Otrich. And thus much I have diligently oberved in Abortions, having made everal diections of them.

And in this manner do Hinds and Does, though for a whole moneth together (and more) after their Rutting time, no enible thing at all be contained
in their uterus, produce by a kinde of Contagion, thee conceptions and rudiments in the hape of eggs, (as Plants bring forth their eed, and Trees their fruit) which about the eighteenth or one and twentieth day of November (at the farthet) are compleat; and that ometimes in the Right Horn, and ometimes in the Left, and at other times in both: having in them a certain diolved ubtance, tranparent, & crytalline (which we call the Colliquamentum, or Eye in the Hen-egg) which is contained in a proper thin orbicular coat of their own, being much purer then that humour wherein the Conception wims afterwards; in the midt whereof the anguineous fibers, & the Punctum aliens (which is the firt foundation of the future foetus) without the preence of any thing ele, are clearly dicerned; and this is the firt Genital particle. Which being contituted, not onely the Vegetative oul, but the Motive alo is aid to be in it, from which all the other parts of the foetus are each in their order generated, formed, dipoed, and endowed with life: after the ame manner as we have declared the Chicken to be contituted out of the Colliquamentum of the Egg.

Both thee humors are in the Conceptions of all Viviparous Animals; which many men conceive to be the Excrements of the Foetus, deeming the one to be its urine, the other its weat; when notwithtanding they have no offenive tate at all, and are alwayes mot manifet in the Conception, even before any particle of the foetus is dicerned.

The Outward coat which embraceth both the humours, is called Chorion; the Inward, Amnium. And more then thee two you can never finde; the former, involving the whole Conception, and extended
over both the Horns of the uterus; the later, wimming in the firt water, and contained onely in one of the Horns, except there be a Twin-foetus; in which cae, there is one in each of the Horns: as in the Gemellifical Egge there are two Colliquamentums. So that where there is a double foetus, they are both contained in one and the ame conception, together with their two-fold crytalline waters: (as in one and the ame Egg.) If you make an inciion into any part of the Exteriour membrane, the more impure water will preently iue out from both the Horns; but the crytalline water, which is comprehended in the interiour membrane called Amnion, doth not flow forth with the former, unles you have peirced it alo.

The Vein, which is firt een within the Amnion, in the crytalline humour, takes its original from the Punctum aliens; exerciing the office, and partaking of the nature of the Umbilical Veels; and being by degrees enlarged, it is dieminated into other ramifications, which are cattered into the Colliquamentum: whereby it is mot evident, that the nutriment is at firt attracted from the Colliquamentum only, wherein the Foetus wims.

Having diected the uterus, I have expoed this Punctum aliens, while it yet continued its palpitation, to the view of our late dread Soveraigne; which was then o mall, that without the advantage of the Sun-beams obliquely illutrating it, he could not have perceived its hivering motion.

The entire Colliquamentum being cat into a ilver or tinn-Baon, which is full of clear warm water, doth very neatly lay open the Punctum aliens to the eye. To which, in the following dayes, a certain gelly, like a litle worm, in the form of a Magot, is adjoined, (as being the firt platform of
the future body) divided into two parts; of one part whereof the Trunk is contituted, & the Head of the other: in the very ame manner, as hath been formerly delivered in the Hitory of the Hen-egg. The Spine of the Back is a litle inflected in manner of a Keel; the Head is imperfectly compoed of three mall veicles, or litle balls, and wimming in the Crytalline water, doth dayly enlarge, and grow into hape: With this difference onely, that the Eyes are much larger, and more viible in Oviparous, then in Viviparous productions.

After the ix and twentieth day of November, the foetus is dicerned, having his whole body almot compleat, being found without ditinction, ometimes eated in the Right, and ometimes in the Left horn of the Vterus: but where there is a Twinfoetus, there is one of them placed in each of the Horns.
And at this time the Male is ditinguihable from the Female by his Genital parts; which are conpicuous in a humane Embryo, o oon as ever the rough Artery doth appear.

You hall finde the Male and Female ometimes in the Right, and ometimes in the Left horn, meerly as it falleth out. But yet the Male is more frequently dicovered in the Left, and the Female in the Right horn, and this frequently in Does, which have Twins within them, and I once alo oberved it in an Ewe. Whence I am confirmed, that the proper contitution, or peculiar virtue of either ide, doth ignifie nothing to the dicrimination of the Sex. Nor is the uterus the Fabricatour or former of the Foetus, no, nor the mother her elf, any more then the Hen is the framer of the Chicken in the Egge whereon he itteth. But as the Chicken is made in the Egge by an internal formative Agent,
o likewie is the foetus contituted out of this Egge of the Doe.

A man would admire to ee the Foetus formed and compleated in the Amnion, in o mall a time after the firt rie and beginning of the Blood and Punctum aliens. For about the nineteenth or twentieth day of November, that Point makes his firt appearance: about the one and twentieth or two and twentieth day, the litle unhapen Worme or Maggot dicovers it elf: but within ix or even daies after that, the Foetus is o compleat, that you may ditinguih the Male from the Female, (by the Genital parts) and perceive the feet formed, and the little hoofes cleft, being then like Gelly, omething inclining to yellow.

So oon as ever the foetus begins to be formed and grow, the ubtance of the Uterus is much extenuated: contrary to the cutom of it in Women, whoe Womb according to the increae of the Foetus becomes thicker, and more flehy. For in Hinds, and Does, how much the more the foetus augmenteth, o much the Hornes of the Uterus approach neerer to the hape of the Guts: and chiefly that Horne, wherein the Foetus doth reide, doth reemble a little wallet, though in its extent and capacity it exceed the other.

This Egge or Conception, doth as yet on no ide adhere, or grow fat to the Matrix (though the foetus is now compleat) but may bee very eaily drawn away whole; as I have tried it in an Ewe, which bore a foetus in her Womb, almot the length of my Thumb. Wherefore it is mot apparent, that the foetus is yet onely nourihed by the White, which is hut up with it in the Conception, as it hath been oberved in the Hen-egge before; for the Orifices of the Umbilical Veels are quite obliterated
between the White of the Conception, and the adjacent humours with their membranes; not being any where as yet fatned to the Uterus it elf, though thoe Veins or Veels onely are the convoy to adminiter nourihment to the foetus. And as in an Egge the propagations of the Veins are firt dieminated into the Colliquamentum; (as the roots of plants are into the ground) and are afterwards communicated to the exteriour Membrane (called the Chorion) and do dipatch their branches up and down with innumerable divarications through the albugineous humour conteined in the utmot membrane, that o they may forage, and provide Aliment: o likewie in humane abortions, I have plainly dicovered the vein in the Chorion; and Aritotle himelf affirmed, that that coat was full
Hit. an. l. 7. c. 7. of veins.

If there be a ingle foetus, the ditribution of its Umbilical veels is extended to both the Hornes of the Womb (having litle branches dieminated through the cavity thereof) that o it may attract aliment on both ides. But if there be two (namely one in each Horne) they both hoot forth their Umbilical propagations into that part onely of the Conception which borders upon their proper Horn: o that the foetus eated in the right Horne deriveth his utenance from the right ide of the conception, and he in the left from the left onely: The Gemellifical conception being in all other matters alo like the Gemellifical Egge.

Now, about the end of November, all the parts are clear and ditinct, and the foetus now appears of the magnitude of a large Beane, or a Nutmeg: the hinder part of his Head being a litle prominent, as it is in a Chicken, but his Eyes are lee. His Mouth lies gaping wide even from Ear to Ear:
for the Cheeks and Lips are lat of all perfected, as being cutaneous parts. So that in all Productions (even in humane alo) the lit of the Mouth is dilated as far as the Ears on both ides, having neither Lips nor Cheeks to abate it. And for this caue, as I conceive, many are born with cleft lips, (we call them Hare-lips, that is, having uch lips as Hares, and Camels have) becaue in the formation of the humane foetus, the upper lips do very lowly cloe.

I have often times cat the foetus, when it was now grown to the quantity of a fair Bean, being tranparent under his coat Amnios, and wimming in his mot pure alinient, into a ilver baon full of the clearet water, whereby I dicovered chiefly thee mot remarkable following things. His brain being of a litle thicker conitence then the White of an Egg, (like milk a litle coagulated) of a rude hape, lieth encompaed on every ide in a membrane, having as yet no cull at all. The After-brain tands up omething prominent, as in a Chicken. The Cone or whole frame of the Heart looks white, and o alo all the other Bowels (even the Liver it elf) are white, and as it were permatical. The Trunk of the Umbilical Veels doth arie from the heart, and paing the gibbous part of the Liver, doth inert it elf into the Trunk of the Vena Porta, or Gate Vein; and running thence a litle farther, and ditinguihing it elf into everal propagations, it is diffued through the colliquamentum, and the coat called Chorion, by an infinite number of branches. The Sides on both hands arie from the pine, o that the Thorax or chet looks like a boat, or litle pinnace, before the Heart and Lungs are retired into its circuite: jut in like manner as it is in the chicken. For the Guts, Heart, and the ret
of the Bowels are very conpicuous, and eem to be litle appendixes of the body; untill at lat the chet and coverture of the lower Belly are drawn over them (as the Roofe is erected upon the open roomes) and o veil and conceal them. At that time the ides as well of the Breat, as the Loines, eem to be white, mucilagineous, and of a imilar contitution, excepting onely that through the inide of the Breat, ome certain lender capillary lines do run along, and o occaion a ditinction between the future Ribs, and the carnous or flehy parts of the ides.

I have alo ometimes een the Twinne-foetus in the Conceptions of Ewes, which have been about the ame time whereof we now peak (and ometimes one alone) which were of the longitude of a tranvere finger: their form was like that of the mallet Lizard, and their magnitude like that of a Wape, or Worm called Eruca: the Spine of the back was bent round, o that the head did almot reach to the taile. Both of them did wim in a peculiar clear humour of their own, incloed within the Amnion: and both were of the ame magnitude, (as if they had been begotten at one and the ame act of coition and conception) For though the one lay in the right, and the other in the left Horn, yet both were included in the ame wallet, and in the ame exteriour water: (and o conequently in the ame egge, or conception.) Their mouthes were wide, but their eyes were mall, and carce dicernable points; contrary to thoe of Birds. Their Bowels or Intrals alo were not as yet incloed within the cavity of the body, but were hanging out. Their Exteriour Membrane called Chorion, did not adhere to the Uterus, o that I could not take away the conception whole & entire.
There were alo in the ame coat an infinite number of Umbilical propagations which had no connexion at all to the Uterus: as we have noted in Deer alo, and after the ame manner, as we have decribed them in the outward membrane of the Hen-egge. There were onely preent two humours, and as many coats conteining them: whereof the exteriour called Chorion was extended over both the Horns, and being full of a more turbid humour, did fahion or hape the egge, or conception. But the coat called Amnios, was almot inviible (like that coat of the Eye which is called Arachnoides, or the Cobweb, being the membrane of the Crytalline humour) conteining in it a clear bright Water like Crytal, wherein this foetus of the Ewe did wim.

The humour contained within the Chorion, was in proportion a hundred times more (I might ay a thouand) then the other, though the Crytalline humour too which is reerved in the Amnios, was in a larger quantity, then to be upected for the Sweat of o mall a foetus wimming amidt it. Nor was it of any ditatful avour, or ent, but exceeding clear: and (as we have noted in Hinds and Does) reembling thinne watry milk, being tainted with no kinde of excrementitious pravity. Now in cae this humour were an Excrement, it would alo grow and encreae as the foetus it elf doth: But I finde the matter clean contrary in the foetus of the Ewe alo; for a litle before it is • aned, there is carce any portion of this humour left. Wherefore I conceive it rather to be the Aliment, then the Excrement of the Foetus.

The Interiour coat of the Ewes womb was imboed with an infinite number of caruncles, (as the Skie is with tarres) which were of the likenes of
Crabbs eyes, as I call them, but omething les; and reembling looe or hanging warts, were glandulous, and white, ticking within the coats of the womb, being omething hollow or excavated on that ide wherewith they incline towards the Conception: (contrary to their coure in Hinds and Does, in which they do extuberate towards the Foetus it elf) and beides all this, they did trut with blood; and their interiour uperficies, as it did direct it elf towards the conception, was full of black, anguineous points. The Umbilical Veels of the Foetus were not as yet inerted into thee caruncles, nor was the conception hitherto fatened to the Uterus.

As for that coat, which they talk much of, and call Allantoides, I can finde no uch matter in the conceptions of Ewes; but afterwards (when the foetus is now grown bigger) when the Egge or Conception doth now cleave to the Uterus, and the veins are inerted into the caruncles, then is the Chorion extended farther, and in its two ends (or Appendixes as it were) a certain humour died yellow (you would conceive it to be an excrementitious humour) is ecluded, and reerved apart from the ret.

As for a Humane Conception, that hardly differs any thing from an Egg, for the firt moneths. For before the After-birth or Uterine cake hath been framed, I have een a white humour (like to the thinner White of the Egge, and equal in magnitude to a Pigeons egge, nay ometimes to a Pheaants) encompaed in a lender membrane; wherein the Embryo, who was as long as the naile of the little finger, did appear like a mall frogge: having a broad body, a wide mouth, and his armes and leggs newly hot forth, like the young buds of flowers:
he had a prominent Occiput, or After-braine, which may be rather called a little bladder annexed like an appendix to the ret of the head, as hath been mentioned in the firt rudiment of the Occiput of chickens.

An other humane Conception I aw (which was about fifty dayes tanding) wherein was an egge, as large as an Hen-egg, or Turkey-egg. The foetus was of the longitude of a large Bean, with a very great head, which was over-looked by the Occiput, as by a cret; the Brain it elf was in ubtance like Coagulated milk; and intead of a olid cull, there was a kind of Leather-membrane, which was in ome parts like a gritle, ditributed from the fore-head, to the Roots of the Noe. The Face appeared like a Dogs nout. Without both Ears, and Noe. Yet was the rough Artery, which decends into the Lungs, and the firt rudiment of the Yard, viible. The two deaf-ears of the Heart, appeared like two black eyes.

In a Woman with childe, who dyed of a Feaver, I found an Hermaphrodite Embryo of almot the ame bignes. Its Privity was like that of a Cony, the labra reembling the prepuce; and the Nymphae, the Glans or Nut. Above this privity I aw the firt rudiments of a Yard, to which there hung down on both Sides, intead of Teticles, the laxe or flaggy skin of the Scrotum, or Cod. Its Uterus or womb. was very litle, reembling the Uterus of an aborted Lamb, or Mole, having both the Horns. And as the Glandules or Kernels, called Protatae, were cituate neer the Yard, o alo were the Teticles, which were of a dicernable magnitude, placed next to thoe Horns. So that, according to outward appearance, it did mot expres a Male childe, but upon inward dicovery of the Parts, a Female.
The womb of the woman that bare it, was very vat, having the bladder of Urine adjoined to it (as its Appendix:) but contrariwie in the Foetus, the Bladder of Urine was large, and the Uterus looked onely like its Appendix.

All thee fore-mentioned humane Conceptions, like the Ewes, had a rough or wrinckled uperficies outwardly, and were dawbed over with a kinde of Gelly, or glutinous ubtance; and at that time, there was neither any appearance of the After-burden, nor yet any union of the Conception to the matrix, nor any inertion of the Umbilical Veels into the matrix, or womb, though they were dieminated into the uperficies of the Conception.

Though divere foetus are ometimes found in the ame Conception of Hindes, and Does, (as divers Chickens in the ame white of a gemellifical Egg) as it alo happeneth in Ewes, he-Goats, and other cloven footed creatures: yet in Bitches, Conies, Sowes, and other Viviparous and Multiparous Animals, the matter is clean otherwie; for every foetus in them doth challenge two everal humors, and two ditinct coats.

In Bitches there are everal Knots through the whole cavity of the Horns of their uterus, in which o many everal humors are contained, and in every one of them a everal Foetus. In the Hare, and Cony which are Does, you may perceive many round gobbets or balls (uch as the eggs of Serpents are) like bracelets made of everal Amber beads.
The Hares Conception is exceeding like an Acorn, and the After-burden covereth it in manner of a Cup; and the Humours contained in the membranes hang down like litle Acorns.

div.head: Of the manner how the Conception of Hindes, and Does, is found to be in the month of December.
EXER. LXX.
div.p: IN the beginning of December, the Foetus is now more grown and perfect, being of a fingers length. The Heart, and other Bowels, together with the Guts (all which were formerly expoed to publick view) are retreated into the hollow of the body; o that you can neither dicern them, nor the motion of the Heart, without diection.

The Conception or Egge, by the mediation of the five Caruncles in each Horn, (formerly poken of) is in five everal places adjoined and fatned to the Uterus, yet not o firmly neither, but that a mall force will disjoin them again. Which being done, you hal dicern the different print of the Caruncles in the outward uperficies of the Chorion, by which Caruncles it was united to the Uterus, the impreion which they leave behinde them being rugged and vicous, as if by that glew or pate, the aid adheion or conjunction had been effected. And thus have we revealed the Nature and ue of thee Caruncles; for they which before (like Warts or Muhroms) were bred at the ides of the Uterus, do now, being knit to the conception, upply the place and office of an After-burden, or Uterine Cake (as it is in Women) namely, they are intead of o many nipples from which the foetus by the aitance of his
Umbilical Veels doth derive to himelf uch Aliment as his Mother affords him: as hall appear hereafter.

The Magnitude and capacity of the Vterus (under which name we undertand the Hornes of the Vterus; namely the places of conception) do enlarge according to the growth of the foetus, but yet o, that, that Horn wherein the foetus etleth his abode, is larger then the other.

Their conception or egge is one onely; whether they produce a ingle, or divere Foetus: and that ingle conception is dilated over both the Horns; o that it looks like a brace of puddings, or rather like one onely, and that tied in the middle, as hath been formerly aid: for paing along lender, and round, from the farthet part of the Horne on one ide, it doth by degrees enlarge, and o goeth on to that common place, which in a Woman we call the Womb and Matrix or Mother; (becaue a Woman in that part is made a Mother, by conceiving and fotering a foetus in it) where it is treightned as if it paed through an Ithmus; and being again dilated, as it arriveth at the other Horn, it proceedeth till on to the farthet extremity thereof likewie; where growing les, and pointed (as it did at the beginning) it erects its non Vltra, and proceeds no farther. Therefore thee kind of conceptions, if they be drawn away entire, do reemble a wallet whoe both ends are full of Water: and thence alo that coat chorion, is likewie called Allantoides; becaue the conceptions of uch Animals reemble a Gut blown up, or tuffed pudding, which is tied fat in the midt.

If you diect an Embryo at this time, you hall dicern all the interiour parts ditinct, and compleat: but chiefly the Stomack, the Heart, and
Kidnies, and the Lungs; which are alo divided into their Lobes, and look as they had blood in them, having gained their jut form. But the complexion of thee Lungs is more ruddy, then of thoe which have at any time breathed; becaue the Lungs tretched and dilated by the Air, put on a whiter colour. And by this obervation of the different complexion, you may dicover whether a Mother brought her Childe alive or dead into the world; for intantly after inpiration the Lungs change colour: which colour remains, though the foetus dye immediatly after.

In a Female foetus, the Teticles (improperly o called) are eated neer the Kidnies, in the hanging or looe ligament of the uterus, or womb, at the ends or extremities of the Horns on both ides; and are for their proportion larger in a foetus, then in a grown body, and look white, like the caruncles.

In the Stomack of the Foetus, there is found a watery ubtance, (not unlike that wherein he (wims) but omething more troubled, and les tranparent: like to that milk which is dreined out of Womens breats, that are about four or five moneths gone, or like white Poet as we call it.
In the upper Guts there is tore of chyle made of the fore-aid ubtance now concocted. But in the Colon or colick Gut there do begin to appear yellow excrements, and haped.

But as for the Urachus (or Perforation of the Navel of the foetus, by which it is imagined to dicharge the urine into the coat called Allantoides) I finde no uch matter; nor any difference at all between the coat Allantoides (which is uppoed to contain the urine) and the Chorion; nor do I dicover any urine in the After-birth, but onely in the
Bladder, and in that, good tore: the Bladder it elf, being omething Oblong, is cituate between the Umbilical Arteries, which arie from the branches of the decending Trunk of the Great Arterie.

The Liver is rude, and almot inform or unhapen, as if it were omething beides Natures intention, it looks onely like a ruddy affuion of Blood. The Brain being now omewhat reduced into hape, is comprehended in a thick membrane. The Eyes lie concealed under the lids; and thoe lids are o tarched together, and hut o fat (as it is with puppies newly whelped) that I had much ado to disjoin them, and open the eyes. The Breat-bone and Ribs do now harden by degrees: and the complexion of the Mucles hifts from white, to be blood coloured.

Having made very many everal diections for the whole coure of this Moneth, I am become more aured, that the caruncles before mentioned, do exercie the office of an After-birth or Uterine cake; which I now dicerned to be red and welled, and about the bignes of a Wall-nut. The Conception, which, as we aid, did before tick only to the caruncles by the help of the glutinous ubtance, doth now dipatch the litle branches of the Umbilical Veels into the very body of the caruncles (as Plants work in their Roots into the earth) by which it is fatened, and grows to the Womb.

About the end of December I have feen the foetus being then about a pan long, lutily betirring himelf, and kicking; opening his mouth and jawes, and alo hutting them again. His hear •
was now placed in its pure, or pericardium, and the Breat being diected, it was very dicernable making apparent and forcible Palpitations; and
yet the Ventricles of the Heart were Vniforme, and of equal magnitude, and did conit of equal height, or of a double cone: the thicknes alo of their ides was equal. Where alo I clearly dicerned the deaf ears of the Heart, which at this time were full of blood, like two pretty large bladders, to continue and perit in their motion for a little pace, even when the Heart it elf had reigned it up.

All the Bowels, which were indeed perfect before, are now larger and more conpicuous. The Scull is partly cartilagineous, and partly bony. The Hoofs are yellowih, flexile, and oft (jut as the Hoofs of grown Deere are, being mollified in eething water) the Caruncles, now very great, (as large Muhroomes) are pred over the whole cavity of the Uterus, and do evidently upply the ue of an After-birth: for everal propagations and thoe large ones too, are from the Umbilical Veels dieminated into them, that o they may derive aliment to the foetus: in like manner as in thoe that are already in the world, the chyle is tranported by the Meeraick branches into the Gate vain of the Liver.

In whatoever Conception of this kind, there is but one onely foetus, there the Umbilical veels are conveied to all the caruncles: (as well of the oppoite, as the ame ide) but in that conception where there is a double foetus, there the ramifications of the Vmbilical veels relating to each foetus, are not propagated beyond the caruncles of the ame ide wherein it reideth.

The leer Vmbilical veins as they repect the foetus, do where they unite and join together determine and end in other greater Veins; and thoe again paing farther on, and uniting, do conclude
in Veins yet greater then themelves, till at the lat they contitute two truncks, which being conjoined, do convey Blood into the Hollow, and Gate Vein. But the Vmbilical Arteries (ariing from the branches of the decending Trunk of the great Artery.) are two, and thoe very mall ones, and uch as were it not for their pule, could carce be dicerned, which being carried along, to the capacity or uperficies of the conception) where the caruncles or After-birth meet the propagations of the Veins) do firt diminih or leen into capillary threads, and at lat become quite inviible, and are clean expunged.

As in the Vterus the Extremities of the Vmbilical veels are terminated into the caruncles, o likewie out of the Vterus, the Vterine veels (which are many, and large) carrying blood from the Mother to the Womb (by the conduct of the upenory ligaments) do terminate outwardly in thoe very caruncles. We are alo to take notice, that the Interiour veels, are all of them Veins, for the mot part: but the Exteriour are for the mot the propagations of Arteries. In the Womans Afterburden, if you mind it well, preently after he is delivered, are many more Arteries then Veines, and alo larger too, which are dieminated with almot innumerable propagations up and down, even to its utmot uperficies. As alo in the fungous Parenchyma, or Affuion of the Spleen, which is not unlike it, the number of the Arteries exceedeth that of the Veins.
The exteriour Vterine veels do, as I ay, tend towards the Matrix, and towards the Teticles, which are eated in the upenory ligament; as ome men imagine.

In the Gibbous or convex part of the caruncles,
which repect the Matrix, I have oberved a wonderful contrivance in Nature: For in divere of the Cavities, and Cotyledones, or Orifices of the veels gaping outwards, I found a white mucilaginous ubtance, which did fill up the whole body of the caruncle, (as the Honey tuffs up the Honey-comb) and was of a complexion, conitence, and tat much like the White of an Egge. But if you pluck a under the conception from the caruncles, you hall preently decry o many priggs, or capillary branches of the Vmbilical veels (which look like long threads or filaments) to be drawn out alo from every one of the Cotyledones, and Combs as it were, and out of their mucous ubtance: jut as Herbs plucked up from the Earth, have their Roots trailing after them.

By which it is evident, that the Extremities of the Vmbilical veels, are no way conjoined to the Vterine veels by an Anatomôis; nor do extract blood from them, but are terminated in that white mucilaginous matter, and are quite obliterated in it, attracting nourihment from it; after the elf ame manner, as they did formerly draw Aliment from the white moiture or ap, which was concluded within the membranes of the conception. And as the chicken in the Hen-egge is uteined by the White attracted by its Vmbilical veels; o the Conception alo of Hinds and Does, is nourihed with a white ubtance like to that, which is tored up in thee litle Cells, and not with blood.

Wherefore thee Caruncles may be jutly tiled the Vterine cakes, or dugs: that is to ay, Convenient and proportionate Organs or Intruments deigned for the concocting of that Albuginous Aliment, and for preparing it for the attraction of the Veins. And therefore thoe Viviparous Animals
which have not thee Caruncles or Afterbirth; (as the Mare, and the Sow have none) their foetus is uteined even till the hour of their birth, with the humours which are conteined in the Conception onely; and their conception doth no where adhere or grow to the Vterus.

It is therefore manifet in thoe, and alo in thee orts or pecies of Viviparous Animals, (and perhaps in all other whatoever;) that the Embryo is in no other manner uteined in the Vterus, then the chicken in the Egge; but out of the ame Nutritive ubtance, and of like kind to the Aliment in the White of an Egge. For as in an Egge, the extremities of the Vmbilical veels are terminated in the White and Yolk: o likewie in Hinds and Does, and other Animals, that are furnihed with thee Caruncles, the extremity of the Orifices of the Vmbilical veels are opened into, & terminated in the humour which is conteined in the Conception; and in that white ubtance, which is found in thoe Orifices or Cotyledones.

And this truth is hence alo aerted, in that the extremities of the threads or filaments of the Vmbilical veels, when they are drawn out of that mucous or white ubtance, are all of them white likewie; which is a forcible argument they do onely imbibe this gelly or mucilage, and not blood. And any man may prove the ame Experiment in an Egge alo, if he deire it.

The After-burden, or Vterine cake of a Woman, is in its gibbous part, wherewith it repects the Womb, uneven, & hilly, by reaon of everal tumors or muhroom-like ubtances; and eems by their mediation to grow to the Womb. As if it were not fatned to the womb in every part, but onely in thoe places, where the veels dieminated into
it do extract Aliment, and in which for that caue, the extremities of the veels are broken off. Now whether thoe extremities or terminations of the veels do uck blood from the Womb, or rather ome kind of concocted ubtance like to the White of an Egge, uch as we perceive plainly in Hinds, and Does, I am not yet atisfied.

Latly, (that the truth in hand may be certainly confirmed) if you queeze thoe caruncles between your fingers; you may eaily Milk as much of that Nutritive juice as a poon can contein, out of any one of thoe Caruncles; (as out of a Nipple) without any appearance of blood at all; which blood you hall never queez from them though you force them never o much. Moreover, the caruncle thus milked & drained, doth contract it elf, and flag, like to a ponge that is queezed, and appears to be bored through with everal perforations. So that by all igns and tokens it appears that thoe Caruncles are Ubera Vterina, the Breats or Vdders of the Uterus, or the receptacles and tore-houes of that Nutritive white ubtance.

At the end of December, thee Caruncles do les firmly cleave to the Vterus, then they did before, and are with cae divided from it. And by how much the foetus doth improve, and grow neerer to the birth, o much the eaier do thoe caruncles disjoin from the Womb: and in the end (as ripe fruit falls off from the Tree) they depart from the Vterus of their own accord, as being things which relate to the conception.

And when they are parted from the Womb, you may, in the impreions which they leave behind them, perceive the points or terminations of the Arteries which pas on towards them, breathing forth blood. But if you force the conception from
the caruncles, no blood doth iue out from the impreions which they leave behind them: though it do eem more cononant to reaon, that blood hould iue out of the caruncles, then of the conception upon their divorce. For ince the caruncles are embroidered by everal propagations of Arteries derived from the Vterus; and are commonly conceived to convey blood for the nutriment of the Foetus, they ought in conequence to abound with plenty of Blood. And yet though you milk or compres them, they effund no blood at all; becaue they are not ful of blood, but of this white ubtance; nor do they eem to be intruments intituted for the concoction of the former, but Promptuaries, or Treauries of the latter. By which it is apparent, that the foetus in the Womb, is not uteined by the Mothers blood, but by this white ubtance fitly prepared. And perhaps even grown bodies are not nourihed by blood, but omething which runs in the blood, is their common and lat Aliment: as hall perhaps be elewhere dicovered in our Phyiological Treatie, and in the proper diceptation relating to the blood.

I do much quetion the truth of that place of Hippocrates, where he aith: Thoe Animals whoe
L. de nat. Mul. de morb. vulg. & Sect. 5. & aphor. 45. Acetabula or Orifices of their Vterine veels are full of a mucous ubtance, do uffer Abortment. For that ubtance is not an Excrement, and caue of Abortion, but an Aliment and firt caue of life. But Hippocrates perhaps meant ome other Acetabula: for in a Woman they are not found, nor hath her After-birth any uch ubtance as this to be enibly perceived in any of its cavities.

The Later Phyitians, according to the opinion of the Arabians, do phanie three everal Nutritive Humours; namely, Rorem, the dewy ubtance,
Gluten, the glutinous ubtance, and Cambium, the ubtance which is immediately transformed into the eence of the parts: and thee Fernelius calls uccos Nutritios, the alible juices; as conceiving, that the Parts of our bodies are not immediatly nourihed by the Blood, as its lat aliment, but by thee ecundary humours: by the firt whereof, as by a kind of Dew, all the mallet particles of the body and parts thereof, are princkled and bedewed; which humour being thickned by a farther concoction, and ticking more firmly to the Parts, is now called Gluten, which at lat being altered and aimilated by the power and virtue of the Parts, is called Cambium.

We may, according to thee Mens conceit, call that ubtance which we finde in the Acetabula, or Orifices of the veels, the Gluten, or Nutritive white, and ay that it is (as being the lat Aliment which is deigned to all the everal parts of the foetus) proportionable to the White or Yolk of the Egge. For as we aid ere-while, with Aritotle, that the Yolk is proportionable to milk: o we likewie conceive it cononant to reaon, to affirm, that this ubtance, which is contained in the Cotyledones, or Acetabula of the Uterine cake, doth upply the office of milk to the foetus, o long as it continues in the womb: and conequently, that the Caruncles are as it were Ubera interna, internal Dugs, and that the alible juice is (after the delivery) tranported into the Breats, and there made milk; that o the foetus may enjoy the ame nutriment after he is born, wherewith he was fed when he continued in the womb. And therefore this onely difference is between the party-coloured Eggs of Oviparous Animals (which are compounded of the Yolk and White) and the Eggs or Conceptions of
Viviparous Animals, that in the former, the Yolk (which is their ecundary utenance) is provided for them within the Egg, and preently upon their Excluion, is hut up within the belly of the Chicken, as being reerved there for their upport; but in the latter, this nutritive ubtance is before the Birth preerved in the Acetabula, and after the Birth tranmitted to the Breats or Udder. So that the Pullus is upplied with a kinde of milke, which is concluded in it elf; but the Viviparous foetus, ucks the ame from the duggs of the Dam.

When December is ended, eeing that in the ubequent moneths of January, February, &c. there is nothing new or notable doth befall the foetus, but all its acceions have been oberved already, (ave onely the Hair, Teeth, Horns, and the like) only the parts formerly decribed eem to have attained a larger Augmentation, litle or nothing repecting the buines of Generation, we conceive it ueles to dicoure any more of them at preent.

But as to the Conceptions of Ewes, I have diected divers of them about this time, which (like thoe of Does) did alo reemble the figure of a Wallet, or double-pudding, being extended over both the Horns of the Womb. In ome of thee Conceptions I found two foetus; in other, one only, and that void of all kinde of wool, with its eyes o congealed and fixed together, that I could not open the lids, and yet the hoofs were already made. Where there were two foetus, they lay in everal Horns of the Uterus, and that promicuouly, without any order at all oberved, the male being ometimes in the left, and the female in the right Horn, and ometimes clean contrary: but both were till encompaed in the ame common
Conception, and concluded in the ame exteriour membrane called Chorion; whoe Extremities or ends on both Sides towards the termination of the Horns, were tained as it were by a kinde of cholerical excrement, and did eem to have ome turbid and excrementitious matter within them.

The Caruncles, or litle Cakes, were divere, and of a different magnitude, and of a ditinct figure from the caruncles of Hinds and Does: for in Ewes, there is a kind of round muhroom with the talk broken off, contained between the Coats of the Uterus, whoe gibbous Part lieth towards the Uterus; (as it is alo in the Conceptions of Cowes) but the concave (which is mooth) towards the foetus: and likewie larger Branches or Veels are derived to this concave part, as it alo happens to the interiour part of a Womans After-burden.

The Propagations of the Umbilical Veels being annexed to the caruncles, do grow o firmly to them, that when I endeavoured to divide them, the gibbous part would be ooner broken off from the interiour coat of the Womb, then recede from the Conception: contrary to their cutom in Hinds and Does, whoe membrane called Chorion, is eaily eparated from the Cotylidones of the caruncles; and the convexe ide of the caruncles, which adhereth to the Conception, may be divided from it; but the Concave part, or root rather, or talk, ticketh fat to the Uterus. But in other matters, the office is alike in all, and they have the like Acetabula, and an Albugineous gelly may in like manner be milked out of them, as out of thee caruncles of Cowes alo.

Where there is but one ingle foetus in a Conception, there that foetus doth tranmit his Umbilical Veels to all the caruncles of both the Horns of
the womb, that o he may derive nutriment from both. But that Horn wherein the foetus himelf (wimming in the crytal water which lies within the coat called Amnion) doth reide, is larger then the other. But where there are two foetus in one and the ame Conception, there each of them are confined to their proper caruncles, and do tranmit their Umbilical Veels into their own proper Horn only, and receive their Nutriment from thence.
If it be a Male foetus, the Teticles are large (for it's time) hanging without in the Scrotum. If an Ewe-lamb, the Udder hanging in the ame place, hath litle Tets or Nipples, as Womens Breats.

In the twofold tomack of the foetus (namely, the Maw and the Dew-lap) there appeared a crytal water like to that where he wam; for they did agree both in colour, ent, tate, and conitence: there was alo in the upper Guts a ubtance like to chyle; in the lower, a green excrement, and dry dung, uch as they ue to eject when they graze: the Liver was omething large, and the Bladder of Gall of an oblong figure, and in ome of them it was quite empty.

But as to the order of the production of the Parts, we have till found the ame to be oberved in all Viviparous Embryo's whatoever, as Experience hath revealed to us in that of the Egge, the Hinde, and the Doe.

div.head: Of the Innate Heat.
EXER. LXXI.
div.p:
BEcaue there is much talk of the Calidum Innatum, or Innate Heat, we do intend in this place (by way of econd coure, or addition) to dicoure a while concerning both it, and the Humidum Primigenium, the Radical or Primigenial moiture; and that the rather, becaue I perceive many men to pleae themelves much with thoe two Notions, when as (according to my judgement) they do not undertand their meaning. The truth is, there is no need at all to enquire after any kinde of pirit ditinct from the Blood it elf, or to introduce any forraign heat, or invoke the Deities to appear in the fable, and o trim up Philoophie with vain opinions and fictions; for what we commonly derive from the Starres, is bred and born at home, and within us. For the Blood alone is the true Galidum Innatum, or firt-born Animal heat: as it is made apparent by our obervations concerning the Generation of Animals; (epecially of the Chicken out of the Egge) and therefore to multiply Entities, is meerly frivolous. For, indeed, there is nothing either before, or more excellent in the Animal body, then Blood; nor are thoe pirits which ome men ditinguih from Blood, any where to be found a part from the blood; and the Blood it elf, without pirit and heat, is no longer to be called Blood, but Gore. The Blood,
De part. an. l. 2 c. 3. aith Aritotle, is in a manner hot, and in uch a manner, as it hath the eence of Blood in being hot jut as if we hould expres Hot water under one word: but
yet being conidered as the ubject of Heat, and uch a ubtance, as when it is in being, is Blood, o it is not hot: for it is in ome repect hot per e, or eentially, & in ome repect it is not hot per e; for Heat is of its eence, as Whitenes is of the eence of a white man: but for amuch as it is blood, in relation to Action or Paion, o it is not calidus per e, or eentially hot.

We Phyitians call that Spiritus, a Spirit, which Hippocrates called Impetum faciens, that is, whatoever doth attempt any thing proprio conamine, by its own proper endeavour, and doth et upon any action, or excite any motion with agility and vehemence: and under that capacity, the pirits of Wine, or of Vitriol, are called pirits. And hereupon Phyitians count as many pirits, as principal parts, or operations; namely, Animal, Vital, Natural, Viory, Auditory, Concoctive, Generative, Implanted, Influent Spirits, &c. But the Blood (the primogenit and principal part of the Body) is furnihed with all thee repective qualities, and endowed with active power beyond all other parts of the body, and doth therefore deerve the name of a pirit
< in non-Latin alphabet > .

Scaliger, Fernelius, & others, having not throughly conidered the excellent endowments implanted in the Blood, have phanied other Aerial or Aetherial pirits, compoed of an Aetherial and Elementary ubtance, to be a more excellent and diviner Innate heat then blood; which they conceited to be the mot immediate intrument of the Soul, mot proportionable to all its operations: grounding their opinion upon this opinion; namely, that the Blood (as being a ubtance compounded out of the Elements only) cannot perform any action beyond the phere or activity of the Elements, and uch bodies as are framed out of them. Hereupon
they feigned a ditinct pirit, and innate heat, which is of a celetial extract; namely, a mot imple, mot ubtle, mot thin, wift, lucid, and aetherial ubtance, partaking of a fift eence. But yet they have no where demontrated that there is any uch ubtance, or that it doth act beyond the power of the Elements, or execute greater things then the Blood alone is able to accomplih. But we, who examine the nature of things according to ene, have never dicovered any uch ubtance. Nor are there in the Body any receptacles deigned to the conervation, or generation of uch matters, and they themelves alo have not aigned any. Feruelius, indeed, aith, That whooever hath not yet attained to the knowledge of the ubtance and condition of the Innate Heat, mut firt conider the tructure of our bodies, and then addres himelf to the arteries which are eated in the cavity of the Heart, and to the Ventricles of the Braine; which when he hall dicover void and empty, and without any humour contained therein, yet can be not imagine that uch worthy matters are made by Nature rahly, and to no ue: and upon this conideration, I conceive, he will preently conclude, that while the Animal was alive, they were replenihed by ome thin Aerial ubtance, which when the animal Soul departed, being exceeding light, did inenibly vanih. Now, to upport this ubtance, the faculty of Inpiration is betowed upon us, which doth not onely coole the body (for that might be derived to us by other meanes) but alo adminiter a kinde of nourihment. But we affirm, that (o long as the Animal is alive) the Arteries & Ventricles of the Heart, are filled with blood; reputing the Ventricles of the Brain, to be too mean intruments for o noble a work, conceiving them rather allotted to the reception of excrements. For, what
hall we ay of thoe everal Animals, whoe Brain hath no Ventricles at all? And though we hould admit, that a kinde of Aire or vapour may be there found (becaue Nature doth decline a vacuity) yet that that ubtance is of a celetial extract, and heir apparent to uch excellent performances, hath no emblance of truth at all. But that which we mot admire, is, How this o exquiite, o divine a Spirit, hould be utained and fed by our common elementary aire? epecially, ince themelves aure us, that none of the Elements can perform any thing beyond their own abilities.

Thee men do likewie confes, that the pirit is in continual declenion, and quickly diipated, and corrupted, and that it could not ubit one moment of time, were it not repaired by the plentiful acceion of outward aliment; and that therefore like the Primum Vivens, the firt particle inpired with life, it mut continually be fed. And now what need of this forraign guet, this Innomate Spirit, or etherial heat? Since the blood is of ability to execute whatoever is attributed thereunto; and ince thee pirits cannot recede from the blood, (without their diolution) Nay they do not move any whither, or ininuate themelves into any part (as ditinct bodies) without the company of the blood. For whether you conceive them to be framed, nourihed, and increaed out of the thinner part of the blood, (as ome imagine) or out of the primigenial moiture (as others) yet all confes that they are no where to be found out of the blood, but that they continually cleave to the blood, as to their upport (as the flame cleaveth to the oyle in the lamp.) And therefore their tenuity, ubtlety, and mobility, &c. are of no more ue then the blood, whoe ineparable companions
they are. So that the blood is ufficient, to become the proportionate and immediate intrument of the Soul; becaue it is every where preent, and doth fly to and fro with an admirable agility. Nor are there any other bodies, or pirital incorporeal qualities, or any diviner heat to be allowed of, (as lux & lumen, the Light, and Shine) as Caear
Dictato. 7. Cremoninus (a man excellently vered in Aritotles Philoophy) doth olidly contend againt Albertus.

If thee men pretend, that thee pirits do reide in the primigenial moiture, as in the lat Aliment, and from thence ininuate themelfs into the whole body, thereby to nourih all the parts; they then conclude upon an impoibility, namely that the Calidum Innatum the Innate Heat, which is the primigenial part of the body (and tands it elf in need of utenance) doth nourih the whole body. For upon this account, the ame thing is both the thing that is nourihed, & alo the thing by which it is nourihed; and the elf ame ubtance, under the ame repect, hould both feed it elf, and be fed alo, which is indeed impoible: for in probability the thing which doth feed, and the thing which is fed, are not o much as mixed together: for micible things mut be of equal power, and operate one upon the other. And Aritotles poition is, Ubi nutritio, ibi nulla mitio et, Where there is Nutrition, there is no Mition. For whereoever Nutrition is, there the Aliment is one thing, and the thing nourihed another; and a neceity of the tranmutation of the one into the other.

But whereas they conceive that the Spirits, and the lat or primigenial Aliment, or ome other thing what ever it be in an Animal, can (more then the blood) operate above the power of the Elements; they eem not to undertand what it is to operate
above the power of the Elements: nor do they rightly interpret that place of Aritotle, where he De gen. an. l. 2. c. 3. aith: Every vertue or faculty of the Soul, eemeth to partake of another ubtance, and that more divine then thoe ubtances which are called Elements. And likewie where he aith, There is a certain thing in the eed of all things, cauing them to be fruitful, which thing is called heat, which is not fire, nor no uch faculty, but a pirit which is conteined in the eed and frothy body, and the nature which is in that pirit is anwerable in proportion to the Element of the Stars For fire doth not generate any Animal, nor doth any thing eem to be contituted by thick, moit, or dry qualities. But the heat of the Sun, and of Animals, not that onely which is conteined in the eed, but alo whatoever excrement there be, though of a different nature yet even that alo hath a vital principle. Wherefor it appeareth by what hath been aid, that the hea • conteined in Animals, neither is it elf fire, nor doth take its original from fire. For I alo do affirm the ame of the Innate Heat, and of Blood, namely that they are not Fire, neither do they take their original from fire, but do partake of a different, and more divine ubtance then fire is, and therefore do not act by any elementary faculty; but as in the eed there is omething which doth make it fruitful, and exceeds the vertues or powers of the Elements in contituting an Animal body; namely the pirit and the nature which is in that pirit, anwerable in proportion to the element or ubtance of the Stars.

So likewie in the Blood, there is a pirit or virtue, which doth act above the power of Elements (mot conpicuous in the nutrition or preervation of each particular part) and alo a nature, nay a oul in that pirit and blood anwerable in proportion
to the Element of the Stars. And latly, it is mot evident, and my obervations do plainly hew it, that there is a Heat in the Blood of Animals (whilet life continueth) which is neither fire, nor doth derive its original from fire.

But for the clearer illutration of thee matters, give us leave to digres a while from our purpoe, and declare briefly, what a pirit is, and what it is to act above the power of Elements, and likewie what is meant by thee words, namely, to partake of a different body, and that more divine, then thoe bodies which are called Elements: as likewie what is that nature in that pirit which is anwerable in proportion to the element or ubtance of the Stars. What A Spirit, and Vital principle is, we have partly poken already, and hall now handle omething more largely. There are three everal (imple) bodies, which do chiefly eem to challenge the name, or function at leat of a pirit; namely, the Fire, the Aire, and the Water; and every one of thee doth eem to partake of a life, or other body, by reaon of their perpetual motion and flux; (I mean) the Flame, the Wind, and the Floud. The Flame is the Flux, or Stream of Fire, the Wind of Aire, and the Flood of Water. Flame like an Animal, doth move it elf, nourih, and increae it elf, and is an Embleme of humane life. And therefore it is much ued in divine Ceremonies: and was religiouly kept (as a acred thing) in the Temples dedicated to Apollo, and Veta, by Virgins; and amongt the Perians, and divere other Nations, it was from all Antiquity honoured with divine worhip. As if God were more viible in Fire, and did convere with us, (as heretofore with Moes) out of the Fire. The Air alo eems to merit the name of a pirit too, for a pirit is called piritus a
pirando, from breathing; and Aritotle confeeth in plain tearms, that there is a kind of life and death of Winds. And latly, the Water of the Flood
De gen. an. l. 4. c. ult. or River, is called Viva, living Water. Thoe three bodies therefore (in as much as they enjoy a kind of life) do eem to operate above the power of Elements, and o partake of a diviner body or ubtance, and hereupon were by the Heathen ranked amongt the gods, who conceived that whatoever did perform any eminent effects, which did urpoe the naked abilities of the Elements, thoe effects did proceed from ome diviner Agent. As if it were the ame thing, to act above the power of the Elements, and to partake of a more divine eence, which did not deduce it elfe from the Elements.

Thus in like manner the Blood doth act above the Power of the Elements, when now being the Primogenite part, and Innate Heat (as it is in the Seed, and in the Spirit) it doth contitute the other parts in order; and this with an eminent providence and undertanding, acting in order to a certain end, as if it did exercie a kind of Ratiocination or dicoure. For it doth not thee offices as as it is Elementary, and deriveth its original from Fire, but in as much as it is made the Primigenial Heat, and mot immediate and convenient intrument of life it elf, by being impowred by the Platical virtue, and function of the Vegetative oul
< in non-Latin alphabet > , the Blood is the Vegetal part of Man, aith Suidas, which is true alo of all other Animals. And Virgil eemeth to have intended as much, where he aith:

l.hi:
—Unâ eâdem
que viâ angui
que Animu
que equuntur:

div.p: The Blood therefore is a Spirit, in regard of its excellent power and virtue; and alo celetial, becaue the Soul is an Inne-mate in that pirit, which Soul is of a nature anwerable in proportion to the Element of the Stars; that is, omething which beareth an Analogy to the Heavens, as being the Intrument and Deputy of the Heavens.

And o in this manner, all natural bodies fall under a double conideration; namely, as they are conidered, in their private capacity, concluded within the bounds of their own proper nature; or ele, as they are the Intruments of a nobler Agent, and uperiour power. For being conidered in their own proper abilities, it is perhaps no quetion, but that being all ubject to generation and corruption; they do derive their original from the Elements, and act according to their rule: but being conidered as they are the Intruments of a more worthy Agent, and regulated thereby, they do not now act of themelves, but by the guidance of another; and thereupon eem to participate of another more divine Eence, and o exceed the power of the Elements.

So likewie the heat of the blood is an animal heat, inamuch as it is guided in its operations by the oul; and alo a Celetial heat, as being ubervient to the Heavens; and latly, a Divine heat, in that it is the Intrument of Almighty God: as we have formerly aid, where we alo did demontrate, that the Male and Female, are the Intruments of the Sun, the Heavens, and of God himelf, as being ubervient to the generation of Animals.

The Inferiour World, according to Aritotle, is o continuous to the Superiour Orbes, that all its motions and mutations do eem to borrow their original, and regulation from them. And truly in this World (which the Greeks call < in non-Latin alphabet > , from the beauty of its order) the inferiour and corruptible things are ubervient to the uperior and incorruptible: and yet they all are obedient to the will of the Almighty and Eternal Creator.

They therefore who conceive that in a body compounded of the Elements, it cannot act beyond the power of the Elements; except it do alo participate of another more divine body; and upon that ground, do uppoe thoe Spirits whereof they treat, to be contituted partly out of the Elements, and partly out of a certain Aetherial and Celetial ubtance, do eem to have built their reaons upon a very hallow foundation. For you can hardly finde out any Elementary body, which doth not in its actions urpas its own proper power. Not to eek farre for an intance, which is every where obvious; the Aire and the Water, while they carry hips to the farthet Indies, and round the world; (and many times alo into contrary parts) while they Grinde, Bake, Sift, drain deep Wells, cut Timber in under, kindle fires, bear up ome things, and overwhelm others, and perform many other innumerable and wonderfull offices, do they not eem to act above the power of Elements? So alo Fire; how many, and how trange employments doth it undergo? viz. in the Kitchen, and alo in the Shops of uch as deal in Mettles, and in the Chymits furnace, by ub
••• ation, fuion, concoction, corruption, coagulation, and infinite other ues. What hall we ay of it, when Iron it elf is produced by its aitance,

When the Load-tone (to which Thales did therefore acribe a Soul) draws Iron unto it, and that Mettle which ubdueth all oppoers, (as Pliny peaketh) L. 36. c. 16. purueth after I know not what vanity; and the Needle alo being only touched by this Loadtone, doth till direct it elf towards the Poles of the world. When our Clocks do faithfully trike all the houres both of Day and Night, do they not eem to partake of another Body, (beides the Elements) and that more divine then the Elements? Since then uch excellent Operations are produced by the dominion and way of Art; which operations do farre exceed the power of the Materials themelves; what hall we then think may be produced by the precript and regiment of Nature, whom Art doth onely imitate? And if they effect uch wonderfull things in obedience to Men, what performances may we expect from them, when they are intruments in the hands of God himelf.

In hort therefore, this ditinction is neceary, namely, that no Primary or firt Agent, doth act any thing beyond its own power: but every Intrumental Agent, doth exceed its own power; for it acts not onely by its own power, but alo by the virtue of the uperiour efficient.

They therefore which deny uch eminent endowments to the blood, and flye up to Heaven to fetch down I know not what Spirits, to whom they may acribe thoe divine operations: they do not know, or at leat do not conider, that the work of Generation (and of Nutrition alo, which is indeed a Species of Generation) for whoe ake
they attribute uch notable prerogatives to thoe Spirits, doth much exceed the power of thoe pirits themelvs: & not of thoe pirits only, but even of the Vegetal Soul, nay of the Senitive, & in a word, of the Rational oul her elf, and not the power only, but the very apprehenion of the Rational oul; for the Nature and Order of Generation, is truly admirable and divine, beyond the comprehenion and grap of our thoughts, or undertanding.

That it may therefore more clearly appear, that thoe eminent attributes which learned men betow upon the Spirits, and the Innate Heat, do belong to the blood alone; Thee few following coniderations do offer themelves, over and above thoe things, which are wonderfully evident in an Egge (before any rudiment of the Chicken appear) and alo in a perfect and adult Foetus. Namely, that the blood being conidered abolutely in it elf out of the Veins, as it is an elementary ubtance, and compoed of everal parts (namly, of erous, thin, cras, and concrete parts) is called Cruor, Gore, and doth poes a few onely, and thoe obcure abilities. But being in the veins, as it is a part of the body, and that alo an Animate, and Genital part, and the Immediate Intrument, and primary eat of the oul: and alo as it eemeth to partake of another more divine body, and is inpired with a divine animal heat; it is then endowed with excellent abilities, and anwerable in proportion to the element of the Stars. In as much as it is a Spirit, o it is the Fire, the Veta, the Houhold deity, the Calidum Innatum, the Sun of the Microcome, and Platoes Fire; not becaue (like ordinary fire) it hineth, burneth, and detroyeth: but becaue it doth conerve, nourih, and encreae it elf, by a free perpetuall motion. It
doth alo challenge the name of Spirit, in as much as it doth primarily, and before the other parts, abound with Radical moiture, which is the lat and neeret aliment thereof, and doth dipence and provide the ame utenance for all the ret of the parts; wherewith it elf is upported: namely while it doth nimbly dart it elf through the whole body, and nourih, cherih, and keep alive all the parts thereof, (which it elf doth firt frame, and adjoin to it elfe) after the ame manner as the uperiour Orbes (but epecially the Sun and Moon) do, by their continual motions, quicken and preerve the inferiour world.

Seeing therefore that the Blood doth act above the power of the Elements, and is inpired with uch notable virtues, being alo the Intrument of the Omnipotent Agent; no man can worthily magnifie and extol its wonderful and divine faculties. In it the oul doth firt, and principally reide, and that not the Vegetative oul onely, but the Senitive and Motive alo; it penetrates every part, and is every where preent; and that being taken away, the oul is preently gone: o that the blood eems to differ nothing from the oul; or ought at leat to be counted that ubtance, whoe act the oul is. For uch is the oul, that it is not altogether a body, nor yet wholly without a body; it comes partly from without, and is partly born at home: in ome ort it is a part of the body, and in ome the beginning and caue of all things which are contained in the Animal body; namely, nutrition, ene, and motion; and o conequently of Life, and Death alo: for whatoever is nourihed, doth alo live; and o on the contrary. Likewie whatoever is plentifully nourihed, is alo inlarged; but that which is too paringly nourihed,
doth diminih: that alo which is perfectly nourihed, doth continue in health, but that which is not, doth incline to dieaes. The blood therefore, as well as the oul, is to be reputed the caue and author, both of Youth, and Old Age, of Sleep and Waking, and of Breathing alo: epecially ince in Natural productions the firt Intrument doth contein in it elf the internal moving caue. And therefore it comes all to the ame reckoning, whether we ay, that the oul and the blood, or the blood with the oul, or the oul with the blood, doth performe all the effects in an Animal.

We ue, as perons that neglect the things themelves, to pay much reverence to the pecious names. The blood which is till at hand, and daily in our view, makes no great noie in our ears; but at the magnificent name of Spirits, and of an Innate Heat, we are trangely amued. But when once the vizour is plucked from before them, as our errour, o our wonder ceaeth. That miraculous Stone, rendered o venerable to Mizaldus by the commendation of Pipinus, did not onely fill him with admiration, but Thuanus alo: (who was an eminent Hitoriographer in his time) I hall here adjoin the Riddle it elf. I aw, aith he, a Stone which was lately brought hither to our King out of the Eat Indies, which Stone did dart forth light, and brightnes, after a wonderful manner, parkling and hining with o much incredible lutre, as if it were all burning, and in a flame. This tone doth by his rayes cattered into every corner, illutrate the ambient aire with o clear a hine, that the firmet ight is carce able to behold it. It is alo mot impatient of earth: for if you attempt to cover it, it doth of its own accord, with an impetuous violence fly upward.
All the Art of man cannot confine and hut it up into a narrow room, for it eemeth to be affected with free & open places onely. The infinite purity, and brightnes thereof, is not tainted by the leat pot, or blemih. It hath no certain hape or figure, but varieth, and is altered in an intant. And though it be mot faire and beautiful to the Eye: yet will it not endure to be touched: and if you attempt too long to handle it, and continue too obtinate in your reolution, it will michiefe you: as many in my preence have deerly found. And if any thing be by violence taken from it, it remaines for all that (which is very wonderful) nothing les then it was before. The tranger who brought it, addes farther to all this, that its virtue and power is exceeding ueful to undry emploiments, but will not dicover them without a great reward.

This travailer alo might have added to his decription, that this Stone is neither oft nor hard; that it puts on everal hapes and complexions, that it hath a continual trembling and palpitation, and doth like an Animal (though it be an Inanimate thing) daily devour great tore of food, converting it to its own nutriment and augmentation: and that he hath been told by men of good credit, that this Stone did long ago fall down from heaven, and is to this day the caue of Thunders and Lightnings; being ome times begotten by the refraction of the Sun-beams through the Waters.

Who can but admire o trange a Stone, and conceive les of it, then to be above the power of the Elements, and o to partake of another body, and of an etherial pirit, epecially when he finds that it is anwerable in proportion to the Element or ubtance of the un himelf. And yet if Fernelius
De abd. rer. cau. l. 2. c. 17 may be the Oedipus, all this is but a Riddle of the Flame.

In like manner, if I hould decribe the Blood under the veil and covering of a Fable, calling it the Philoophers tone, and diplaying all its endowments, operations, and faculties, in an aenigmatical manner; doubtles every body would et a greater price upon it, and believing it to act beyond the Activity of the elements, would acribe another and more divine body unto it.

div.head: Of the Primigenial Moiture.
EXER: LXXII.
div.p: WE have now adorned the Blood with the Title of Calidum Innatum; and do likewie conceive it proper, to dignifie the Colliquamentum Crytallinum, as we cal it (out of which the foetus, and its firt parts do immediately arie) by the name of Humidum radicale & Primigenium, the Radical and Primigenial moiture. For we meet with nothing in the Generation of Animals, to which this title doth upon better right belong.

We have tiled it the Radical moiture, becaue out of it the firt particle of the foetus, namely the Blood, and all the pot-genit parts do arie, as out of their Root; and do owne the ame, as the matter out of which they are procreated, ed, increaed and conerved.

We likewie call it Primigenial, becaue it is firt generated in the contitution of every Animal, and is as it were the foundation of all the other parts: as is evident in an Egge, in which after a hort time of Incubation, it doth approve it elf to
be the firt production of the implanted fructifying, and generative faculty.

It is likewie the mot imple, pure, and incere body imaginable: wherein all the parts of the Chicken do abide in potentiâ, but none, actu: nature eeming to have afforded to it the ame priviledge which men commonly acribe to the materiaprima, or firt Matter, for which all things pring; namely, to be capable of all formes, potentially, but to poes none, actually. So the Crytalline humour of the Eye, to the intent that it may be uceptible of all Colours, is it elf void of all: and in like manner the Mediums, or organs of each particular ene, are quite detitute of the qualities of enible things, or objects: namely the Organs of Hearing and Smelling, and the Aire which is ubervient unto them, are without all Sound or Odour: o likewie, the moiture of the tongue and mouth, is of it elf inipid. And upon this Argument chiefly doe they rely, who contitute Intellectum poibilem incorporeum, a Potential Undertanding which is incorporeal, namely, becaue it is uceptible of all formes without matter; and as the Hand is called Organum Organorum, the intrument of intruments, o they affirm that to be forman formarum, the Form of forms, having no matter at all, but being altogether Incorporeal, and therefore they aert it to be Poibilis, Potential, but not Paibilis, paible. And this moiture alo doth eem, if not the ame, yet proportionable to the lat Aliment, whereof Aritotle doth teach that the Animal Geniture or Seed is made. I ay the lat Aliment, which the Arabians call Ros, the Dew, wherewith all the parts of the Body are moitned and bedewed. For as that dew doth by farther condenation and adheion pas into the alible gluten,
or glewey ubtance, and Cambium, which is that ubtance which doth contitute the parts of the body: o on the contrary, in the firt generation and nutrition, out of the glutinous ubtance diolved and rarefied, is made a Dew: namely, out of the White of an Egge is the Colliquamentum framed; which is the radical moiture, and Ros primigenius, the primigenial Dew. Nay if there be any faith due to our obervations, the matter is the elfe ame in both; and that is a truth which all Philoophers conent in, and Phyitians do not dient, namely, that an Animal is nourihed by the ame thing whereof it is made; and augmented by that out of which it is generated. So that Ros nutritius, the nutritive Dew, doth differ from the Colliquamentum, or primigenial moiture, onely under the everal repect of that which is firt, and that which is after: in that this is concocted and made by the Parents, and that by the Foetus it elfe: and both the juices are the next and immediate aliment of the Animal: yet not the firt aliment; according to that aying, Contraria ex contrariis augeri necee et, Contraries are are necearily encreaed out of contraries; but the lat (as I have aid, and as Aritotle alo doth denote) according to that other aying, Similiae ex imilibus, Like are fed by like. And both thee humours doe tand in that proximâ potentiâ, that next or mot immediate capacity or potentiality, by which (all impediments being removed) they are ready of their own accord, or by the law of nature, to pas or be transformed into all the parts of the Body.

Which things being o, all the controveries which doe arie concerning the matter, and aliment of Animals, eeme to be eaily reconciled.
For whereas ome were of opinion, that the eed, or matter ejected in coition was deduced from all the parts of the body, and that therefore the child had the reemblance of the Parents imprinted in it, Aritotle aith thus: We mut be of a different judgement from the Ancients: for whereas they doe
De gen. an. l. 1. c. 18. own that to be the eed which is dicharged from the whole body; we conclude that to be the eed, which of its own inclination doth conduce to the contitution of the whole body: and whereas they call it a Colliquamentum, or melted ubtance, we rather tile it excrementum, an excrement; (but he had a little before aid, I call an excrement the reliques of the aliment, and a Colliquamentum, that which is eparated from the excrement by a praeternatural reolution:) for that which commeth lat to the parts, and is the excrement of that lat aliment, is in probability a like ubtance. As Painters have commonly ome remnant of thoe colours, which they have pent upon their Pictures: but now that which doth melt away and diolve, doth corrupt and degenerate. One Argument to prove that the excrement is rather the eed, then any colliquated matter, is this; namely, that thoe Animals which are of great growth, are les fruitfull; but little Animals are mot of all fertile. For there mut of neceity be more diolved matter in great Animals, but les excrement: for the tock of aliment is wated in the upport of a large bulk; and thereupon there is little excrement. Moreover, there is no place deigned by nature for the reception of that ubtance or matter which doth melt off from the body: but there is a place aigned to all the natural excrements: as for example, the Guts are intended for the excrements of the dry aliment; the bladder of urine for the moit; the tomack for the profitable or uefull excrements; and the Womb, the Genital parts,
and the Breats, for the Seminal: for unto thoe places they reort, and aemble themelves. Likewie by everal other arguments he proceedeth to maintain, that the eminal ubtance, out of which the Foetus is framed, is the ame with that which is provided for the nourihment of the parts. As if a man hould deire a little colouring from a Painter; urely the Painter would not crape off that colouring which he hath already laid upon his Picture, but afford him ome of that which remains, and this upernumerary taffe is of the ame nature with that which he hath expended upon his Picture. So likewie the Excrement of the lat Aliment, or the Reliques of that nutritious ubtance which is called Ros, and Gluten, is depoited in the Genetal parts: and this opinion is mot agreeable to the Generation of the Egges in the Hen.

Phyitians alo (who conclude that all the parts at the beginning are made out of eed, or perme, (and upon that ground call them permatical parts) do affirm that the eed is by the power of the Genital parts made out of the lat aliment (which they with Aritotle conceive to be blood) and o doth contitute the matter of the Foetus. It is indeed a plain cae, that the egge is produced by the Hen, and from her lat aliment (namely her Ros nutritius, her nutritive juice.) The White therefore of an Egge, or that primogenit, or rather antegenit colliquamentum, or melted ubtance, is to be reputed the truer eed of the Hen (though it be not ejected in coition, but provided ready before coition, or ele collected after it; (as hall be perhaps more largely declared, to be incident to everal Animals) which the geniture of the Male, doth according to Aritotle, coagulate.

Since therefore I plainly ee, that all the parts are fahioned and fed by this one moiture onely, (as the matter and firt root of all) and ince the fore-cited argument doth necearily conclude as much; I can carce refrain my pen from rebuking thoe that follow Empedocles and Hippocrates alo: (who will needs have all imilar bodies to be generated by the congregation of the four contrary Elements: (as being mixt bodies) and diolved or corrupted by their egregation) nor is Democritus and the Epicureans, who follow him, les blameable, who contitute all things out of the confluence of Atomes of different Figures. For it was their errour of old, and is a popular errour at this day, that all imilar bodies are framed out of heterogeneous or different bodies. For according to this opinion, had a man Lincous his eyes he could not dicerne any thing that were imilar, one in number, identity, and continuity: but there were nothing but an appearing union, and an aembly or heap made up of a congregation and certaine colligation of indiviible bodies: o that generation were nothing ele but an aggregation, and convenient poiture of everal parts.

But for my part, neither in the production of Animals, nor in the generation of any imilar body whatoever, (whether it were of the parts of Animals, Plants, Stones, or Minerals, &c.) I could never dicover any uch congregation, or any everal praeexitent micible bodies, which were to be united afterwards in the work of Generation.
