Nor (o far as I could ever yet perceive, or by any meanes oberve) are there any imilar parts which are firt contituted in their everal order, or exitence at the ame time together (as membranes,
fleh, fibres, gritles, bones, &c.) that o from them conioined together (as out of the Elements or firt rudiments of Animals) the organs or parts, and the whole entire animal hould at lat be framed; but as we aid before, the firt rudiment of the body is onely a imilar oft gluten, or tiff, ubtance, not unlike a permatical concernment, or coagulated eed: out of which (the decree of Generation going on) being changed, cut in under, or ditributed into everal parcels, as by the divine Mandat as we have aid, (let here be a Bone, there a Nerve, or a Mucle, here the Bowels, the receptacles of the Excrements, &c.) out of an inorganical ubtance, was made an organical: out of one, and that one being of the ame nature, were many things made, and thoe alo divere, and contrary: not by a kind of tranpoition, or local motion (as if by the virtue of the heat, there did arie a congregation of homogeneous, and a digregation of hetorogeneous bodies) but rather by a digregation of homogeneous parts, or bodies, then any compoition of heterogeneous.

And this do I believe to be oberved in every Generation; o that the Similary mixt bodies have not their Elements exitent in time before them, but are rather themelves in being before their Elements, (whether you undertand by Elements the Fire, the Aire, the Earth, and the Water, with Empedocles, and Aritotle; or the Salt, the Sulphur, and the Mercury, with the Chymits; or the Atomes with Democritus) as being in Nature more perfect then they. There are I ay mixt and compounded bodies, even in repect of time before any Elements, as they call them, into which they are corrupted and determine; for they are diolved into thoe elements rather in order to our apprehenion,
then really and actually. And therefore thoe bodies called Elements, are not before thoe things which are made and generated; but rather after them, and their Reliques rather then their Principles. Nor doth Aritotle himelf, nor any other Philoopher, demontrate that the elements do ubit apart, or are the Principles of imilar bodies.

Indeed Aritotle, where he goes about to prove, L. 3. de coelo. c. 31. that there are uch things as Elements, eems to waver in his judgement, whether he hould reolve that they were actually in being, or onely in potentiâ: and doth conceive that in natural things they are in potentiâ rather then actu: and therefore he affirms that there are uch things as Elements, out of the diviion, egregation, and olution of things. And yet that is but an infirme argument, namely, that natural bodies are generated or compounded firt out of thoe things, into which they are at lat diolved and corrupted: for by that argument, omethings hould be compounded of Glae, of Ahes, and of Smoak; (becaue we ee them reduced at lat into uch bodies) and ince Artificial Ditillation doth clearly demontrate, that o many everal Vapours or Waters, and thoe all of them of different Species, are extracted out of o many everal bodies; the number of the elements ought to multiply in infinitum. Nor doth any Philoopher ay, that the Bodies which are diolved by Art, and are called Sincere Bodies, and indiviible in pecies, are more ingle elements, then the Aire, Water, and Earth, which we perceive by Sene, and are obvious to our eyes.
But thee matters do properly relate to that part of Phyiology, which treateth of the Elements, and the Temperaments: where alo we hall dicoure more copiouly of them.

div.head: Of the Birth.
div.p: AFter the Generation, the Birth ucceedeth, by which the Foetus comming into the world, doth enjoy the outward Aire. Whereupon we conceive it convenient to peak omething concerning it. And therefore (with Fabricius) we hall conider the Caues, Manner, and Times of Birth; as alo thoe things which are precedent and ubequent thereunto.

Thoe things which are incident a litle before the Birth, and epecially to Women, preaging the approaching delivery, are in part the preparation and dipoition of the Childing Woman, whereby he may bring forth: and in part the cite, or proper poition of the Infant in order to the Birth.

As concerning the Poition, Fabricius aith, that it is of a conglobated and inflex figure, left the Foetus by his extream and eminent parts, might injure the
De form. Foetus c. 9. pag. 140. The Poition of the Foetus in the Womb. Womb, or the conteining membranes: and likewie that o he may be comprehended in the leer roome. But I am not of opinion that the foetus doth till oberve the ame cite or poiture of his members in the Womb, (for the fore-cited caues.) For he wimmeth in a water, and moveth himelf to and fro, he tretcheth himelf, now this way, and anon that, and o is variouly inflected, and tumbled up and down; in o much that ometimes being entangled in his own Navel-tring, he is trangely innared. True it is that all Animals, while they lye till and leep, do for the mot part draw in, and contract themelves, and direct themelves toward an Oval or Conglobated figure. So likewie Embryo's, which pas their time
mot in lumbers, do compoe their bodies in that poture wherein they are formed: (as being the mot natural, mot eaie, and mot advantagious for their leep.) And therefore the Infant in the Womb is commonly found, with his Knees drawn up to his Belly, his Thighs bent backwards, his Feet hanging down, and his Hands elevated to his Head, whereof the one is placed about his Temples or Ears, and the other at his Cheek; in which parts there are white pots dicovered in the skin, as being the ignes of his confrication: His Spine is bent round, and his Neck being inflected, his Head hangs neer his Knees. The Embryo is cituated with that poition of parts, wherewith we commonly apply our elves to ret, with his Head uppermot, and his Face directed towards his mothers Spine. But a litle before his Birth, his head being bent downwards, he dives towards the bottom, and the Orifice of the Matrix, (as if he were eeking his way out.) So Aritotle: All Animals
Hit. an. 2. c. 8. do naturally come into the world with their head formot; but thoe that lye cros, or come with their heels formot, are unnatural births. But yet this is not contant in all Animals, but according to their everal ite or poition in the Womb, o is their Birth various; as in Bitches, Sows, and other Multiparous Animals. And the Great-bellied Women know full well, that even the humane Embryo doth ometimes acquire a different cituation; when they find the Child kick ometimes above, ometimes below, and now on this ide, and at other times on that.

So alo the Matrix being neer delivery, doth The Matrix. bear down, groweth oft, and openeth its Orifice. The Waters alo as they commonly call them, are Gathered, that is, a certain part of the Chorion, in
which the fore-aid humour is conteined, doth uher in the Foetus, and lide down from the Matrix into the Vagina, or Sheath of the Womb: and the neighbouring parts alo are looened, and ready to ditend: alo the Articubation of the Holy bone, and the Share-bone to the Hanch-bone (which Copulation, or Articulation is by Synchondrois, or a gritly ligament) is o oftened and loened, that the fore-aid bones do eaily give way to the parting Infant; and by gaping open, do amplifie the whole region of the Hypogatrium, or Lower belly. And when thee things are in this condition, it is certain that the Birth is at hand. And that o the Foetus (like a ripe fruit) may come forth into the World, Nature makes this proviion of dilating the parts: as he likewie concocteth the Milk which is ent before into the Breats, that the Infant now ready to be born, may have his entertainment ready to wellcome him, being now to be uteined from without. And thee are the fore-runners of the Birth. Wherefore the Milk is counted amongt the chiefet ignes of an imminent birth: I mean uch Milk, which both for tore, plenty, and conitence, is convenient to feed the Child: which (according to Aritotle) is never o qualified but neer the time of the Birth, and therefore is never found before the eventh moneth.

Fabricius concludeth upon two queries, chiefly Gen. an. l. 4. c. 8. & l. 7. c. 5. pag. 141. in order to the Foetus: namely, how the birth is, and when? the lat whereof relates to the time of Bearing, the firt to the manner of the Birth it elf.

The times of bearing, are by Aritotle conceived De gen. an. l. 4. c. 4. & ult. to be various. There are, aith he, peculiar times of bearing to all kind of Animals, for the greatet part as long as they live: for the race of Animals which is
longer liv'd then others, mut of neceity be more durable. But the magnitude of the Animals is by him aigned as the chiefet caue of the variety of the times of bearing. For, aith he, the great fabrick, either of Animals, or any thing ele, cannot be eaily abolved in a hort pace: Wherefore Mares, and thoe Animals that are of kin to them, though they live but a horter time, yet they are longer in bringing forth: And therefore the Elephant (as they ay) is two years in her production, becaue of its exceive magnitude. But every Animal hath certain bounds of magnitude, which it cannot exceed: and therefore they have a definit matter, out of which they are made: he addeth moreover: But there is exceeding good reaon, why Animals do receive the dimenion or meaure of their times of ingravidation, generation, and their lives alo by certain Circulations. Now I call a Circulation, a day, a night, a moneth, a year, and all thoe times which are decribed by them, as alo the motions of the Moon: for thee are the common beginnings of Generation to all Animals: For it tands to good reaon that the Circulations of les principal things hould follow the Circulations of more principal. And therefore Nature hath defined or limited the generation and deceae of Animals, by their motions.
And as the Births of Animals do depend upon the Revolutions or Circuits of the Sun and Moon, o do their times of Coition, and bearing their young vary, and are either more prolixe, or breifer.

The time of going with young (aith Aritotle in the ame place) is enormous onely in Women. For all other creatures have ome one time, but a Woman hath everal, for a Child may be borne either the Seventh, or the Tenth moneth, and likewie in the moneths intervening
between the Seventh and the Tenth: For they that are borne in the Eighth moneth, though they do eldom live, yet they may live. Divere Animals have indeed a et time of bringing forth, and pecially in the Spring, when the Sun returnes; divere in the Summer, and ome in the Autumne, as the Gritley Fihes. And hence it happens, that when the time of bringing forth approacheth, they direct themelves to their wonted places, where they may afely build their Stalls, or Nets, where they may bring forth, cherih, and utaine their young.

Hence it is that thoe Winds which blow about the beginning of the pring, are called, Or
• ithiae, namely from the comming or flocking in of the Birds, which about that time, do by the help of thoe Winds arrive at certain uual places. And Fihes alo which wim in Shoals many hundred thouands together, do conpire to meet in uch particular parts, and at uch et times, to pawn and cherih their fry.

And likewie in the Spring, o oon as ever the Cankerwormes do appear, (whoe eeds are for the mot part carried about by the Winds like inviible Atomes; and are not begotten as people commonly believe, either of their own accord, or out of putrefaction) the trees do preently hoot forth their buds, which are to become the utenance of thoe creatures: and they themelves alo are purued by mall Birds, and conducted into their Nets to be devoured by their young.

So that whenoever we ee unuual kinds of thee Canker-wormes, we do likewie meet with everal orts of forraign litle birds, which are eldom een at other times, (as if thee Birds did
<2 pages missing>
Son ued for the Inheritance, did cat him in Law though his Mother did affirm that the eldet Son was born in the thirteenth moneth: becaue there eemet to be no certain time allotted for bringing forth. There was a Woman not long ince amongt us, which kept a Child within her above ixteen moneths, and perceived him to betir himelf in her Womb above ten monethes (as many did evidence) and ye • at lat he brought him forth alive. But, I confes thoe are rare accidents. And therefore Spigelius doth reprechend Ulpian the Lawyer without caue in that he admits none to be legitimate Heires tha • are borne after the tenth moneth. For Lawes and rules of Art, are for the mot proportioned o • fitted to the actions of life, which are rightly ordered.

Beides, it mut not be denied, that there are many crafty, fraudulent Women, which for lu ••
Hit. an. l. 7. c. 4. cre ake, or for fear of punihment or infamy, wi •• feign and wear that they are with Child. And likewie it is well known, that others are eaily deceived, and being inexperienced in the matter do conceive themelves to be with Child, when it is no uch thing. And to this purpoe are thoe words of Aritotle. The conception of thoe Infants which are borne after the eleventh moneth eemeth to have not been exactly known to the Women who are with Child, for the women do not know when they firt conceived. For their Wombs being poeed with flatulencies, and they afterwards conceiving a Child upon Coition, conceive that flatulency to have been the firt beginning of their conception, becaue they then had ome uual indications, as do accompany uch as do really conceive. And we have alo a • other times known, that after three, or four moneths pace, the former conception dying in
the Womb, and putrifying, and the corrupt matter (like to putrid after-purgings) flowing forth, a Superfoetation hath happened: and yet the ame Women have contantly affirmed that they have been delivered of a Child after the fourteenth moneth. It falleth out ome times, aith Aritotle, that after one Abortment, tenne or twelve ucceeding Ibid. Infants which have been conceived by a uperfoetation, have fallen from the Mother. But if the Mothers have been delivered in ome hort time after, they have brought forth that Child which was begotten by a uperfoetation: and o they bring them forth, like thoe children which are born Twinnes: As the Fable runs of Iphicles and Hercules. And this hath been already found to be o. For a certain Adultres brought forth two Children, one like her own Husband, and the other like the Adulterer. And likewie a certain Woman a long while ince, having Twinnes within her, did conceive a third Child alo, o that when the time of her delivery was fully come, he brought forth the Twinnes in their jut time, and they were perfect: but the third was but of five moneths time, and o he died intantly.

A certain Servant-Maid being gotten with Child by her Mater, to hide her knavery came to London in September, where he Lay in by tealth: and being recovered again, returned home: but in December following, a new birth (for he had a Superfoetation) did proclaime the crime which he had cunningly concealed before.

It happened to another Woman (as Aritotle proceedeth) that when he had brought forth one Child in the eventh moneth, he was after two moneths end, delivered of two more, whereof the firt Child died, but the Twins urvived. Likewie ome Women that have uffered abortment, have conceived two Children at
the ame time, whereof the one hath been aborted before the time, and the other hath continued the full time, and been brought forth perfect.

For it is an eaie matter, that the firt, or lat Conception which is conceived by a Superfoetation; being ejected after the third or fourth month, the following moneths may be reckoned more or les then they ought to be, epecially by credulous or unskilful Women.

I have ometimes known the Conception to perih in the Womb, and being turned into Putrid Matter, to have glided and iued forth: (like the flores albi) and this both in Women and other Animals. There was not long ince a Woman in London, which after uch a kinde of Abortment did conceive again; and was delivered at the jut time. But a litle after, as he went about her worke, being not in any great paine, or ditemper, he did eject by peices the black litle Bones, which related to her former Abortment. Some of thee Bones were brought to me, which I could dicover to be the fragments of the Spine, the Bone of the Thigh, and of other Bones.

I know a young Woman, who was the Daughter of a Phyitian, who was of my neer acquaintance, which being Big, felt all the Symptomes incident to Women in that condition; and continuing healthy and prightly, after the fourteenth week he perceived the motions of a Foetus in her Womb; and having finihed her time for going with Child, conceiving the hour of her delivery to be nigh at hand, he had her Bed furnihed, her Cradle ready, and all the implements appertaining to the purpoe laid out for ue. But all thee preparations came to nothing, and Lucina
was cros to her wihes; for her cutomary paines quite left her, and her Belly as it roe by degrees, o it unk againe, and hee never icke for the matter, but he remained barren ever after.

I alo knew a noble Matron, who had borne above ten Children, and whoe Coures were never uppreed unles he were with Child. But being afterwards married to another Husband, beides other uual ignes, he apprehended her elf to be with Child, by the tirring of it (which both he her elf, and her Siter alo, who then lay with her in bed, did many times in the night perceive) and all the Arguments I could ugget, could not remove that perwaion from her: till at the lat, all her hopes vanihed into flatulency and fatnes.

So that ometimes, the mot approved ignes of Ingravidation, have not onely deluded the illy Women, but the experienced Midwives, and the skilful Phyitians themelves. Wherefore, ince beides the deceits of Women themelves, there are everal fale Indications of Gravidation, we mut not rahly determine of the Inordinate Birth, before the Seventh Moneth, or after the Eleventh.

The ordinary Computation of going with Child, oberveth that time which our bleed Saviour, the perfectet of all men, did fulfil in the Virgins Wombe: namely, from the day of the Annunciation, which is in March, to that bleed day of the Nativity, which we celebrate in December. And according to this Rule, the Sager Matrons keeping their account (while they cat in the wonted day in every moneth, whereon they were accutomed to have their purgations) they
are eldom out of their Reckoning; but, ten Revolutions of the Moone beeng expired, they are delivered, and reap the fruit of their Wombe, upon that very day whereon (were it not for their Praegnation) their Purgations would enue.

As concerning the caues of the excluion or delivery of the Foetus, Fabricius, beides that given De uu part. l. 15. c. 7. by Galen (wherein he delivers, That the Foetus is o long continued in the Wombe, till being now enlarged and made perfect, he is capable of being utained at the mouth: by which argument, the weaker orts of Foetus ought to protract their continuance in the Wombe, which yet is no uch matter:) conceives the other reaon, and that the more rational one too, to be the neceity that the Foetus tandeth in of more large refrigeration procured by repiration: becaue the Foetus, o oon as it is borne, doth preently repire, but doth not o oon feed. And this (he affirmeth) is not onely obervable in Men and Beats, but chiefly in Birds: which though they be mall, and have yet but a tender bill, yet will the Chickens peck that part of the hell, where they tand in mot need of repiration: which thing they doe, being more treightned for Breath, then Aliment: Seeing that immediately as oon they are ecaped out of the hell they doe repire, but abtaine from meat two or three dayes together.
But whether Repiration be intituted for Refrigeration, or for any other ue: we hall more largely debate elewhere, out of our Obervations.

In the mean time I hall propoe this Probleme to the Learned; namely, How the Embryo doth ubit after the eventh moneth in his Mothers womb? when yet in cae he were borne, he would intantly breath: nay he could not continue one mall
hour without it? and yet remaining in the womb, though he pas the ninth moneth, he lives, and is afe without the help of Repiration. I hall deliver it yet more plainly. How commeth it to pas, that the Foetus being now borne, and continuing yet covered over with his entire membranes, and abiding till in his water, can ubit for ome hours pace, without any danger of uffocation: and yet being hifted out of thoe membranes, if he have but once attracted the Aire into his Lungs, he cannot afterwards live a minute without it, but dyeth intantly? doubtles this is not for want of Refrigeration: for in a difficult Delivery, he ticketh fat in the treights without any¯ Repiration, ometimes for ome houres together; and yet we find him alive: but yet o oon as he hath ecaped, and tated the vital air, if you deprive him of it, you detroy him in a moment. So likewie in the Cearean Section the Infant is taken out of his Mothers wombe, many houres after his Mothers deceae, and yet he is found alive, and continueth afe, without the ue of Aire, though he lye intombed in the Secundines: but having once attracted the Aire, (though you intantly retore him to the Secundines againe) he will expire for want of breath. Whooever doth carefully conider thee things, and look narrowly into the nature of Aire, will (I uppoe) eaily grant, that the Air is allowed to Animals, neither for refrigeration, nor nutrition ake. For it is a tryed thing, that the Foetus is ooner uffocated after he hath enjoyed the Aire, then when he was quite excluded from it: as if the Heat within him, were rather inflamed, then quenched by the Aire.

But thus much we have dicovered by the way
concerning Repiration; being perhaps reolved to dicus the debate more fully in its proper place: then which diquiition you hall hardly meet with a more nice; for it is debated with Arguments of almot equall weight on both ides.

I return to the Birth, which Fabricius conceiveth to come to pas (beides the fore-mentioned neceity of Repiration, and want of Sutenance) becaue the Foetus being grown bigger, doth pres out by his weight; and alo can be no longer conteined within, by reaon of his large bulk; and likewie, aith he, the Excrements are o multiplied, that there is no longer place for them in the membranes. But we have already proved, that the humours in the Wombe are not Excrementitious. Nor is the reaon deduced from the Weight and Magnitude of the Foetus more available then the former: for the Foetus wimming aloof in the humours, is carce any burden at all to the After-birth or Womb; for ome Infants of nine moneths are very litle, and les then ome others of eight moneths onely, yet can they no longer ubit in the Womb. And as to the Weight, Twins of eight moneths do preponderate any one ingle Foetus whatoever, though of nine moneths abode in the Womb, yet are they not born till the nineth moneth. Nor can we quarrel at the carcity of Aliment: ince at that time there is entertainment enough even for Twins, and ometimes for more Infants: and alo the milk which is conducted to the Breats of Women in Child-bed, being recalled to the Uterus, would as conveniently upply the foetus in the Womb, as out of it.

I hall rather impute the caue of being born, to the juice conteined in the Amnion, which being
mot proportionate to the nourihing of the Foetus, doth either much faile, or ele is depraved by the admixture of the uperfluities. As I have alo hinted before.

But as for the diverity of going with Child, which is contrary to the time allotted by Nature (which diverity doth chiefly repect Women) I do acribe it to the cutome of living, the infirmity of the contitution, and the everal paions incident to Women. And therefore thoe tame Animals, which live amongt us, by reaon of their lazy lives, and plenty of food, are of more incertainty in their times of Coition, and production, then wild Beats, which live according to Natures intent. Likewie ickly Women have eaier and greater dipatch in their Travaile, then others: but it falls out clean contrary to uch Women, whoe trength is very much conumed. For the ame thing befalls them, as happeneth to Plants, whoe fruits and eeds, do more lowly and eldom arrive to maturity in cold Countries, then to other Plants of the ame kind which are in a fat and warm oile.

So Orenges in England adhere to the trees almot two whole years together, before they come to maturity: and Figgs alo carce ever arrive at any perfection here, which are ripe in Italy twice or thrice a year. And the like befalleth the fruits of the Womb; namely, the Foetus is brought to maturity ooner or later, by reaon of the carcity or plenty of Aliment, the imbecillity, or trength of the body, and the orderly or inordinate regiment of life (according to the ix non-naturall things recited by Phyitians.)

Fabricius hath decribed the Manner of the Birth, thus: The Womb being dilated by the weight
of the Foetus; in o much that it can now be no farther ditended, and thereupon being excited to diburden The manner of the Birth. it elf, is by the motion of the tranvere fibres gathered up into it elfe, and o contracted into a narrower compas. And therefore, whereas before, neither the Excrements, by means of their abundance, nor the Foetus by reaon of his weight could be conteined any longer, the Uterus being more treightned and drawn together then it was, can be much les able to contein them, and therefore firt the membranes as being the weaker parts, and more ditended, do break, and the humour which is mot fluxile, doth firt pas out to make the parts glibbe. And hereupon the Foetus followeth, as being not onely increaed in his weight (by reaon that he now no longer wimmeth in the humour) and o decendeth downwards, forcing the Orifice of the Womb, but as being alo compreed, driven forward, and hut out by the action of the Womb itelfe: in which act on, the mucles of the Abdomer, together with the Midriffe, are wonderfully aitant.

By which words he decribes the ejectment of the Excrements of the Guts, and an Abortion rather, then a Natural Birth: for though the membranes in Women do for the mot part break, and o diload the Water before the Birth; yet that is not always o: for other Animals do not bring forth as they do, but produce the Entire Conception together, (namely the foetus together with the Secundines) as we may oberve in Ewes, Mares, Bitches, and other Animals: and epecially in the Viper, which doth conceive within an Egge which is of one onely colour, having a oft hell (uch as the humane conception is) and continueth that Conception o long within her, until a foetus be formed thereout, which he doth produce wrapped
up in a membrane, which membrane (according to Aritotle) is broken up the third day. And yet it o happeneth, ometimes, that the young Hit. an. l. 5. c. 34. ones are produced, having eaten through the membranes, (while they are yet in the Uterus.)

And o alo it is no novelty to experienced Midwives, that their Women do ometimes bring forth their Conceptions whole, and entire, without any breach in the Membranes at all. And this kind of birth eemeth to me the mot Natural; wherein the foetus (like a mellow fruit which droppeth from the tree, without haking out its eed before the time aigned by nature) is born with the Secundines embracing it. But, where it cometh otherwie to pas, and the After-burden doth adhere to the Uterus after the Child is borne: it is oftentimes hardly divided from it, and doth induce evil Symptomes, which are accompanied with noiome mells, and ometimes with a Gangreen, whereby the Mother is brought into imminent danger.

Becaue therefore the Birth decribed by Fabricius, is not agreeable to all kinds of Births, but onely to Women, and not to all their Births neither, but to uch onely whoe Births are premature, and as it were forced: it is to be ranked rather amongt preternatural, precipitate, and in ome ort abortive productions.

In a Natural and Genuine Birth, therefore, two Two things required in a Natural Birth. things are required, which are aitant the one to the other, that is to ay, the Woman in travaile, and the Foetus which is to be produced. Both which, except they be ripe for the buines, the Birth is hardly uccesful. For if the Foetus being diquiet, and coveting to be enlarged, doe prevent his parent by exciting her, and offering
violence to her womb: or if the Mother, by reaon of the infirmity of her retention, (as if her womb were diturbed with a kind of naueounes) or by ome neceity of expulion, be before hand with the Infant, the Birth is to be reputed a Dieae or Symptome, rather then a Natural and critical Production. As alo when ome parts of the conception ecape out, and others are til retaind within: namly, if the Foetus attempt a departure ere the After-burden be dimied from the ides of the Womb; or ele the After-burden, on the contrary, be looe from the Uterus, the foetus being not rightly compoed, nor the Uterus relaxed for the accommodation of the work. And therefore the younger, more giddy, and officious Midwives are to be rebuked; which, when they hear the woman in travaile, cry out for paine, and call for help; let they hould eem unskilful at their trade, and les buie then comes to their hare, by daubing over their hands with oyles, and ditending the parts of the Uterus, do mightily betirre themelves, and provoke the expulive faculty by medicinal potions: o that being impatient of a competent expectation, by their deire to haten and promote the Birth, they do rather retard and pervert it, and make it an unnatural and difficult delivery; and leaving the Membranes, or ome part of the After-burden till adhering to the Womb, they do both expoe the poor women to the injuries of the Aire; and vainly perwading them to their three-legged toole, weary them out, and bring them in danger of their lives. It is much happier with poor women, and thoe that dare not own their great bellies, where the Midwives help is never required; for the longer they retain and retard
the Birth, the eaier, and more uccesfull proves the delivery.

And therefore there are chiefly two orts of Unnatural Births; namely when the foetus is either born before, or after the time allotted by nature: (and this is a kinde of Abortive Birth) and the Birth proves difficult and painful, becaue it doth not ucceed in that manner, and order as it ought to do: or ele is hindered by ome bad Symptomes: which cometh to pas cheifly for two reaons: namely, in that the Mother doth faile in her expulive office, or ele that the Foetus is himelf but luggih, and o doth not promote his own releae: for a facile and natural delivery relieth upon the endavour and joint furtherance of both parties.

Fabricius doth acribe the work of bringing forth to the Uterus, to which performance, aith he, the Mucles of the Lower Belly, and the Midrifle are aitants. But when I conider the matter throughly, the throws of the woman in travaile do eem to proceed from the Motion and Agitation of all the Body, (jut as we find it in Sternutation.) I knew a young Woman, which by reaon of her extream torment in her travaile fell into a Sowne; and became intantly o conternated, tupid, and leepy, that nothing could recover her. I being called in to her cure (finding that Clyters, and other proper remedies had been applied to no purpoe, and that nothing could go down her throat) I put up a feather which was dipped in a trong Sneezing medicine, into her Noe; by which being moved (though he was o overwhelmed with a deep tupidity, that he could neither neeze, nor be awaked) he began to be eized by a kind of general Convulion, all her body over, which beginning
at the houlders, did by degrees extend it elf to the lower parts. But as often as I applied this provocation to her, her delivery was advanced and came on, and at lat, the Mother being inenible of it her elf, and remaining till in her leepy condition, a healthy and prightly Child was born into the world.

We may oberve the manner of their throwes, in other Animals: (as in the Ewe, the Bitch, and in great Cattel) wherein we hall dicover that it is not by the ole action of the Uterus, or Belly either, but is the joint conflict of all the whole body. And how much the Foetus doth conferre to the acceleration and facilitating of his owne Birth, is cheifly evident in Oviparous Creatures: for it is apparent that the Foetus it elf, and not the Mother, doth break through the hell. By which it is probable that in Viviparous births alo, the chiefet caue of being born is owed to the Foetus it elf, and that, to his indutry and indeavour, and not to his weight, as Fabricius conceiveth. For what doth the weight thereof conduce to the birth in four-footed beats which tand upright, or it down; or in Women which lye along? nor doth the endeavour of the foetus proceed, as he uppoeth, from its largenes of bulk, or the plenty of the water, (the Water indeed is the caue of the delivery of the foetus which is dead and putrified in the womb, in that by its corruption and acrimony it doth extimulate the Uterus to relieve it elf) but the foetus himelf ets open the Gates of the Womb with his head turned downward, and unlocks their incloure by his own force, and o truggleth himelf into the world by conquet: And therefore that kind of birth is counted the nimbler and more fortunate. But when the Child comes into the world
thruting his feet formot, aith Pliny, the birth is counted unnatural, and thoe that are o born are called
L. 7. c. 8. Agrippae, quai aegre parti, born with much difficulty: For their birth is low and painful. And yet notwithtanding in abortment, and where the foetus is dead, or that there would be a hard delivery any other way, o that there is neceity of handy-work in the buines, the more convenient way of comming forth, is with the feet formot; for by that means the treights of the Uterus are opened, as it were by a Wedge. Wherefore when the hope of delivery relieth chiefly upon the foetus, (as being trong and lively) we mut endeavour to further his comming out with his head fore-mot; but in cae the task is like to depend upon the Uterus, we mut procure his comming out with his feet fore-mot.

That the aitance of the foetus is chiefly required in the birth, is evident, not in Birds onely, which do by their own indutry without the help of their Parent break up the hell; but alo in other Animals; for all Flies, and Butterflies, doe perforate the litle membranes (in which they did lurk when they were the Worme Aurelia) and likewie the Silk-worm doth at his appointed time mollifie and erode the litle Silken bagge, which he had weaved for his defence and ecurity, and o gets out without any forraign aide. And in like manner, Waps, Beetles, and other Inects; and all Fihes, are borne without others helps; as doth chiefly appear in the Raie, the Fork-fih, the Lamprey, and all cartilagineous Fihes, which do conceive their Egges within themelves, and thoe perfect ones, and party-coloured, (being furnihed with a Yolk and White) and concluded in a trong cartilagineous quadrangular
hell: out of which being detained within the Belly and the Uterus, they do form their young; which breaking open the hell by force, do get abroad: as alo the young Vipers, by their eroion of the membrane which conteineth the Egge, do ometimes in their Mothers Bowels, and ometimes as they tick in the very paage, and other times at the end of two or three daies after their nativity, expoe themelves to the wide World. From whence that Fable, that the Vipers do eat their way through their Mothers bowels, and o revenge the death of their Father, took its foundation: When yet they do no more then all other iues which come into the world, breaking through the membranes which encompas them, either in their very Birth it elf, or a litle after it.

But how great furtherance the foetus doth conferre to its own Birth, everal obervations doe clearly evince. A certain Woman here amongt us (I peak it knowingly) was, (being dead over night) left alone in her Chamber: but the next morning an Infant was there found between her Leggs, which had by his own force wrought his releae. Gregorius Nymmanus, hath collected certaine examples of this nature out of approved Authors.

I alo knew a Woman, who had all the interiour part of the neck of her Womb excoriated and torne, by a difficult and painful delivery: o that her time of Lying in being over, though he proved with Child againe afterward, yet not onely the ides of the Orifice of the Neck of the Womb neer the Nymphae did cloe together, but all the whole Cavity thereof, even to the inner Orifice of the Matrix, whereby there was no entrance even
for a mall probe, nor yet any egres to her uual fluxes. Hereupon the time of her delivery being now arrived, the poor oul was lamentably tortured, and laying aide all expectation of being delivered, he reigned up her keys to her Huband, and etting her affairs in order, he took leave of all her friends. When behold, beyond expectation, by the trong contet of a very luty Infant, the whole tract was forced open, and he was miraculouly delivered; the luty Child proving the author of his own, and his Parents life, leaving the paage open for the ret of his Brethren who hould be borne in time to come. For, proper applications being adminitered, his Mother was retored to her former health.

I hall adde one example more memorable then this. The Queen had an exceeding white Mare, excellently haped, preented unto her: whoe genitall parts (let by going to Hore hee might endanger the beauty of her proportions, and become unfit for ue) were, as the cutome is, locked up all with iron rings. Notwithtanding which, this Mare (by what accident I cannot tell, nor could the Groomes inform me) was made big with Foale: and at lat, when they feared no uch matter, he foaled by night, and the Foale was found alive next morning by the mares ide. When I came to heare thereof, I went preently to the Stables, and aw both the labia of the lap, which were locked up with rings, and all the privity towards the left ide, o torne and dilacerated from the right haunch-bone, that the unity of that mot tight part being diolved, by the incredible force of the young Foale, hee might eaily finde a paage through that wide gap. So forcible is the vigour and efficacy of a mature and liuely Foetus.

But on the contrary, in cae the Foetus be ickly, and languihing, or borne before its time; it is not properly a birth, but an abortment: and the Foetus is rather ejected, then borne: and therefore though he be now ome dayes old, he will neither take the breat kindly, nor depoite his excrements as he ought to doe.

Fabricius doth propoe two things worthy admiration De form. foet. pag. 142. (as he aith) in the birth, and after it: the firt is concerning the dilatation of the Uterus in the Birth: and the other is, of the reduction of the Uterus after the Birth into its former compas and narrownes: Wondering that the womb hould be o much ditended to make way for the foetus, and that in a hort time after delivery, it hould retire into its pritine dimenion.

How the Neck of the Womb, which is thick, hard, and o hut up, that it will not admit a lender probe, hould ubcribe to o vat a ditention in the time of Delivery, We may with Galen De u. part. l. 15. c. 7. pag. 143. admire, aith he, but we hall never comprehend it.

Yet he gives this Reaon for it, namely That the Uterus, while it is not pregnant, is a thick and hard body, o likewie is its orifice; but being impregnated, it becomes oft and thin: and the nearer it drawes to delivery, o much the more is the ubtance, and by conequence its orifice too, made thinner, and ofter. And this he conceiveth to be effected by its ditention; which being ditended, its compact and complicated body (if he may o peak) is expanded and moothed, and o, though it was thick and hard before, yet now it is rendred thin and oft, and o conequently fit to afford an exit to the foetus. And afterwards he aith, There was one, who once enquired of me, how, if it be o indeed, it can be true that in women
with childe the orifice of the womb is o occluded, that not o much as a mall probe can get into it? I make anwer, that it came to be o, in that the womb while it is ditended, and is unfolded like a linnen cloth that is compacted and folded up together, doth begin to be raied up firt in its upper part, and there to be unfolded, and after it the lower parts do by degrees begin to ditend, till at the lat that ditending faculty doth arrive at the very orifice of the womb it elf; which is convenient to be o then, when the Uterus is inclining towards delivery. Wherefore the Orifice of the womb is deervedly hut for the firt months, (whilet it is cras and obdurate) but in the lat dilated. And thus much touching Galens unknown caue: we might alo adde other Reaons, whereby the dilatation of the womb becometh more eaie, as, uppoe, the Excrements of the Foetus, namely the Sweat and the Urine: which though they are contained in their own proper membranes and receptacles, yet may the power of Humectation arrive even unto this Orifice, epecially ince it is placed below, and neer to thee humours, being alwaies preent with them. Adde alo moreover, that a certain mucous and pituitous ubtance is alwaies found about the orifice of the womb.

But, in my opinion, this worthy man is mitaken; for the Neck of the womb is not hard by complication, but of its own eence, and nervous contitution: and likewie, thoe accidental Caues (which he alledgeth) are of litle advantage to this purpoe. For, doubtles, this is done by the Divine Providence of Nature (as well as the ret of the wonderfull Fabrick of the Body) which doth direct her workmanhip to a certain End, Action, and Ue. The Wombs contitution therefore is uch, that in the firt Conception it
hould have its nervous Orifice contringed, for retention ake, which afterwards in the delivery of the foetus (like the fruit in the Tree) doth of hard become oft and mellow, for the convenience of expulion: and that not from any unfolding, but from the alteration of its Temper; for even the connexion of the bones themelves, namely the Synchondrois of the Haunch-bone with the Share, and Holy-bone, & the ynneureis or natural union or coalition of the Rump, or utmot end of the Os Sacrum is diolved and mollified. It is indeed a wonderfull thing, that the litle bud of a growing Nut (as uppoe of the Kernel of an Almond, or other Fruit) hould break thoe bones which a Malet can hardly bruie: and that the tender fibers of the Ivy-root crawling along the narrow chinks or crannies of tones, hould at lat demolih large walls. But it is nothing o wonderfull, that the genital parts of Women which are relaxed in the birth, hould afterward harden, and draw themelves together, becaue it is natural to thoe parts; epecially if we conider that the Yard of the Male is in coition very much tretched, and hardened, and anon doth flagge, and often. We are more to admire (which is beyond all plicature or folding) that the ubtance of the Uterus is not onely dayly amplified and ditended, according to the growth of the foetus, (as if it were, according to the opinion of Fabricius, unfolded) but doth grow thicker, more carnous, and tronger then before. That indeed is more wonderfull; yet, as Fabricius admireth it, that the o large bulk of the Uterus hould in o few dayes pace, by the cutomary purgations of Child-bed, return to its pritine dimenions: ince it is not o in other
• umours and impotumations: which coniting of
praeternatural, and digetive faculties, which rebell againt the expulive, are longer under cure. And yet this is no more admirable, then the other works of Nature; for all things are filled with the Deity, and the God of Nature diplayeth himelf in all things.

In the lat place, Fabricius doth mot admire, that thoe Veels of the Embryo (namely the Oval perforation out of the Hollow-vein into the Venal Arterie, and the paage from the Arterial Vein into the Aorta; (whereof we have treated at large, in our Tract of the Circulation of the Blood) hould preently after the birth wither, and be obliterated, and is enforced to betake himelf to that reaon cited by us before out of Aritotle; namely, that all parts are contituted for ome Action ot other, De part. an. l. 1. c. 5. and that Action being taken away, the parts alo themelves do vanih. As the Eye eeth, the Eare heareth, the Braine perceiveth, the Stomack concocteth; not becaue they are endowed with uch a kinde of temper and fabrick; but thoe organs are therefore endowed with uch a kinde of temper and fabrick, that o they may perform the Functions aigned them by Nature.

By which argument it appeareth, that the Uterus is the chiefet of the Parts dedicated to Generation: for the Teticles are contituted for the geniture or eed; but the eed for coition; and coition it elf, or emiion of eed, that the Uterus may receive fecundity, and o generation enue thereby.

We have formerly aid, that the Egge is as it were the fruit of Animals, and as it were an expoed Womb. Now on the contrary, we hall contemplate the Uterus as an Egge reiding within. For as Trees, at et times, do flourih with leaves, flowers, and fruits: and Oviparous Animals
do ometimes generate eggs, and lay; but ometimes they grow emerit, and the place or part which did contain them is not to be found: o alo Viviparous Animals have their Spring, and Autumne. At the Seaons of fecunditie and generation, the Genital parts, epecially in Females, are very much altered: inomuch that the Ovary in Birds, which at other times is conpicuous, doth then appear omething turgid: and the Belly of Fihes, about the time of Spawning, doth much exceed all the ret of their body, by reaon of the multitude of their eggs, and affluence of their eed or pawne. In many Viviparous Animals, the Genitals (namely the Uterus, and Spermatical Veels) are perceived to be at ome times of a divere Contitution, Temper, and Fabrick; but as they grow pregnant, or forbear to be o, o do they diverly change; o that a man can hardly know them for the ame things. For as in Nature nothing is wanting, o there is no uperfluity. And therefore the Genital parts, when there is no more ue of them, do wither, are retracted, and as it were obliterated and expunged.

At the times of Coition, the Teticles are conpicuous in male Hares, and Moles, and the Hornes are then viible in the Uterus of their females. It were trange to relate, how great an affluence of eed is then conpicuous in the larger ort of Moles, and Mice, in which at other times no eed at all is to be een (but their Teticles are extenuated and retracted into their Bellies) but when they forgoe impregnation, there is hardly any uch thing as a Uterus to be perceivd: inomuch that it is a difficult matter to ditinguih Male from Femal.

The Womb doth, chiefly in Women, exceedingly
vary both in Temper, as alo in thoe Adjuncts which follow the Temper (namely Scituation, Magnitude, Figure, Colour, Thicknes, Hardnes, & Denity.) Unripe Virgins, as their Breats are no bigger then the Breats of Boyes; o is their Uterus very mall, white, of a skinny ubtance, detitute of Veines, and in magnitude, not exceeding the top of ones Thumb, or a large Bean. So alo antient Women, as their breats do ink, o have they a retreated, flaggy, lank, pallid Womb, void of Veins and Blood. Which I alo conceive to be the caue, why Women growing Antient have not their monthly Termes: but that they decend into the Haemorrhoides, or ele do abruptly forake them, and o endanger their health. But when the Womb is now chill, and as it were defunct, & all the Veins and Arteries thereof are expunged, the uperfluous blood, when it boileth, doth either retagnate, or divert its coure into the neighbouring Haemorrhoids. But on the contrary, in pale Virgins, and uch as have the Green icknes (whoe Womb is lender, and their Terms are at a tay) by Coition with the Male, aith Aritotle,
De gen. an. l. 3. c. 1. the excrement of the Terms is drawn down, for the Uterus being tepefied, doth attract the humours, and the paages are opened. Whereupon a vat abatement of their ditemper doth enue: for the Womb being unmindefull of his function, many michiefes do befall the Body in general: becaue the Womb is a principal part, which doth eaily draw the whole body into conent with it. No man (who is but never o litle vered in uch matters) is ignorant, what grievous Symptomes, the Riing, Bearing down, and Perverion, and Convulion of the Womb do excite; what horrid extravagancies of minde, what Phrenies, Melancholy Ditempers,
and Outragiounes, the praeternatural Dieaes of the Womb do induce, as if the affected Perons were inchanted: as alo how many difficult Dieaes, the depraved effluxion of the Terms, or the ue of Venus much intermitted, and long deired do foment. Nor is it les known, how great an Alteration doth befall Virgins, when their Uterus doth enlarge, and is tepefied, for they grow mature, and their Complexion doth improve; their Breats trut forth, they become more beautifull, their Eyes gliten, their Voice is more tunable, their Gate, Geture, and Dicoure, are more gracefull then formerly; and their more grievous Ditempers are at this time, or never, cured.

I knew a noble Lady, which was wilde by reaon of a Uterine Melancholy and Ditemper, for above ten years together: and when all Remedies had been in vain employed, he fell at lat into the Bearing down of the Uterus; which accident, contrary to others judgement, I did prognoticate would conduce to her health; and perwaded her not to return her womb, untill its ditemper was awaged by the outward cold aire: the ucces was anwerable to my perwaion, and in a hort time he was perfectly cured; and her womb being at lat retored to its eat, did remaine there, and he lives a healthy life, even to this day.

I knew another Woman, which was troubled with Hyterical ymptoms, uch as no Applications could ubdue; who at length after many yeares was cured by the Bearing down of the Womb. And both thee being relieved in their Symptoms, I did retore their wombs to their places with happy ucces. For the Uterus being by any harp humour excited violently to
expulion, doth not onely gently bear down, but (like unto the Right Gut when it is irritated by a troubleom Tenemus) doth precipitate it elf outward.

Divers therefore is the Contitution of the Uterus; and that not onely praeternatural, but natural alo, namely, in the time of Fecundity, and Barrennes. In young Girles, and Women pat Childing, it is (as I have aid) of the magnitude of a Bean, and without any blood: in a Virgin ripe for a husband, it reembleth the bulk and form of a Pear: in fruitfull Women, and uch as are apt to conceive, it is as large as a mall Gourd, or a Gooe-egge; and doth likewie well as the breats do, and growing more laxe and flehy, it becommeth warme; and as Virgil peaketh of the Fields,

q.l: They all a flowing moiture have,
And o a fruitfull eed do crave.

div.p: Wherefore their Terms being now at hand, or newly over, whilet the warmth and moiture of the Part (which are two neceary caues of Generation) do remain, Women are mot apt to conceive. And o other Animals likewie (when they are excited to Venery) their Genital parts are moit, turgid, and welled.

And this Contitution I have found in the Womb, before the Birth. But in Women with Child, the Uterus (as hath been aid) doth extend according to the growth of the Infant, and o enlargeth into a vat proportion. I have found it preently after Delivery, of the bignes of ones head, and
thicker then the middlefingers breadth, and fraught with divere veels full of blood. It is indeed a wonderful thing, and (as Fabricius noteth) doth much exceed our humane apprehenion, that the o vat bulk of the Uterus hould o much leen, in o hort a pace, namely in the pace of fifteen, or twenty days.

For no ooner is the foetus and the After-burden excluded, but the Uterus doth by degrees gather it elf together, treighteneth its Neck, and retreateth it elf towards the interiour parts; being partly inenibly abated by a diaphoreis, and partly diolved into the Purgations: and all the bordering parts, the bones, belly, and all the Hypogatrical region, are together contracted, and grow irme againe. In the Purgations, firt of all pure blood, then corrupt blood, like that Water wherein fleh that is newly killed is wahed, and then paler blood doth iue forth: our women doe call it lact is proventum, the coming of the Milke, when their purgations are now no longer died with blood; becaue perhaps, the Milk doth at that time flow more plenteous, and ound for the Infant, from the breats; and the purgations do then begin to diminih, and dry away: the alible juice being now tranlated from the Uterus to the breats.

And yet other Animals do not require o great trouble in the buines, for the fore-aid parts in them are, in the compas of a day or two, quite retored, and perfectly conolidated. Nay ome of them (as the Hare, and the Coney) in the pace of an hour after they have kindled, do admit the Buck, and are again fructified by Coition. As we have hewed that the Hen o oon as ever he hath layed, is compreed by the Cock. But Women alone,
as they onely have Termes, o do they abound with after-purgings, and do alone undergoe difficult and hazardous deliveries: becaue their Uterus doth either uneaonably gather it elf together, by reaon of weaknes, or ele the After-purgings are depraved contrary to nature, or do not come away kindly. For it often befalls Women (epecially the more tender ort) that the After-purgings being corrupted, and grown noiome within, do call in Feavers, and other grievous Symptomes. For the Womb being excoriated by the eparation of the After-burden (epecially if the eparation were violent) like a large inward Ulcer, is cleaned and mundified by the liberal emanations of the After-purgings. And hereupon we conclude of the welfare or danger of a Woman in Child-bed, according to her excretions. If any part of the After-burden be left ticking to the Uterus, the After-purgings will flow forth evil-ented, green, and as if they proceeded from a dead body: and ometimes the courage and trength of the womb being quite vanquihed, a uddaine Gangrene doth induce a certain death.

In cae any Clotted Blood, or any other preternatural matter, do remain in the cavity of the womb after the Delivery; the Womb will neither retire upwards, nor cloe its Orifice, but its Neck will continue oft and open: As I have had experience in a Woman, which lying very ick of a Malignant Feaver, and being very weak, did uffer an Abortion: who after the excluion of the Foetus; which was incorrupt and entire, yet lay exceeding weak with a diorderly Pule, and in a cold weat, as if he were a dying. I perceived the Orifice of her Womb was lax, oft, and very open, and her After-purgings were omething noiome: whereupon
I upected that omething did lurke in her Womb which did putrefie: and putting in my hand, I extracted a fale Conception, as bigge as a Gooe-egge; which was made of a mot thick, nervous, and almot gritly ubtance, having ome perforations in it: (whereout did iue a vicid and putrefied matter) and immediately upon this he was dicharged of thoe greivous Symptomes, and uddainly after did perfectly recover.

When the Neck of the Womb doth a litle contract it elf, and thereupon the Clotted Blood doth get out, though not without pain and difficulty, cauing thoe paines, which our Midwives call the After-throws: the danger is then uppoed to be over, and indeed it is uually o; becaue it is a igne of the trength and firmnes of the Uterus, collecting it elf eaily together; whereby the After-purgings are more readily expelled, and the Woman is the ooner well.

But I have known the Orifice of the Womb draw together o cloe in ome immediately after the delivery, that the Blood being deteined in the Womb, and thereupon uddenly putrefying and thickening into Clots, did induce mot greivous Symptomes; and when no means would availe to unburden them, a preent death inued.

A very Honourable Lady in Child-bed falling into a feaver (by reaon no After-purgings came from her) had her Privities woln, and cortching: the Orifice of her Matrix being hard, and hut up, I did open it a litle way by force with an Iron Intrument, that o I might immit an Injection by a litle Syringe; whereupon black, clotted, and noiome blood did iue out, even to ome certain pounds weight, whereby he received preent eae.

The Wife of a Doctor of Divinity, who was of a good habit of Body enough, but being Barren, did conult me; and being very deirous of Children, he had tried many Medicines, and Phyicians, but all to no purpoe: he had her Termes at the uual times; but ometimes (epecially when he had rod on Hore-back) ome corrupt and purulent ubtance did iue from her: Which preently after would top again. Some conceived it to be the Whites: others upected it to be ome deep Ulcer: being perwaded thereunto, chiefly, becaue her flux was not contant, and by litle and litle, but by certain Intervalls, and much at a time: Whereupon by the help of a Speculum Matricis they did urvey all the heath of the Uterus, and did apply everal Medicines, but all in vain. At lat I, being called, did open the inward Orifice of the Womb, and preently there did iue forth to the quantity of two poonfulls, of corrupt matter, prinkled with bloody treaks. Which when I perceived, I told them that there lay an Ulcer lurking in the cavity of her Womb; and by injecting proper Medicaments, I retored her to her former health. But being intent upon the cure, and eeing the ordinary remedies did litle availe, I applied more forcible ones; becaue I upected that the Ulcer was inveterate (and perhaps with fleh growing upon it) wherefore to my former injections, I added a litle Roman Vitriol; by whoe acrimony the Uterus being extimulated, did grow o hard, that it did eem as hard to the touch as a Stone: and occaioned everal Hyterical Symptomes withall; which Phyitians commonly conceive to proceed from the uffocation of the Matrix, and foul vapours being thence ent upwards. This inconvenience continued a while; till the
Uterus being awaged by milder applications, and uch as abate pains, did relax its Orifice againe, and did exclude the harp liquour which I had injected, together with a putrid matter. Whereby the Patient was in a hort time retored.

I conceived it convenient to transferre this Hitory out of my Medicinal Obervations, to this place, that it may evidently appear, of how harp and quick a ene the Uterus is: and how eaily it doth cloe it elf upon the preence of its adververary: epecially in a greivous and difficult Lying in. Now thee caualties are mot incident to Women above all other Creatures, and of them, to thoe that are tenderly brought up, and doe lead a edentary and lazy life; as alo to uch as are of a ickly contitution, and do eaily fall into ditempers.

For Country Women, and uch as take great paines, are not o dangerouly ill, upon o mal grounds. Some of thee will be with Child again within a moneths time: when as the other are often out of order for two years after.

Hippocrates allotteth as many daies for the Afpurgings, as for the formation of the foetus; and therefore I. de foetu. more for a female, then a male Child. But that, witnes Scaliger, is fale: For none of our Women are purged above a moneth after their delivery: many
Com. in hit. an. Arit. l. 7. c. 3. not beyond fifteen daies: and ome but even: nay I have known a Woman, who was cleaned in three days, even after he had brought forth Twins. Galen hath many things concerning this ubject, in his Book < in non-Latin alphabet > . The Women (as the report goeth) in the New-found Land, keep cloe the day of their delivery; but the next day returne to their ordinary emploiments.

I will onely adde, for concluion, a memorable relation, delivered to me from the Noble Lord George Carew, Baron of Tatnes, and for a long time Preident of Munter in Ireland, who alo wrote the Annals of thoe times. There was a Woman bigge with Child, which followed her Husband, who was a Souldier in the Army; and the Army being daily in motion, was it eemes forced to make a Halt, by reaon of a litle River that run cros the place whether they intended to March: whereupon the poor woman finding her labour come upon her, retired to the next thicker, and alone by her elf, without any Midwife, or other preparation, brought forth Twins: which he preently carried to the River, and there wahed both her elf and them; which done, he wrapt her Infants into a coure cloath, and tied them to her back, and that very day, marched along with the Army twelve mile together, bare-footed: and was never the wore for the matter.

The next day after, the Deputy of Ireland, the Lord Montioy (who at that time was General of the Army againt the Spaniards, at the iedge of Kingale) and the Preident of Munter, being affected at the trangenes of the tory, did both vouchafe to be God-fathers to the Infants.

div.head: Of the Membranes and Humours of the Uterus.
div.p:
HIeronymus Fabricius recounteth four orts of bodies,
Lib. de for. foetus c. 1. which do conit without the Foetus, namely the Umbilical Veels, the Membranes, Humours, and flehy ubtance. Concerning which, I hall briefly declare, wherein I differ in opinion from him, (by the intigation of everal Obervations) but firt I hall uccinctly lay down his opinion.

p.U:
aith he, three Membranes, two whereof do encompas the Infant throughout, but the third doth not. Of thoe which do incompas the Foetus, one is the interiour, called
< in non-Latin alphabet > id et, amiculum, the litle covering. The other is placed next to the former, and called in Greek
< in non-Latin alphabet > , in Latine, Innominata, the coat without a name (but it is by Interpreters fally called Secundae, or Secundina, the Secundine) and this alo doth encompas the whole Foetus. The third is called
< in non-Latin alphabet > , id et, Intetinalis, the Gut-like Membrane, becaue it is like a tuffed Gut, or Pudding: which therefore doth not encompas the Foetus, but lieth over part of the breat and lower belly, and is extended to each horn of the Uterus. He doth confes that this Membrane is onely to be found in a Lamb, and a Calfe; and aith that it is joined to the Uterus, and doth by the Urachus receive the Urine of the foetus from the Bladder. And therefore, aith he, In Horned beats, which
cap. 7. have this coat called Allantoides, the Urachus is o large, and traite, that it reembleth a Gut; growing by degrees leer and leer, even till it reach to the bottom of the bladder: which doth eaily evince
that its original is rather from the Allantoides, then from the Bladder. But in a Man, and other Animals which have teeth in both Jawes, the fore-mentioned largenes of the Urachus is o mall, that whereas it rieth ingle from the bottom of the Bladder, it is preently after divided into mot lender fibers, which paing along with the Umbilical Veels, do transfund the Urine into the coat Chorion (in an almot inviible manner.) And upon this ground he doth challenge Arantius of a double errour; both in that he denyed any Urachus to be found in a humane foetus; and likewie for aying, that it doth dicharge its Urine through its privy member.

div.p: But for my part, I confes my elf to be involved in the ame errours with Arantius (if at leat they be errours.) For I am ure of this, that if you compres the bladder of a large-grown foetus, (be it the humane foetus, or of any other Animal) the Urine will tart out at the Privities. But as for the Urachus, I never yet aw any uch thing, nor could ever oberve that upon compreion of the bladder, the Urine would guh out into the Secundines. I have indeed in Sheep and Deer, een a certain Proces of the bladder, which doth contain Urine in it; but never aw any uch as the Urachus by him decribed.

And yet I will not too tiffly deny, that there is a Coat called Allantoides; for the Interiour membranes are o thin and tranparent, (uch as wee have ignified to be found between the two whites of an Egg) that they may eaily impoe upon the Eye. Likewie in a Hen-egg, between the Colliquamentum and the White (that is, between the Amnion, and the Chorion) there is to be een ome whitih excrements, nay, ometimes the very downright excrements of the Guts; as we have formerly
poken, and Coiterus hath alo oberved. Moreover, the Membrane of the Colliquamentum it elf (wherein the Chicken doth wim) though it be pellucid, thin, and o ubtle, that (according to Fabricius his own confeion) thinner cannot be imagined: yet (ince according to Him, all the membranes though never o thin, are nevertheles double) Nature may poibly ometimes upon neceity depoit the Urine, or ome other excrement between the Reduplications or folds thereof. And uch a kinde of Allantoides as this, I hall willingly indulge to Fabricius: but as for any other kinde of Pudding, carried on to both the bornes of the Womb, I finde no uch thing in the Secundines of Cloven-footed-beats, nor any thing ele, but the Conception it elf. I onely finde, (as I have aid before) a kinde of Proces of the bladder, which being eated between the Umbilical Arteries, doth contain an excrementitious humour, and this Proces is in ome longer, and in others horter.

Wherefore, in my judgment, the Coat which Fabricius calls Allantoides, is the meer Chorion: and yet the Antients called it Allantoides, from the figure of a double-pudding, which it doth reemble. For the exteriour membrane, which (like a Wallet tyed in the middle) is extended to the extremities of each Horn; and paing through the interpoed part of the Uterus (or the connexion of both the Horns) is fatened together, is the Chorion; which, in Sheep, Goats, Hinds, and Does, and other clovenfooted beats, if you take it in your hand in the middle of that paage, you may draw it away entire: and this we have called their Egge, or Conception.

For it containeth as an Egge doth, a two-fold
liquor, a foetus, and all things relating thereunto; and hath the ame qualifications which Aritotle aigneth to an Egge; namely, that out of part thereof an Animal ought to be contituted, and that the remainder ought to become the upport and utenance of that Animal, when it is now contituted.

And therefore that Coat which Fabricius calleth Allantoides, I either conceive to be the Choriou, or that omething praeter-natural had befalne ome Animal which he had een. For certain it is, that it is onely to be found in ome few Animals, and not alwaies in them neither: for at the Beginning it is not found, & afterwards, in ome it is more, and in others les conpicuous, and in ome nothing at all is dicernable, but meerly a Proces. And Fabricius himelf conceiveth it not uefull to the encompaing of the Infant, but only to the reception of the Urine. And truly I believe, that he maketh mention of it, rather in jutification of the Doctrine of the Antients, then that himelf found any uch thing, or thought it uefull to any intent. But (both with the Antients, and the whole School of Phyitians) he doth confes, that the Chorion doth contain Urine; where hee aith, that two humours are about the foetus, the one being Sweat, which is in the Amnion, the other Urine, which is contained in the Chorion.

By which it is manifet, that the Antients undertood one & the ame membrane under a double compellation; namely, in cloven-footed beats, (in whom alone it is found) they called it Allantoides, by reaon of its figure: but in other Animals, they called it Chorion, from its emploiment, becaue they conceived it was deigned for the entertainment of the Urine. And therefore they
confes that this Coat is neither found in a Man, nor any other Animals. For what need of any other Coat to entertain the Urine, when that office, by their own confeion, is already executed by the Chorion? And indeed, there can no probable reaon be alledged why that coat hould be found in Sheep, Goats, and other beats which cleave the hoof, and not alo in Dogs, Cats, Mice, and Others. For if it were intituted for the reception of the Urine, it is neceary, that the foetus of Sheep, and Cowes, hould either abound with greater plenty of Urine then other animals which have Teeth in both Jawes; or ele, that there are three divere kindes of humours; or at leat two Receptacles of the Urine. For this I am ure, that the Chorion is from the firt beginning full of water. But I do not here intend to dipute controveries, I hall rather reheare what I have found by experience.

It is one thing to exhibit the fabrick of a Conception, or Embryo that is now perfected, as Fabricius doth: but another thing, to dicloe the the generation thereof, and firt cheme and rudiments of all: as it is a divere buines to decribe Apples, or the ripe eeds of Plants, and their firt production from the bud. We therefore will briefly relate, how the Conception is framed by litle and litle, even from the beginning to the end; that it may thence more likely appear, what we are to conclude concerning the Membranes, and other Appurtenances relating to the Foetus.

All Living things do derive their Original (as we have aid) from omething, which doth contain in it both the matter, and efficient virtue and power: which therefore is that thing, both out of which, and by which, whatoever is born, doth deduce
its beginning. And uch an Original or Rudiment in Animals (whether they proceed from other Animals which do beget them, or ele are pontaneous, and the Iues of Putrefaction) is a certain humour, which is concluded in ome certain coat, or hell; namely, a imilar body, having life actually in it, or in potentiâ: and this, in cae it be generated within an Animal, and do there remain, untill it have produced an Vnivocal Animal, is commonly called a Conception: but if it be expoed without, by being born, or ele aume its beginning elewhere, it is called either an Egg, or a Worm. But I conceive that both ought alike to be called Primordium, the firt Rudiment from which an Animal doth pring; as Plants aume their nativity from the Seed: and all thee Primordia are of one kinde, namely, Vital.

And this kinde of Rudiment I finde in the Vterus of all Viviparous Animals, before any part of the foetus appear; namely, there is a cleare, tiffe, white humour (like the white of an Egge) which is included in a membrane, which I call their egge: and this doth fill up all the Vterus, and both the Horns thereof, in Hindes, Does, Sheep, and other Beats which cleave the Hoof.

In proces of Time, there is a mot pure, and clear watry part ditinguihed or evered from the ret of the Rudiment, or egge, which we call the Colliquamentum, or diolved part in a Hen-egge) and this doth in brightnes or perpicuity farre exceed all the ret of the egge (in which it is comprehended. The form thereof is round, and it is concluded in its own proper membrane, which is mot thin and tranparent, which they call Amnion; as for the ret of the humor, which is thicker and darker then this, an exteriour coat, which is
contiguous to the concave uperficies of the Vterus, and embraceth the whole Egge, doth contain it: which obtaineth a everal figure, according to the diverity of the hape of the womb: for in ome it is oval, in other oblong, but in Beats which cleave the hoof, it reembleth a Wallet.

A litle while after, there doth appear in this crytal Colliquamentum, Punctum rubrum aliens, A Red leaping Point; from which mot lender trings of litle Veines are dieminated, like rayes or beames. Anon the firt concrement or ubtance of the Body doth appear, like a Magot, which is bent like a Keel of a Ship: and o the ret of the Parts doe follow in their order, as hath been related in our Hitory. For we have oberved that the Procreation of the foetus in Viviparous Animals is intituted in the ame manner out of the Egg or Conception, as the Chicken out of the Henn-Egg.

But thee Viviparous conceptions do (as I have noted) differ in Figure, Number, and Connexion to the Vterus. For at the beginning, the Conception (epecially in thoe that cleave the hoofe) doth not grow to the Vterus; but being onely contiguous thereunto, doth fill up all its cavity, and ditend it, and may be eaily drawn out whole.

In uch Creatures as cleave the hoofe, (which do conceive in the Horns of the Womb) and alo in thoe that are whole-hoofed, there is onely one of thee eggs found at a time, and that alo extending it elfe to both the Hornes, and though ometimes they do produce a ingle, and ometimes a double foetus; and thereupon have ometimes one ingle Colliquamentum, and ometimes two (namely, one in the Right, and another in
the Left Horn) yet are they till concluded in that Common Egg or Conception.

But in other Animals, o many foetus, o many everal Eggs are to be een apart; and as many Colliquamentums in them, as it is in the Dog, the Cat, the Moue, and uch like Animals as have teeth in both their Jawes.

The Figure of the Conception in uch as cleave the hoof, is like a Wallet; namely uch, as Fabricius doth attribute to the Allantoides. In a Mare, the internal hape of the womb reembleth a litle oblong Sack; but in a Woman, it is Orbicular.

In thoe Animals, whoe conception doth cleave to their womb (which, truly, is not o in many, untill the foetus be fully formed) it is ditinguihed by its Diverity of Connexion: for in ome, it doth tick onely in one place, by the mediation of a carnous ubtance, which we call Placenta, the Uterine cake in women, becaue it reembleth the round figure of a Cake; but in others, it groweth to the Uterus in everal places, being fatened thereunto by divers flehy ubtances, or caruncles: namely, by five, in Hindes, and Does; by more in Cowes, but they are leer alo: but in the race of Sheep, by very many, and thoe of different magnitude. In Dogs and Cats, thee Carnous Bodies, do (like a girdle) encompas every conception round. A like ubtance doth in Hares, and Moles, grow to the ides of their Uterus: as alo the Uterine cake in a woman, which embraceth more then one half of the conception (as the cups do the Acorns, when they firt pring) and therefore the gibbous part thereof doth tick fat to the womb, but the hollow part doth grow to the Chorion.

Thee things being premied, we hall now dicloe, what our judgement is of thee Humours,
membranes, flehy ubtance, and alo of the ditribution of the Vmbilical veels (which are poken of by Fabricius.)

Fabricius doth rightly undertand by the words < in non-Latin alphabet > and < in non-Latin alphabet > , the Secundines, or After-Burden,
cap. 5. namely not the Membranes onely, but all that which doth come away lat in the delivery (or at let, not long after it) and is contituted of humours, membranes, and flehy ubtance, as alo of the Vmbilical Veels.

But as for what he relateth concerning the humours, Of the Humours. which as he uppoeth he doth receive from the Ancients (as a thing mot ure, and which tandeth in no need of any proof) namely, that the water in the Amnion, wherein the foetus wimmes, is its weat; and that that outward Water in the Chorion is the Vrine, are both incongruous, and fale aertions: For both thoe two humours do appear in the conception before any portion of the foetus it elf be in being: and that which he calleth the Urine, is before that (which they conceive to be the weat.) Nay you may find thee humours, epecially the lat, in ome barren, and unfruitful conceptions (wherein there is no tract of a foetus at all.)

Such Conceptions as thee, or Subventaneous eggs, Women do ometimes eject: and Aritotle aith De gen. an. l. 3. c. 9. Ibid. thy are called, Fluxus, Emanations or Fluxes, but we call them fale conceptions, and lips. Such an egge as thee, did Hippocrates hake from his aborting Mintrel. For thoe creatures which do breed an Animal within themelves, have in ome ort after their firt conception, omething like an egge within them, for a humour is conteined in a thin membrane, jut as if you hould pluck the hell off of the egge. But as for that humour conteined in the Chorion, which
Fabricius and other Phyitians conceive to be the Urine, Aritotle eemeth to apprehend it to be the liquour of the Sperme, or Geniture. For, he aith, Hit. an. l. 7. c. 7. The eed being received by the Uterus, having continued in it a while, is covered with a membrane. For if it chance to fall out, before any dearticulation, or delineation of the parts do appear, it looketh like an egge covered with a membrane, when the hell is pilled off. But that membrane is full of Veins, namely, the Chorion, which hath aumed its denomination a venarum choro, ive copia, from the conflux or multitude of veins.

I have often een thoe kind of egges ejected in the econd, or third moneth: they are many times corrupt and rotten within, and do teale out inenibly (like the Whites) and o delude thoe, who have entertained hopes of a true conception.

Again, thoe fore-mentioned humours cannot be conceived to be weat, or Urine: becaue they abound in uch plenty at the very beginning, that the Embryo wimming in the middet thereof, is thereby ecured (whilet his Mother runneth, or danceth, or doth imply her body by any forcible agitation) from the colliion of the circumjacent parts, as it were by a fortres.

Add to all this, that many Animals never weat at all: (when yet according to Aritotle, all Water, Land, and Volatile Animals, and I hall put in creeping things, and Inects alo, whether they be produced in the hape of an egge, or an Animal, or ele be pontaneous productions, are all procreated after a like manner) all fowl, creeping things, and fihes, are conceived neither to Sweat, nor Urine. Ibid. The Dog, and Cat, do never weat; nor any other Animal, while it doth emit abundance of Urine.
And certainly it is impoible, that any Animal hould make water, before the Reines and Bladder are made.

Beides, which is a more evincing Argument then the ret, thee humours cannot be excrementitious, becaue o many litle filaments of Veins are dieminated into them: which doe derive Aliment from thence (as from a large tock) and afterwards conduct it unto the foetus.

Againe, if the humour conteined in the Chorion, be the Urine; what need is there of the Allantoides? and if the humour conteined in the Amnion be the Sweat, why did nature, who is o exact in all her contrivances, order the matter o ill, as to condemn the foetus to lye wallowing in its own Excrement? and why doth the Parent preently after delivery (for that is uual with everal creatures) devour that which is but the Excrement of her foetus, together with the membranes which contein it, with o much greedines and appetite? Some have oberved, that if the Animal do not eat up thee membranes and humours, it will not give down its Milk freely.

If, notwithtanding all thee arguments, ome men will till maintain that thee humours (which we dipoe to the nutriment of the foetus) are excrementitious; and that upon this inducement, viz. becaue they alo improve according to the growth of the foetus: and that in the birth of ome Animals (at which time the whole tock of Aliment is in probability almot conumed) great tore of thee humours doth abound; and that therefore they mut needs performe other offices, then can well conit with the dignity of the nutriment. Yet for all this, I confidently pronounce, that thee humours are the Aliment of the foetus
