from the beginning of all; (as the Colliquamentum and the White do erve the Chicken for the ame purpoe) but in proces of time, the thinner, and purer parts being exhauted, the reliques do then put on the nature of an ueful excrement: and are reerved in ome Animals, that o they may ecure the foetus and facilitate the delivery. For as Wine, when the Spirits are exhaled, turnes into deadwine: and as everal Excrements do reult from the reliques of the Aliment: o in like manner, when all that ubtance, which is commodious to the utenance of the foetus, is derived out of the humour concluded in the Chorion; the remainder doth turn into a kind of excrement, and is reerved for the ues aforeaid. But all that humour which was included in the Amnion, it commonly pent neer the approaching delivery; o that it is probable, that the foetus deireth to get out by reaon his proviions faile him.

Latly, if at any time there be any other humour conteined in the Allantoides (as indeed there ometimes is) I eteem it to be a preter-natural humour. For I have een when women at their delivery have had a mighty flux of water; and ometimes a two-fold water: our Midwives call them the By-waters. And therefore ome women have a montrous great belly, though they are brought to bed of a very litle & lean Childe; but uch women do effund abundance of Waters. Some are of opinion, that the larger quantity of Waters, doth accompany weakly, and thoe female Children: but the leer, trong, and male Children. I have often een waters burt forth in the midt of the going with Child without Abortion, the Child remaining afe, and trong even to the birth. As therefore there are naturally
but two Waters only, (whereof the one is conteined in the Chorion, and the other in the Amnion) o it may ometimes fall out, beide the ordinary coure of nature, that everal Waters may be accumulated in membranes proper to themelves, or ele in the reduplications of the Chorion.

As for the Membranes or Coats of the Womb, Of the Membranes. ince their proper ue and office chiefly is, to contein the Waters; and thoe Waters appear to be two only; it is mot certain that the membranes themelves are not (neceary and uually) more then two.
But as for thoe who reckon three, I conceive they were deluded, becaue the Ancients call the elf-ame membrane ometimes Chorion, from the conflux of Veines; and ometimes Allantoides, from its figure.

Every conception is covered over with thee two membranes; as alo every Braine hath a double Meninx: every Tree and Shrub a two-fold Bark; every Seed and Fruit a two-fold Covering: whereof the Exteriour is the harder, and tighter.

The more Interiour of the two fore-mentioned membranes (conteining the Colliquamentum, or purer humour) is the thinnet, and is called Amnion, that is, Amiculum, the litle covering, becaue it covereth and involveth the foetus. The Exteriour (which is by much the larger, and tronger membrane) is called Chorion, becaue (aith Fabricius) many Veins, and Arteries are aembled in it, tanquam in Choro, as in a Quire. And hence the Coat of the Eye, and likewie that contexture of Veins and Arteries which is found in the Ventricles of the Brain, are both called
< in non-Latin alphabet > , from the reemblance they have with thee veines in the Chorion.
This Membrane Chorion doth fill all the Womb; conteining a tiffe, troubled humour; and to its exteriour part, the Vterine Cake or Caruncles adhering, do faten the Conception to the Womb.

The Interiour part of this Membrane (in a Woman) is almot conjoined to the Amnion, nor is it eaily eparated from it. In thoe Animals which cleave the hoofe it is exceeding large, and conteineth a hundred-fold more moiture in it, then the Amnion. For the Amnion at the beginning, is carce o large as a Nutmeg, or fair Bean, and is commonly found in one Horn of the womb onely, namely in that where the Foetus inhabiteth.

The Coat Chorion is (chiefly in Women) rough, and vicous without; but within mooth, and glibbe, and interwoven with abundance of Veins. The upper part of it is (in Women) thicker, and ofter, but the lower part, thinner and more membranous.

In women the After-burden groweth to the upper part of this membrane: But in Sheep, everal Caruncles are fatened to everal parts of it. In Hinds, and Does, the conception doth cling to the Vterus at five places onely: but in a Mare it doth adhere to the Vterus in an infinite company of places. And therefore Fabricius aith, that the cap. 3. After-birth is in almot all Viviparous creatures, a oft fleh, lax, porous, thick, and omething black, growing about the terminations of the Vmbilical veels, which he reembleth to a looer Parenchyma or affuion of a Liver or Spleen; which is therefore by Galen called Caro adenoa, a glandulous 5. apho. 45. fleh; and we now commonly call it Hepar Vterinum, the Uterine Liver; into which the extremities of the Vmbilical veels are dieminated,
which do derive nutriment from the womb to the foetus.

But now, this flehy Subtance neither is in all Animals, nor at all times in thoe in whom it is: but in thoe Animals onely in whom the conception doth firmly cleave to the womb, and then onely, when it is fatened to the womb to bring down utenance to the foetus. For in the beginning, the conception (like an egge eated in the womb) is contiguous to all the circum-jacent parts of the Uterus, but doth on no ide grow thereunto; but doth produce its foetus (as it is in an Egge which is at upon by the Henne) out of the Humours contained in it: but that adhaeion and cleaving to the womb, is then firt of all procured, and alo this flehy body is then firt beginning to be generated (which flehy ubtance is the Tye of the Conception to the womb) when the foetus is now perfectly formed, and tanding in need of other, and more plentifull upply of Aliment, doth dipatch the Extremities of the Umbilical veels to the Uterus, as Emiaries or Agents, that may from thence (as the Roots to Plants) convey proviions. For in the beginning, (as we have hewed) when the Punctum aliens, and the Blood doe onely appear, the Propagations of the Vmbilical vesels are onely diseminated through the Colliquamentum, and the Coat Amnion. But when once the fabrick of the Body is et up, thoe Propagations do conduct themelves farther, and being grown more numerous, are divaricated in the Chorion alo, that o they may tranport utenance from thence to the foetus, out of the whitih humour which reideth there.

By which it appeareth, that the foetus of Viviparous Animals is at the beginning fed in the ame
manner, as the Chicken is utained in the egge; and doth for that caue abide in the Vterus, that at length (when it hath no longer a upply from its own tock) it may, by the mediation of the caruncles grow to the Vterus; and be more plentifully upported, by the contribution of its Parent.

Wherefore Fabricius did rightly oberve, that the conception was in ome Animals carce fatened to the Vterus at all. And therefore Sowes, and Mares, have none of this carnous connexion; but their egge or conception, as it is firt of all contituted out of the moiture or juices which do flow in the Vterus, (as the Egge in the Hen is enlarged by the White, without any tye to the Vterus) o doth it alo receive Augmentation; and the foetus alo, having Aliment adminitred to him from the conception, (wherein he is contained) is in the ame manner upported, as the egge out of the liquors. Whence a notable argument doth reult, that the Foetus of thoe Animals is no more nourihed by the Mothers blood, then the Chicken in the egge: and that the Humour comprehended in the Chorion, is neither Urine, nor any other Excrement, but the Aliment of the Foetus. Although (as we have oberved before) when the alible juice is exhauted, the remainder thereof doth degenerate into an Excrement, like to the Urine. And this alo is evident, from that which we have formerly noted, concerning the Cotyledones; namely, that the flehy ubtance is in thoe Animals of a pongy ubtance, and doth (like a Honycomb) conit of innumerable acetabula, holes or orifices, which are all of them full of a mucous white matter; (which Galen alo records to be anciently oberved) and that thence the Extremities of
the Vmbilical vesels do uck Nutriment, which they tranport to the foetus; as the mall branches of the Meenterical veines do, in thoe Animals which are already born, derive chyle out of the coats of the Guts, through which they are diffued.

I therefore apprehend the imployment of the Vterine cake and the caruncles, to be uch as is commonly imputed to the Liver and the Breats. For the Liver doth adde a preparation to the chyle which is attracted from the Guts, fitting the ame for the utenance of the Body; and likewie the Vterine cake doth afreh concoct the alible nutriment which proceedeth from the Parent, to upport the foetus. The Breats alo (being compoed of a glandulous ubtance) do trut with milk; and though they are parts which (in ome Animals) do not appear at all, yet at the time of pregnation they are een to be full, and tumorous: o the Vterine cake, being a laxe or flaggy and fungous ubtance, both flow with a whitih ap, and is never found but at the time of Ingravidation. The Liver, I ay, is the nutritive intrument of the Body wherein it is; the Breats of the Infant, and the Placenta of the Embryo. And as the mother doth by her own food acquire more milke then he hath ue for to utain her fleh, and blood, which milk is reconcocted in her breats, and treaured up; o alo uch Females as are great with young (in whoe womb this Placenta is) do prepare, and uppeditate to their foetus an aliment which is defecated by thoe caruncles: by which it cometh to pas, that an impure or laudible diet is adminitred to the Embryo's, according as the Parents diet it elf is either wholome or impure, and according to the ufficient or imperfect concoction,
which they afford it in thoe organs of the Vterus. For ome Embryo's have a more perfect organ provided for them, uch as is that carnous ubtance of the Uterus, which is wanting in ome. In ome likewie this Vterine cake is thicker, larger, and fuller of Blood; but in others it is more pongy and paler: like thoe two Sweet-breads, or glandulous bodies called Thymus, and Pancreas. For you hall finde as much difference of thee in Animals, as of the Breats, or of the Bowels: for to intance onely in Livers, they are in ome ruddy and anguine; in others, (as in the greatet part of Fihes, and likewie Cachectical perons) pale. Mares do feed upon the crude gras, and do not chew the cud; Sowes will themelves with any filth, and both thee want a Vterine cake, which is the organ of compleating the Aliment.

And therefore true is that of Fabricius; aying, cap. 3. This flehy ubtance is, in everal kinds of Animals, different in Magnitude, Figure, Scite, and Number. Women have one onely; as Mice, Conies, Ginny-pigs, Bitches, Cats, and everal Animals, whoe feet are ditinguihed into toes, and have teeth in both jawes: but all Animals which cleave the hoof, and have teeth in one jaw onely, whether they be dometicks, as the Sheep, the Cow, and the Goat; or wilde, as the Hinde, the Doe, the Roe, and the like, have divere. Again, thoe Animals which have but one, in them it either reembleth a Cake (and thence cometh its denomination) as in Women, Conies, the Hare, and the Mole, Mice, and Ginney-pigs: or ele it reembleth a zone or girdle, or wath ingirting the trunck of the body, as in Bitches, Cats, Ferrets, and the like. In ome it is like a chalice, or Acorn cup, comprehending the greater part of the foetus (as in the Hare and the Cony:) where the convexe
part groweth to the Vterus, and the concavous repects the foetus. Likewie in thoe females which have but one, and that reembling a Cake, though the figure be alike in them all, yet the cituation is unlike. For in a woman it groweth to the bottom of the womb, and is ditant a great way, that is by the length of long vesels from the foetus: but in Mice, Ginny-pigs, and Conies, it is annexed partly to the Region of the Loynes, partly to the ides of the breat. But thoe animals which have more of thee carnous ubtances then one, they are all of them furnihed with teeth in one jaw onely, as Sheep, Cowes, Hinds, Roe-deer, and the like, and yet in thee alo there is a diverity. For Ewes have more caruncles, and thoe of different magnitude; the bigget whereof are as large as a Nutmeg; the leat, as a Cich-peae, or Vetch: which are alo of a round figure, and ruddy complexion, and their convex parts do repect the Uterus, appearing like oft Warts, or Nipples. But Cowes have greater, flatter, and paler, which are of a pongy conitence, like Muh-rooms: and thee eem to take their original from the Chorion. Hindes and Does have five onely; and thoe bred out of the womb, do protuberate towards the conception, and there exhibit their Cavities. But being firmly fatened to the Uterus, are not eaily eparated from it; except it be when the birth is drawing nigh; at which time (like ripe fruits) they do very eaily forego their former connexion. And being torn off from the womb, I have oberved the greater part of the Blood which flowes afterward, to iue, not from the Conception, but from the Uterus it elf.

Fabricius treating of the Union of this Carnous ubtance with the Vterus, doth labour by many (but weak) arguments to prove, that the Vmbilical
veels, do join to the extremities of the veels of the Womb by everal inertions: and De form. foet. pag. 122. this he doth undertake, chiefly, to countenance the old opinion received almot by all: for he confeeth that he can deliver nothing certaine touching this matter, becaue the Carnous ubtance hinders a man from dicovering the truth thereof. But yet neither ene, nor reaon do evince, that there are any more Anatomoes in the Vterus, then in the Liver, between the branches of the Gate, and Hollow-vein; or in the Breats, between the veins which convey blood, and thoe that waft the Milk. There is indeed, in ome places a kind of contiguity or juxtapoition of thoe veels, and ometimes an inertion of the one into the Coat of the other; but no where any uch coalition, or Vnion, as Fabricius conceiteth. For were it o, the veines ought to be inerted into the Arteries: for the veels, which do convey blood into the Vterus and Caruncles are Arteries: but they which tranport it from the Vterus to the Foetus, are Veins, as is apparent to all men; becaue they waft the blood from the After-birth into the Hollow-vein.

Wherefore the Opinion of Arantius eems to me to be more true; namly that the Orifices of the Umbilical veels are not united to the Orifices of the Veels of the womb. For there are fewer Veels conducting blood to the womb, then veins returning it to the foetus: and the greatet part of the propagations of thee are terminated in the Chorion. And yet Fabricius, either overwayed by his repects to Antiquity, or his envy to Arantius, doth tubborny perit in the patronage of the old opinion.

As concerning the Cotelydones, or Acetabula,
cap. 4. De Acetabulis.
Fabricius concludeth nothing certain: but only compileth the everal opinions of Antiquity. But we have before, in the Hitory of Hinds and Does, hewed in what Animals thee Acetabula are; where we have withal ignified, that they are certain litle Cells of mall capacity, dipered through the Caruncles or flehy ubtance, and fraught with a white, or gellyih ubtance: as the Honey-comb is full of Honey.

In Hinds, they do fitly reemble the hape of that cavity in the Haunch-bone which receiveth the Bone of the Thigh; and therefore they are by the Greeks called Cotyledones: and in Latine, Acetabula, becaue they reemble thoe litle Veels or Sawers, which were anciently brought to the table with Vineger for awce. Thee cavities do not exceed in magnitude the perforations of a large ponge, and into each of them, o many lender prigs of the Umbilical Veels do deeply ininuate themelves; becaue in them is laid up the utenance of the foetus, and not blood (as Fabricius conceived) but a gelly reembling the thicker white of an egge. Whereby it appears (as we have formerly declared) that the foetus of uch as cleave the hoof (as likewie all other) are not uteined by the mothers blood.

That which Aritotle delivereth concerning the Hit. an. l. 7. c. 8. Acetabula, that they are diminihed as the Foetus doth improve: is contrary to experience; for the larger the foetus, the larger the caruncles alo, and their Acetabula, or cavities, are more capacious, and more numerous, and more full of an albugineous juice.

If you compres thee caruncles, no blood at all doth iue out; but as water, or honey doth
ditill out of a queezed Sponge, or Honey-comb. So in like manner if you pres the Acetabula, an albugineous liquor doth drop out; and when that liquor is preed out, the Acetabula are more contract, pale, and flaggy: and at lat do reemble the Nipples of the Breats, or large falling Warts.

Aritotle indeed doth truly affirm, that thee Acetabula are not in all Animals; for they are not in Women, nor in any ele (as far as I know) who have onely one carnous ubtance in their Vterus. But as for their office and ue: I conceive that all the Caruncles (like Breats) do not contein blood, but diget a ap, like to the White of an Egge, which they do adminiter to nourih the foetus.
The decription of the Vmbilical Veels, is Of the Navel. elegantly delivered by Fabricius, as his Tables or Pictures of them are very artificial. cap. 2.

The Veins, aith he, paing from the Uterus towards the Foetus, are ever united, and improved: nor doth their conjunction give over, until two large Trunks do reult out of them all; which penetrating the Navel of the Infant, they do contitute one onely large Trunk; which is inerted into the Liver of the Infant, and perforated into the Hollow and Gatevein. In like manner, the Arteries adjoined to thee Veins, which are very numerous, and mall, paing on from the Womb to the Foetus, and at lat uniting their forces together, and o enlarging, do conpire into two large Trunks alo; which after they have paed the Navel, do eparate themelves and break company from the Veins, and ticking to the ides of the Bladder of Urine, by the help of an intervening Membrane; they do here and there dipere themelves
into the branches of the great Artery decending into the Thighs. But we mut take notice that this decription given by Fabricius, doth agree only to the Navel of an Infant, and is not common to the foetus of every Animal at large: Nor yet to an Infant neither, but after it is fully formed; for the Arteries (at the beginning,) are inconpicuous, as being o lender, that we have need of the quick ight of a Lynceus to dicern them: nor do they indeed reveal themelves afterwards, but only by their pulation: for in other things they are no way ditinguihable from Veins. Becaue therefore (as I have hewed elewhere) the lender branches or filaments of the Arteries have no pulation, (at let o far as we can dicover) they cannot be known from Veins: for they are at that time o thin & ubtle, that they are woven to the coats of the veins like the finet threds: or rather do obcurly ininuate themelves into the tunicles of the veins: whereby they are utterly indicernable. But all the veins (by a retrograde production) uniting their prigs at lat, do all conpire into one Trunk, (as all the branches into one tock) as alo the Meeraick Veins are all concluded in the Venae Portae.

Neer the Embryo, they are divided into two Trunks; but when once they enter into him, they do contitute one onely Navel, which doth terminate in the Hollow-vein, neer the right deaf-eare of the Heart; & paing through the Liver, is inerted into the Gate-vein, and doth catter no more Propagations, untill by a very large Orifice it diplayeth it elf out of the gibbous part of the liver. So that if you open the Trunk of the Hollow-vein from the deaf-ear of the Heart, downwards, and o exhaut it of all its blood, you may perceive three Orifices as
conjoined together; one whereof is the entrance into the decending Trunk of the Hollow vein, the other is the going out of the Branch of the Liver dieminated through all its gibbous part; but the third is the Original of this Umbilical vein. Whereby it clearly appeareth, that the original of the veins is not to be ought for in the Liver: becaue the Orifice of the decending Trunk of the Hollow-vein is much larger then the Liver-branch; for the Umbilical branch is as large as that. But the Branches are never aid to be the Original of their Trunk, but rather where the Trunk is larget, there are wee to repute the Original of the branches toreide: now that happeneth at the entrance of the right ventricle of the Heart; and therefore that ventricle is to be accounted the original, & promptuary of all the veins.

I return now to the Umbilical veels, which are not divided after the ame maner in all Animals; for there are found in ome 2. or more litle Branches in the body of the foetus; whereof ome pas into the Liver, others into the Vena Portae, or Meeraical veins. But in a human foetus, the Trunks of the veins & arteries being involved together, are complicated, ome 3. or 4. Fingers breadth from the Navel (as if one hould twit o many wax candles together like a cord) being skinned over, and conglutinated by the help of a thick & gellyih memmembrane. This litle cord paing on to the Chorion, is in the flat part of the After-birth, and interior uperficies of the Chorion ditributed into everal Propagations; and thence is ramified into many other almot infinite litle Branches; by which the Aliment attracted as it were by o many roots, is derived to the foetus. The Veines relating to this litle Cord, are ditinguihed in undry places by
litle knobbs, or warts, as it were by litle bladders full of blood, that o the blood might not ruh in too forcibly upon the foetus. By the number of thee protuberations, the upertitious Midwives do pend their divination concerning the number of children yet to come; and in cae they finde none of thee knobs, they pronounce the Woman barren for the future; and likewie by the ditance betweene thee protuberations, they fondly propheie of the pace between childe and childe; and alo of the dicrimination of the Sex, from the variety of their complexion.

Alo the contitution of the Umbilical vesels is like to this, in almot all other foetues which have but one onely Uterine cake; namely, in Bitches, Mice, and others: but the litle cord is in them horter, and les complicated. But in Cows, Ews, Hindes, Does, Sowes, and other Animals, whoe foetus is not utained by aliment derived from one carnous ubtance, or cake, but from divere, the ditribution of the Umbilical vesels is alo divere: For the litle branches, or terminations of the vesels are not dieminated through the cake onely, but alo (and that chiefly too) without it, through the coat called Chorion, dipatching their mot lender fibers thither likewie: jut as the ditribution of the Umbilical vesels (namely without the litle cord) appeareth in a humane foetus, before the conception is fatened to the Uterus. Whereby it appeareth, that the Embryo doth not derive all his Aliment from the cake; but part thereof, and that the chiefet, from the humor contained in the Chorion.

As touching the ues of the Vmbilical vesels,
I do not conent with Fabricius: for he is of opinion that all the blood is derived to the foetus from the Vterus by the veines; and the vital pirits from the mother by the Arteries. He alo denyeth, that any part of the foetus in the womb doth execute any publick function: but affirmeth, that each particular part taketh care onely for it elfe, how it may be nourihed, augmented, and preerved. And alo, becaue he findeth no Nerve amongt the Umbilical Veels, he concludeth the foetus to be void of all Sene and Motion: Implying, that the Mothers Womb, or the Uterine Cake, is as it were the Heart, and Original from whence all things pring to the foetus, and from whence the Influent heat is divided amongt all the parts. All which are manifet mitakes. For the Humane Embryc, when he is not yet four moneths tanding in the Womb (and ome ooner) exercieth an opparent motion, volutation, and calcitration: epecially if he be prejudiced by extremity of cold or heat, or any other outward inconvenience. Likewie the Punctum aliens it elf, (before the Heart is erected) doth tirre by an apparent pulation, and alo ditribute blood, and pirits: and being (as we have oberved) reduced to a dying and langiuihing condition by cold, is by the freh acceion of heat, kindled anew, and revived. And alo in the Caearean birth, it is very evident, that the Embryo's life doth not immediately proceed from the Parent, nor the Spirits reult from her: for we have often een Infants, which have been cut out of their Mothers Womb, urvive their Parent for everal hours: and have alo known a Cony and a Hare which did live, though they were born by inciion made upon the Uterus of
their Parents. Moreover, it is a ure way to know whether the Infant that ticketh in the birth be alive, or not, by the pulation of the Vmbilical Arteries. But mot certain it is, that thoe Arteries are not moved by the virtue or operation of the Mothers, but of his own proper Heart: For they keep a ditinct time and pawze, from the Mothers pule: which is eaily experimented, if you lay one hand upon the Mothers wret, and the other on the Infants Navel-tring. Nay in a Caarean Section, when the Embryo's have been yet involved in the membrane called Chorion, I have oftentimes found (even when the Mother was extinct, and tiffe almot with cold) the Vmbilical Arteries beating, and the Foetus himelf luty. Wherefore it is not true, that the Spirits do proceed to the foetus from the Mothers Arteries: nor is that more true; namely, that the Vmbilical Veels of the foetus are conjoined by Anatomois, to the Veels of the Vterus. For the Foetus enjoyeth his own proper life, and is furnihed with beating Arteries, which are full of Blood, and Spirits long before the conception (in which he is formed, and walloweth) doth cleave to the Vterus: jut as it is with Chicken in the Egge.

As for the ue of the Arteries in the foetus (as alo in grown bodies) we have in our Treatie of the Circulation of the blood, demontrated it to be much different from what hath been formerly received: all which is alo confirmed from hence.

The Secundines; they alo are an undeniable part of the Conception, and do depend upon the Foetus, auming life and their vegetal faculty from him. For as in the Meentery, the blood
is derived to the Guts, by the branches of the Coeliacal, and Meenterical Arteries; and that very Blood being circulated by the Veines, doth convey the chyle together with it unto the Liver, and the Heart: o in like manner, the Vmbilical Arteries do derive blood to the Secundines, which blood the Veins do reduce to the Foetus, together with alible juice. And therefore thoe Arteries do not immediately proceed from the Heart as principal Veels; but (as intruments of inferiour rank and quality) do arie out of the Crural branches.

There came forth a Book of late, wrote by Adrianus Spigelius, entituled De formato Foetu, of the formed foetus: wherein he treateth concerning the Ue of the Umbilical Arteries; and doth demontrate by powerful arguments, that the Foetus doth not receive its Vital Spirits by the Arteries from the Mother: and hath fully anwered thoe arguments which are alledged to the contrary. But he might alo as well have proved by the ame Arguments, that the Blood neither is tranported into the foetus from the Mothers Veines by the Propagations of the Umbilical Veins: which is cheifly made manifet by the examples drawn from the Hen-egge, and the Caearean Birth.

For did the Heat and Life flow to the blood from the Mother; he being extinct, the Infant would intantly dye alo; (for he mut needs be a thing concluded in the ame fatality) nay before her: for when death approacheth, the ubordinate parts doe firt languih, and grow cold, before the principal; and hereupon the Heart declines the lat of all. The Blood, I
ay, of the Foetus himelfe, hould grow chill firt, and diproportionate to its Office, as being derived from the Uterus; eeing that the Vterus it elf, is deprived and detitute of all vital heat, before the Heart.

div.head: Of the Conception.
div.p: FAbricius hath indeed recounted many miraculous things, concerning the Birth, but wee meet with more things worthy our wonder concerning the Conception. It is indeed a dark, obcure buines; however we hall adventure to propoe omething in a problematical way, in uch ort that it hall appeare we doe not onely goe about to ubvert other mens opinions, but alo to dicloe our owne. And yet whatoever falleth from me concerning this ubject, I deire may not be o taken, as if I conceived them pronounced by an Oracle; but that liberty which I freely allow all other men, I doe of right challenge to my elf; that o I may offer thoe things as true, which eem probable in uch dark matters, until uch time as they can be convinced of fality or errour.

This imployment doth chiefly relate to the Uterus, without whoe preparations and functions, you may in vaine expect a Conception. And becaue it is certaine, that the Geniture of the Male doth not o much as reach to the cavity of the Uterus, much les abide there for any time; that geniture doth derive foecundity to the Uterus only by a kinde of contagion, (not as if it were now tangent, and operating, but becaue it hath formerly touched.) The Woman or Female doth eem after the permatical, contact (in coition) to be affected in the ame manner, and to be rendered prolifical, by no enible corporeal Agent, as the Iron
touched by the Loadtone, is preently indowed with the virtue of the Loadtone, and doth draw other iron-bodies unto it. Namely, having once received that virtue, which we have poken of, it doth exercie the platick generative power, and procreateth its own like, no otherwie then plants doe, which we ee are impowered with the force of both Sexes.

But I cannot but wonder, where that faculty, (when the act of coition is finihed, before the production of the Egge or Conception doth reide? and to what that active vertue of the Male is imparted? namely, whether to the Uterus alone, or to the whole Female? or rather, primarily to the Uterus, but econdarily to the Female? or latly, whether, as we ee with our eyes, and think with our braines, o a female doth conceive with her Vterus?

For though the female ometimes (conceiving after coition) doth not produce a Foetus: yet we know that thoe Symptomes did enue, which gave a cleare tetimony of a conception et on foot, (though it came to nothing.) Your litle Bitches which are kept too plentifully, and thereupon admit coition (without ucces) are notwithtanding oberved to be luggih about the jut time whereat they ought to puppy, and bark as if they were in ditres, and likewie filtch away the young whelps from another Bitch, and lick them over and cherih them, (as tenderly as if they were their own natural productions) and fight eagerly to keep them from the true Parent. Nay ome of them have milk, or beetings (as they call it) in their teats; and are obnoxious to the ditempers incident to thoe that have really puppied;
jut as Hennes will cluck in their eaon, though they have no eggs at all to it upon. Some kinde of birds (as namely Pigeons) if they admit coition at the wonted time, though they lay no eggs at all, or ubventaneous ones onely, yet are poeed with their uual edulity & providence of building nets.

For the vertue proceeding from the Male, doth o largely fructifie the whole Female, that it produceth a thorough change and alteration, as well in the frame of their minds, as in the contitution of their bodies. And though this doe principally happen to the Vterus fitted for the impreion; and from thence the power and efficacy thereof be derived to the whole body; (as from the turgent teticles of the Male, there is an acceion of trength uperadded to the whole body) yet the ame cruple remaines: namely, how this power communicated to the Vterus it elfe, doth inhere in it? as whether in the whole Vterus, or in any one part of it onely? For there is nothing to be found abiding therein after coition: for the geniture of the Male doth either uddenly fall out againe, or vanih away, and the blood doth circulate againe from the uterus, by the veels.

Beides, what preparation or maturity of the Vterus is it, that doth require the genitall eed; or from whence doth it proceed? for unles the uterus be prepared for coition, all other attempts are frutrate; nay everal animals doe not admit coition it elf, without they be thus prepared. That maturity, I confes, doth ooner befall them, by reaon of their convere with the Male, and the incitements which he ueth to provoke them; yet
it is procured (as that ripenes of fruits in plants) by natures owne inclination and tendency. But what this Alteration is, I hall now deliver, according as I have found it by experience.

Firt of all the uterus appears thicker and more flehy: and afterwards (foramuch as concerneth the interiour uperficies, which is the place where the future conception is to be received) it groweth more tender, anwering in lubricity and oftnes to the internal ventricles of the Braine, as we have even now affirmed concerning Hindes, and other creatures which cleave the hoofe. But in Bitches, Cats, and other multiparous Animals, whoe feet are ditinguihed into toes, the hornes of the Wombe doe exactly reemble the litle mooth trumpets of a womans womb, or the appendixes of the guts of Birds, or the Ureters in Men: and in ome places have litle knobs which doe well inward, and become exceeding oft, through which, after coition (as we have oberved in Hinds and Does) as if they did open themelves, the firt albugineous humours doe tranpire into the capacity of the Uterus, out of which humours the Conception or Egge is formed. And this is the manner how the Uterus is by the Coition of the Male (like Fruit by the Summer heat) impregnated, and heightned into the highet pitch of maturity.

But becaue there are no manifet igns of Conception viible, before the Uterus doth begin to open, and the albugineous liquor, or lender threads, (like the Spiders web) and the firt rudiments of the future Egge or Conception appear: and eeing the ubtance of the Uterus, now ready
for Conception, doth o neerly reemble the Contitution of the Braine: why may we not imagine, that both their functions are alo alike; and that omething like, if not the elfe ame thing that the phantame, or appetite is to the brain, is excited in the Uterus: from which the generation or procreation of the Egge doth ucceed? for both their functions are equally called conceptions, and both are Immaterial; though they be the principles of all the actions of the body: namely this, of the Natural, that of the Animal actions: this the firt caue and principle of all actions relating to the generation of Animals, & that of all actions tending to their preervation. And as Appetite doth pring from the conception of the braine, and that conception from the outward appetible or deirable objects: So alo from the Male (as being the more perfect Animal) as from the mot natural appetible object, the natural conception dotharie in the Uterus, as the Animal conception in the Brain.

And from this Appetite or Conception it cometh to pas, that the female doth produce an offpring like the male Genitor. For as we, from the Conception of the Form, or Idea, in the Braine, do fahion a form like to it in our works, o doth the Idea or Species of the Genitor, reiding in the Uterus, by the help of the formative facultie, beget a Foetus like the Genitor himelf; namely by implanting that Immaterial pecies which it hath, upon its Workmanhip. In like manner as Art, which is the < in non-Latin alphabet > , or Species of the future work, doth produce a Like in its operation, and generate it in the matter: As the Builder erects a Houe, according to his pre-received conception. And the ame thing happeneth in other productions,
and artificial generations. So that what dicipline doth effect in the Braine, namely Art, that in proportion doth the Coition of the Male effect in the Uterus, namely the platical Art: whereby everal foetues are procreated either like or unlike, by the ame Coition. For if the Generations, and firt artificial conceptions (which are onely imitations of the natural) are thus produced by the Braine; how much more probable is it, that the Exemplars of Animal Generation and conception, are in like manner produced by the Uterus.

And becaue Nature (all whoe works are admirable and divine) doth intitute uch an Organ (namely the Braine) by whoe enitive faculty and virtue, the conceptions of the rational oule doe exit; namely Deires, and Arts, and the Principles and Caues of o many everal productions, whereof man (by the motive faculty of the Braine) is the Author by Imitation; why hall we not think, that the ame Nature, which hath contrived the Womb, which is a no lee admirable Organ then the Braine, and hath framed it of a like contitution to execute the office of Conception, hath deigned it alo to a like function, or at leat to one which beareth an Analogy with it: and that Nature did intend an Organ which is every way like the Braine, to an imployment, like to that to which the Braine is aigned? For ince a skilful Artificer, doth accomplih his Workmanhip, by his ingenious proportioning one Intrument to one thing, and the ame to the ame, and the like to the like: So that by the materials and hape of his Intruments, a man may eaily judge of their ue and
actions; no les then Aritotle hath intructed us, to know the nature of Natural Bodies, by Analyt. l. 2. c. 35. their conformation, and the Fabrick of their Parts; and the Art of Phyiognomy, doth by lineaments and parts of the face (as the Eye, Noe, Fore-head, &c.) give judgement of the manners and dipoitions of Men: What hall hinder us, out of the ame fabrick of parts, to pas our conjecture that their Office is alo the ame?

But uch is the prepoterous ucces of things, that when we come to debate cutomary and familiar things, their frequency doth diminih their greatnes, and admiration which is due unto them; but when matters of les conequence (but uch as are more unuual) do preent themelves, wee intantly magnifie them becaue of their novelty and rarity. Whooever hall weigh with himelf, how the brain of the Artit, or the Artit himelf by virtue of his brain, doth form things which are not preent with him, but uch as he only hath formerly een, o much to the life: and how litle birds which immure themelves all winter long, do exactly chant, and recall to minde thoe Ditties, the next Spring, which they had learned the Summer before, though they did never practie them all the while; and which is yet more trange, how a litle bird will mot artificially contrive a Net (whereof hee never aw any platform before) and that not from her memory, or any habit implanted in her, but onely by meere phanie: and how a young Spider, without any pattern, or brain, by the help of phanie onely, doth
dipoe her web; whooever, I ay, doth diligently ponder thee things, will, I conceive, not think it an aburd or montrous matter, for a woman to become the efficient caue of Generation, being impregnated by the conception of a generall, immateriall Idea.

I know full well, that ome coffing perons will laugh at thee conjectures; approving nothing but their owne private inventions. Yet this is the wont of Philoophers, when they cannot clearly dicover how things themelves are brought about, to conceive ome way cononant to the coure of nature, and the next borderer upon truth her elfe, how uch matters may be atchieved. And, indeed, all thoe Opinions (which we now cry up) were at firt meere figments, and imaginations; untill they wrought a olid credit in us, by enible experiment, and were ratified by their neceary knowne caues. Aritotle aith, That Philoophers are in ome ort lovers of Fables, becaue a Fable doth conit of
Metaph. l. 1. c. 2. trange things. And, indeed, thoe who were firt poeed with the admiration of things, did advance Philoophy. And for my owne particular, ince I plainly ee that nothing at all doth remaine in the Uterus after coition, whereunto I might acribe the principle of generation; no more then remaines in the braine after enation, and experience, whereunto the principle of Art may be reduced; but finding the contitution to be alike in both, I have invented this Fable. Let the Learned and ingenious tock of men conider of it; let the upercilious reject it: and for the coffing
ticklih generation, let them laugh their winge.

Becaue, I ay, there is no Senible thing to be found in the Uterus, after coition; and yet there is a neceity, that omething hould be there, which may render the female fruitfull; and that (in probability) can be no corporeal eence; we have no refuge left us, but to fly to meere Conception, and reception of Species without any matter; namely, to apprehend, that the ame thing is effected in the womb, as in the Braine: unles ome cunning Philoopher, whom the Gods have better provided for, can finde out ome efficient caue, which is not concluded in our recapitulation.

Some Philoophers, even of our owne time, have furbuhed over the old opinion concerning the Atomes: and doe therefore conceive, that this Contagion (as alo all other) doth proceed from the mot ubtle effluviums, or emanations of the maculine eed, which do eaily tranpire after the manner of Odours, and o are hot into the Uterus at the time of coition. Some againe raie up certaine incorporeal pirits, like o many Agents, Angels, or Daemons. Others undertand a Contagion, like to a kinde of ferment, or ower levening. Others phanie, and imagine otherwie. Allow therefore, amongt others, ome place for this conjecture of mine, untill there be ome certainty etablihed in the buines.

I have oberved many things, which will eaily extirpate the recited opinions of other men: (o that now it is much more obvious to ay what it is not, then what it is) but thoe Obervations relate not to this place,
but mut be propoed elewhere. At the preent I hall ay this onely: If that which we commonly call Contagion, as being derived from the permatical contact in coition, and remaining behinde in the female, (when the Geniture it elfe is not then in preence) is the efficient and operatour of the future procreation: if, I ay, this Contagion (whether it be Atomes, or Odour, or Ferment, or whatoever ele) be free from the nature of a body, it mut of neceity be an incorporeal thing. And if moreover, upon enquiry it do appear, to be neither a Spirit, nor a Daemon, nor a Soul, nor any part of a Soul, nor yet omething which hath a Soul (as I conceive I can demontrate by everal arguments, and experiments.) What remains, ince I can imagine nothing ele, nor no man hath hitherto dreamed of any other thing, but freely to profes my elf to be at a tand? But He that doubts & admires, aith Aritotle, doth confes Ibid. he doth not know. Wherefore, if to avoid the tain of Ignorance, ingenuous Men turn Philoophers, it is cleare, that they purue Knowledge, for Knowledge ake, and not for any other ue.

Wee ought not therefore to be condemned, if being deirous of knowing things, and upon that account walking in untrodden paths, wee et before you omething, which, at firt bluh, may eem fabulous, and fictitious. For as all things are not to be wallowed with too much credulity; o thoe things which have been exactly and long conidered, are not utterly to be depied, though they doe not appeare o rare to harp-witted men.

Aritotle himelf wrote a Book de Mirabilibus
Metaph l. an. • .
Auditis, of Heare-ay Wonders. And in another place hee aith, That wee mut not onely pay thankes to them, to whoe Opinions a man may afely ubcribe; but to thoe alo who have poken but uperficially to the purpoe. For even they alo are of ome ue, for they exercie our habits. For had not Timotheus been, wee had lot a great deale of Muicke: And yet if Phrynis had not been, Timotheus had not been exitent neither. In like manner they who have delivered any kinde of truth; for wee have received ome Opinions from ome Philoophers, and yet ome others were the occaion of thee Philoophers.

And therefore being moved by the example and authority of o Gallant a peron as Aritotle, leat I might eem made up of nothing but the ubverion of other mens Doctrines; I have choen rather to propoe a feigned Opinion, then none at all: and have contented my elf in this place to play the Phrynis to Timotheus; viz. to hake off the loth and drowzines of the Age wee live in, and to awaken the wits of Indutrious heads, permitting rather that abler men hould port themelves with my propoals, then that any carefull Enquirer into the nature of Things hould accue mee of luggihnes.

Truth is, a man cannot earch after a more augut Theorem, nor learn any thing of more ue, then this; namely, How all things are produced by an Univocal Agent? or after what manner the ame thing doth till generate the ame? and that not onely in the productions of Art, (for o a Houe erects a Houe, one Face limnes another, and one Image
formeth another Image) but in thoe alo which relate to the Minde: as a Minde begets a Minde; and one Opinion another Opinion. Democritus his Atomes, and Eudoxus his Chiefet Good placed in Pleaure, did impregnate Epicurus: Empedocles his Foure Elements, Aritotle: the Doctrine of antient Thebes, Pythagoras and Plato: and Geometrie, Euclid. Jut in this manner is the Son borne like the Father; and the Virtues which doe innoble a Family, and the Hereditary Vices alo, are ometimes after many Generations tranported to Poterity: ome Dieaes alo produce their like in other ubjects; as the Leproie, the Gout, Syphilis, or French-Pox, and o forth. But what talke I of Dieaes, ince Succeion Arit. hit. an. l. 7. c. 6. &, de gen. an. l. 1. c. 17 l. 7. c. 11. hath at a vat remove, repeated the very Moles, Warts, and Scarres, which the Greatgrand-ires formerly wore? The marke of the Familie (aith Plinie) is repeated in the armes of the Daci, every fourth Birth. That Minde, Opinion, and thoe very Manners, which are now out of ue, may many yeares hence (when all thoe are decryed, which are now received) returne againe. For the Eternall minde of the Divine Creatour; which is imprinted in Things, doth create the Image of it elfe in Humane Conceptions.

Having therefore overcome ome difficulties which relate to this Subject, I have a trong deire to dicoure the Matter more cloely: that what I have hitherto delivered curorily, may eeme to carry a fairer probability at leat with it, and
alo to excite the Wits of Studious men, to make a deeper earch into the buinee.

Therefore (that we may illutrate the thing the better) let A tand for the fruitfull egge (namely the matter of the fruitfull chicken) which is alterable and convertible into a chicken, or is a chicken in poe: and let B tand for that which fructifieth the egge, ditinguihing it from a ubventaneous egge: namely, the efficient caue of the chicken, or that which doth alter the Egge, and convert or terminate it into a chicken. And C for the chicken it elfe, or final caue, for whoe ake both the Egge, and that which fructifieth the Egge doe exit: namely, the act, or reaon of the chicken.

Now we take it for granted (which Aritotle doth demontrate) that every firt Mover or Alterer is together with that thing which is moved or altered by it. Now thoe things are mot properly aid to be imul, together, which are generated at the ame time: o that movens & mobile the thing altering, and the thing altered are actually together, and in cae one of them be, the other mut needs bee alo; for of neceity if the effect be in being, the caue thereof mut alo be.

Whenoever therefore A (namely the fruitful Egge, is actually in Being; B likewie (namely the internal mover, and efficient, or fructifier) is actually in being alo. But whenoever B is actually exitent, C alo, (at leat in ome ort) namely the Species of the chicken, or the form without matter is exitent. For B is the internal efficient of the chicken; that is to ay, that thing which doth
move, or alter) A, (namely the Egge) into C, namely the Reaon of the chicken. That therefore every moving thing, may be together with the thing that is moved; and every caue with the thing caued, it is neceary that C, hould exit together with B, becaue the Final caue, as well in Nature, as Art, is the firt of all the caues; for it moveth, and is it elfe not moved: But the efficient moveth, becaue it is incited by the finall caue. For there is in every efficient, in ome ort, ratio finis, the reaon of the End or finall caue; by which final caue, the efficient, operating with providence, is moved.

Aritotles Authority is clearly on our ide. de part. an. l. 1. c. 1. That eemeth, aith he, to be chiefet amongt Natural caues, which we ignifie under this notion, Cujus Gratia, for whoe ake: For that is the reaon; but the reaon is the firt caue as well in Natural, as Artificial effects. For when the Phyitian doth define Health, and the Maon a Houe, by either the Intellect, or by Sene, he ueth to render the reaons and caues of the thing which he doth effect, and alo ubjoineth the reaon why hee maketh it o: though that caue which is the caue for whoe ake, which is the caue, and reaon of the good and faire, is rather conjoined to the works of Nature, then of Art.

p.U:
aith he, is the thing for whoe
Phy. l 2. tract. 3. ake: as the thing for whoe ake we walk, is Health. For if you ake, why a man doth walk, we reply, to continue his Health: and having made that anwer, we conceive we have rendered the caue thereof. And therefore whatoever is interpoed, ome other thing moving thereunto, is done for the Ends ake: as Extenuation is procured
for Health ake, or Purgation, or Phyick, or any other intruments, for all thoe are for the Ends ake. And a while after. But we ought alwayes to eek out the firt caue of every thing: as in other matters. As a man buildeth becaue he is a Builder: but he is a Builder by reaon of his Art of building: this therefore is the firt caue: and o it is in all things whatoever. And hereupon he affirmeth, that, that caue which doth firt move, and in which the Reaon and
de gen. an. l. 2. c. 1. form doth lye, is a worthier, and more divine caue, then the material.

div.p:
In every Natural Generation of Animals therefore, both the matter out of which, and the efficient by which (namely A, the thing moved, and B, the thing moving) are both for the ake of the Animal already begotten, or which is to be begotten: becaue that which moveth, and is not moved it elfe, namely C, is alike in them both. For both they (namely A, & B,) are both movable, and moved; namely the thing fructifying, which is B, (which doth both move and is moved,) and that thing which is fructified, which is A, namely the Matter or Egge, which is onely moved or altered. Wherefore if no moveable thing be actually moved, unlee the thing moving be together preent with it. Certainly, neither hall the Matter be moved, nor the Efficient move or effect any thing, unlee the firt mover bee in ome ort preent too: viz. the form, or pecies which is without Matter, and is the principal caue. For the Efficient and Generant (according de gen. an. l. 2. c. 4. to Aritotle) as they are uch, do belong to that which is effected, and generated. And
therefore it is a yllogime framed out of the firt and neceary caues: namely,

list.item: Whenoever B is actually exitent, C alo is actually exitent: (namely, moving in ome ort)
Whenoever A is actually exitent, B is alo actually exitent.
Therefore, whenoever A is actually exitent, C alo is actually exitent.

div.p: Indeed Natural, and Artificial Generation are after one and the ame manner. For both are intituted for the ake of omething, and doe alike out of a kinde of providence direct themelves to a propoed End: for both are firt moved by ome conceived form, which is immaterial, and is produced by Conception. For the Braine is the Organ of Arit. de part. an. l. 1. c. 6. the Conception of the one, (for Art is the Reaon of the Worke) (devoyd of all Matter) in the Soule, whoe Organ the Braine is) but the Uterus, or Egge of the Other.

The Conception therefore of the Egge, or Uterus, is (in ome ort) like the Conception of the Braine it elfe, and both
of them doe alike partake of the End. For the Species, or Forme of the Chicken is in the Uterus, or Egge, without any matter at all: as the reaon of the Work is in the Artificer, and the Reaon of the Houe, in the Brain of the Builder.

But becaue, < in non-Latin alphabet >
inee, this word, to bee in, is perhaps an Equivocal word, and things may bee aid to bee Simul, together, everall wayes; therefore we ay, and affirme, that the Species and Immateriall Forme of the future Chicken is Aliquo modo, in ome ort, the caue of the pregnation, and fecundity of the Uterus: becaue, after coition, there is no corporeal thing found therein.

But how this Immateriall caue, as the principle, can be alike in the Braine, and in the Vterus, and how they agree among themelves, or doe differ, namely the Conceptions of the Braine, and of the Vterus, or Art, and Nature; and in what manner, that which fructifieth (namely, the internal Efficient caue of the procreation of an Animall) is in the Male, and its Geniture; in the Female and her Wombe; in the Egge alo, or mixt Workmanhip of both; and what the difference betweene them is: hereafter, when wee hall treat Univerally of the Generation of all Animals (even of thoe alo, which are generated by Metamorphois; namely, of Inects, and Spontaneous Productions, in whoe Egges, or firt Rudiments, there is a plaine Species or Immateriall forme, as being the moving principle in regard of thoe things which are to be
produced, as alo in all other Seed whatoever) and alo when we hall dicoure of the Soule, and its affections; and alo how Arts, Memory, and Experience, are onely the Conceptions of the Brain, wee hall endeavour both largely, and perpicuouly to explaine.

div.head: ERRATA.
div.p: PAg. 42. lin. 36. read ariing from the Chine. p. 46. l. 30. r. doth, but by Juxtapoition. p. 67, l. 11. carried it to. p. 69. l. 20. every other. p. 70. l. 27. clocking. p. 93. l. 23. its growth. p. 105. l. 11. is yet. p. 291. l. 13. cone. p. 292. l. 5. for are not, r. would not be. ibid. l. 12. after part, r. made up of thoe humours mixt together; it is a imilar animate part. ibid. l. 14. del. and. p. 293. l. 16. del. it. p. 294. l. 25. for pour out the Serum, r. pour it out.
